the fulton county grand jury said friday an investigation of atlanta ' s recent primary election produced `` no evidence ' ' that any irregularities took place .	1024.7805
the jury further said in term-end presentments that the city executive committee , which had over-all charge of the election , `` deserves the praise and thanks of the city of atlanta ' ' for the manner in which the election was conducted .	417.58563
the september-october term jury had been charged by fulton superior court judge durwood pye to investigate reports of possible `` irregularities ' ' in the hard-fought primary which was won by mayor-nominate ivan allen jr . .	1704.2018
`` only a relative handful of such reports was received ' ' , the jury said , `` considering the widespread interest in the election , the number of voters and the size of this city ' ' .	143.38506
the jury said it did find that many of georgia ' s registration and election laws `` are outmoded or inadequate and often ambiguous ' ' .	369.7022
it recommended that fulton legislators act `` to have these laws studied and revised to the end of modernizing and improving them ' ' .	512.6308
the grand jury commented on a number of other topics , among them the atlanta and fulton county purchasing departments which it said `` are well operated and follow generally accepted practices which inure to the best interest of both governments ' ' .	557.9965
however , the jury said it believes `` these two offices should be combined to achieve greater efficiency and reduce the cost of administration ' ' .	260.52936
the city purchasing department , the jury said , `` is lacking in experienced clerical personnel as a result of city personnel policies ' ' .	310.2755
it urged that the city `` take steps to remedy ' ' this problem .	505.10257
implementation of georgia ' s automobile title law was also recommended by the outgoing jury .	691.3698
it urged that the next legislature `` provide enabling funds and re-set the effective date so that an orderly implementation of the law may be effected ' ' .	847.43304
the grand jury took a swipe at the state welfare department ' s handling of federal funds granted for child welfare services in foster homes .	1285.9656
`` this is one of the major items in the fulton county general assistance program ' ' , the jury said , but the state welfare department `` has seen fit to distribute these funds through the welfare departments of all the counties in the state with the exception of fulton county , which receives none of this money .	267.80423
the jurors said they realize `` a proportionate distribution of these funds might disable this program in our less populous counties ' ' .	680.7066
nevertheless , `` we feel that in the future fulton county should receive some portion of these available funds ' ' , the jurors said .	294.18658
`` failure to do this will continue to place a disproportionate burden ' ' on fulton taxpayers .	470.55463
the jury also commented on the fulton ordinary ' s court which has been under fire for its practices in the appointment of appraisers , guardians and administrators and the awarding of fees and compensation .	530.12573
the jury said it found the court `` has incorporated into its operating procedures the recommendations ' ' of two previous grand juries , the atlanta bar association and an interim citizens committee .	855.26666
`` these actions should serve to protect in fact and in effect the court ' s wards from undue costs and its appointed and elected servants from unmeritorious criticisms ' ' , the jury said .	490.74036
regarding atlanta ' s new multi-million-dollar airport , the jury recommended `` that when the new management takes charge jan . 1 the airport be operated in a manner that will eliminate political influences ' ' .	466.84933
the jury did not elaborate , but it added that `` there should be periodic surveillance of the pricing practices of the concessionaires for the purpose of keeping the prices reasonable ' ' .	237.08678
on other matters , the jury recommended that ( 1 )	173.22693
four additional deputies be employed at the fulton county jail and `` a doctor , medical intern or extern be employed for night and weekend duty at the jail ' ' .	878.07947
fulton legislators `` work with city officials to pass enabling legislation that will permit the establishment of a fair and equitable ' ' pension plan for city employes .	642.43726
the jury praised the administration and operation of the atlanta police department , the fulton tax commissioner ' s office , the bellwood and alpharetta prison farms , grady hospital and the fulton health department .	1026.1444

-- committee approval of gov . price daniel ' s `` abandoned property ' ' act seemed certain thursday despite the adamant protests of texas bankers .	1109.1104
daniel personally led the fight for the measure , which he had watered down considerably since its rejection by two previous legislatures , in a public hearing before the house committee on revenue and taxation .	573.39233
under committee rules , it went automatically to a subcommittee for one week .	314.5519
but questions with which committee members taunted bankers appearing as witnesses left little doubt that they will recommend passage of it .	1655.1041
daniel termed `` extremely conservative ' ' his estimate that it would produce 17 million dollars to help erase an anticipated deficit of 63 million dollars at the end of the current fiscal year next aug . 31 .	552.3839
he told the committee the measure would merely provide means of enforcing the escheat law which has been on the books `` since texas was a republic ' ' .	519.5133
it permits the state to take over bank accounts , stocks and other personal property of persons missing for seven years or more .	607.63336
the bill , which daniel said he drafted personally , would force banks , insurance firms , pipeline companies and other corporations to report such property to the state treasurer .	1200.6177
the escheat law cannot be enforced now because it is almost impossible to locate such property , daniel declared .	426.77042
dewey lawrence , a tyler lawyer representing the texas bankers association , sounded the opposition keynote when he said it would force banks to violate their contractual obligations with depositors and undermine the confidence of bank customers .	1977.1538
`` if you destroy confidence in banks , you do something to the economy ' ' , he said .	102.77466
`` you take out of circulation many millions of dollars ' ' .	180.23233

vast spraying programs conducted by `` technicians with narrow training and little wisdom ' ' are endangering crops and wildlife , carl w . buchheister , president of the national audubon society , said today .	494.71854
`` it is like handing a loaded automatic to an 8-year-old and telling him to run out and play ' ' , he commented .	604.1004
buchheister told delegates to the west coast audubon convention that aerial spraying in louisiana failed to destroy its target , the fire ant .	1326.1875
`` but it did destroy the natural controls of a borer and released a new plague that wrecked a sugar cane crop ' ' , he said .	703.8557
the conservation leader said other mistakes in spraying had caused serious damage in ohio and wyoming .	1790.0039

seventeen years ago today , german scientist willy fiedler climbed into a makeshift cockpit installed in a v-1 rocket-bomb that was attached to the underbelly of a heinkel bomber .	5236.966
the world war 2 , german bomber rolled down a runway and took off .	1205.5282
the only way fiedler could get back to earth alive was to fly the pulse jet missile and land it on the airstrip .	705.3771
this had never been done before .	421.6826
now a quiet-spoken , middle-aged man , fiedler is an aeronautical engineer for lockheed ' s missiles and space division at sunnyvale , where he played a key role in the development of the navy ' s polaris missile .	581.34424
he sat in his office yesterday and recalled that historic flight in 1944 .	1283.4005
`` the first two pilots had crashed ' ' , he said .	130.68506
`` i had developed the machines and therefore knew them .	415.96558
it was time to go up myself ' ' .	55.199684
fiedler was then technical director of hitler ' s super-secret `` reichenberg project ' ' , which remained unknown to the allies until after the war .	311.30576
about 200 of the special v-1 rocket-bombs were to be made ready for manned flight with an explosive warhead .	3312.6826
the target was allied shipping -- a desperate effort to stave off the allied invasion of europe .	1598.2363
the success of the project depended upon fiedler ' s flight .	706.0397
squeezed into the few cubic feet normally filled by the rocket ' s automatic guidance mechanism , the scientist waited while the bomber gained altitude .	1710.8931
at 12 , 000 feet , fiedler signaled `` release ' ' , and started the roaring pulse-jet engine -- then streaked away from beneath the heinkel .	1826.1696
to the german pilot in the bomber the rocket became a faint black speck , hurtling through the sky at the then incredible speed of 420 m . p . h . .	647.0599
it was probably man ' s first successful flight in a missile .	201.7296
`` she flew beautifully ' ' , said fiedler .	81.80204
`` there was only one power control -- a valve to adjust the fuel flow .	841.18835
i had exactly 20 minutes to get down to the test strip ' ' .	164.4854
using a steering system that controlled the modified rocket ' s tail surfaces and wings equipped with ailerons , fiedler was to land the missile on a skid especially bolted under the fuselage .	2104.9163
he managed to maneuver the missile to a landing speed of 200 m . p . h . -- fast even for a modern jet plane touchdown -- and banked into the airfield .	546.943
moments later the v-1 skimmed across the landing strip , edging closer and closer to a touchdown -- then in a streamer of dust it landed .	1190.757
fiedler went on to make several other test flights before german pilots took over the reichenberg missiles .	3515.3723
the missiles were to be armed with an underwater bomb .	652.38025
pilots would steer them in a suicide dive into the water , striking below the waterline of individual ships .	1090.7505
a crack corps of 50 pilots was formed from the ranks of volunteers , but the project was halted before the end of the war , and the missiles later fell into allied hands .	405.65488
now a family man with three children , fiedler lives in a quiet residential area near the lockheed plant at sunnyvale .	696.33954
his spare time is spent in soaring gliders .	43570.457
`` it ' s so quiet ' ' , he said , `` so slow , serene -- and so challenging ' ' .	288.45645

-- greece and west germany have ratified an agreement under which germany will pay $28 , 700 , 000 to greek victims of nazi persecution , it was announced today .	722.4494
probably the hottest thing that has hit the dallas investment community in years was the morton foods stock issue , which was sold to the public during the past week .	410.05435
for many reasons , the demand to buy shares in the dallas-headquartered company was tremendous .	583.5806
it was not a case of the investment bankers having to sell the stock	490.2981
it was more one of allotting a few shares to a number of customers and explaining to others why they had no more to sell .	452.15005
investors who wanted 100 shares in many cases ended up with 25 , and customers who had put in a bid to buy 400 shares found themselves with 100 and counted themselves lucky to get that many .	668.96295
in fact , very few customers , anywhere in the nation , were able to get more than 100 shares .	224.41273
some dallas investment firms got only 100 shares , for all of their customers .	227.73239
a measure of how hot the stock was , can be found in what happened to it on the market as soon as trading began .	377.0538
the stock was sold in the underwriting at a price of $12 . 50 a share .	368.91205
the first over-the-counter trade wednesday afternoon at eppler , guerin & turner , the managing underwriter , was at $17 a share .	5490.696
and from that the stock moved right on up until it was trading thursday morning at around $22 a share .	1782.9973
but the morton foods issue was hot long before it was on the market .	272.89523
indeed , from the moment the reports of the coming issue first started circulating in dallas last january , the inquiries and demand for the stock started building up .	885.6477
letters by the reams came in from investment firms all over the nation , all of them wanting to get a part of the shares that would be sold ( 185 , 000 to the public at $12 . 50 , with another 5 , 000 reserved for morton foods employes at $11 . 50 a share ) .	426.93857
there was even a cable in french from a bank in switzerland that had somehow learned about the dallas stock offering .	853.1547
`` we subscribe 500 shares of morton foods of texas .	3563.4514
cable confirmation ' ' , it said translated .	89.4867
but e . g . t . could not let the swiss bank have even 10 shares .	231.06673
after it allotted shares to 41 underwriters and 52 selling group members from coast to coast there were not many shares for anyone .	1561.2855
but the result of it all was , e . g . t . partner dean guerin believes , an effective distribution of the stock to owners all over the nation .	303.95465
`` i feel confident the stock will qualify for the ' national list ' ' ' , he said , meaning its market price would be quoted regularly in newspapers all over the country .	289.91425
he was also pleased with the wide distribution because he thought it proved again his argument that dallas investment men can do just as good a job as the big new york investment bankers claim only they can do .	521.5964
but what made the morton foods stock issue such a hot one ? ?	806.5157
the answer is that it was a combination of circumstances .	107.36352
first , the general stock market has been boiling upward for the last few months , driving stocks of all kinds up .	976.94086
as a result , it is not easy to find a stock priced as the morton issue was priced ( at roughly 10 times 1960 earnings , to yield a little over 5 per cent on the 64-cent anticipated dividend ) .	839.5967
second , the `` potato chip industry ' ' has caught the fancy of investors lately , and until morton foods came along there were only two potato chip stocks -- frito and h . w . lay -- on the market .	1245.2296
both of those have had dynamic run-ups in price on the market in recent months , both were selling at higher price-earnings and yield bases than morton was coming to market at , and everyone who knew anything about it expected the morton stock to have a fast run-up .	1426.8046
and third , the potato chip industry has taken on the flavor of a `` growth ' ' industry in the public mind of late .	267.09274
foods , which long had been considered `` recession resistant ' ' but hardly dynamic stocks , have been acting like growth stocks , going to higher price-earnings ratios .	1495.54
the potato chip industry these days is growing , not only as a result of population increase and public acceptance of convenience foods , but also because of a combination of circumstances that has led to growth by merger .	473.47565
the history of the u . s . potato chip industry is that many of today ' s successful companies got started during the deep depression days .	333.18765
those that remain are those that were headed by strong executives , men with the abilities to last almost 30 years in the competitive survival of the fittest .	483.07227
but today many of those men are reaching retirement age and suddenly realizing that they face an estate tax problem with their closely held companies and also that they have no second-echelon management in their firms .	952.0493
so they go looking for mergers with other firms that have publicly quoted stock , and almost daily they pound on the doors of firms like frito .	2444.6348
all those things combined to make the morton foods stock the hot issue that it was and is .	305.17673
now , if morton ' s newest product , a corn chip known as chip-o ' s , turns out to sell as well as its stock did , the stock may turn out to be worth every cent of the prices that the avid buyers bid it up to .	674.1123

here ' s an idea for a child ' s room that is easy to execute and is completely charming , using puppets for lamp bases .	540.8025
most children love the animated puppet faces and their flexible bodies , and they prefer to see them as though the puppets were in action , rather than put away in boxes .	927.3037
displayed as lamps , the puppets delight the children and are decorative accent .	1333.006
to create such a lamp , order a wired pedestal from any lamp shop .	1678.5769
measure the puppet to determine the height of the light socket , allowing three to four inches above the puppet ' s head .	378.67233
make sure that the metal tube through which the wire passes is in the shape of an inverted `` l ' ' , the foot of the `` l ' ' about three inches long , so that the puppet can hang directly under the light .	328.90353
using the strings that manipulate the puppet , suspend him from the light fixture by tying the strings to the lamp base .	1350.3518
in this way , you can arrange his legs and arms in any desired position , with feet , or one foot , barely resting on the pedestal .	547.41425
if the puppets are of uniform size , you can change them in accord with your child ' s whims .	473.38034
although a straight drum shade would be adequate and sufficiently neutral that the puppets could be changed without disharmony , it is far more fun to create shades in the gay spirit of a child ' s playtime .	645.1116
those illustrated are reminiscent of a circus top or a merry-go-round .	1182.4103

is there anything a frustrated individual can do about communism ' s growing threat on our doorstep and around the world ? ?	396.67188
more than 300 teenagers last sunday proved there is and as many more are expected to prove it again for jim kern and his wife lynn from 4 to 8 p . m . sunday at first presbyterian church .	478.62802
at that time the second half of the christian youth crusade against communism will be staged .	612.25836
a young real estate salesman , kern first got seriously interested in the problems posed by communism when in the navy air force .	968.5597
he was particularly struck by a course on communist brainwashing .	1185.6273
kern began reading a lot about the history and philosophy of communism , but never felt there was anything he , as an individual , could do about it .	258.65305
when he attended the christian anti-communist crusade school here about six months ago , jim became convinced that an individual can do something constructive in the ideological battle and set out to do it .	842.92377
the best approach , he figured , was to try to influence young people like the high schoolers he and his wife serve as advisors at first presbyterian church .	1069.3134
and he wanted to be careful that the kids not only learn about communist but also about what he feels is the only antidote -- a biblically strong christianity .	1023.65045
so the christian youth crusade against communisn developed and more than 300 top teenagers and 65 adult advisers from presbyterian churches of the area sat enthralled at the four-hour program .	5895.271
this sunday those attending the second session will hear a lecture by kern on the world situation	852.6605
a review of the philosophy of communist leaders by ted slack , another real estate agent who became interested as a philosophy major at the university of miami	1004.1471
and talks on how their christian faith can guide them in learning about and fighting communism during high school and college days , by ted place , director of greater miami youth for christ , and jon braun , director of campus crusade for christ .	898.0491
the second half of the film `` communism on the map ' ' and the movie `` operation abolition ' ' also will be shown .	235.36057

but mr . kennedy had become convinced that a personal confrontation with mr . khrushchev might be the only way to prevent catastrophe .	233.51205
that objective set the high stakes and drama of the vienna meeting .	521.85767
despite efforts by washington last week to play down the significance of the meeting , it clearly was going to be one of the crucial encounters of the cold war .	160.21568
the u . s . and soviet heads of government have met three times since sir winston churchill in 1953 introduced a new word into international diplomacy with his call for a fresh approach to the problem of peace `` at the summit of the nations ' ' .	486.20703
the first time was in 1955 when a full-dress big four summit meeting produced the `` spirit of geneva ' ' .	1044.1837
the spirit served chiefly to lull the west while moscow made inroads into the middle east .	1545.5673
in 1959 president eisenhower and premier khrushchev held an informal session in the u . s . .	156.59021
that meeting produced the `` spirit of camp david ' ' -- a spirit , it later turned out , that masked a basic misunderstanding about progress toward a berlin settlement .	459.81863
on the third occasion -- another big four summit session at paris a year ago -- there was no problem of an illusory `` spirit ' ' .	530.9752
premier khrushchev wrecked the conference at its initial session with a bitter denunciation of the u . s . for the u-2 incident .	277.19867
the episode tended to confirm the u . s . belief that propaganda , the hope of one-sided concessions , and the chance to split the allies , rather than genuine negotiation , were the soviet leader ' s real aims in summitry .	490.60864
thus when premier khrushchev intimated even before inauguration that he hoped for an early meeting with the new president , mr . kennedy was confronted with a delicate problem .	317.182
shortly before his nomination he had set forth his basic view about the problem of negotiations with the soviet leader in these words	354.51578
`` as long as mr . khrushchev is convinced that the balance of world power is shifting his way , no amount of either smiles or toughness , neither camp david talks nor kitchen debates , can compel him to enter fruitful negotiations ' ' .	559.90405
the president had set for himself the task , which he believed vital , of awakening the u . s . and its allies to the hard and complex effort necessary to shift that balance .	286.46848
he did not want the effort weakened by any illusion that summit magic might make it unnecessary .	5760.8657
he wanted time , too , to review the united states ' global commitments and to test both the policies he had inherited and new ones he was formulating .	411.40753
above all , he did not want to appear to be running hat in hand to premier khrushchev ' s doorstep .	324.33994
at the same time the president took pains not to rule out an eventual meeting with the soviet leader .	664.9206
ideally , he knew , it should be preceded by concrete progress at lower levels .	264.98425
but mr . kennedy saw value even in an informal meeting , provided that undue hopes were not raised in connection with it .	1071.4054
it would give him an opportunity to take the measure of his chief adversary in the cold war , to try to probe mr . khrushchev ' s intentions and to make clear his own views .	211.18007
moreover , an eventual meeting was desirable if for no other reason than to satisfy world opinion that the u . s . was not inflexible and was sparing no effort to ease international tensions .	496.43106
both elements -- the caution about a meeting , the willingness eventually to hold one -- were reflected in a letter from the president which ambassador llewellyn e . thompson brought back to russia late in february .	736.46173
the letter , dated feb . 22 , was delivered to premier khrushchev in novosibirsk , siberia , on march 9 .	512.35364
it dealt mainly with a broad range of east-west issues .	481.5973
but it also briefly suggested the possibility of a meeting with mr . khrushchev before the end of the year if the international climate were favorable and schedules permitted .	287.9985
developments over the next two months , however , caused the president to reconsider the question of the timing .	174.24226
there were intense discussions in the inner councils of the white house about the advisability of an early meeting , not because the international climate was improving , but precisely because it was deteriorating alarmingly .	586.6927
the president was especially concerned about the deadlock in the nuclear test ban negotiations at geneva .	857.8296
the deadlock has been caused by the russians ' new demand for a three-man ( east , west and neutral ) directorate , and thus a veto , over the control machinery .	539.83325
in the u . s . , strong pressures have been building up for a resumption of tests on grounds that the russians may be secretly testing .	276.5545
mr . kennedy was less troubled by that possibility than by the belief that a geneva breakdown , or even continued stalemate , would mean an unchecked spread of nuclear weapons to other countries as well as a fatal blow to any hope for disarmament .	1022.44995
there was reason to believe that premier khrushchev was also concerned about a possible spread of nuclear weapons , particularly to communist china .	649.21985
the question arose as to whether a frank discussion of that danger with the soviet leader had not become urgent .	478.2322
moreover , moscow appeared determined to apply the tripartite veto principle to the executive organs of all international bodies , including the u . n . secretariat and the international control commission for laos .	342.76666
mr . kennedy was convinced that insistence on the demand would make international agreements , or even negotiations , impossible .	584.59467
developments in cuba and laos also suggested the advisability of an early summit meeting .	878.7107
initially the white house reaction was that the bitter exchanges with moscow over cuba and the conflict in laos had dampened prospects for a meeting .	736.80524
at the same time , there was increased reason for a quick meeting lest the soviet leader , as a result of those episodes , come to a dangerously erroneous conclusion about the west ' s ability and determination to resist communist pressure .	692.8526
in cuba , the u . s . had blundered badly and created the impression of impotency against communist penetration even on its own doorstep .	1056.2988
in laos , the picture was almost equally bad .	1030.9105
u . s . willingness to accept a neutral laos may have led premier khrushchev to believe that other areas could be `` neutralized ' ' on soviet terms .	450.51422
beyond that , allied disagreement about military intervention in laos -- despite warnings that they might do so -- allowed moscow to carry out with impunity a series of military and diplomatic moves that greatly strengthened the pro-communist forces .	1198.1573
as a result , the west is in a poor bargaining position at the current geneva negotiations on laos , and south vietnam and other nations in southeast asia are under increased pressure .	458.89276
in the light of those events , there appeared to be a real danger that premier khrushchev might overreach himself .	609.70624
ambassador thompson reported from moscow that the soviet leader ' s mood was cocky and aggressive .	426.18515
he has indicated that he plans new moves on berlin before the year is out .	324.40057
the president and his advisers felt that the time might have come to warn premier khrushchev against a grave miscalculation in areas such as berlin , iran or latin america from which there would be no turning back .	727.50616
it was in the midst of such white house deliberations that premier khrushchev on may 4 made new inquiries through the u . s . embassy in moscow about a meeting with the president in the near future .	325.69662
mr . kennedy told moscow he would give his answer by may 20 after consultation with the allies .	637.97046
the response from london , paris and bonn was favorable .	438.2959
firm arrangements for the meeting in vienna were worked out in a final exchange between moscow and washington last week .	299.45792
apparently at the insistence of the u . s . , the simultaneous announcements issued in washington and moscow last friday emphasized the `` informal ' ' nature of the meeting .	203.7005
`` the president and chairman khrushchev understand that this meeting is not for the purpose of negotiating or reaching agreement on the major international problems that involve the interest of many other countries .	487.95126

the vienna meeting will bring together a seasoned , 67-year-old veteran of the cold war who , in mr . kennedy ' s own words , is `` shrewd , tough , vigorous , well-informed and confident ' ' , and a 44-year-old president ( his birthday is may 29 ) with a demonstrated capacity for political battle but little experience in international diplomacy .	474.21243
the announcement last week of the forthcoming encounter produced strong reactions in the u . s . of both approval and disapproval .	159.77777
the approval did not arise from an expectation of far-reaching agreements at vienna .	1163.451
the inclination was to accept the statement that there would be no formal negotiations .	215.38629
but those who were in favor of the meeting felt that a frank exchange between the two men and an opportunity to size one another up would prove salutary .	507.25525
mr . khrushchev is known to rely heavily on his instincts about his adversaries and to be a shrewd judge of men .	1109.6812
the feeling was that he would sense an inner core of toughness and determination in the president and that plain talk by mr . kennedy would give him pause .	475.40833
apart from the personal equation , another reason advanced in favor of the meeting was that too often in the past the u . s . appeared to have been dragged reluctantly to the summit .	210.95201
premier khrushchev has made propaganda capital out of that fact and in the end got his summit meeting anyway .	894.0844
this time the initiative came , in part at least , from washington .	116.362305
there was also the fact that by the time he meets mr . khrushchev , the president will have completed conversations with all the other principal allied leaders .	211.5216
thus he will be in a position to disabuse the soviet leader of any notions he may have about grave allied disunity .	740.1343
finally , there was a wide area of agreement on the value of the president ' s making a final effort in the summit spotlight for a nuclear test accord .	406.48825
there is no single issue that has aroused stronger feelings throughout the world .	524.26324
if tests are to be resumed , the argument went , it is vital that the u . s . make plain that the onus belongs to the soviet union .	188.3867
disapproval of the meeting was based largely on the belief that the timing could hardly be worse .	302.34055
after cuba and laos , it was argued , mr . khrushchev will interpret the president ' s consent to the meeting as further evidence of western weakness -- perhaps even panic -- and is certain to try to exploit the advantage he now believes he holds .	261.18015
moreover , the president is meeting the soviet leader at a time when the administration has still not decided on the scope of america ' s firm foreign policy commitments .	361.93518
the question was raised , for example , as to what attitude the president would take if mr . khrushchev proposes a broad neutral belt extending from southeast asia to the middle east .	609.7952
there are , so my biologist friends tell me , mechanisms of adaptation and defense that are just too complete and too satisfactory .	1462.8799
mollusks are a case in point .	106.85874
the shell , which served the strain so well at a relatively early stage in the evolutionary scheme , tended to cancel out the possibility of future development .	681.64526
though this may or may not be good biology , it does aptly illustrate the strength and the weakness of american catholic higher education .	561.7809
there can be no doubt that the american catholic accomplishment in the field of higher education is most impressive our european brethren never cease to marvel at the number and the size of our colleges and universities .	532.28894
the deeper wonder is how this miracle was accomplished in decades , rather than in centuries and by immigrant minorities at that .	909.3129
by way of explanation we ourselves are prone to imagine that this achievement stems from the same american catholic zeal and generosity which brought the parochial school system into existence .	917.06464
there is , however , one curious discrepancy in this broad and flattering picture .	784.73395
viewing the american catholic educational achievement in retrospect , we may indeed see it as a unified whole extending from grade school to university .	949.9352
but the simple truth is that higher education has never really been an official american catholic project	808.06006
certainly not in the same sense that the establishment of a parochial school system has been a matter of official policy .	309.26514
official encouragement is one thing , but the down-to-earth test is the allocation of diocesan and parochial funds .	519.9689
american catholics have responded generously to bishops ' and pastors ' appeals for the support necessary to create parochial schools but they have not contributed in a similar fashion to the establishment of institutions of higher learning .	623.957
they have not done so for the simple reason that such appeals have hardly ever been made .	520.7482
diocesan authorities generally have not regarded this as their direct responsibility .	593.39197
all of this may be understandable enough it is , however , in fact difficult to see how diocesan authorities could have acted otherwise .	421.43695
yet for better or for worse , the truth of the matter is that most american catholic colleges do not owe their existence to general catholic support but rather to the initiative , resourcefulness and sacrifices of individual religious communities .	466.82397
community esprit de corps has been the protective shell which has made the achievement possible .	321.1647
to understand the past history -- and the future potential -- of american catholic higher education , it is necessary to appreciate the special character of the esprit de corps of the religious community .	236.5982
it is something more than the arithmetical sum of individual totals of piety and detachment .	1848.0201
a religious community with a vital sense of mission achieves a degree of group orientation and group identification seldom found elsewhere .	1104.6688
the fact that the group orientation and group identification are founded on supernatural principles and nourished by the well-springs of devotion simply give them a deeper and more satisfying dimension .	1937.2201
the net result is a uniquely satisfying sense of comradeship , the kind of comradeship which sparks enthusiasm and blunts the cutting edge of sacrifice and hardship .	1571.0905
american catholic colleges and universities are , in a very real sense , the product of `` private enterprise ' ' -- the `` private enterprise ' ' of religious communities .	129.27943
had it not been for such private enterprise , diocesan authorities might of course have been goaded into establishing institutions subsidized by diocesan funds and parish collections and staffed by religious as paid employees .	2709.2434
there is however no point in speculating about such a possibility the fact of the matter is that our institutions of higher learning owe their existence to a spirit not unlike that which produces the `` family business ' ' .	379.19635
this `` family-community ' ' spirit is the real explanation of the marvel of our achievement .	135.64871
it is this spirit which explains some of the anomalies of american catholic higher education , in particular the wasteful duplication apparent in some areas .	612.70105
i think for example of three women ' s colleges with pitifully small enrollments , clustered within a few miles of a major catholic university , which is also co-educational .	909.5137
this is not an isolated example	5754.4688
this aspect of the total picture has been commented upon often enough .	1010.19257

apart , however , from the question of wasteful duplication , there is another aspect of the `` family business ' ' spirit in american catholic higher education which deserves closer scrutiny .	466.42856
for while the past needs of the church in this country may have been adequately met by collegiate institutions , which in temper and tone closely resembled junior colleges and finishing schools , it would seem that today ' s need is for the college which more closely resembles the university in its `` pursuit of excellence ' ' .	430.5073
at the earlier `` pre-academic excellence ' ' stage of catholic education , the operation could be conducted on an intra-mural community basis .	837.91565
but with today ' s demand for professional qualifications and specialized training , the need for `` outsiders ' ' becomes more pressing .	425.0454
the problem is not merely that more `` outside teachers ' ' are needed but that a different brand is called for .	374.93835
commenting on the earlier stage , the notre dame chapter of the american association of university professors ( in a recent report on the question of faculty participation in administrative decision-making ) noted that the term `` teacher-employee ' ' ( as opposed to , e . g . , `` maintenance employee ' ' ) was a not inapt description .	427.10126
today however , the `` outsider ' ' is likely to have professional qualifications of the highest order ( otherwise the college would not be interested in hiring him ) and to be acclimatized to the democratic processes of the secular or state university .	400.63452
and while no one expects total democracy on the academic scene , the scholar will be particularly sensitive to a line between first and second class citizenship drawn on any basis other than that of academic rank or professional achievement .	748.8701

it is natural that he should turn for his major support to a select and dedicated few from the organization which actually owns the university and whose goals are , in their opinion , identified with its highest good and ( to use that oft-repeated phrase ) ' the attainment of excellence ' ' ' .	432.40912
the pattern here pictured is clearly not peculiar to notre dame it is simply that the paradox involved in this kind of control of the institution by `` the organization which actually owns ' ' it , becomes more obvious where there is a larger and more distinguished `` outside ' ' faculty .	407.89322

`` outside ' ' faculty members want to be considered partners in the academic enterprise and not merely paid employees of a family business .	510.37247

in the academic world there is seldom anything so dramatic as a strike or a boycott all that happens is that the better qualified teacher declines to gamble two or three years of his life on the chance that conditions at the catholic institution will be as good as those elsewhere .	611.30383
to appreciate the nature of the gamble , it should be realized that while college teaching is almost a public symbol of security , that security does not come as quickly or as automatically as it does in an elementary school system or in the civil service .	334.17734

broadly speaking the total catholic atmosphere is such an intangible but the larger demand is for a sense of creative participation and mature responsibility in the total work of the university .	317.57474
religious who derive their own sense of purpose through identification with the religious community rather than the academic community are prone to underestimate both the layman ' s reservoir of idealism and his need for this identification .	640.30225
there is no need here to spell out the conditions of creative teaching except to point out that , at the college level , the sense of community and of community responsibility is even more necessary than it is at other levels .	287.8741

competent teachers are well versed in the technique of leading students to pre-set conclusions without destroying the students ' illusion that they are making their own decisions .	741.41754

the anti-trust laws inform a business that it must compete , but along completely undefined lines	510.8482

the industry is so structured that price-setting by a multi-product company will vary with the way overhead charges are allocated -- whether marginal or average pricing is applied .	2881.4714
the problem becomes even more complex where an enterprise is engaged in the manufacture of a wide variety of other goods in addition to the heavy electrical equipment .	439.43915

in other words , the anti-trust laws , designed to reduce prices to the consumer on monday , wednesday and friday , become a tool to protect the marginal manufacturer on tuesday , thursday and saturday .	436.07947

as the time for independence approached there were in the congo no fewer than 120 political parties , or approximately eight for each university graduate .	961.781
first , there were those congolese ( among them joseph kasavubu ) who favored splitting the country into small independent states , balkanizing it .	4941.7183
second , there were those ( moise tshombe ) who favored near-balkanization , a loose federalism having a central government of limited authority , with much power residing in the states .	1544.3231
third , there were those ( notably patrice lumumba ) who favored a unified congo with a very strong central government .	2022.333
and fourth , there were moderates who were in no hurry for independence and wished to wait until the congo grew up .	645.9584
however , the positions of all parties and leaders were constantly shifting .	567.0643
a final factor which contributed greatly to the fragmentation of the congo , immediately after independence , was the provincial structure that had been established by the belgians for convenience in administration .	437.91196
they had divided the congo into six provinces -- leopoldville , kasai , kivu , katanga , equator and eastern -- unfortunately with little regard for ethnic groupings .	2206.005
thus some provinces contained tribes which detested each other , and to them independence meant an opportunity for war .	781.3824
the belgian congo was granted its independence with what seemed a workable western-style form of government there were to be a president and a premier , and a bicameral legislature elected by universal suffrage in the provinces .	956.2989
well-wishers around the world hoped that the congo would quickly assume a respectable position in the society of nations .	517.1157

there wouldn ' t be much demand for it , i ' m afraid ' ' .	93.37031
behind this reply , and its many variations , is the ever-present budget problem all libraries must face , from the largest to the smallest .	484.3879
what to buy out of the year ' s grist of nearly 15 , 000 book titles ? ?	246.7746
what to buy for adult and child readers , for lovers of fiction and nonfiction , for a clientele whose wants are incredibly diversified , when your budget is pitifully small ? ?	1455.764
most library budgets are hopelessly inadequate .	3541.6772
a startlingly high percentage do not exceed $500 annually , which includes the librarian ' s salary , and not even the new york public has enough money to meet its needs -- this in the world ' s richest city .	318.44406
the plight of a small community library is proportionately worse .	1344.8351
confronted with this situation , most libraries either endure the severe limitations of their budgets and do what they can with what they have , or else depend on the bounty of patrons and local governments to supplement their annual funds .	689.2441
in some parts of the country , however , a co-operative movement has begun to grow , under the wing of state governments , whereby , with the financial help of the state , libraries share their book resources on a county-wide or regional basis .	391.9296
new york state has what is probably the most advanced of these co-operative systems , so well developed that it has become a model for others to follow .	407.44202
because it is so large a state , with marked contrasts in population density , the organization of the new york co-operative offers a cross-section of how the plan works .	441.67203
at one extreme are the systems of upper new york state , where libraries in two or more counties combine to serve a large , sparsely populated area .	912.5834
at the other are organizations like the newly formed nassau library system , in a high-density area , with ample resources and a rapidly growing territory to serve .	879.1994
both these types , and those in between , are in existence by reason of a legislative interest in libraries that began at albany as early as 1950 , with the creation by the legislature of county library systems financed by county governments with matching funds from the state .	661.57117
it was a step in the right direction , but it took an additional act passed in 1958 to establish fully the thriving systems of today .	393.67206
under this law annual grants are given to systems in substantial amounts .	677.92737
an earlier difficulty was overcome by making it clear that individual libraries in any area might join or not , as they saw fit .	517.3816
some library boards are wary of the plan .	282.9623
a large , well-stocked library , surrounded in a county by smaller ones , may feel that the demands on its resources are likely to be too great .	265.4619
a small library may cherish its independence and established ways , and resist joining in a cooperative movement that sometimes seems radical to older members of the board .	726.01294
within a system , however , the autonomy of each member library is preserved .	196.7968
the local community maintains responsibility for the financial support of its own library program , facilities , and services , but wider resources and additional services become available through membership in a system .	395.41153
all services are given without cost to members .	726.05133
so obvious are these advantages that nearly 95 per cent of the population of new york state now has access to a system , and enthusiastic librarians foresee the day , not too distant , when all the libraries in the state will belong to a co-op .	515.2284
to set up a co-operative library system , the law requires a central book collection of 100 , 000 nonfiction volumes as the nucleus , and the system is organized around it .	513.3005
the collection may be in an existing library , or it may be built up in a central collection .	184.53229
each system develops differently , according to the area it serves , but the universal goal is to pool the resources of a given area for maximum efficiency .	230.9491
the basic state grant is thirty cents for each person served , and there is a further book incentive grant that provides an extra twenty cents up to fifty cents per capita , if a library spends a certain number of dollars .	748.9597
in nassau county , for example , the heavily settled long island suburb of new york city , the system is credited by the state with serving one million persons , a figure that has doubled since 1950 .	497.5539
this system , by virtue of its variety and size , offers an inclusive view of the plan in operation .	406.5158
the nassau system recognizes that its major task it to broaden reference service , what with the constant expansion of education and knowledge , and the pressure of population growth in a metropolitan area .	322.60178
the need is for reference works of a more specialized nature than individual libraries , adequate to satisfy everyday needs , could afford .	702.77185
nassau is currently building a central collection of reference materials in its hempstead headquarters , which will reach its goal of 100 , 000 volumes by 1965 .	484.83066
the major part of this collection is in the central headquarters building , and the remainder is divided among five libraries in the system designated as subject centers .	397.6288
basic reference tools are the backbone of the collection , but there is also specialization in science and technology , an indicated weakness in local libraries .	456.48428

the entire headquarters collection is available to the patrons of all members on interlibrary loans .	603.5507
headquarters gets about 100 requests every day .	5563.3286
it is connected by teletype with the state library in albany , which will supply any book to a system that the system itself cannot provide .	389.5713

local libraries find , too , that the new plan saves tax dollars because books can be bought through the system , and since the system buys in bulk it is able to obtain larger discounts than would be available to an individual library .	483.6508

played mostly on the freeways around los angeles , it goes like this	236.1728
a driver cruising easily at 70 m . p . h . in lane a of a four-lane freeway spies an incipient traffic jam ahead .	1777.0337
traffic in the next lane appears to be moving more smoothly so he pokes a tentative fender into lane b , which is heavily populated by cars also moving at 70 m . p . h . .	880.22797
the adjacent driver in lane b has three choices open to him .	1777.3481

the damage to human germ plasm would be such that in the next few generations 160 , 000 children around the world would be born with gross physical or mental defects .	868.6254

as of october 25 , the aec had reported 24 shots in the new soviet series , 12 of them in a megaton range , including a super bomb with a yield of 30 to 50 megatons ( the equivalent of 30 million to 50 million tons of tnt )	748.52844
and president kennedy indicated there were one or two more than those reported .	366.21588

some government scientists say privately that the figure probably is closer to 80 megatons , and that the full 50-megaton bomb that khrushchev mentioned may still be detonated .	825.47705

one of the inescapable realities of the cold war is that it has thrust upon the west a wholly new and historically unique set of moral dilemmas .	895.6124
the first dilemma was the morality of nuclear warfare itself .	471.7642
that dilemma is as much with us as ever .	283.0109
the second great dilemma has been the morality of nuclear testing , a dilemma which has suddenly become acute because of the present series of soviet tests .	326.42148
when this second dilemma first became obvious -- during the mid to late ' 50 ' s -- the united states appeared to have three choices .	543.43195
it could have unilaterally abandoned further testing on the grounds of the radiation hazard to future generations .	528.4804
it could have continued testing to the full on the grounds that the radiation danger was far less than the danger of communist world domination .	458.3417
or it could have chosen to find -- by negotiation -- some way of stopping the tests without loss to national security .	860.5085
this third choice was in fact made .	153.28531
with the resumption of soviet testing and their intransigence at the geneva talks , however , the hope that this third choice would prove viable has been shaken .	590.6475
once again , the united states must choose .	125.13605

the first choice , abandoning tests entirely , would not only be unpopular domestically , but would surely be exploited by the russians .	890.36346
the second choice , full testing , has become even more risky just because the current soviet tests have already dangerously contaminated the atmosphere .	2234.5186

it is by no stretch of the imagination a happy choice and the arguments against it as a practical strategy are formidable .	579.63806
its primary advantage is that it is a moral choice	170.78789

leaving aside the choice of unilateral cessation of tests as neither sane nor clearly moral , the question must arise as to why resumption of atmospheric tests on our part would not be a good choice .	955.4137
for that is the one an increasingly large number of prominent americans are now proposing .	950.319
in particular , governor nelson rockefeller has expressed as cogently and clearly as anyone the case for a resumption of atmospheric tests .	1367.9805
speaking recently in miami , governor rockefeller said that `` to assure the sufficiency of our own weapons in the face of the recent soviet tests , we are now clearly compelled to conduct our own nuclear tests ' ' .	267.8529
taking account of the fact that such a move on our part would be unpopular in world opinion , he argued that the responsibility of the united states is `` to do , confidently and firmly , not what is popular , but what is right ' ' .	151.15628
what was missing in the governor ' s argument , as in so many similar arguments , was a premise which would enable one to make the ethical leap from what might be militarily desirable to what is right .	342.60065
the possibility , as he asserted , that the russians may get ahead of us or come closer to us because of their tests does not supply the needed ethical premise -- unless , of course , we have unwittingly become so brutalized that nuclear superiority is now taken as a moral demand .	497.83038
besides the lack of an adequate ethical dimension to the governor ' s case , one can ask seriously whether our lead over the russians in quality and quantity of nuclear weapons is so slight as to make the tests absolutely necessary .	530.2018
recent statements by the president and defense department spokesmen have , to the contrary , assured us that our lead is very great .	654.3236
unless the administration and the defense department have been deceiving us , the facts do not support the assertion that we are `` compelled ' ' to resume atmospheric testing .	445.33652
it is perfectly conceivable that a resumption of atmospheric tests may , at some point in the future , be necessary and even justifiable .	597.1054
but a resumption does not seem justifiable now .	448.42886
what we need to realize is that the increasingly great contamination of the atmosphere by the soviet tests had radically increased our own moral obligations .	1102.9161
we now have to think not only of our national security but also of the future generations who will suffer from any tests we might undertake .	398.04996
this is an ethical demand which cannot be evaded or glossed over by talking exclusively of weapon superiority or even of the evil of communism .	1635.9752
too often in the past russian tactics have been used to justify like tactics on our part .	1047.389

for ten years a small group of european and u . s . critics has been calling attention to the half-forgotten austrian expressionist egon schiele , who died 42 years ago at the age of 28 .	806.8668
the critics ' campaign finally inspired the first major u . s . exhibit of schiele ' s works .	203.3108
the show has been to boston and manhattan , will in time reach pittsburgh and minneapolis .	700.9826
last week it opened at the j . b . speed museum in louisville , at the very moment that a second schiele exhibit was being made ready at the felix landau gallery in los angeles .	483.20795
schiele ' s paintings are anything but pleasant .	809.00775
his people ( see color ) are angular and knobby-knuckled , sometimes painfully stretched , sometimes grotesquely foreshortened .	3682.2593
his colors are dark and murky , and his landscapes and cityscapes seem swallowed in gloom .	2090.989
but he painted some of the boldest and most original pictures of his time , and even after nearly half a century , the tense , tormented world he put on canvas has lost none of its fascination .	531.70465
the son of a railway stationmaster , schiele lived most of his childhood in the drowsy danubian town of tulln , 14 miles northwest of vienna .	3759.812
he was an emotional , lonely boy who spent so much time turning out drawings that he did scarcely any schoolwork .	1671.1383
when he was 15 , his parents finally allowed him to attend classes at the academy of fine arts in vienna .	435.62582
even there he did not last for long .	1297.5948
cried one professor after a few months of student schiele ' s tantrums and rebellion `` the devil himself must have defecated you into my classroom ' ' ! !	674.78094
for a while his work was influenced deeply by the french impressionists , and by the patterned , mosaic-like paintings of gustav klimt , then the dean of austrian art .	1730.0753
gradually schiele evolved a somber style of his own -- and he had few inhibitions about his subject matter .	891.65594
his pictures were roundly denounced as `` the most disgusting things one has ever seen in vienna ' ' .	507.02625
he himself was once convicted of painting erotica and jailed for 24 days -- the first three of which he spent desperately trying to make paintings on the wall with his own spittle .	1007.5342
for years he wore hand-me-down suits and homemade paper collars , was even driven to scrounging for cigarette butts in vienna ' s gutters .	6900.425
drafted into the austrian army , he rebelliously rejected discipline , wangled a vienna billet , went on painting .	2078.7888
it was not until the last year of his life that he had his first moneymaking show .	421.47958
the unabashed sexuality of so many of his paintings was not the only thing that kept the public at bay his view of the world was one of almost unrelieved tragedy , and it was too much even for morbid-minded vienna .	569.7913
he was obsessed by disease and poverty , by the melancholy of old age and the tyranny of lust .	503.40378
the children he painted were almost always in rags , his portraits were often ruthless to the point of ugliness , and his nudes -- including several self-portraits -- were stringy , contorted and strangely pathetic .	2722.9368
the subject he liked most was the female body , which he painted in every state -- naked , half-dressed , muffled to the ears , sitting primly in a chair , lying tauntingly on a bed or locked in an embrace .	986.1898

his addle-brained knight-errant , self-appointed to the ridiculous position in an age when armor had already been relegated to museums and the chivalrous code of knight-errantry had become a joke , is , as cervantes no doubt intended , a gaunt but gracious symbol of good , moving soberly and sincerely in a world of cynics , hypocrites and rogues .	1977.5961

you will need a stereo music system , with speakers preferably placed at least seven or eight feet apart , and one or more of the new london `` phase 4 ' ' records .	654.04694
there are 12 of these to choose from , all of them of popular music except for the star release , pass in review ( sp-44001 ) .	452.98175
this features the marching songs of several nations , recorded as though the various national bands were marching by your reviewing stand .	1164.982
complete with crowd effects , interruptions by jet planes , and sundry other touches of realism , this disc displays london ' s new technique to the best effect .	1041.4298
all of the jackets carry a fairly technical and detailed explanation of this new recording program .	754.96893
no reference is made to the possibility of recording other than popular music in this manner , and it would not seem to lend itself well to serious music .	269.0064
directionality is greatly exaggerated most of the time	235.12276
but when the sounds of the two speakers are allowed to mix , there is excellent depth and dimension to the music .	235.7084
you definitely hear some of the instruments close up and others farther back , with the difference in placement apparently more distinct than would result from the nearer instruments merely being louder than the ones farther back .	739.5775
this is a characteristic of good stereo recording and one of its tremendous advantages over monaural sound .	1347.6083
london explains that the very distinct directional effect in the phase 4 series is due in large part to their novel methods of microphoning and recording the music on a number of separate tape channels .	794.07086
these are then mixed by their sound engineers with the active co-operation of the musical staff and combined into the final two channels which are impressed on the record .	433.12683
in some of the numbers the instrumental parts have even been recorded at different times and then later combined on the master tape to produce special effects .	826.85114
some clue to the character of london ' s approach in these discs may be gained immediately from the fact that ten of the 12 titles include the word `` percussion ' ' or `` percussive ' ' .	193.40329
drums , xylophones , castanets , and other percussive instruments are reproduced remarkably well .	1700.6195
only too often , however , you have the feeling that you are sitting in a room with some of the instruments lined up on one wall to your left and others facing them on the wall to your right .	264.89404
they are definitely in the same room with you , but your head starts to swing as though you were sitting on the very edge of a tennis court watching a spirited volley .	583.76404
the percussive twenties ( sp-44006 ) stirs pleasant memories with well-known songs of that day , and johnny keating ' s kombo gives forth with tingling jazz in percussive moods ( sp-44005 ) .	2222.1875
big band percussion ( sp-44002 ) seemed one of the least attractive discs -- the arrangements just didn ' t have so much character as the others .	349.87265
there is an extraordinary sense of presence in all of these recordings , apparently obtained at least in part by emphasizing the middle and high frequencies .	615.524
the penalty for this is noticeable in the big , bold , brilliant , but brassy piano sounds in melody and percussion for two pianos ( sp-44007 ) .	1667.2948
all of the releases , however , are recorded at a gratifyingly high level , with resultant masking of any surface noise .	1130.5676
pass in review practically guarantees enjoyment , and is a dramatic demonstration of the potentialities of any stereo music system .	590.39746
many hollywood films manage somehow to be authentic , but not realistic .	293.33517
strange , but true -- authenticity and realism often aren ' t related at all .	429.03345
almost every film bearing the imprimatur of hollywood is physically authentic -- in fact , impeccably so .	1178.4543

paul paray , rounding out his current stint with the orchestra , is a solid musician , and the philharmonic plays for him .	354.67014
their collaboration in the beethoven second symphony was lucid , intelligent and natural sounding .	5222.527
it was not a heavy , ponderous beethoven .	6348.203
the music sang nicely , sprinted evenly when necessary , was properly accented and balanced .	3988.8445

fortunate for the music itself , it is not too frequent a visitor	313.26495

he did not let the strings , for instance , weep , whine or get hysterical .	1295.622
his interpretation was a model of refinement and accuracy .	664.31335

his tone is the weakest part of his equipment	842.74567

`` melodious birds sing madrigals ' ' saith the poet and no better description of the madrigaling of the deller consort could be imagined .	1424.4579
their vanguard album madrigal masterpieces ( bg 609	21691.617
stereo bgs 5031 ) is a good sample of the special , elegant art of english madrigal singing .	548.9717
it also makes a fine introduction to the international art form with good examples of italian and english madrigals plus several french `` chansons ' ' .	831.9387
the english have managed to hold onto their madrigal tradition better than anyone else .	1600.8746
the original impulses came to england late ( in the sixteenth century ) and continue strong long after everyone else had gone on to the baroque basso continuo , sonatas , operas and the like .	922.40106
even after elizabethan traditions were weakened by the cromwellian interregnum , the practice of singing together -- choruses , catches and glees -- always flourished .	4513.5996
the english never again developed a strong native music that could obliterate the traces of an earlier great age the way , say , the opera in italy blotted out the italian madrigal .	1134.7686
latter-day interest in elizabethan singing dates well back into the nineteenth century in england , much ahead of similar revivals in other countries .	406.24915
as a result no comparable literature of the period is better known and better studied nor more often performed than the english madrigal .	846.2955
naturally , mr . deller and the other singers in his troupe are most charming and elegant when they are squarely in their tradition and singing music by their countrymen william byrd , thomas morley and thomas tomkins .	1616.1478
there is an almost instrumental quality to their singing , with a tendency to lift out important lines and make them lead the musical texture .	762.3091
both techniques give the music purity and clarity .	6543.848
claude jannequin ' s vocal description of a battle ( the french equivalents of tarantara , rum-tum-tum , and boom-boom-boom are very picturesque ) is lots of fun , and the singers get a sense of grace and shape into other chansons by jannequin and lassus .	1319.0312
only with the more sensual , intense and baroque expressions of marenzio , monteverdi and gesualdo does the singing seem a little superficial .	3097.581
nevertheless , the musicality , accuracy and infectious charm of these performances , excellently reproduced , make it an attractive look-see at the period .	1165.1599
the elements of elegance and color in jannequin are strong french characteristics .	1109.5087
baroque instrumental music in italy and germany tends to be strong , lively , intense , controlled and quite abstract .	664.36975
in france , it remained always more picturesque , more dancelike , more full of flavor .	1445.6554
couperin and rameau gave titles to nearly everything they wrote , not in the later sense of `` program music ' ' but as a kind of nonmusical reference for the close , clear musical forms filled with keen wit and precise utterance .	865.62933
both composers turn up on new imports from france .	315.01633
bam is the unlikely name of a french recording company whose full label is editions de la boite a musique .	1642.4668

the concerts -- nos . 2 , 6 , 9 , 10 and 14 are represented -- are really closer to chamber suites than to concertos in the italian sense .	447.46106
the sonatas , `` la francaise ' ' , `` la sultane ' ' , `` l ' astree ' ' and `` l ' imperiale ' ' , are often more elaborately worked out and , in fact , show a strong italian influence .	154.37634
couperin also turns up along with some lesser-known contemporaries on a disk called musique francaise du 18e siecle ( bam ld 060 ) .	455.9739

a very casual , pleasant program -- one of those easy-going things that make newport ' s afternoon programs such a relaxing delight -- was held again under sunny skies , hot sun , and a fresh breeze for an audience of at least a couple of thousands who came to newport to hear music rather than go to the beach .	769.4098

hendricks ' story was designed for children and he had a small audience of small children right on stage with him .	302.39923

this urgent visage beckons us ' ' .	435.39902

but chains of movements are not necessarily communicative , and it is in the realm of communication that the works prove disappointing .	532.1336
one frequently has the feeling that the order of their movement combinations could be transposed without notable loss of effect , there is too little suggestion of organic relationship and development .	514.18756

ring of bright water , by gavin maxwell .	862.7691
only once in a very long while comes a book that gives the reader a magic sense of sharing a rare experience .	835.01355
`` ring of bright water ' ' by gavin maxwell is just that -- a haunting , warmly personal chronicle of a man , an otter , and a remote cottage in the scottish west highlands .	824.37177
`` he has married me with a ring of bright water ' ' , begins the kathleen raine poem from which maxwell takes his title , and it is this mystic bond between the human and natural world that the author conveys .	516.4782
the place is camusfearna , the site of a long-vanished sea-village opposite the isle of skye .	2676.0535
it is a land of long fjords , few people , a single-lane road miles away -- and of wild stags , greylag geese , wild swans , dolphins and porpoises playing in the waters .	3624.331

-- the performances of the comedie francaise are the most important recent events in the new york theater .	449.89212
they serve to contradict a popular notion that the comedie merely repeats , as accurately as possible , the techniques of acting the classics that prevailed in the 17th century .	536.2765
on the contrary , the old plays are continually being reinterpreted , and each new production of a classic has only a brief history at the comedie .	556.3862
of course , the well-received revivals last longer than the others , and that further reminds us that the comedie is not insensitive to criticism .	1177.5842
the directors of the comedie do not respond to adverse notices in as docile and subservient a manner as the broadway producers who , in two instances this season , closed their plays after one performance .	737.6349
but they are aware of the world outside , they court public approval , they delight in full houses , and they occasionally dare to experiment in interpreting a dramatic classic .	1192.3712
in france , novel approaches to the classic french plays are frequently attempted .	1185.6873
the government pays a subsidy for revival of the classics , and this policy attracts experimenters who sometimes put moliere ' s characters in modern dress and often achieve interesting results .	1137.2305
so far as i know , the comedie has never put moliere ' s people in the costumes of the 20th century , but they do reinterpret plays and characters .	219.49171
last season , the comedie ' s two principal experiments came to grief , and , in consequence , we can expect fairly soon to see still newer productions of racine ' s `` phedre ' ' and moliere ' s `` school for wives ' ' .	265.4913
the new `` phedre ' ' was done in 17th century setting , instead of ancient greek	537.3925
perhaps that is the comedie ' s equivalent for thrusting this play ' s characters into our own time .	472.80557
the speaking of the lines seemed excessively slow and stately , possibly in an effort to capture the spirit of 17th century elegance .	1893.4519
a few literary men defended what they took to be an emphasis on the poetry at the expense of the drama , but the response was mainly hostile and quite violent .	379.28113
the new `` school for wives ' ' was interpreted according to a principle that is becoming increasingly common in the playing of classic comedy -- the idea of turning some obviously ludicrous figure into a tragic character .	588.96204
among the moliere specialists of some years ago , louis jouvet tried to humanize some of the clowns , while fernand ledoux , often performing at the comedie , made them more gross than moliere may have intended .	854.5504
apparently , jouvet and ledoux attempted just these dissimilar approaches in the role of arnolphe in `` the school for wives ' ' .	683.09454
i say `` apparently ' ' although i saw jouvet as arnolphe when he visited this country shortly before his death	1453.4938
by that time , he seemed to have dropped the tragic playing of the last moments of the comedy .	166.1639
arnolphe , it will be recalled , is a man of mature years who tries to preserve the innocence of his youthful wife-to-be .	1116.749
the part can lend itself to serious treatment	1365.0281
one influential french critic remarked `` pity for arnolphe comes with age ' ' .	494.6473
accordingly , at the comedie last year , jean meyer played a sympathetic arnolphe and drew criticism for turning the comedy into a tragedy .	1001.8767

tartuffe is the religious hypocrite who courts his benefactor ' s wife .	2514.9148

as early as 1928 , however , the sloan style began to change .	159.7664
the dark pigments of the early work were superseded by a brighter palette .	1110.6552
the solidity of brush stroke yielded to a hatching technique that finally led to virtual abandonment of american genres in favor of single figure studies and studio nudes .	1754.6423
the exhibition presents all phases of sloan ' s many-sided art .	268.20795
in addition to the paintings are drawings , prints , and illustrations .	642.9885

any musician playing beethoven here , where beethoven was born , is likely to examine his own interpretations with special care .	779.76404

his readings were careful without being fussy , and they were authoritative without being presumptuous .	1077.6477

in the autumn of 1959 , the british broadcasting corporation presented a series of talks by four scientists competent in cosmology .	1967.347
three of these men discussed major theories of the universe while the other acted as a moderator .	681.4637
the participants were professor h . bondi , professor of mathematics at king ' s college , london	424.0043
dr . w . b . bonnor , reader in mathematics at queen elizabeth college , london	1138.4606
dr . r . a . lyttleton , a lecturer at st . john ' s college , cambridge , and a reader in theoretical astronomy at the university of cambridge	209.08472
and dr . g . j . whitrow , reader in applied mathematics at the imperial college of science and technology , london .	612.515
the programs were so well received by the british public that the arguments have been published in a totally engrossing little book called , `` rival theories of cosmology ' ' .	597.71075
dr . bonnor begins with a discussion of the relativistic theories of the universe , based on the general theory of relativity .	276.9125
first of all , and this has been calculated by observation , the universe is expanding -- that is , the galaxies are receding from each other at immense speeds .	502.2656
because of this dr . bonnor holds that the universe is becoming more thinly populated by stars and whatever else is there .	1513.9116
this expansion has been going on for an estimated eight billion years .	837.69714
dr . bonnor supports the idea that the universe both expands and contracts , that in several billion years the expansion will slow up and reverse itself and that the contraction will set in .	833.9341
then , after many more billions of years , when all the galaxies are whistling toward a common center , this movement will slow down and reverse itself again .	820.54565
professor bondi disagrees with the expansion-contraction theory .	1927.8163
he supports the steady-state theory which holds that matter is continually being created in space .	810.85376
for this reason , he says , the density of the universe always remains the same even though the galaxies are zooming away in all directions .	498.8355
new galaxies are forever being formed to fill in the gaps left by the receding galaxies .	1042.4514
if this is true , then the universe today looks just as it did millions of years ago and as it will look millions of years hence , even though the universe is expanding .	333.5049
for new galaxies to be created , professor bondi declares , it would only be necessary for a single hydrogen atom to be created in an area the size of your living room once every few million years .	522.9288
he contends this idea doesn ' t conflict with experiments on which the principle of conservation of matter and energy is based because some slight error must be assumed in such experiments .	368.56708
dr . lyttleton backs the theory that we live in an electric universe and this theory starts with the behavior of protons and electrons .	522.58875
protons and electrons bear opposite electrical charges which make them attract each other , and when they are joined they make up an atom of hydrogen -- the basic building block of matter .	683.0659
the charges of the electron and proton are believed to be exactly equal and opposite , but dr . lyttleton is not so sure .	638.92975
suppose , says dr . lyttleton , the proton has a slightly greater charge than the electron ( so slight it is presently immeasurable ) .	887.661
this would give the hydrogen atom a slight charge-excess .	2603.4817
now if one hydrogen atom were placed at the surface of a large sphere of hydrogen atoms , it would be subject both to the gravitation of the sphere and the charge-excess of all those atoms in the sphere .	262.94595
because electrical forces ( the charge-excess ) are far more powerful than gravitation , the surface hydrogen atoms would shoot away from the sphere .	945.5525
dr . lyttleton then imagines the universe as a large hydrogen sphere with surface atoms shooting away from it .	1359.2571
this , he claims , would reasonably account for the expansion of the universe .	153.16672
this slim book , while giving the reader only a fleeting glimpse of the scientific mind confronting the universe , has the appeal that informed conversation always has .	589.60266

refrigeration , automated processing and packaging conspire to defy season and banish spoilage .	8386.888

and extra weight increases the risk of cancer , diabetes , artery disease and heart attack .	592.8818
with meat , milk , butter and ice cream , the calorie-heavy u . s . diet is 40% fat , and most of that is saturated fat -- the insidious kind , says dr . keys , that increases blood cholesterol , damages arteries , and leads to coronary disease .	747.00024
throughout much of the world , food is still so scarce that half of the earth ' s population has trouble getting the 1 , 600 calories a day necessary to sustain life .	528.78284
the deficiency diseases -- scurvy , tropical sprue , pellagra -- run rampant .	14424.687
in west africa , for example , where meat is a luxury and babies must be weaned early to make room at the breast for later arrivals , a childhood menace is kwashiorkor , or `` red johnny ' ' , a growth-stunting protein deficiency ( signs reddish hair , bloated belly ) that kills more than half its victims , leaves the rest prey for parasites and lingering tropical disease .	1759.522
in the well-fed u . s . , deficiency diseases have virtually vanished in the past 20 years .	741.4455
today , as harrison ' s principles of internal medicine , a standard internist ' s text , puts it , `` the most common form of malnutrition is caloric excess or obesity ' ' .	477.60187

he is particularly vulnerable to diabetes .	732.5607
he may find even moderate physical exertion uncomfortable , because excess body fat hampers his breathing and restricts his muscular movement .	19372.996
physiologically , people overeat because what dr . jolliffe calls the `` appestat ' ' is set too high .	333.6471
the appestat , which adjusts the appetite to keep weight constant , is located , says jolliffe , in the hypothalamus -- near the body ' s temperature , sleep and water-balance controls .	758.847
in moderate doses , alcohol narcotizes the appestat and enhances appetite ( the original reason for the cocktail )	4508.317
but because liquor has a high caloric value -- 100 calories per oz . -- the heavy drinker is seldom hungry .	1824.2417
in rare cases , diseases such as encephalitis or a pituitary tumor may damage the appestat permanently , destroying nearly all sense of satiety .	4152.349
far more frequently , overeating is the result of a psychological compulsion .	974.49634
