this gives greater opportunity for the learning process .	162.60086
use dramatization -- for example , in discussing the lord ' s supper or church symbolism .	250.8604
some excellent filmstrips with recordings and motion pictures may be secured from your denominational headquarters to enrich the class session .	965.16833

invite class members to share in an extra period of bible study each week .	847.0553
ask each new member to bring his pledge of loyalty to the reception service .	394.3227
there is a growing conviction among pastors and church leaders that all those who come into the fellowship of the church need preparatory training , including those coming by transfer of membership .	748.62805
george e . sweazey writes `` there is danger in trying to make admission to the church so easy and painless that people will scarcely know that anything has happened ' ' .	282.08746
people appreciate experiences that demand something of them .	446.08377
those who transfer their membership are no exception to the rule .	295.93723
for most of them , it will be their first experience in membership training , since this is a recent development in many churches .	167.62852
those coming from other denominations will welcome the opportunity to become informed .	514.8372
the preparatory class is an introductory face-to-face group in which new members become acquainted with one another .	2180.25
it provides a natural transition into the life of the local church and its organizations .	190.79147
the total process of evangelism reaches the crescendo when the group of new members stands before the congregation to declare publicly their faith and to be received into the fellowship of the church .	519.09357
this should be a high moment in their lives , a never-to-be-forgotten experience .	714.55066
they should sense the tremendous significance of joining the spiritual succession reaching back to christ our lord and forward to an eternal fellowship with the saints of the ages .	657.1123
every detail of the service merits careful attention -- the hymns , the sermon , the ritual , the right hand of fellowship , the introduction to the congregation , the welcome of the congregation .	619.2179
this is a vital part of their spiritual growth and assimilation .	245.61519
it will help to determine the attitude of the new members toward the church .	117.31113

chapter 6 planning for the assimilation and growth of new members	255.63344
the church is `` the family of god ' ' .	40.25012
the members of the `` family ' ' are drawn together by a common love for christ and a sincere devotion to his kingdom .	352.85373
every member of the family must have a vital place in its life .	257.21466
this is no spectator-type experience	2197.2212
everyone is to be a participant .	534.87067
yet the most difficult problem in the church ' s program of evangelism is right at this point -- helping new members to become participating , growing parts of the fellowship .	253.39421
very easily they may be neglected and eventually join the ranks of the unconcerned and inactive .	560.39496
a study of major denominational membership statistics over a twenty-year period revealed the appalling fact that nearly 40 per cent of those who joined the church were lost to the church within seven years .	536.1653
one denomination had a membership of 1 , 419 , 833 at the beginning of the period under study , and twenty years later its membership stood at 1 , 541 , 991 -- a net growth of only 122 , 158 .	726.38727
yet during the same period there were 1 , 080 , 062 additions .	2627.6245
another major church body had 4 , 499 , 608 members and twenty years later its membership stood at 4 , 622 , 444 .	1792.3132
during this time 4 , 122 , 354 new members were brought into the fellowship .	1685.8973
still another denomination had 7 , 360 , 187 members twenty years ago .	4601.7837
during this period 7 , 484 , 268 members were received , yet the net membership now is only 9 , 910 , 741 .	2385.1404
these figures indicate that we are losing almost as many as we are receiving into membership .	466.48282
this problem is illustrated by the fact that many local churches drop from the active membership rolls each year as many as they receive into the fellowship .	542.9308
studies of membership trends , even in some areas where population is expanding , show that numbers of churches have had little net increase , though many new members were received .	521.57874
something is wrong when these things happen .	741.41296
the local `` family of god ' ' has failed its new members through neglect and unconcern for their spiritual welfare .	618.8917
new members can become participating , growing members .	1550.8229
but this will not happen merely through the natural process of social life .	341.4937
it must be planned and carefully developed .	540.2852
the entire membership of the local church must be alerted to their part in this dynamic process .	284.47754
if the church has followed the plan of cultivation of prospects and carried through a program of membership preparation as outlined earlier in this book , the process of assimilation and growth will be well under way .	499.5196
those who enter the front door of the church intelligently and with christian dedication will not so easily step through the back door because of lost interest .	1112.437
however , it is not enough to bring persons to christian commitment and train them in the meaning of christian discipleship .	446.4964
when they unite with the church they must find in this fellowship the satisfaction of their basic spiritual needs or they will never mature into effective christians .	414.2753
the church expects certain things of those who become members .	760.25336
the new members justifiably expect some things from their church family	1366.7404
-- opportunities for study of the christian faith and the bible	143.7592
-- guidance in christian social concerns .	590.3051
men need unity and they need god .	319.33908
care must be taken neither to confuse unity with uniformity nor god with our parochial ideas about him , but with these two qualifications , the statement stands .	726.3215
the statement also points to a classic paradox the more men turn toward god , who is not only in himself the paradigm of all unity but also the only ground on which human unity can ultimately be established , the more men splinter into groups and set themselves apart from one another .	662.2254
to be reminded of this we need only glance at the world map and note the extent to which religious divisions have compounded political ones , with a resultant fragmentation of the human race .	551.6619
massacres attending the partition of india and the establishment of the state of israel are simply recent grim evidences of the hostility such divisions can engender .	597.1527
the words of cardinal newman come forcibly to mind `` oh how we hate one another for the love of god ' ' ! !	552.2072
the source of this paradox is not difficult to identify .	332.3381
institutions require structure , form , and definition , and these in turn entail differentiation and exclusion .	467.6104
a completely amorphous institution would be a contradiction in terms	173.06206
to escape this fate , it must rule some things out .	243.16437
for every criterion which defines what something is , at the same time proclaims -- implicitly if not openly -- what that something is not .	1488.4855
some persons are so sensitive to this truth as to propose that we do away with institutions altogether	1076.5388
in the present context this amounts to the advice that while being religious may have a certain justification , we ought to dispense with churches .	445.0109
man is at once a gregarious animal and a form-creating being .	1919.1544
having once committed himself to an ideal which he considers worthwhile , he inevitably creates forms for its expression and institutions for its continuance .	600.253
to propose that men be religious without having religious institutions is like proposing that they be learned without having schools .	1712.3312
both eventualities are possible logically , but practically they are impossible .	430.19806
as much as men intrinsically need the unity that is grounded in god , they instrumentally require the institutions that will direct their steps toward him .	821.6686
yet the fact remains that such institutions do set men at odds with their fellows .	737.80084
is there any way out of the predicament ? ?	145.4992
the only way that i can see is through communication .	149.83417
interfaith communication need not be regarded as an unfortunate burden visited upon us by the necessity of maintaining diplomatic relations with our adversaries .	903.8406
approached creatively , it is a high art .	121.556046
it is the art of relating the finite to the infinite , of doing our best to insure that the particularistic requirements of religious institutions will not thwart god ' s intent of unity among men more than is minimally necessary .	1149.9414
in a certain sense , interfaith communication parallels diplomatic communication among the nation-states .	6718.1987
what are the pertinent facts affecting such communication at the present juncture of history ? ?	529.41614
i shall touch on three areas personal , national , and theological .	1258.0007
by personal factors i mean those rooted in personality structure .	1138.7787
some interfaith tensions are not occasioned by theological differences at all , but by the need of men to have persons they can blame , distrust , denounce , and even hate .	656.28314
such needs may rise to pathological proportions .	692.1684
modern psychology has shown that paralleling `` the authoritarian personality ' ' is `` the bigoted personality ' ' in which insecurity , inferiority , suspicion , and distrust combine to provide a target for antagonism so indispensable that it will be manufactured if it does not exist naturally .	557.3527
fortunately the number of pathological bigots appears to be quite small , but it would be a mistake to think that more than a matter of degree separates them from the rest of us .	378.33212
to some extent the personal inadequacies that prejudices attempt to compensate for are to be found in all of us .	700.03766
interfaith conflicts which spring from psychological deficiencies are the most unfortunate of all , for they have no redeeming features whatsoever .	919.5119
it is difficult to say what can be done about them except that we must learn to recognize when it is they , rather than pretexts for them , that are causing the trouble , and do everything possible to nurture the healthy personalities that will prevent the development of such deficiencies .	405.02594
while the personality factors that aggravate interfaith conflict may be perennial , nationalism is more variable .	1974.033
the specific instance i have in mind is the afro-asian version which has gained prominence only in this second half of the twentieth century .	259.8295
emerging from the two centuries of colonial domination , the afro-asian world is aflame with a nationalism that has undone empires .	1235.6593
no less than twenty-two nations have already achieved independence since world war 2 , , and the number is growing by the year .	220.10715
as an obvious consequence , obstacles to genuine interfaith communication have grown more formidable in one important area relations between christians and non-christians in these lands .	2161.4128
colonialism alone would have been able to make these difficulties serious , for christianity is so closely tied to colonialism in the minds of these people that repudiation of the one has tended automatically toward the repudiation of the other .	470.22626
actually , however , this turns out to be only part of the picture .	144.51543
nationalism has abetted not only the repudiation of foreign religions but the revival of native ones , some of which had been lying in slumber for centuries .	730.5483
the truth is that any revival of traditional and indigenous religion will serve to promote that sense of identity and volksgeist which these young nations very much need .	1454.4027
insofar as these nations claim to incarnate traditions and ways of life which constitute ultimate , trans-political justifications for their existence , such people are inevitably led to emphasize the ways in which these traditions and ways are theirs rather than someone else ' s .	951.64624
all this works severely against the kind of cross-cultural communication for which christian missions stand .	1507.0535
africans and asians tend to consider not only missions but the local churches they have produced as centers and agents of western culture and ideology if not of direct political propaganda .	435.92587
the people hardest hit by this suspicion are , of course , christians on the mainland of china .	259.82355
for example , in burma and ceylon many buddhists argue that buddhism ought to be the official state religion .	2025.399
in 1960 ceylon nationalized its sectarian -- preponderantly christian -- schools , to the rejoicing of most of its 7 , 000 , 000 buddhists and the lament of its 800 , 000 roman catholics .	1312.1025
again , india has imposed formidable barriers against the entrance of additional missionaries , and fanatical hindu parties are expected to seek further action against christians once the influence making for tolerance due to nehru and his followers is gone .	1761.4282
the progressive closing of afro-asian ears to the christian message is epitomized in a conversation i had three years ago while flying from jerusalem to cairo .	1109.0421
i was seated next to the director of the seventh day adventists ' world radio program .	514.9592
he said that on his tour the preceding year a considerable number of hours would have been available to him on japanese radio networks , but that he had then lacked the funds to contract for them .	421.86984
after returning to the united states and raising the money , he discovered on getting back to japan that the hours were no longer available .	283.6353
it was not that they had been contracted for during the interval	324.30792
they simply could no longer be purchased for missionary purposes .	1737.1017
it is not unfair to add on the other side that the crude and almost vitriolic approach of certain fundamentalist sects toward the cultures and religions among which they work has contributed measurably to this heightening of anti-christian sentiment .	1424.8165
ironically , these are the groups which have doubled or tripled their missionary efforts since world war 2 , , while the more established denominations are barely maintaining pre-war staffs .	996.85736
although i have emphasized the barriers which an aroused nationalism has raised against relations between christians and non-christians in asia , the fact is that this development has also widened the gulf between certain afro-asian religions themselves .	1149.7128
the partition of india has hardly improved relations between hindus and muslims	9051.385
neither has the establishment of the state of israel fostered harmony between muslims and jews .	592.7198
i turn finally to several theological developments .	3140.3025
the modern world has been marked by progressive disaffection with claims to divine sanction for the state , whatever its political form .	899.3295
the american constitution was historic at this point in providing that `` congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion or prohibiting the free exercise thereof ' ' .	616.13947
one of our foremost jurists , david dudley field , has gone so far as to call this provision `` the greatest achievement ever made in the course of human history ' ' .	473.99246
the trend throughout the world ' s religions has been toward a recognition of at least the practical validity of this constitutional enactment .	307.70096
pakistan was created in 1947 expressly as a muslim state , but when the army took over eleven years later it did so on a wave of mass impatience which was directed in part against the inability of political and religious leaders to think their way through to the meaning of islam for the modern political situation .	536.4269
`` what is the point ' ' , charles adams reports the pakistanis as asking , `` in demanding an islamic state and society if no one , not even the doctors of the sacred law themselves , can say clearly and succinctly what the nature of such a state and society is ' ' ? ?	323.16867
the current regime of president mohammad ayub khan is determinedly secular .	16434.719
and while the nation was formerly named `` the islamic republic of pakistan ' ' , it is now simply `` the republic of pakistan ' ' .	368.5453
comparable trends can be noted elsewhere .	656.66534
the new regime in turkey is intentionally less muslim than its predecessor .	8948.577
the religious parties in israel have experienced a great loss of prestige in recent months .	558.80707
during the years when israel was passing from crisis to crisis -- the sinai campaign , the infusion of multitudes of penniless immigrants -- it was felt that the purpose of national unity could be best served if the secular majority were to yield to the religious parties .	897.66
now that israel enjoys relative prosperity and a reduction of tensions , the secularists are less disposed to compromise .	1022.1262
and in this country gustave weigel ' s delineation of the line between the sacral and secular orders during the last presidential campaign served to provide a most impressive roman catholic defense of the practical autonomy of both church and state .	1065.5829
the failure at that time of the puerto rican bishops to control the votes of their people added a ring of good sense to father weigel ' s theological argument .	815.4461
everywhere there seems to be a growing recognition of the fact that governments and religious institutions alike are too fallible and corruptible -- in a word , too human -- to warrant any claim of maintaining partnership with the divine .	592.47003
my father went as a missionary to china in a generation that responded to student volunteer movement speakers who held watches in their hands and announced to the students in their audiences how many chinese souls were going to hell each second because these students were not over there saving them .	1489.1136
that mention of this should bring smiles to our lips today is as clear an indication as we could wish of the extent to which attitudes have changed .	477.66107
i do not mean to imply that christians have adopted the liberal assumption , so prevalent in hinduism , that all religions are merely different paths to the same summit .	721.3224
leslie newbiggin reflects the dominant position within the world council of churches when he says , `` we must claim absoluteness and finality for christ and his finished work , but that very claim forbids us to claim absoluteness and finality for our understanding of it ' ' .	432.98477
newbiggin ' s qualification on the christian claim is of considerable significance .	225.33737
the roman catholic church has excommunicated one of its priests , father feeney , for insisting that there is no salvation outside the visible church .	749.76874
in mentioning this under `` salvation reconsidered ' ' i do not mean to imply that roman catholic doctrine has changed in this area but rather that it has become clearer to the world community what that doctrine is .	351.2082
when they say that under no circumstances would it ever be right to `` permit ' ' the termination of the human race by human action , because there could not possibly be any proportionate grave reason to justify such a thing , they know exactly what they mean .	317.87863
of course , in prudential calculation , in balancing the good directly intended and done against the evil unintended and indirectly done , no greater precision can be forthcoming than the subject allows .	1521.3931
yet it seems clear that there can be no good sufficiently great , or evil repelled sufficiently grave , to warrant the destruction of mankind by man ' s own action .	385.58957
i mean , however , that the moral theologian knows what he means by `` permit ' ' .	208.9189
he is not talking in the main about probabilities , risks and danger in general .	375.9122
he is talking about an action which just as efficaciously does an evil thing ( and is known certainly and unavoidably to lead to this evil result ) as it efficaciously does some good .	1251.2161
he is talking about double effects , of which the specific action causes directly the one and indirectly the other , but causes both	512.7916
of which one is deliberately willed or intended and the other not intended or not directly intended , but still both are done , while the evil effect is , with equal consciousness on the part of the agent , foreknown to be among the consequences .	534.7245
this is what , in a technical sense , to `` only permit ' ' an evil result means .	472.4713
it means to do it and to know one is doing it , but as only a secondary if certain effect of the good one primarily does and intends .	414.92023
of course , grave guiltiness may be imputed to the military action of any nation , or to the action of any leader or leaders , which for any supposed good `` permits ' ' , in this sense , the termination of the human race by human action .	211.98366
certainly , in analyzing an action which truly faced such alternatives , `` it is never possible that no world would be preferable to some worlds , and there are in truth no circumstances in which the destruction of human life presents itself as a reasonable alternative ' ' .	408.59555
naturally , where one or the other of the effects of an action is uncertain , this has to be taken into account .	141.1946
especially is this true when , because the good effect is remote and speculative while the evil is certain and grave , the action is prohibited .	447.96683
presumably , if the reverse is the case and the good effect is more certain than the evil result that may be forthcoming , not only must the good and the evil be prudentially weighed and found proportionate , but also calculation of the probabilities and of the degree of certainty or uncertainty in the good or evil effect must be taken into account .	422.84558
there must not only be greater good than evil objectively in view , but also greater probability of actually doing more good than harm .	1032.9595
if an evil which is certain and extensive and immediate may rarely be compensated for by a problematic , speculative , future good , by the same token not every present , certain , and immediate good ( or lesser evil ) that may have to be done will be outweighed by a problematic , speculative , and future evil .	738.8447
nevertheless , according to the traditional theory , a man begins in the midst of action and he analyzes its nature and immediate consequences before or while putting it forth and causing these consequences .	700.0083
he does not expect to be able to trammel up all the future consequences of his action .	192.29274
above all , he does not debate mere contingencies , and therefore , if these are possibly dreadful , find himself forced into inaction .	809.05743
he does what he can and may and must , without regarding himself as lord of the future or , on the other hand , as covered with guilt by accident or unforeseen consequences or by results he did not `` permit ' ' in the sense explained .	467.7924
by contrast , a good deal of nuclear pacifism begins with the contingencies and the probabilities , and not with the moral nature of the action to be done	280.52557
and by deriving legitimate decision backward from whatever may conceivably or possibly or probably result , whether by anyone ' s doing or by accident , it finds itself driven to inaction , to non-political action in politics and non-military action in military affairs , and to the not very surprising discovery that there are now no distinctions on which the defense of justice can possibly be based .	589.58777
mr . philip toynbee writes , for example , that `` in terms of probability it is surely as likely as not that mutual fear will lead to accidental war in the near future if the present situation continues .	384.60144
if it continues indefinitely it is nearly a statistical certainty that a mistake will be made and that the devastation will begin ' ' .	245.58322
against such a termination of human life on earth by human action , he then proposes as an alternative that we `` negotiate at once with the russians and get the best terms which are available ' ' , that we deliberately `` negotiate from comparative weakness ' ' .	321.85165
he bravely attempts to face this alternative realistically , i . e . , by considering the worst possible outcome , namely , the total domination of the world by russia within a few years .	272.20905
this would be by far the better choice , when `` it is a question of allowing the human race to survive , possibly under the domination of a regime which most of us detest , or of allowing it to destroy itself in appalling and prolonged anguish ' ' .	331.36447
nevertheless , the consequence of the policy proposed is everywhere subtly qualified it is `` a possible result , however improbable ' '	548.3736
`` the worst , and least probable ' ' result	2314.9807
`` if it didn ' t prevail mankind would still be given the opportunity of prevailing ' '	161.09396
for `` surely anything is better than a policy which allows for the possibility of nuclear war ' ' .	185.71577
if we have not thought and made a decision entirely in these terms , then we need to submit ourselves to the following `` simple test ' ' `` have we decided how we are to kill the other members of our household in the event of our being less injured than they are ' ' ? ?	261.79446
thus , moral decision must be entirely deduced backward from the likely eventuality	19106.125
it is no longer to be formulated in terms of the nature of present action itself , its intention , and proximate effect or the thing to be done .	202.1583
several of the replies to mr . toynbee , without conscious resort to the traditional terminology with regard to the permission of evil , succeed in restoring the actual context in which present moral and political decisions must be made , by distinguishing between choosing a great evil and choosing in danger of this evil .	711.3499
`` it is worse for a nation to give in to evil than to run the risk of annihilation ' ' .	132.77147
`` i am consciously prepared to run the continued risk of ' race suicide by accident ' rather than accept the alternative certainty of race slavery by design .	1809.4602
but i can only make this choice because i believe that the risk need not increase , but may be deliberately reduced ' ' ( by precautions against accidents or by limiting war ? ?	383.74374
) `` quoting mr . kennan ' s phrase that anything would be better than a policy which led inevitably to nuclear war , he ( toynbee ) says that anything is better than a policy which allows for the possibility of nuclear war ' ' .	293.9859
`` if asked to choose between a terrible probability and a more terrible possibility , most men will choose the latter ' ' .	298.0698
`` if philip toynbee is claiming that the choice lies between capitulation and the risk of nuclear war , i think he is right .	235.7801
i do not accept that the choice is between capitulation and the certainty of nuclear war ' ' .	137.54362
even professor arnold toynbee , agreeing with his son , does so in these terms `` compared to continuing to incur a constant risk of the destruction of the human race , all other evils are lesser evils .	430.39893
let us therefore put first things first , and make sure of preserving the human race at whatever the temporary price may be ' ' .	314.28537
mr . philip toynbee affirms at one point that if he shared the anticipations of orwell in nineteen eighty-four , if he believed communism was not only evil but `` also irredeemably evil ' ' , then he might `` think it right to do anything rather than to take the risk of a communist world .	563.5799
even a nuclear holocaust is a little less frightful to contemplate than a race of dehumanised humans occupying the earth until doomsday ' ' .	1455.0658
no political order or economic system is so clearly contrary to nature .	627.83264
but one does not have to affirm the existence of an evil order irredeemable in that sense , or a static order in which no changes will take place in time , to be able truthfully to affirm the following fact there has never been justitia imprinted in social institutions and social relationships except in the context of some pax-ordo preserved by clothed or naked force .	775.4181
on their way to the heavenly city the children of god make use of the pax-ordo of the earthly city and acknowledge their share in responsibility for its preservation .	482.31226
not to repel injury and uphold and improve pax-ordo means not simply to accept the misshapen order and injustice that challenges it at the moment , but also to start down the steep slope along which justice can find no place whereon to stand .	1176.2318
toynbee seems to think that there is some other way to give justice social embodiment .	460.05948
`` i would far rather die after a russian occupation of this country -- by some deliberate act of refusal -- than die uselessly by atomisation ' ' .	894.37524
would such an act of refusal be useful ? ?	520.43317
he does not mean , in fact he addresses himself specifically to reject the proposition , that `` if we took the risk of surrendering , a new generation in britain would soon begin to amass its strength in secret in order to reverse the consequences of that surrender ' ' .	384.60876
he wants to be `` brutally frank and say that these rebellions would be hopeless -- far , far more hopeless than was the hungarian revolution of 1956 ' ' .	689.0416
this is not a project for regaining the ground for limited war , by creating a monopoly in one power of the world ' s arsenal of unlimited weapons .	394.88416
it is a proposal that justice now be served by means other than those that have ever preconditioned the search for it , or preconditioned more positive means for attaining it , in the past .	970.9462
`` it is no good recommending surrender rather than nuclear warfare with the proviso that surrender could be followed by the effective military resistance by occupied peoples .	1670.6699
hope for the future would lie in the natural longing of the human race for freedom and the right to develop ' ' .	117.192604
this is to surrender in advance to whatever attack may yet be mounted , to the very last	474.31738
it is to stride along the steep slope downward .	4419.6724
the only contrary action , in the future as in the past , runs the risk of war	154.7064
and , now and in the future unlike in the past , any attempt to repel injury and to preserve any particular civilized attainment of mankind or its provisional justice runs some risk of nuclear warfare and the danger that an effect of it will , by human action , render this planet less habitable by the human race .	759.0935
that is why it is so very important that ethical analysis keep clear the problem of decision as to `` permitted ' ' effects , and not draw back in fright from any conceivable contingency or suffer paralysis of action before possibilities or probabilities unrelated , or not directly morally related , to what we can and may and must do as long as human history endures .	947.8738
finally , just as no different issues are posed for thoughtful analysis by the foreshortening of time that may yet pass before the end of human life on this earth , but only stimulation and alarm to the imagination , the same thing must be said in connection with the question of what we may perhaps already be doing , by human action , to accelerate this end .	437.43445
we should not allow the image of an immanent end brought about indirectly by our own action in the continuing human struggle for a just endurable order of existence to blind us to the fact that in some measure accelerating the end of our lease may be one consequence among others of many other of mankind ' s thrusts toward we know not what future .	637.8582
much more than shelter , housing symbolizes social status , a sense of `` belonging ' ' , acceptance within a given group or neighborhood , identification with particular cultural values and social institutions , feelings of pride and worth , aspirations and hopes basic to human well-being .	731.76575
for almost one-sixth of the national population discrimination in the free selection of residence casts a considerable shadow upon these values assumed as self-evident by most americans .	1006.2537
few business groups in recent years have come under heavier pressure to face these realities than real estate brokers and home builders .	1524.5295
this pressure has urged re-evaluation of the assumptions underlying their professional ethics	9684.767
it has sought new sympathy for the human aspirations of racial minority groups in this country .	439.76617
it is not surprising that , as spokesman for real estate interests , the national association of real estate boards ( nareb ) and its local associations have sought to limit and often ignore much of this pressure .	585.46814
how does the local realtor see himself in the context of housing restrictions based on race , religion or ethnic attachment ? ?	916.0
what does he conceive his role to be in this area of social unrest ? ?	129.86676
what ought to be , what is his potential role as a force for constructive social change ? ?	385.30484
what social , ethical and theological insights can the church and university help him bring to bear upon his situation ? ?	482.05774
recently , a group of the faculty at wesleyan university ' s public affairs center sought some answers to these questions .	772.79144
several new england realtors were invited to participate in a small colloquium of property lawyers , political scientists , economists , social psychologists , social ethicists and theologians .	1297.0591
here , in an atmosphere of forthrightness and mutual criticism , each sought to bring his particular insights to bear upon the question of discrimination in housing and the part each man present played in it .	624.5976
for a number of years , wesleyan has been drawing varied groups of political and business leaders into these informal discussions with members of the faculty and student body , attempting to explore and clarify aspects of their responsibility for public policy .	569.0541
this article presents our observations of that session , of the realtors as they saw themselves and as the faculty and students saw them .	288.49994
such conversation quickly reveals an ethically significant ambivalence in the self-images held by most realtors .	2539.424
within the membership of this group , as has been found true of men in other professional or trade associations , the most ready portrayal of oneself to `` the public ' ' is that of a neutral agent simply serving the interests of a seller or buyer and mediating between them .	595.6843
professional responsibility is seen to consist largely in serving the wishes of the client fairly and in an efficient manner .	489.23383
but as conversation goes on , particularly among the realtors themselves , another image emerges , that of considerable power and influence in the community .	311.51096
obviously , much more than customer expectation is determining the realtor ' s role .	887.3001
judgments are continually rendered regarding the potential buyers ' income , educational level and above all , racial extraction	1280.8604
and whether these would qualify them for `` congenial ' ' , `` happy ' ' relations to other people in certain community areas .	184.85251
how explicit such factors have been historically is evident in any chronology of restrictive covenant cases or in a review of nareb ' s code of ethics article 34 in the code , adopted in 1924 , states that `` a realtor should never be instrumental in introducing into a neighborhood a character of property or occupancy , members of any race or nationality or any individuals whose presence will clearly be detrimental to property values in that neighborhood ' ' .	865.6128
though the reference to race was stricken by the association in 1950 , being an agent of such `` detrimental ' ' influences still appears as the cardinal sin realtors see themselves committed to avoid .	846.7827
the rationale for this avoidance was most frequently expressed in economic terms	2069.1958
all feared the supposed stigma they believed would inevitably attach to any realtor who openly introduced non-white , particularly negro , peoples into all-white , restricted areas .	4712.1343
they would become tagged as men not interested in being purely real estate `` professionals ' ' but agitators for some kind of `` cause ' ' or `` reform ' ' , and this was no longer to be a `` pro ' ' .	161.68732
obviously what we are confronted with here is the identification of `` professional ' ' with narrow skills and specialization , the effective servicing of a client , rather than responsiveness to the wider and deeper meaning and associations of one ' s work .	333.39346
these men -- for the most part educated in our `` best ' ' new england colleges , well established financially and socially in the community -- under kindly but insistent probing , reveal little or no objective or explicit criteria or data for their generalizations about the interests and attitudes of the people they claim to serve , or about the public responses that actually follow their occasional breach of a `` client-service relationship ' ' .	670.83136
this narrow `` professionalism ' ' does not even fit the present realities of their situation , as the pressure of minorities and the power and respectability of the realtors increase .	203.77045
as our discussion continued , the inadequacy of the `` client relationship ' ' as an interpretation of their `` way of operating ' ' became evident .	217.35474
realtors live in their communities as specialists in a given area of work , as members of social and professional organizations , as citizens and civic leaders , as church laymen , as university alumni , as newspaper readers , etc . .	343.7184
from such communal roles the realtor finds the substance that shapes his moral understanding .	926.82715
it seems to us that choices exercised by realtors in moral situations center in at least three areas ( 1 ) the various ways in which they interpret a particular social issue	946.47815
( 2 ) their pattern of involvement in the regular legal and political processes	583.2114
and , most pervasively , ( 3 ) their interpretation of who is a `` real pro ' ' , of what it means to be a professional man in a technical , fragmented society .	174.23718
( 1 ) most of the realtors minimized their own understanding of and role in the racial issue , pleading that they only reflect the attitudes and intentions of their society .	381.33124
there is some reality to this	56.739204
the commission on race and housing concluded that `` there is no reason to believe that real estate men are either more or less racially prejudiced , on the whole , than any other segment of the american population ' ' .	464.24118
but such a reaction obscures the powerful efforts made in the past by both nareb and its local boards for the maintenance of restrictive clauses and practices .	1228.9858
also , it does not recognize the elements of choice and judgment continually employed .	436.6315
like business and university groups generally , these men had very limited knowledge of recent sociological and psychological studies and findings that might illumine the decisions they make .	1133.0508
realtors , both generally and in this group , have invariably equated residential integration with a decline in property values , a circumstance viewed with considerable apprehension .	978.23676
recent studies by the commission on race and housing and others , however , point to a vast complex of factors that often do not warrant this conclusion .	334.70343
there are increasing numbers of neighborhoods that are integrated residentially without great loss of property values , the white population having taken the initiative in preparing the areas for an appreciation of the negroes ' desire for well-kept housing , privacy , etc . .	630.14624
data on the decline of property values in an area after a new racial group enters it has to be assessed in terms of the trends in property values before the group comes in .	312.43286
often they are able to get in only because the area is declining economically .	406.5943
significantly , no realtor and few of the faculty present were familiar with any of the six volumes ( published by the university of california press ) that present the commission ' s findings .	311.24625
no one anticipates any radical shift in this situation , but questions concerning reading habits , the availability of such data and the places where it is discussed must surely be raised .	337.37454
the role of both church and university as sources of information and settings within which the implications of such information may be explored needs consideration .	370.3524
relevant `` facts ' ' , however , extend beyond considerations of property values and maintenance of `` harmonious ' ' neighborhoods .	366.7956
discussion of minority housing necessarily involves such basic issues as the intensity of one ' s democratic conviction and religious belief concerning equality of opportunity , the function and limitations of government in the securing of such equality , and the spotlight that world opinion plays upon local incidents of racial agitation and strife .	516.7465
`` against the grain of creation ' '	85.54963
( 2 ) realtors realize , of course , that they are involved in an increasingly complex legal and political system that is opening up opportunities for leverage on their relation to clients as well as opportunities for evasion of their responsibility for racial discrimination in housing .	644.0469
on the positive side , recent federal action has largely undermined the legal sanction so long enjoyed by the segregationist position	3515.8284

judicial opinion since the supreme court decision on shelley v . kraemer ( 1948 ) has rendered racial restrictive covenants unenforcible .	4688.8193

one of the roles of the social scientist , ethicist or theologian in our discussions with the realtors became that of encouraging greater awareness of the opportunities offered by the legal and political processes for the exercise of broad social responsibilities in their work .	573.1066
but responsiveness to these opportunities presumes that all of us judge the good as a human good and not simply as a professional , white , american good .	532.376
such judgments are meaningful only in so far as persons are members of a world , let us say a community , that embraces scarsdale or yonkers , but is also infinitely richer since it is all-inclusive .	889.29504
that community of all creation is , then , the ultimate object of our loyalty and the concrete norm of all moral judgment .	324.95557
racial discrimination is wrong , then , not because it goes against the grain of a faculty member trying to converse with a few realtors but because it goes against the grain of creation and against the will of the creator .	322.8397
thus , moral issues concerning the nature of the legal and political processes take on theological dimensions .	468.84506

science is placing in our hands the ultimate power of the universe , the power of the atom .	153.89142
religion , or the lack of it , will decide whether we use this power to build a brave new world of peace and abundance for all mankind , or whether we misuse this power to leave a world utterly destroyed .	490.24664
how can we have the wisdom to meet such a new and difficult challenge ? ?	322.26108
we may feel pessimistic at the outlook .	88.928276

and it is in this new vision of the atom that we find an affirmation and an invigoration of our faith .	373.931

you know that i could hold right here in my hand the little chunk of uranium metal that was the heart of the bomb that dropped on hiroshima .	768.2747
it was only about the size of a baseball	79.73174
but packed in that metallic ball there was the explosive force of 20 , 000 tons of aj .	494.0097
that is enough tnt to fill the tower of the empire state building	511.9292
and with the availability of bombs of that size , war became a new problem .	196.52907
now we might have restricted the use of uranium bombs by controlling the sources of uranium because it is found in only a few places in the world .	482.413
but we had hardly started to adjust our thinking to this new uranium weapon when we were faced with the hydrogen bomb .	766.7559
hydrogen is just as plentiful as uranium is scarce .	2250.7322
we know that we have hydrogen in water	2790.1785
water is af and the h stands for hydrogen	565.3744
there is also hydrogen in wood and hydrogen in our bodies .	455.19336
i have calculated that if i could snap my fingers in one magic gesture to release the power of all the hydrogen in my body , i would explode with the force of a hundred bombs of the kind that fell on hiroshima .	401.29434
i won ' t try the experiment , but i think you can see that if we all knew the secret and we could all let ourselves go , there would be quite an explosion .	219.82774
and then think how little hydrogen we have in us compared with the hydrogen in delaware bay or in the ocean beyond .	460.9255

of course , there is also an optimistic side to the picture .	232.99487

then think of delaware bay and the ocean and you see that we have a supply of power for millions of years to come .	189.1371
it is power with which we can literally rebuild the world , provide adequate housing , food , education , abundant living for everyone everywhere .	1727.0231

to grasp our new view of the atom , we have to appreciate first of all how small the atom is .	189.07875
i have been trying to make this clear to my own class in chemistry .	274.07513
one night there were some dried peas lying on our kitchen table , and these peas looked to me like a little group of atoms	864.49536
and i asked myself a question suppose i had the same number of peas as there are atoms in my body , how large an area would they cover ? ?	765.49774
i calculated first that there are about an octillion atoms in the average human body	496.84787
that is a figure one with 27 ciphers , quite a large number .	1400.4246
then i calculated that a million peas would just about fill a household refrigerator	2498.6511
a billion peas would fill a small house from cellar to attic	1126.4124
a trillion peas would fill all the houses in a town of about ten thousand people	203.053
and a quadrillion peas would fill all the buildings in the city of philadelphia .	145.11578
i saw that i would soon run out of buildings at this rate , so i decided to take another measure -- the whole state of pennsylvania .	196.48213
imagine that there is a blizzard over pennsylvania , but instead of snowing snow , it snows peas	2177.5737
so we get the whole state covered with peas , about four feet deep .	919.61145
you can imagine what it would look like going out on the turnpike with the peas banked up against the houses and covering the cars	429.74823
pennsylvania thus blanketed would contain about a quintillion peas .	1522.3407
but we still have a long way to go .	105.845215
next we imagine our blizzard raging over all the land areas of the entire globe -- north america , south america , europe , asia , and africa , all covered with peas four feet deep	719.975
next we freeze over the oceans and cover the whole earth with peas , then we go out among the neighboring stars , collect 250 planets each the size of the earth , and also cover each of these with peas four feet deep	646.78284
finally we go into the farthest reaches of the milky way	2120.866
we cover each of these with our blanket of peas and then at last we have octillion peas corresponding in number to the atoms in the body .	1144.6829
so you see how small an atom is and how complicated you are .	437.62848
now although an atom is small , we can still in imagination have a look at it .	332.74152
let us focus on an atom of calcium from the tip of the bone of my finger and let us suppose that i swallow a magic alice in wonderland growing pill .	1279.5033
i start growing rapidly and this calcium atom grows along with me .	1660.3212
i shoot up through the roof , into the sky , past the clouds , through the stratosphere , out beyond the moon , out among the planets , until i am over a hundred and fifty million miles long .	358.85806
then this atom of calcium will swell to something like a great balloon a hundred yards across , a balloon big enough to put a football field inside .	1134.2264
and if you should step inside of such a magnified atom , according to the physics of forty years ago , you would see circulating over your head , down at the sides , and under your feet , some twenty luminous balls about the size of footballs .	503.9098
these balls are moving in great circles and ellipses , and are of course , the electrons , the particles of negative electricity which by their action create the forces that tie this atom of calcium to the neighboring atoms of oxygen and make up the solid structure of my finger bone .	880.4059
since these electrons are moving like planets , you may wonder whether there is an atomic sun at the center of the atom .	277.14645
so you look down there and you see a tiny , whirling point about the size of the head of a pin .	246.64684
this is the atomic sun , the atomic nucleus .	356.55267
even if the atom were big enough to hold a football field , this nucleus is still only about the size of a pinhead .	431.56186
it is this atomic nucleus that contains the positive charge of electricity holding these negatively charged electrons in their orbits	2940.4045
it also contains nearly all the mass , and the atomic energy .	229.41982
you may ask what else there is , and the answer is nothing -- nothing but empty space .	455.24002
and since you are made of atoms , you are nothing much but empty space , too .	453.43323
if i could put your body in an imaginary atomic press and squeeze you down , squeeze these holes out of you in the way we squeeze the holes out of a sponge , you would get smaller and smaller until finally when the last hole was gone , you would be smaller than the smallest speck of dust that you could see on this piece of paper .	625.90674
someone has remarked that this is certainly the ultimate in reducing .	540.7375
at any rate , it shows us how immaterial we are .	1028.3197
now this 1920 view of the atom was on the whole a discouraging picture .	220.82327
for we believed that the electrons obeyed the law of mechanics and electrodynamics	3338.61
and therefore the atom was really just a little machine	728.7481
and in mechanics the whole is no more than the sum of the parts .	192.8228
so if you are made of atoms , you are just a big machine	452.3269
and since the universe is also made of atoms , it is just a supermachine .	566.1114

these ripples spread out in symmetrical patterns like the rose windows of a great cathedral .	1363.7925

and so today when we examine the structure of our knowledge of the atom and of the universe , we are forced to conclude that the best word to describe our universe is music .	175.75052

to what extent and in what ways did christianity affect the united states of america in the nineteenth century ? ?	200.20648
how far and in what fashion did it modify the new nation which was emerging in the midst of the forces shaping the revolutionary age ? ?	483.9652
to what extent did it mould the morals and the social , economic , and political life and institutions of the country ? ?	243.95724
a complete picture is impossible -- partly because of the limitations of space , partly because for millions of individuals who professed allegiance to the christian faith data are unobtainable .	888.7952
even more of an obstacle is the difficulty of separating the influence of christianity from other factors .	470.92432

in the twentieth century its influence grew , as did that of the protestantism of the nineteenth-century immigration .	343.00443

the american dream was compounded of many strains .	1708.4066
some were clearly of christian origin , among them the great awakening and other revivals which helped to make christian liberty , christian equality , and christian fraternity the passion of the land .	437.57425
some have seen revivalism and the search for christian perfection as the fountain-head of the american hope .	358.94568
here , too , must be placed unitarianism and , less obviously from christian inspiration , emerson , transcendentalism , and the idealism of walt whitman .	1824.9413
we must also remember those who reacted against the dream as a kind of myth -- among them melville , hawthorne , and henry james the elder , all of them out of a christian background .	593.3691
with such a dream arising , at least in part , from the protestant heritage of the united states and built into the foundations of the nation , it is not surprising that many efforts were made to give it concrete expression .	168.18625
a number were in the nature of movements to relieve or remove social ills .	643.228
significantly , the initiation and leadership of a major proportion of the reform movements , especially those in the first half of the nineteenth century , came from men and women of new england birth or parentage and from either trinitarian or unitarian congregationalism .	549.6582
several of the movements were given a marked impetus by revivalism .	1185.435
quakers , some from new england , had a larger share than their proportionate numerical strength would have warranted .	1976.5469
we do well to remind ourselves that from men and women of new england ancestry also issued the church of jesus christ of latter day saints , the seventh day adventists , christian science , the american board of commissioners for foreign missions , the american home missionary society , the american bible society , and new england theology .	861.00635
the atmosphere was one of optimism , of confidence in human progress , and of a determination to rid the world of its ills .	345.46902
the hopkinsian universal disinterested benevolence , although holding to original sin and the doctrine of election , inspired its adherents to heroic endeavours for others , looked for the early coming of the millennium , and was paralleled by the confidence in man ' s ability cherished by the unitarians , emerson , and the transcendentalists .	549.15125
we should recall the number of movements for the service of mankind which arose from the kindred evangelicalism of the british isles and the pietism of the continent of europe -- among them prison reform , anti-slavery measures , legislation for the alleviation of conditions of labour , the inner mission , and the red cross .	685.51276
we cannot take the space to record all the efforts for the removal or alleviation of collective ills .	563.1388
a few of the more prominent must serve as examples of what a complete listing and description would disclose .	727.6585
several were born in the early decades and persisted throughout the century .	275.86725
some disappeared with the attainment of their purpose .	316.25845
still others sprang up late in the century to meet conditions which arose from fresh stages of the revolutionary age .	575.597
the movement to end negro slavery began before 1815 and mounted after that year until , as a result of the civil war , emancipation was achieved .	523.36676
long before 1815 the christian conscience was leading some to declare slavery wrong and to act accordingly .	1148.5079
for example , in 1693 the philadelphia yearly meeting of friends declared that its members should emancipate their slaves and in 1776 it determined to exclude from membership all who did not comply .	1647.922
in the latter year samuel hopkins , from whom the hopkinsian strain of new england theology took its name , asked the continental congress to abolish slavery .	1511.5082
as we have seen , methodism early took a stand against slavery .	1760.5936
beginning at least as far back as 1789 various baptist bodies condemned slavery .	5029.1367
after 1815 anti-slavery sentiment mounted , chiefly among protestants and those of protestant background of the older stock .	690.49084
the nineteenth-century immigration , whether protestant or roman catholic , was not so much concerned , for very few if any among them held slaves they were mostly in the northern states where slavery had disappeared or was on the way out , or were too poverty-stricken to own slaves .	684.34485
the anti-slavery movement took many forms .	482.09818
benjamin lundy ( 1789-1839 ) , a quaker , was a pioneer in preparing the way for anti-slavery societies .	316.95523
it was he who turned the attention of william lloyd garrison ( 1805-1879 ) to the subject .	544.70917
garrison , massachusetts born of nova scotian parentage , was by temperament and conviction a reformer .	4252.595
chiefly remembered because of his incessant advocacy of `` immediate and unconditional abolition ' ' , he also espoused a great variety of other causes -- among them women ' s rights , prohibition , and justice to the indians .	459.9182
incurably optimistic , dogmatic , and utterly fearless , in his youth a devout baptist , in spite of his friendship for the quaker poet john greenleaf whittier ( 1807-1892 ) he eventually attacked the orthodox churches for what he deemed their cowardly compromising on the slavery issue and in his invariably ardent manner was emphatically unorthodox and denied the plenary inspiration of the bible .	926.3332
a marked impulse came to the anti-slavery movement through the finney revivals .	585.39026
finney himself , while opposed to slavery , placed his chief emphasis on evangelism , but from his converts issued much of the leadership of the anti-slavery campaign .	484.56512
theodore dwight weld ( 1803-1895 ) was especially active .	402.49054
weld was the son and grandson of new england congregational ministers .	1044.9303
as a youth he became one of finney ' s band of evangelists and gave himself to winning young men .	522.9282
a strong temperance advocate , through the influence of a favorite teacher , charles stewart , another finney convert , he devoted himself to the anti-slavery cause .	432.57675
a group of young men influenced by him enrolled in lane theological seminary and had to leave because of their open anti-slavery position .	1322.0083
the majority then went to the infant oberlin .	770.66077
they and others employed some of finney ' s techniques as they sought to win adherents to the cause .	413.354
weld contributed to the anti-slavery convictions of such men as joshua r . giddings and edwin m . stanton , enlisted john quincy adams , and helped provide ideas which underlay harriet beecher stowe ' s uncle tom ' s cabin .	2066.3594
he shunned publicity for himself and sought to avoid fame .	569.2037
wendell phillips ( 1811-1884 ) , from a prominent massachusetts family , in his teens was converted under the preaching of lyman beecher .	584.10095
although he later broke with the churches because he believed that they were insufficiently outspoken against social evils , he remained a devout christian .	730.35846
he was remembered chiefly for his fearless advocacy of abolition , but he also stood for equal rights for women , for opportunity for the freedmen , and for prohibition .	597.25116
the anti-slavery movement and other contemporary reforms and philanthropies were given leadership and financial undergirding by arthur tappan ( 1786-1865 ) and his younger brother , lewis tappan ( 1788-1873 ) .	1313.1378
individuals possessing unusual gifts and great personal power were transmuted at death into awesome spirits	3170.3396
they were almost immediately worshipped for these newer , even more terrible abilities .	1194.5862
their direct descendants inherited not only their worldly fortunes , but also the mandate of their newfound power as spirits in the other half of the universe .	504.2771
royal lineages could be based on extraordinary worldly achievements translated into eternal otherworldly power .	21752.148
thus , the emperor could draw on sources not available to those with less puissant ancestors .	1436.3518
but this eminence was not without its weighty responsibilities .	1913.655
since he possessed more power in an interdependent universe of living beings and dead spirits , the emperor had to use it for the benefit of the living .	292.77887
the royal ritual generated power into the other world it also provided the living with a way to control the spirits , and bring their powers directly to bear on the everyday affairs of the world .	290.06802
proper ritual observance at any level of society was capable of generating power for use in the spirit world	350.4275
but naturally , the royal ritual , which provided unusual control over already supremely powerful divine spirits , was held responsible for regulating the universe and insuring the welfare of the kingdom .	1504.0397
this is the familiar system of `` cosmic government ' ' .	74.69746
the chinese emperor , by proper observance of ritual , manifested divine powers .	2178.5645
he regulated the dualities of light and darkness , yang and yin , which are locked in eternal struggle .	666.57513
by swaying the balance between them , he effected the alternation of the seasons .	781.0617
his power was so great that he even promoted and demoted gods according to whether they had given ear or been deaf to petitions .	1558.0593
in this system , no man is exempt from obligations .	2091.0168
failure in daily moral and ethical duties to one ' s family , outrages to community propriety , any departure from rigid standards of moral excellence were offenses against the dead .	863.2497
and to offend the dead meant to incur their wrath , and thus provoke the unleashing of countrywide disasters .	5244.0977
the family home was , in fact , a temple	100.20931
and the daily duties of individuals were basically religious in nature .	446.54648
the dead spirits occupied a prominent place in every hope and in every fear .	311.51038
the common belief was that there existed one moral order , which included everything .	569.52484
the dead controlled the material prosperity of the living , and the living adhered to strict codes of conduct in order not to weaken that control .	556.9542
men believed they could control nature by obeying a moral code .	1283.3866
if the moral code were flouted , the proper balance of the universe would be upset , and the disastrous result could be floods , plague , or famine .	489.0659
modern westerners have difficulty comprehending this fusion of moral and material , largely because in the west the historical trend has been to deny the connection .	451.2377
living in urban conditions , away from the deadweight of village constraint and the constrictions of a thatched-roof world view , the individual may find it possible , say , to commit adultery not only without personal misgivings , but also without suffering any adverse effects in his worldly fortunes .	1271.5854
basing action on the empirical determination of cause and effect provides a toughness and bravado that no powerful otherworldly ancestor could ever impart -- plus the added liberation from the constraint of silent burial urns .	3577.0574
in china , the magical system par excellence was taoism .	7469.176
the taoists were quietist mystics , who saw an unchanging unity -- the tao -- underlying all phenomena .	1215.4435
it was this timeless unity that was all-important , and not its temporary manifestations in the world of reality .	309.77847
the taoists believed the unity could be influenced by proper magical manipulation	1401.7179
in other words , they were actually an organization of magicians .	584.64844
mahayana buddhism was no exception to these prevailing magical concepts .	1814.6013
after this form of indian buddhism had been introduced into china , it underwent extensive changes .	1348.9204
during its flowering in the sixth to the eighth centuries , mahayana offered a supernatural package to the chinese which bears no resemblance to the highly digested philosophical zen morsels offered to the modern western reader .	1377.4039
mahayana had gods , and magic , a pantheon , heavens and hells , and gorgeously appareled priests , monks , and nuns , all of whom wielded power over souls in the other world .	1704.7219
the self-realized mahayana saint possessed superhuman powers and magic .	5174.922
the mahayana that developed in the north was a religion of idolatry and coarse magic , that made the world into a huge magical garden .	530.76666
in its monastic form , mahayana was merely an organization of magic-practicing monks ( bonzes ) , who catered to the chinese faith in the supernatural .	960.05493
nonmagical confucianism was a secular , rational philosophy , but even with this different orientation it could not escape from the ethos of a cosmic government .	338.80823
confucianism had its own magic in the idea that virtue had power .	977.817
if a man lived a classical life , he need not fear the spirits -- for only lack of virtue gave the spirits power over him .	421.43875
but let us not be mistaken about confucian `` virtue ' '	640.32544
this was not virtue as we understand the word today , and it did not mean an abandonment of the belief in magic manipulation .	307.96222
to the confucian , `` virtue ' ' simply meant mastery and correct observance of three hundred major rules of ritual and three thousand minor ones .	1134.9692
propriety was synonymous with ritual observance , the mark of a true gentleman .	601.1237
to live correctly in an interdependent moral and material universe of living and dead was decisive for man ' s fate .	492.1675
this , in brief , was the historical background out of which zen emerged .	436.17142
promoters of zen to the west record its ancestry , and recognize that zen grew out of a combination of taoism and indian mahayana buddhism .	1300.645
but the `` marvelous person ' ' that is supposed to result from zen exhibits more chinese practicality than indian speculation -- he possesses magical powers , and can use them to order nature and to redeem souls .	1205.7369
proponents of zen to the west emphasize disproportionately the amount of mahayana buddhism in zen , probably in order to dignify the indisputably magical taoist ideas with more respectable buddhist metaphysic .	3373.0972
but in the chinese mind , there was little difference between the two -- the bonzes were no more metaphysical than a magician has to be .	408.04672
actually , zen owes more to chinese quietism than it does to mahayana buddhism .	4593.484
the ch ' an ( zen ) sect may have derived its metaphysic from mahayana , but its psychology was pure early taoist .	4321.649
this is well evidenced by the quietist doctrines carried over in zen the idea of the inward turning of thought , the enjoinder to put aside desires and perturbations so that a return to purity , peace , and stillness -- a union with the infinite , with the tao -- could be effected .	914.9729
in fact , the antipathy to outward ceremonies hailed by modern exponents as so uniquely characteristic of the `` direct thinking ' ' zennist was a feature of taoism .	1874.1984
so , too , was the insistence on the relativity of the external world , and the ideas that language and things perceived by consciousness were poor substitutes indeed for immediate perception by pure , indwelling spirit the opposition of pure consciousness to ratiocinating consciousness .	1019.40094
zen maintains that cognitive things are only the surface of experience .	151.11543
one of its features attractive to the west is its irreverence for tradition and dogma and for sacred texts .	1556.9304
one patriarch is supposed to have relegated sacred scriptures for use in an outhouse .	1835.193
but this is not the spirit of self-reliant freedom of action for which the westerner mistakes it .	959.81287
it is simply that in taoist tradition -- as in all good mysticisms -- books , words , or any other manifestations that belong to the normal state of consciousness are considered only the surface of experience .	683.9899
the truth -- the eternal truth -- is not transmittable by words .	1219.0741
reality is considered not only irrelevant to the acquisition of higher knowledge , but a positive handicap .	416.2743
the technique of reality confusion -- the use of paradox and riddles to shake the mind ' s grip on reality -- originated with fourth and third century b . c . chinese quietism the koan is not basically a new device .	858.8123
it is important for an understanding of zen to realize that the esoteric preoccupations of the select few cannot be the doctrine of the common man .	397.03503
in the supernatural atmosphere of cosmic government , only the ruling elite was ever concerned with a kingdom-wide ordering of nature popular religion aimed at more personal benefits from magical powers .	2272.6255
and this is only natural -- witness the haste with which modern man gobbles the latest `` wonder drug ' ' .	793.1981
early chinese anchoritism was theoretically aimed at a mystic pantheist union with the divine , personal salvation being achieved when the mystical recluse united with divine essence .	3636.6675
but this esoteric doctrine was lost in the shuffle to acquire special powers .	364.9968
the anchorite strove , in fact , to magically influence the world of spirits in the same way that the divine emperor manifested his power .	480.13437
thus , the mahayana metaphysic of mystical union for salvation was distilled down to a bare self-seeking , and for this reason , the mystic in asia did not long remain in isolated contemplation .	1574.5833
as the zen literature reveals , as soon as an early zen master attained fame in seclusion , he was called out into the world to exercise his powers .	546.48157
the early anchorite masters attracted disciples because of their presumed ability to perform miracles .	1622.0106
exponents of zen often insist that very early zen doctrine opposed the rampant supernaturalism of china , and proposed instead a more mature , less credulous view of the universe .	1518.7104
in support of this , stories from the early literature are cited to show that zen attacks the idea of supernatural power .	658.4915
but actually these accounts reveal the supernatural powers that the masters were in fact supposed to possess , as well as the extreme degree of popular credulity `` hwang pah ( o baku ) , one day going up mount tien tai which was believed to have been inhabited by arhats with supernatural powers , met with a monk whose eyes emitted strange light .	1439.5972
they went along the pass talking with each other for a short while until they came to a river roaring with torrent .	981.0849
there being no bridge , the master had to stop at the shore	158.36429
but his companion crossed the river walking on the water and beckoned to hwang pah to follow him .	1561.4666
thereupon hwang pah said `` if i knew thou art an arhat , i would have doubled you up before thou got over there ' ' ! !	1768.7516
the monk then understood the spiritual attainment of hwang pah , and praised him as a true mahayanist .	3448.2239
a second tale shows still more clearly the kind of powers a truly spiritual monk could possess `` on one occasion yang shan ( kyo-zan ) saw a stranger monk flying through the air .	1393.7175
when that monk came down and approached him with a respectful salutation , he asked `` where art thou from ' ' ? ?	568.271

in the popular chinese mind , ch ' an ( zen ) was no exception to the ideas of coarse magic that dominated .	666.0649
a closer look at modern zen reveals many magical carryovers that are still part of popular zen attitudes .	2638.2021
to the zen monk the universe is still populated with `` spiritual beings ' ' who have to be appeased .	561.20013

the fruit is allowed to mature on the tree , but it is still firm at this point .	138.7528

here is truly a `` great recording of the century ' ' , and its greatness is by no means diminished by the fact that it is not quite perfect .	201.16814
this recording surely belongs in everyone ' s collection .	132.26054
must records always sound like records ? ?	248.39491
from the beginning of commercial recording , new discs purported to be indistinguishable from the real thing have regularly been put in circulation .	2171.3752
seen in perspective , many of these releases have a genuine claim to be milestones .	793.72296
although lacking absolute verisimilitude , they supply the ear and the imagination with all necessary materials for re-creation of the original .	432.0066
on the basis of what they give us we can know how the young caruso sang , appreciate the distinctive qualities of parsifal under karl muck ' s baton , or sense the type of ensemble toscanini created in his years with the new york philharmonic .	768.2048
since the concept of high fidelity became important some dozen years ago , the claims of technical improvements have multiplied tenfold .	3557.187
in many cases the revolutionary production has offered no more than sensational effects the first hearing was fascinating and the second disillusioning as the gap between sound and substance became clearer .	1260.3375
other innovations with better claims to musical interest survived rehearing to acquire in time the status of classics .	4854.9863
if we return to them today , we have no difficulty spotting their weaknesses but we find them still pleasing .	1021.97614
records sound like records because they provide a different sort of experience than live music .	500.12186
this difference is made up of many factors .	161.63542
some of them are obvious , such as the fact that we associate recorded and live music with our responses and behavior in different types of environments and social settings .	475.00748
( music often sounds best to me when i can dress informally and sit in something more comfortable than a theatre seat .	712.6407
) from the technical standpoint , records differ from live music to the degree that they fail to convey the true color , texture , complexity , range , intensity , pulse , and pitch of the original .	720.68604
any alteration of one of these factors is distortion , although we generally use that word only for effects so pronounced that they can be stated quantitatively on the basis of standard tests .	502.4134
yet it is the accumulation of distortion , the fitting together of fractional bits until the total reaches the threshold of our awareness , that makes records sound like records .	1046.788
the sound may be good	959.74963
but if you know the real thing , you know that what you are hearing is only a clever imitation .	206.50677
command ' s new brahms second is a major effort to make a record that sounds like a real orchestra rather than a copy of one .	575.6722

because of this , only those with truly fine equipment will be able to appreciate the exact degree of the engineers ' triumph .	401.9888
the easiest way to describe this release is to say that it reproduces an interesting and effective steinberg performance with minimal alteration of its musical values .	1208.3551
the engineering as such never obtrudes upon your consciousness .	3890.2683
the effect of the recording is very open and natural , with the frequency emphasis exactly what you would expect from a live performance .	426.17136
this absence of peaky highs and beefed-up bass not only produces greater fidelity , but it eliminates listener fatigue .	5131.1943
a contributing factor is the perspective , the uniform aesthetic distance which is maintained .	395.22342
the orchestra is far enough away from you that you miss the bow scrapes , valve clicks , and other noises incidental to playing .	6083.2886
yet you feel the orchestra is near at hand , and the individual instruments have the same firm presence associated with listening from a good seat in an acoustically perfect hall .	882.29834
command has achieved the ideal amount of reverberation .	4370.8525
the music is always allowed the living space needed to attain its full sonority	2682.7944
yet the hall never intrudes as a quasi-performer .	7908.0273
the timbre remains that of the instruments unclouded by resonance .	1224.2042
all of this would be wasted , of course , if the performance lacked authority and musical distinction .	283.57285
for me it has more of both elements than the majority of its competitors .	238.81038
steinberg seems to have gone directly back to the score , discounting tradition , and has built his performance on the intention to reproduce as faithfully as possible exactly what brahms set down on paper .	902.4392
those accustomed to broader , more romantic statements of the symphony can be expected to react strongly when they hear this one .	299.5792
without losing the distinctive undertow of brahmsian rhythm , the pacing is firm and the over-all performance has a tightly knit quality that makes for maximum cumulative effect .	1583.9194
the presto ma non assai of the first trio of the scherzo is taken literally and may shock you , as the real allegro con spirito of the finale is likely to bring you to your feet .	762.669
in the end , however , the thing about this performance that is most striking is the way it sings .	244.73451
steinberg obviously has concluded that it is the lyric element which must dominate in this score , and he manages at times to create the effect of the whole orchestra bursting into song .	332.80847
the engineering provides exactly the support needed for such a result .	227.62381
too many records seem to reduce a work of symphonic complexity to a melody and its accompaniment .	560.08777
the command technique invites you to listen to the depth of the orchestration .	146.71529
your ear takes you into the ensemble , and you may well become aware of instrumental details which previously were apparent only in the score .	782.70544
it is this sort of experience that makes the concept of high fidelity of real musical significance for the home music listener .	416.78632
the first substantially complete stereo giselle ( and the only one of its scope since feyer ' s four-sided lp edition of 1958 for angel ) , this set is , i ' m afraid , likely to provide more horrid fascination than enjoyment .	885.48175
the already faded pastel charms of the naive music itself vanish entirely in fistoulari ' s melodramatic contrasts between ultravehement brute power and chilly , if suave , sentimentality .	6275.5786
and in its engineers ' frantic attempts to achieve maximum dynamic impact and earsplitting brilliance , the recording sounds as though it had been `` doctored for super-high fidelity ' ' .	1086.8666
the home listener is overpowered , all right , but the experience is a far from pleasant one .	787.23865
as with the penultimate giselle release ( wolff ' s abridgment for rca victor ) i find the cleaner , less razor-edged monophonic version , for all its lack of big-stage spaciousness , the more aurally tolerable -- but this may be the result of processing defects in my sd copies .	2398.371
