the design of a mechanical interlocking frame is much like a mechanical puzzle , but once understood , the principles can be applied to any track and signal arrangement .	587.0823
in the frame are two sets of bars which interact with each other to prevent the operator from making dangerous moves .	831.94745
the main set of bars are the `` tappets ' ' and one tappet is connected to each lever .	240.35974
if the lever is pulled to clear a signal or move a switch , the tappet moves a short distance lengthwise at the same time .	606.5646
close behind the plane of the tappets are the locking bars .	216.71257
these can also move a short distance but at right angles to the tappets .	840.8932
the number of locking bars required depends on how many false moves must be prevented .	1381.5369
in the sides of the tappets are notches with sloping sides , and connection between the tappets and locking bars consist of cams called `` dogs ' ' .	666.57263
two or more dogs are mounted on each locking bar .	723.8086
these slide into and out of the notches in the tappets as the tappets are moved , locking and unlocking them .	683.346
here ' s how the scheme works suppose the operator pulls the lever to clear a particular signal .	1721.6432
this also pulls the tappet connected to the particular lever and forces any dogs seated in the notches to the side , thus moving one or more locking bars .	577.01416
the dogs on the other ends of these locking bars are thus forced into notches in other tappets .	1215.6846
by this scheme , pulling one signal to clear locks all the other switch and signal levers in safe positions until the first signal is again restored to normal .	2095.1628
interlocking signals are normally at stop or `` red ' ' position , and a lever must be pulled to `` clear ' ' the signal .	229.7146
this is not necessarily to green , however , for in some situations only a yellow indication is given to a train to let it into the `` plant ' ' .	276.3528
a turnout may have two levers , one to actually move the switch points , the other to lock the points .	347.59085
a signal cannot be cleared until all the related turnouts are properly thrown and locked .	1858.2384
such locks are nearly always used where the switch points `` face ' ' oncoming traffic .	796.0757
the lock insures that the points are thrown all the way with no chance that a wheel flange will snag on a partly thrown point .	838.38965
if the points aren ' t thrown all the way , the turnout cannot be locked , and in turn , the signal cannot be cleared .	130.65315
generally , these locks on turnouts are called `` facing point locks ' ' .	921.6096
figs . 1-6 show typical arrangements of track and signals .	1177.1392
each diagram is accompanied by a `` dog chart ' ' , a list of the levers that show which other levers any particular lever will lock if pulled .	706.2778
the lines connecting the wedge-shaped dogs represent the locking bars at right angles to the tappet bars .	3105.2979
by studying the track-signal diagrams you ' ll note several other details .	736.11975
derails -- mechanical track devices that actually guide the wheels off the rails if a train passes a `` stop ' ' signal -- are used in many instances .	1148.1115
`` home ' ' signals have two blades .	2277.4944
the blacked-in blades indicate a fixed aspect -- the blade does not move .	366.86295
as an engineer approaches the plant the position of the home signal is seen in advance when he passes the `` distant ' ' signal located beyond the limits of the interlocking plant .	349.76773

scientists say that the world and everything in it are based on mathematics .	347.16895
without math the men who are continually seeking the causes of and the reasons for the many things that make the world go ' round would not have any means of analyzing , standardizing , and communicating the things they discover and learn .	509.17722
math and the formulas that allow it to be applied to different problems are , therefore , essential to any scientific endeavor .	318.7763
it ' s not a science as involved as determining what makes the earth rotate on its axis or building a rocket or putting a satellite into orbit but it is , nevertheless , a science .	759.2651
but because science is based on mathematics doesn ' t mean that a hot rodder must necessarily be a mathematician .	544.9656
a guy can be an active and successful hot rodder for years without becoming even remotely involved with mathematical problems	4613.895
however , he will have a clearer understanding of what he is doing and the chances are he will be more successful if he understands the few formulas that apply to rodding .	364.65164
a mathematical formula is nothing more than a pattern for solving a specific problem .	485.68243
it places the various factors involved in the problem in their correct order in relation to each other so that the influence of factors on each other can be computed .	317.34598
the first step in using a formula is to insert the numerical values of the factors involved in their correct positions in the formula .	328.3084
this changes the formula to an `` equation ' ' .	78.01564
the equation is used for the mathematical process of solving the problem .	174.47348
equations for rodding formulas are not complicated .	423.20364
they involve only simple mathematics that are taught in grammar school arithmetic classes .	2886.316
however , it is essential that the various mathematical symbols used in the equations be understood so that the mathematical processes can be done properly and in their correct order .	543.6982
they indicate simple division , multiplication , subtraction , and addition .	253.60213
the symbol for division is a straight line that separates two numbers placed one above the other .	823.66724
the lower number is always divided into the upper number af	893.1142
the symbol for multiplication is `` **b ' ' .	164.63841
it is used to separate two or more numbers in a row .	335.8931
numbers to be multiplied together may be multiplied in any order .	461.50717
the result will be the same regardless of the order used .	194.69437
the symbol for subtraction is the standard minus sign .	912.2566
this is nothing more than a dash .	257.50772
it separates two or more numbers .	285.52505
the number on the right of the symbol is always subtracted from the number on the left of the symbol .	161.48868
when more than two figures are separated by subtraction symbols the subtraction must be carried out from the left to right if the result is to be correct .	515.73724
for example , for the problem af , 10 from 25 equals 15 , then 6 from 15 equals 9 .	703.9299
addition is indicated by the + symbol .	35328.137
the symbol is used to separate two or more numbers .	284.59775
numbers separated by addition symbols may be placed in any order .	269.34872
when solving an equation that involves division as well as other steps , do all the division steps first to reduce those parts of the equation to their numerical value .	618.1644
multiplication , subtraction , and addition can then be accomplished as they appear in the equation by starting at the left end of the equation and working toward the right .	260.0675
completing the division first also includes those division parts that require multiplication , subtraction , or addition steps af .	1102.7794
this would be reduced by multiplying 8 times 6 and then dividing the product by 12 .	831.14966
this part of the equation would then become 4 .	661.6077
for use in formulas , fractions should be converted to their decimal equivalents .	601.09454
the easiest way to do this is with a conversion chart .	401.14874
charts for this purpose are available from many sources .	263.5598
they are included in all types of mathematical handbooks and they are stamped on some types of precision measuring instruments .	1098.9767
the various mathematical processes can be simplified by carrying the results to only two or three decimal places .	468.4701
shortening the results in this manner will not have any detrimental effect on the accuracy of the final result .	210.8617
some formulas contain `` constants ' ' .	192.32217
a constant is a number that remains the same regardless of the other numbers used in the formula and the resultant equation .	292.64154
it is a number without which the equation cannot be solved correctly .	1510.0437
rodding formulas apply to many phases of the sport .	242.03766
the answers they give can often pave the way to performance increases and , quite often , are necessary for completing entry blanks for different events .	1295.4972
when it is needed , one formula is as important as another .	303.75208
however , some formulas are used more than others .	311.9645
we ' ll take them in the general order of their popularity .	130.6739
a rodder should be able to compute the displacement of his engine .	263.3441
displacement is sometimes referred to as `` swept volume ' ' .	72.89212
most entry blanks for competitive events require engine displacement information because of class restrictions .	3900.5474
it is good to be able to compute displacement so that changes in it resulting from boring and stroking can be computed .	1524.84
factors involved in the displacement formula are the bore diameter of the engine ' s cylinders , the length of the piston stroke , the number of cylinders in the engine , and a constant .	251.52348
the constant is , which is one-quarter of 3 . 1416 , another constant known as `` pi ' ' .	719.89435
pi is used in formulas concerned with the dimensions of circles .	1125.5018
actually , the engine displacement formula is the standard formula for computing the volume of a cylinder of any type with an added factor that represents the number of cylinders in the engine .	414.47232
the cross-sectional area of the cylinders is determined and then the volume of the individual cylinders is computed by multiplying the area by the stroke length , which is the equivalent of the length of the cylinders .	199.839
multiplying the result by the number of cylinders in the engine gives the engine ' s total displacement .	229.98816
dimensions in inches , and fractions of inches will give the displacement in cubic inches .	483.75754
dimensions in centimeters and fractions of centimeters will give the displacement in cubic centimeters ( cc . ) .	409.57483
one inch equals 2 . 54 centimeters one cubic inch equals 16 . 38 cubic centimeters .	4056.1829
for example , let ' s consider a standard 283 cubic inch chevy aj .	6062.9307
these engines have a cylinder diameter of 3-7/8 inches and a stroke length of 3 inches .	1408.9061
the formula , with the fractions converted to decimals , becomes af .	3429.3376
to arrive at the answer , multiply the numbers together by starting at the left of the group and working to the right .	214.9851
the different steps will look like this af	675.5684
a cylinder ' s compression ratio is computed by comparing the cylinder ' s volume , or its displacement , with the total volume of the cylinder and its combustion chamber .	331.99615
cylinder volume can be determined mathematically but combustion chamber volume must be measured with a liquid .	1425.7028
cylinder volume is determined in exactly the same manner as for the displacement formula af .	445.32272
to measure the volume of one of the combustion chambers in the cylinder head , install the valves and spark plug in the chamber and support the head so that its gasket surface is level .	537.7289
then pour water or light oil from a graduated beaker into the chamber to fill the chamber to its gasket surface .	1196.0201
this is possible with water and other liquids that have a high surface tension .	537.4559
such liquids will rise to a considerable height above the surface around the chamber before they will flow out of the chamber .	282.31607
the amount of liquid poured into the chamber is determined by subtracting the quantity still in the beaker when the chamber is full from the original quantity .	547.8783
most beakers are graduated in cubic centimeters ( cc . ) , making it necessary to convert the result to cubic inches .	511.91284
however , the displacement of the cylinder can be converted to cubic centimeters .	300.80145
the compression ratio arrived at with the formula will be the same regardless of whether cubic inches or cubic centimeters are used .	617.6706
the only precaution is that all volumes used in the formula be quoted in the same terms .	259.88638
the volume of the cylinder opening in the head gasket must be computed by multiplying its area in square inches by the gasket ' s thickness in thousandths of an inch .	921.448
sometimes it is necessary to roughly calculate the square inch area of the opening but the calculation can usually be made with sufficient accuracy that it won ' t affect the final computation .	518.38226
the volume of the opening is added to the combustion chamber volume .	947.6306
another thing that must be taken into consideration is the volume of the area between the top of the piston and the top of the cylinder block when the piston is in top dead center position .	231.30486
compute this volume by measuring the distance from the top of the block to the piston head as accurately as possible with a depth micrometer or some other precision measuring device and then multiply the area of the cylinder by the depth .	571.79614
the formula for this step is af .	228.25421
this volume is added to the total volume of the combustion chamber and head gasket opening .	426.31934
the total of these three volumes is the `` final combustion chamber volume ' ' .	395.11676
after the factors just described have been computed , they are applied to the following formula af	416.4353
for an example let ' s dream up an engine that has a final combustion chamber volume of 5 cubic inches and a cylinder volume of 45 cubic inches .	540.22156
applying these figures to the formula we get the equation af .	286.43134
the compression ratio is 10 to 1 .	190.6949
this method of computing compression ratio cannot be used accurately for engines that have pistons with either domed or irregularly shaped heads .	5617.0938
any irregularity on the piston heads will make it impossible , with normal means , to determine the final combustion chamber volume because the volume displaced by the piston heads cannot be readily computed .	1034.9069
the only way to determine the final combustion chamber volume when such pistons are used is by measuring it with liquid while the cylinder head is bolted to the cylinder block and the piston is in top dead center position .	989.2149
there are four versions of the formula that involves the relationships of car speed , engine speed , rear axle gear ratio , and rear tire size .	1104.8005
by using the appropriate version any one of these factors can be determined for any combination of the other three .	313.92545
to simplify the formulas a representative symbol is substituted for each of the factors .	321.39236
tire size can be determined in several ways but the one that is the easiest and as accurate as any is by measuring the effective radius of a wheel and tire assembly .	494.43036
this is done by measuring the distance from the surface on which the tire is resting to the center of the rear axle shaft .	377.8185
a tire must be inflated to its normal hot operating pressure and the car must be loaded to its operating weight when this measurement is made .	639.8374
the measurement must be in inches .	675.0001
any fraction of an inch involved in the measurement must be converted to a decimal equivalent to simplify the mathematics .	595.5335
when tire size is measured in this manner a constant of 168 is used in the formula .	358.2776
to determine car speed for a given combination of engine speed , gear ratio , and tire size , the formula is af .	386.11835
for an engine speed of 5000 rpm , a gear ratio of 4 . 00 to 1 , and a tire radius of 13 inches , the equation would look like this af	437.61533
to determine engine speed for a given combination of the other three factors the formula is af .	277.8895
using the same figures as for the previous example , the equation becomes af	303.17456
to determine the rear axle gear ratio for a combination of the other three factors , the formula is af .	362.90192
using the figures from the previous examples , the equation becomes af .	299.23267

bill ruger ' s long-awaited deerstalker ( under $110 ) is a new rifle action in a caliber that upsets all the modern theory of high-velocity fans	1556.0681
it ' s a short , light , quick-handling , fast-firing little timber gun designed to push a heavy slug at modest velocity but with lots of killing power and ample range for our most popular big game -- whitetail .	2465.0598
ruger reports that on his recent african safari the little magnum cartridge was a real work horse .	1790.703

these are fairly large , tough animals .	780.55164

at least five years ago , tom robinson of marlin made up an over/under double rifle for me in this caliber , using the now defunct model 90 action in 20-gauge size .	1698.0145
after figuring out how to regulate the barrels so that they shot to the same point of impact , we fired this little 20-inch-barrel job on my home range and in marlin ' s underground test gallery .	1829.5853
we quickly ran into the same trouble that plagued bill ruger in his first experiments three or four bullets would be placed well in a six-inch bull at 100 yards and then , unaccountably , one could stray far out of the group .	938.2805
ruger learned that this was because the higher velocity achieved in a long barrel was upsetting the shape of the unjacketed revolver bullet .	2551.494
the new , jacketed slug in magnum corrected this .	6475.4355
but even without jacketed bullets , i had enough faith in my double to take it on an opening-day deer hunt that first year .	998.15356

he moved only about 30 feet after the 240-grain slug hit him -- and this was after the bullet had passed through a sapling .	1065.1013
three more deer have fallen to this same gun , and all were one-shot kills .	815.81177

livery stable -- j . vernon , prop . ' ' .	113.73449
coaching had declined considerably by 1905 , but the sign was still there , near the old wells fargo building in san francisco , creaking in the fog as it had for thirty years .	600.4525
john vernon had had all the patronage he cared for -- he had prospered , but he could not retire from horsedom .	659.62634
he had two interests in life the pleasures of the table and driving .	193.09497
twice a week he drove his tallyho over the santa cruz road , upland and through the redwood forest , with orchards below him at one hand , and glimpses of the pacific at the other .	987.20984
the journey back he made along the coast road , traveling hell-for-leather , every lantern of the tallyho ablaze .	1307.792
the southward route was the classic run in california , and the most fashionable .	306.17047
his patronage on this stretch was made up largely of san franciscans -- regulars , most of them , and trenchermen like himself .	1151.2812
they did not complain at the inhuman hour of starting ( seven in the morning ) , nor of the tariff , which was reasonable since it covered everything but the tobacco .	527.07837
breakfast was at the palace hotel , luncheon was somewhere in the mountain forest , and dinner was either at boulder creek or at santa cruz .	1846.6301
gazing too long at the scenery could be tiring , so halts were contrived between meals .	2419.1719
then the chinese hostler , who rode with vernon on the box , would break open a hamper and produce filets of smoked bass or sturgeon , sandwiches , pickled eggs , and a rum sangaree to be heated over a spirit lamp .	2036.6146
in spring and in autumn the run was made for a group of botanists which included an old friend of mine .	501.75455
they gathered roots , bulbs , odd ferns , leaves , and bits of resin from the rare santa lucia fir , which exists only on a forty-five mile strip on the westerly side of these mountains .	1198.4509
in the spanish days franciscan monks roamed here to collect the resin for incense .	12019.163
it yields a fragrance as orphic as that of the pastilles of malabar .	3460.3467
vernon was serviceable on the botanical field trips , but he could arrange no schedule with the cooks , and he was glad when the trips dropped off , and the botanists began to motor out by themselves .	886.7603
my friend often breakfasted with vernon on the morning of the regular tallyho run .	340.2595
this was an honor , like dining with a captain at his private table .	548.8151

( gastronomes have long argued about which came first , the palace ' s or antoine ' s .	310.54178

here is an original kedgeree recipe from the family club ' s kitchen	1054.2277
flake ( for three ) a cupful of cold boiled haddock , mix with a cupful of cooked rice , two minced hard-boiled eggs , some buttery white sauce done with cream , cayenne , pepper , salt , a pinch of curry , a tablespoonful of minced onion fried , and a bit of anchovy .	2635.02
heat and serve hot on toast .	3020.59
the omelet named for ernest arbogast , the palace ' s chef , was even more in demand .	302.33826

built upon seven hills , istanbul , like rome , is one of the most ancient cities in the world , filled with splendor and contrast .	288.27466

at the moment , many of these are being pulled down .	306.65002

for almost 3 , 000 years europe and asia have rubbed shoulders in its streets .	981.28516
founded in the ninth century b . c . it was called byzantium 200 years later when byzas , ruler of the megarians , expanded the settlement and named it after himself .	1088.216
about a thousand years after that , when the roman empire was divided , it became capital of the eastern section .	249.72623
on may 11 , 330 , a . d . , , its name was changed again , this time to constantinople after its emperor , constantine .	532.08746
in 1453 when the last vestige of ancient roman power fell to the turks , the city officially shifted religions -- although the patriarch , or pope , of the orthodox church continued to live there , and still does -- and became the capital of the ottoman empire .	755.7166
when that was broken up after the first world war , its name was changed once more .	423.17093

( do start fires one or two hours ahead of time to obtain a lasting bed of glowing coals .	754.99194
keep ashes from one barbecue to the next to sprinkle over coals if they are too hot , and to stop flames that arise from melting grease .	1069.5011
do line barbecue fire bowl with heavy foil to reflect heat .	1069.5587
don ' t forget to buy a plastic pastry brush for basting with sauces .	706.589
clean it meticulously in boiling water and detergent , rinse thoroughly .	5163.9526
do build a wall of glowing coals six to eight inches in front of meat that is barbecued on an electric spit .	1552.6356
make use of the back of the barbecue or of the hood for heating vegetables , sauces and such .	427.36935
don ' t fail to shorten cooking time by the use of aluminum foil cut slightly larger than the surface of steaks and chops .	1200.1077
sear on both sides then cover meat loosely with heat reflecting foil for juiciest results .	7472.824
do avoid puncturing or cutting into meats to test them .	1709.7245
if doubtful about a steak , boldly cut it in half .	807.99414
if necessary to replace both halves on grill , sear cuts and allot extra time .	5850.158

all framing in hotei is one-inch mahogany which , in the dressed state you buy it , is about the 13/16-inch thickness specified in the drawings .	785.03674
therefore , the lumber is bought in planks and ripped to size for battens , etc . , on a table saw .	599.54443
besides flathead bronze screws , silicon bronze stronghold nails ( made by independent nail & packing co . , bridgewater , mass . ) are used extensively in assembly and weldwood resorcinol glue is used in all the joints .	2463.6907
construction follows a thorough study of the drawings .	97.69618
start by laying out the six frames and the transom on a level floor .	319.7276
draw each outline in a different-color chalk , one on top of the other .	578.37024
in this way you will be able to detect any obvious mistakes .	233.04898
the transom frame is made first with the joints lapped , glued and fastened with one-inch , no . 12 stronghold nails .	1642.8788
after notching it for the keelson , chines and battens , the half-inch plywood transom is secured to it with glue and the same type nails .	1049.5164
all frames are butted at the joints and 3/8-inch plywood gussets are glued and nailed on each side of each joint , again using the one-inch , no . 12 nails .	1092.8083
the frames are notched only for the keelson and the chines .	440.7783
if notched for the battens , they would require more work , be weakened and limber holes would have to be bored so that bilge water could flow through .	1649.0911
nowhere in the boat do the frames come in contact with the plywood planking .	540.5599
the jig is erected after the frames and transom are complete .	333.3423
this is an important step because any misalignment would cause progressively worse misalignment in the hull as you advance in construction .	3784.548
be sure all members are parallel , vertical and level as required .	1524.7345
after the frames and transom are set up on the jig and temporarily braced , a piece of three-inch-wide mahogany ( only widths will be given since the 13/16-inch thickness is used throughout ) is butted between frames one and two below the line of the keelson .	1044.6388
the frames are glued and screwed to this piece .	208.90096

it is over this piece that the laminated stem and keelson are spliced .	2868.2073
the keelson , made of two three-inch widths , is next installed .	1643.6829

note , however , that it is six inches shorter at the forward end .	361.14322

a stem jig is next cut to the proper shape and temporarily fastened to frame one .	743.35956
the stem is laminated from four pieces .	367.01447
take two three-inch-wide pieces and rip them down the center of the thickness to make the four .	257.3905
then spread a generous amount of glue on the four pieces and bend them into place on the jig .	359.48816

all bottom battens are two inches wide .	1508.5453
the side ones are a half-inch narrower .	3720.7292
the battens are carefully fastened in place after some necessary fairing on all frames .	923.61005

fairing is always a tedious job but the work can be cut down considerably with a skill planer and a simple jig .	848.1077
i clamped a 30-inch piece of aluminum to the base of the planer with a pair of sure grips .	436.35822
the aluminum , flush against the battens , acted as a fairing stick and enabled me to plane the chines and keelson to the proper bevels easily .	2192.6985
if you don ' t own a planer and don ' t want to buy one , it ' s well worth renting .	229.85135
the planking is five-ply , 3/8-inch-thick weldwood royal marine plywood .	19416.963
this can be obtained in 42-inch widths 24 feet long .	5509.795
the 42-inch width leaves very little waste .	753.1711
plank the sides first , using glue and one-inch , no . 12 stronghold nails at all battens , the stem and the transom .	522.67645
another person inside with a weight against each batten will help in the fastening .	1081.6514
the best procedure is to have a few friends hold the planking in place while you mark it off .	1032.4075
i used a homemaster routo-jig made by porter cable for this job .	2014.4113
it ' s good for cutting all the planking because it cuts with a bit-like blade at high rpm and does not chatter the plywood like a saber saw .	2393.3967
when cut , the planking is clamped in place for a final and careful trimming .	1624.3481
then it is marked on the inside where it comes in contact with the transom , frames , keelson and all the battens .	355.14584
it may then be pre-drilled for the fastenings .	4832.711
the next step is to remove it and spread glue where it has been marked at the contact points .	374.39597
then it is replaced and fastened .	341.98108
the bottom planking is applied in the same manner .	124.18135
after planking , the bottom gets a layer of fiberglas .	1178.2555
the spray rails are first glued on the outside and fastened from the inside with screws .	460.14566
then the chines are rounded off and the bottom is rough-sanded in preparation .	1045.5219
since the sides are also covered up to the spray rails , they are also rough-sanded in that area .	604.7068
the cloth is laid on one half of the bottom at a time .	84.61502
a 50-inch width is used on each side and it laps the keel line by about three inches .	568.6977
lay the cloth in place and trim it to size .	445.57272
then remove it and give the whole bottom a coat of resin .	965.4197
when the resin has hardened , mix up another batch with a pigment added if you wish .	2061.5732
i used bright red , mixing the pigment in thoroughly before adding the hardener .	3893.256
using a cheap brush , coat one side of the bottom with the resin and then apply the cloth .	429.73816
when the cloth is smooth , apply another coat of resin , spreading it with a paint roller .	1784.2587
be sure it is well saturated and then allow it to harden .	2651.9373
when the whole bottom has hardened , use a disk sander to feather the edges of the cloth at the keel line and near the spray rail .	1302.0481
then lay a three-inch-wide strip of cloth along the keel line from the transom to the point of the stem .	311.46375
before the resin has hardened , screw a one-inch mahogany keel strip along the centerline .	8425.465
this protects the bottom in beaching .	2674.459
fiberglas materials are available from glass plastic supply co . , 1605 w . elizabeth ave . , linden , n . j . .	479.70346
they will also supply literature on application .	459.37442
the hull is now turned over ( with the help of about seven friends ) and placed in a level , well-braced position .	447.36996
i set it on the gator trailer .	3259.7817
i laid three layers of glass cloth on the inside of the stem , also installing a bow eye at this time .	355.5776

this is made up of scraps left over from the sides and bottom .	702.8861

with modern techniques of woodworking and the multitude of cutting tools , fixtures , and attachments available , the drill press has become a basic home workshop tool .	1295.071
the drill press consists of a vertical shaft ( spindle ) which is tapered or threaded on one end to hold a drill chuck , a tubular housing ( quill ) in which the spindle is mounted , a head in which the quill is mounted , a feed lever which moves the quill up or down , a power source , and a movable table upon which the work is placed .	572.93207
there is often a means of locking the quill and , on larger presses , the table can be tilted .	519.35925
the size of the press is usually expressed in terms of chuck capacity ( the maximum diameter tool shank it will hold ) or distance between the spindle center and the column .	1299.8564
a press with an 11 inch capacity lets you drill to the center of a 22 inch board or circle .	993.709
a new radial drill press with a 16 inch capacity has a tilting head that allows drilling to be done at any angle .	1763.9464
the head is mounted on a horizontal arm that swivels on the supporting column to position the drill bit instead of the work .	755.91486
the drill press should be leveled and , depending on whether it is a bench or floor model , bolted securely to a sturdy bench or stand or screwed to the floor with lag or expansion screws .	1134.8146
this will reduce vibration and increase accuracy .	324.1448
a coat of paste wax or a rubdown with a piece of wax paper will protect the polished surface of the table	1011.2278
wiping with a slightly oiled cloth will discourage rusting of the column and quill .	4304.205
presses not fitted with sealed spindle bearings will need a drop of oil now and then in the lubrication holes in the quill .	1308.9419
the rest of the press should be kept clean by dusting with a clean rag or brush .	1314.6641
be careful to keep the drive belt free of oil and grease .	1307.8325
belt tension is adjusted by manipulation of two locking bolts and a movable motor mount .	2419.7432
keep the belt just tight enough so the pulleys won ' t slip when pulled by hand	2371.017
excess tension will only cause undue wear on the motor and spindle bearings .	1370.3556
most drill presses have a quill return spring that raises the spindle automatically when the feed lever is released and holds the quill in the raised position .	1170.6873
the return spring tension may be adjusted to suit individual requirements by gripping the spring housing with a pair of pliers ( to prevent the spring from unwinding when it is released ) , loosening the lock nut or screw , and rotating the housing until the desired tension is achieved .	1224.93
turning the housing clockwise will reduce tension , counter-clockwise will increase it .	1291.2855
some manufacturers have had the foresight to provide a socket for the chuck key	724.47644
otherwise , you ' ll have to spend a few minutes to either attach a suitable spring clip somewhere on the press head or fit the key to a length of light chain and fasten to the bottom of the motor mount so that the key is out of the way when not in use .	428.6341
drill speeds are important if you want a good job .	166.01144
each cutting tool will operate best at a given speed , depending on the material worked .	358.2547
on most drill presses , it is impossible to get the exact speed , but you can come close by adjusting the drive belt on the step-cone pulleys .	378.311
you will find a chart giving the various speed ratios available with your particular drill press somewhere in the instruction booklet that came with the tool .	1715.1438
see the table on page 34 for exact recommended speeds .	2720.8809
generally , the larger the tool and the harder the material , the slower the speed .	215.8047
feed pressure is also of major importance .	246.7501
too much pressure will force the tool beyond its cutting capacity and result in rough cuts and jammed or broken tools .	1127.1555
too light a feed , particularly with metal or other hard material , causes overheating of the tool and burning of the cutting edge .	722.28986
the best results will be obtained by matching the correct speed with a steady feed pressure that lets the tool cut easily at an even rate .	760.95447
there are numerous types and styles of tools to drill holes .	992.9166
the most common are the twist drill , the solid center shaft with interchangeable cutting blades , the double spur bit , and the power wood bit .	1283.9215
all will do a good job if sharp , but the twist drills don ' t cut quite as smoothly as the others , since they do not have the outlining spurs that sever the fibers before actual boring starts .	984.1778
the adjustable fly cutter is very useful for cutting large diameter holes and can be used to cut exact-size discs by reversing the cutter blade .	2277.742
since fly cutters are one sided and not balanced , they should be used at the slowest speed available , and fed very slowly to avoid binding .	736.995
fly cutters can fool you into putting your hand too close to the tool , so if you want to avoid nicked fingers , keep your hands well out of the way .	831.8086
when drilling all the way through a workpiece , always place a piece of scrap wood underneath .	2289.619
this will not only protect the work table , but also assure a clean breakthrough .	771.13055
another method of assuring a clean hole is to first drill a small pilot hole all the way through , then drill half way with the dimensional bit , turn the piece over , and finish from the other side .	566.5194
in soft woods with pronounced grain , there is sometimes a tendency for the hole to wander , due to the varying hardness of the wood .	528.028
in this case , drilling a small pilot hole or clamping the work will do much to improve accuracy .	1746.7201
when a hole is to be bored to a predetermined depth , mark the depth on the side of the stock , then run the bit down so that it is even with the mark .	256.52948
the depth gauge rod can now be set , and any number of holes bored to exact and identical depth .	1054.3724
the old-time bridges over the merrimac river in massachusetts are of unusual interest in many respects .	700.67786
for their length , their types of construction , their picturesque settings , and their literary associations , they should be known and remembered .	298.77457
in this sequence i shall write about them in the order of their erection .	198.2205
the first bridge known to have been covered wholly or in part , -- and perhaps the most interesting one , connected newbury ( now newburyport ) with salisbury point .	656.7627
its building was first proposed in 1791 , when a group of citizens , mostly newburyport men , petitioned the general court for an act of incorporation .	668.1523
this document began `` no . 1 newbury port , may 30th , 1791	4174.365
`` whereas , a bridge over merrimack river , from the land of hon ' ble jonathan greenleaf , esquire , in newbery , to deer island , and from said island to salisbury , would be of very extensive utility , by affording a safe conveyance to carriages , teams and travellers at all seasons of the year , and at all times of tide .	1679.8131
`` we , the subscribers , do agree , that as soon as a convenient number of persons have subscribed to this , or a similar writing , we will present a petition to the hon ' ble general court of the commonwealth of massachusetts , praying for an act incorporating into a body politic the subscribers to such writing with liberty to build such a bridge , and a right to demand a toll equal to that received at malden bridge , and on like terms , and if such an act shall be obtained , then we severally agree each with the others , that we will hold in the said bridge the several shares set against our respective names , the whole into two hundred shares being divided , and that we will pay such sums of money at such times and in such manners , as by the said proposed corporation , shall be directed and required ' ' .	459.11996
this paper was signed by forty-five persons , subscribing a total of two hundred shares .	644.41156
a month later the general court served notice to the town of newbury that the bridge was to be built .	578.4822
the matter was considered and reconsidered , and finally opposed , but in spite of many objections , the court granted a charter on january 9 , 1792 .	407.77283
on november 26 of that year the bridge was completed and opened .	360.33322
timothy palmer , who invented and later patented the arch type of construction for wooden bridges , was the genius who planned and supervised the building of the essex , or `` deer island ' ' bridge although the actual work was carried out under the direction of william coombs , who received $300 as recompense .	723.6761
this two-part bridge is best described by rev . timothy dwight , president of yale college , in his `` travels in new-england and new-york ' ' , published in new haven in 1821 .	674.79865
`` it consists of two divisions , separated by an island at a small distance from the southern shore .	498.52924
the division between the island and this shore , consists principally of an arch	1932.4991
whose chord is one hundred and sixty feet , and whose vortex is forty feet ( it was actually 37 feet ) above the high-water mark .	2483.201
in appearance and construction it resembles the pascataqua bridge .	5098.6626
the whole length of essex bridge is one thousand and thirty feet and its breadth thirty-four .	2853.9492
i have already mentioned that mr . timothy palmer of newburyport was the inventor of the arched bridges in this country .	307.18915
as mr . palmer was educated to house-building only , and had never seen a structure of this nature	479.57816
he certainly deserves not a little credit for the invention ' ' .	82.307434
it is hardly necessary to remind students of covered bridges that timothy palmer was born in 1751 in nearby rowley	5240.3027
that he moved with his parents to west boxford when he was sixteen years old	1110.4741
and was there apprenticed to a builder and architect , moody spofford .	1206.2867
it was indeed a remarkable feat that a man who had had no experience of bridge building should have applied the principle of the arch , which appears in his famous bridges at portsmouth , haverhill , and philadelphia .	399.739
the essex merrimack bridge when first built was not covered .	457.1423
as far as we know , no american bridge had been thus protected in 1792 .	596.80853
richard s . allen is the authority for the statement that the northern section was probably roofed by 1810 .	736.0815
its original appearance is shown in an engraving published in the `` massachusetts magazine ' ' in may 1793 , which is reproduced herewith ( fig . 1 ) .	602.38605
a brief description accompanying the picture says that the bridge contained more than 6000 tons of timber .	979.0777
between the abutments on the newbury shore and the south bank of deer island there was one span or arch measuring 160 feet	2382.9587
between the north shore of deer island and the salisbury side there was an arch of 113 feet and a series of piers with a draw forty feet long .	790.95996
a dinner and celebration in honor of this piece of engineering took place july 4 , 1793 , in a tavern erected by the corporation on the island .	367.6296
it is said that the eccentric timothy dexter , who was one of the first share-holders , stood on the table and made a speech worthy of the occasion .	573.07635
the `` essex journal ' ' says that he `` delivered an oration on the bridge , which for elegance of style , propriety of speech or force of argument , was truly ciceronian ' ' .	461.37735
the reporter must have written this with tongue in cheek , because dexter ' s oration could hardly be understood	2067.0818
and , although he later explained that he was talking french , it seems rather more likely that he had succumbed to the joys of the evening .	356.6234
the north portion of the essex bridge was well worth the cost of construction , although it proved to be twice what was estimated in the beginning .	243.81248
it stood in its original form until 1882 .	7589.3096
the southern half , however , on account of its underbracing , was considered by boat owners a menace to navigation .	967.30615
in 1810 it was torn down and replaced by a chain suspension bridge .	984.7031
this was built by john templeman from plans submitted by james finley of fayette county , pennsylvania .	2636.3535
timothy palmer had general supervision of the work .	93.29341
an advertisement in the `` newburyport herald ' ' , december 21 , 1810 , shows palmer in a new light as an expert on chain bridges .	790.9641
information is hereby given that mr . timothy palmer of newburyport , mass . has agreed to take charge of the concerns of the patentees of the chain bridge , in the states of massachusetts , new hampshire , vermont , rhode island , and connecticut , so far as relates to the sale of patent rights and the construction of chain bridges .	265.43875
`` mr . palmer will attend to any applications relating to bridges and if desired will view the proposed site , and lay out and superintend the work , or recommend a suitable person to execute it .	815.61523
this chain bridge proved less durable than the wooden arch on the salisbury end .	589.7059
it fell , february 6 , 1827 , carrying with it a horse and wagon , two men and four oxen .	635.90857
the horse and men were saved , but the oxen drowned .	1021.1719
in spite of this catastrophe , the bridge was rebuilt on the same plan and opened again on july 17 , 1827 .	593.5023
this second chain bridge was 570 feet long , had two thirty-foot towers and a draw , and a double roadway .	2061.1367
the essex bridge was a toll crossing until 1868 , when the county commissioners laid out all the merrimack bridges as highways .	1747.9349
sturdy and strong after more than a century of continuous use , the old covered , wooden bridge that spans the tygartis valley river at philippi will have a distinctive part in the week-long observance of the first land battle of the civil war at its home site , may 28th to june 3rd .	787.7922
colonel frederick w . lander , impersonated , will again make his break-neck ride down the steep declivity of talbott ' s ( now college ) hill and thunder across the bridge to join colonel benjamin f . kelley ' s ( west ) virginia infantry , then swarming through the streets in pursuit of the retreating confederates .	2650.8892
he was closely followed by the ohio and indiana troops -- thus the old bridge has another distinction	879.7999
that of being the first such structure secured by force of arms in the war of the ' 60s .	584.20874
the bridge has survived the natural hazards of the elements , war , fire , and floods , as well as injuries incident to heavy traffic , for more than a hundred years .	392.52774
twice during the civil war it was saved from destruction by the opposing armies by the pleas and prayers of a local minister .	434.17065
it still stands as a monument to the engineering skills of the last century and still serves in the gasoline age to carry heavy traffic on u . s . route 250 -- the old beverly and fairmont turnpike .	592.5474
it is one of the very few , if not the only surviving bridge of its type to serve a main artery of the u . s . highway system , thus it is far more than a relic of the horse and buggy days .	197.07288
this covered , wooden bridge is so closely identified with the first action in the early morning of june 3 , 1861 , and with subsequent troop movements of both armies in the philippi area that it has become a part and parcel of the war story .	392.57394
so frequently have pictures of the bridge appeared in books and in national publications that it vies with the old john brown fort at harpers ferry as the two nationally best known structures in west virginia .	1181.9238
completed and opened for traffic in 1852 , the bridge was designed and built by lemuel chenoweth and his brother , eli , of beverly .	1373.6902
the chenoweth brothers were experienced bridge builders , and against the competition of other , and better known , bridge designers and builders they had constructed nine of the covered , wooden bridges on the parkersburg and staunton turnpike a dozen years before , as well as many other bridges for several counties .	986.52234
the philippi bridge , however , was the chenoweth master piece , with its 139-foot , dual lane , span -- and it stands today as a monument to its builders .	833.9822
never rebuilt , the bridge was strengtened in 1938 by two extra piers , a concrete floor , and a walk-way along the upper side in order to care for modern traffic .	825.3798
during the war it was in constant use by the wagon trains transporting supplies from the railhead at grafton to the troops operating in the interior .	1384.2727
union soldiers at times used it for sleeping quarters to escape from the rain or other inclement weather , and some of them left momentoes of their stay by carving their names and small tokens on its walls and beams .	1448.5514
but what the elements could not do was seriously threatened when brigadier general william e . ( grumble ) jones reached philippi while on the famous jones-imboden raid in may , 1863 .	1959.9414
general jones was fresh from a long series of bridge burnings , including the long bridge at fairmont , and , after seeing a great drove of horses and cattle he had collected safely across the bridge , he sent his men to work piling combustibles in and around it .	839.577
reverend joshual corder , a baptist minister , gathered a few citizens of southern sympathies , to call on jones and plead with him to spare the structure	752.3742

it is a good eight years now since each of us acquired a swimming pool -- eight enlightening , vigorous , rigorous , not wholly unrewarding years .	2581.895
we have learned a lot -- a dash of hydrochemistry here , a bit about plumbing and pump-priming there .	1909.687
we have had sound grounding in the principles of the mailed-fist-in-velvet-glove school of diplomacy .	1296.7593

position may not be everything , but in the case of a pool it can certainly contribute difficulties , social and/or physical .	368.58344
one of us has a pool set in a wooded area very near the house .	478.9289
the other has his pool far away from the house in a field high on a hill .	289.2847

you are likely to be nearer the truth .	141.3961

on the other hand , out-of-sight does not lead to out-of-mind when children cannot be easily observed and you have to make a long trek to reach the pool .	792.69904
another dilemma as picturesque as a sylvan pond in the forest may be , trees offer a leaf and root hazard to the well-being of a pool .	564.80316

eight years ago while we were going through the mud-sweat-and-tears construction period , we were each solaced by the vision of early morning dips and evening home-comings to a cool family collected around the pool with a buffet table laid out nearby for the lord and master ' s delectation .	1290.0103

our respective families looked as if they had quadrupled .	534.1936

from proud pool-owners to perpetual hosts and handymen was a short step -- no more than the change from city clothes to trunks .	1612.2115
naive of us , maybe , but the results of our impulsive invitations to `` come over next summer and swim in our new pool ' ' were both unexpected and unsettling .	712.2809

since our viewpoints in this respect coincided precisely , we present the fruits of our efforts herewith as a single social code for pool owners .	1997.2745
first and foremost no one -- no , not anyone -- in the family is allowed to issue blanket invitations to his or her own circle .	547.19476
just short of forty lashes we finally managed to coerce our children to this view .	1687.7023

draw a line across the country at the latitude of lower pennsylvania .	282.6147

a relatively simple switching arrangement reverses the cycle so that the machine literally runs backward , and the heat is extracted from outdoor air and turned indoors .	1426.0652

a very rough rule of thumb is that , under favorable conditions , you ' ll need 15 btu ' s of cooling for every square foot of your house .	478.20233
this is if outdoor temperatures have a high average of 95 degrees .	1401.639
you ' ll need more if the high average is above that , less if it ' s below .	197.11714
coolers are also rated by tons .	480.9568
a ton of cooling compares to the cooling you get by melting a ton of ice .	1028.7454
by accepted definition , a 1-ton conditioner will provide 12 , 000 btu of cooling in one hour .	800.5774
