a stream or pond which is attractive in the springtime may become stagnant or dry in late summer .	716.6635
if the site is on a reservoir , the level of the water at various seasons as it affects recreation should be studied .	304.9399
check the quality of the water .	42.36142
a stream which has all of its watershed within a national forest or other lands under good conservation practices is less likely to be affected by pollution than one passing through unrestricted logging or past an industrial area .	1269.9458
other factors , such as water temperature , depth of water , the fish life it supports , wave action , flooding , etcetera , will affect its recreation value .	862.3738
other natural features which can be of high interest are the forests , canyons , mountains , deserts , seacoast , beaches , sand dunes , waterfalls , springs , etcetera with which the area is blessed .	893.262
just as the national and state parks place emphasis on features which are of national or state significance , counties should seek out these features which are distinctive of their area .	746.2526
although the site may not contain the features themselves , there are often opportunities to include them as additional interest to the site .	249.91968
the route to the park may lead people past them or display views of them .	727.5131
a group of native trees or plants which are outstanding in a particular county can be featured at the site .	354.98807
the fish , animals , and birds which may be found at the site are another interest .	138.27185
fishing interest calls for a check of the species found , quantity and size , the season they are available , and the stocking program of the fish commission .	363.68546
animals may be present at the site or provide hunting in nearby areas .	481.83804
the site may be on one of the major flyways of migratory birds or have its own resident bird life .	1515.281
clams , crabs , and other marine life may add interest at coastal areas .	840.2038
each area has its own historical interests with which much can be done .	392.40814
park visitors are always eager to learn more about the area they are in .	263.2252
the historical sign tells its story , but nothing gets interest across as well as some of the original historical items or places themselves which still have the character of the period covered .	493.39456
notice should be taken of unusual rock formations , deposits , or shapes of the earth ' s crust in your region .	720.1144
those which tell a story of the earth ' s formation in each area can add geological interest to the recreation sites .	337.52417
an old shipwreck , a high dam , an old covered bridge , a place to find agates or other semi-precious stones or a place to pan gold , etcetera may be of interest .	1038.313
some areas may provide archeological values such as ancient indian village sites or hunting areas , caves , artifacts , etcetera .	2104.7146
how well can the site be developed ? ?	422.11127
look at the physical features of the land to determine how desirable it is for use , what can be done to correct the faults , and what it will cost to make the area meet your needs in comparison to other sites .	270.33163
many things need to be checked	332.79007
-- the size of the area alone can be a determining factor .	273.24234
an area may be too small for the needs of the project .	103.94513
areas should be large enough to include the attractions , have ample space for the use of facilities needed , and have room around the edges to protect the values of the area from encroachment by private developments .	427.40826
acreage in excess of the minimum is good practice as recreation areas are never too large for the future and it is often more economical to operate one large area than several small ones .	473.15448
shape of the area is also related to the use attractions and needs of the development .	336.7477
a large picnic area or camping development is most efficient in shape as a square or rectangle several hundred feet in width in preference to a long narrow area less than one hundred feet wide .	1225.6505
this is true because of savings in utility lines and the fact that your buildings have a useful radius equal in all directions .	1200.822
however , a narrow strip may be very practical for small developments , or to provide additional stream frontage for a fisherman ' s trail , or include scenic strips within the park unit .	650.3492
-- the values of the site may be affected by the appearance of the adjoining lands , ownership and use of the land , and the utilities available there .	216.49889
for instance , a site adjoining other publicly owned lands , such as a national forest or a public road , may be desirable , whereas a site next to an industrial plant might not .	868.32227
the utilities available nearby may provide a savings in the cost of extending electricity or water to the site .	342.20474
check the elevation of the ground , degree and direction of slopes , drainage , rock outcrops , topsoil types and quality , as well as subsoil .	1532.8744
nearly level areas are required for parking areas , beaches , camp areas , ballfields , etcetera .	1047.7817
determine how much topography limits useful area or what the costs of earth moving or grading might be .	1159.6133
-- in addition to its recreation interests , water is needed for drinking , sanitation , and irrigation .	793.8092
the quantity and quality of water sources is often a big factor in site selection .	750.2315
the area may provide good springs or opportunities for a well or be near to municipal water lines .	995.4751
figure the cost of providing water to the use areas .	297.42023
-- the existing plant growth calls for thorough checking .	3109.248
look at the trees as to size and interest , the amount of shade they provide , how healthy they are , the problems of maintenance , fire hazards , wind throw , etcetera .	339.61276
an area may have been partially logged and requires removal of stumps or clean-up .	5470.025
some shrubs may be of good landscaping value , other areas of brush may need to be cleared .	1110.9576
the extent and location of open areas is noted .	284.2003
-- how much will wind , rain , sun , and temperature affect the use ? ?	611.2814
an area sheltered from strong winds may be highly desirable for recreation use .	700.3765
the direction , velocity , and season of these winds should be noted as to just how they will affect the recreation use and your maintenance and operation of the area .	234.58499
lack of rainfall and extreme temperatures may call for the development of shade and irrigation of a site to make it useable .	872.26794
sometimes , you have a choice of exposure for sites where the topography or trees of the area will provide afternoon shade , morning sun , or whatever may be most desirable for the use intended .	451.33472
-- some areas may already have been improved and contain buildings , roads , utilities , cleared land , etcetera which may raise the cost of the site .	375.2122
your invitation to write about serge prokofieff to honor his 70th anniversary for the april issue of sovietskaya muzyka is accepted with pleasure , because i admire the music of prokofieff	2062.2683
and with sober purpose , because the development of prokofieff personifies , in many ways , the course of music in the union of soviet socialist republics .	305.29578
the serge prokofieff whom we knew in the united states of america was gay , witty , mercurial , full of pranks and bonheur -- and very capable as a professional musician .	717.4903
these qualities endeared him to both the musicians and the social-economic haute monde which supported the concert world of the post-world war 1 , era .	1137.5446
prokofieff ' s outlook as a composer-pianist-conductor in america was , indeed , brilliant .	400.17822
prokofieff ' s classical symphony was hailed as an ingenious work from a naturally gifted and well-trained musician still in his twenties .	1896.3623
to the traditionalists , it was a brilliant satire on modernism	1107.7499
to the neo-classicists , it was a challenge to the pre-war world .	169.10663
what was it to prokofieff ? ?	510.8475
a trial balloon to test the aesthetic climate of the times	342.177
a brilliant piece de resistance ? ?	173.03665
certainly its composer was an ascending star on a new world horizon .	2020.5199
i heard the classical symphony for the first time when koussevitzky conducted it in paris in 1927 .	593.2794
some musicians were enthusiastic , some skeptical .	655.22003
i myself was one of the skeptics ( 35 years ago ) .	188.9214
i remember ernest bloch in the foyer , shouting in his high-pitched voice `` it may be a tour de force , mais mon dieu , can anyone take this music seriously ' ' ? ?	973.1507
the answer is , `` yes ' ' ! !	45.510384
certainly , america took prokofieff and his classical symphony seriously , and with a good deal of pleasure .	469.37967
his life-long friend , serge koussevitzky , gave unreservedly of his praise and brilliant performances in boston , new york , and washington , d . c . , , to which he added broadcastings and recordings for the whole nation .	312.44162
chicago was also a welcome host there , in 1921 , prokofieff conducted the world premiere of the love for three oranges , and played the first performance of his third piano concerto .	580.5132
`` uncle sam ' ' was , indeed , a rich uncle to prokofieff , in those opulent , post-war victory years of peace and prosperity , bold speculations and extravaganzas , enjoyment and pleasure `` the golden twenties ' ' .	746.1604
we attended the premieres of his concertos , symphonies , and suites	717.1551
we studied , taught , and performed his piano sonatas , chamber music , gavottes , and marches	1381.8169
we bought his records and played them in our schools and universities .	263.23624
we unanimously agreed that prokofieff had won his rights as a world citizen to the first ranks of twentieth-century composers .	761.27344
nevertheless , prokofieff was much influenced by paris during the twenties the paris which was the artistic center of the western world -- the social paris to which russian aristocracy migrated -- the chic paris which attracted the tourist dollars of rich america -- the avant-garde paris of diaghileff , stravinsky , koussevitzky , cocteau , picasso -- the laissez-faire paris of dadaism and ultramodern art -- the paris sympathique which took young composers to her bosom with such quick and easy enthusiasms .	1891.4857
so young prokofieff was the darling of success in his motherland	1831.3538
in the spacious hunting grounds of `` uncle sam ' '	178.94388
in the exciting salons of his lovely , brilliant paris -- mistress of gaiety -- excess and abandon -- world theatre of new-found freedoms in tone , color , dance , design , and thought .	1491.6813
meanwhile , three great terrible forces were coagulating and crystallizing .	9561.4795
in this world-wide conscription of men , minds , and machines , prokofieff was recalled to his native land .	378.72125
the world exploded when fascism challenged all concepts of peace and liberty , and the outraged , freedom-loving peoples of the capitalist and socialist worlds combined forces to stamp fascist tyranny into cringing submission .	4128.0547
after this holocaust , a changing world occupied the minds of men	634.27264
a world beset with new boundaries , new treaties and governments , new goals and methods , and the age-old fears of aggression and subjugation -- hunger and exposure .	595.5137
in this changed world , prokofieff settled to find himself , and to create for large national purpose .	334.92407
here , this happy , roving son of good fortune proved that he could accept the disciplines of a new social-economic order fighting for its very existence and ideals in a truculent world .	680.3808
here , prokofieff became a workman in the vineyards of socialism -- producing music for the masses .	625.1488
it is at this point in his life that the mature prokofieff emerges .	412.81607
one might have expected that such a violent epoch of transition would have destroyed the creative flair of a composer , especially one whose works were so fluent and spontaneous .	2611.5261
he accepted the environment of his destiny -- took root and grew to fulfill the stature of his early promise .	386.33176
by 1937 he had clarified his intentions to serve his people `` i have striven for clarity and melodious idiom , but at the same time i have by no means attempted to restrict myself to the accepted methods of harmony and melody .	538.6897
this is precisely what makes lucid , straightforward music so difficult to compose -- the clarity must be new , not old ' ' .	469.13867
how clearly he saw the cultural defection of experimentation as an escape for those who dare not or prefer not to face the discipline of modern traditionalism .	1185.8875
and with what resource did prokofieff back up his credo of words -- with torrents of powerful music .	973.6399
compare the vast difference in scope and beauty between his neat and witty little classical symphony and his big , muscular , passionate , and eloquent fifth symphony	1000.4379
or the love for three oranges ( gay as it is ) with the wonderful , imaginative , colorful , and subtle tenderness of the magnificent ballet , the stone flower .	754.33594
this masterpiece has gaiety , too , but it is the gaiety of dancing people earthy , salty and humorous .	794.364
of course , these works are not comparable , even though the same brain conceived them .	661.51434
the early works were conceived for a sophisticated , international audience	901.01
the later works were conceived to affirm a way of life for fellow citizens .	452.75305
however , in all of prokofieff ' s music , young or mature , we find his profile -- his `` signature ' ' -- his craftsman ' s attitude .	490.62784
prokofieff never forsakes his medium for the cause of experimentation per se .	446.50198
in orchestration , he stretches the limits of instrumentation with good judgment and a fine imagination for color .	764.14954
his sense for rhythmic variety and timing is impeccable .	923.81226
his creative development of melodic designs of slavic dance tunes and love songs is captivating witty , clever , adroit , and subtle .	5344.494
his counterpoint is pertinent , skillful , and rarely thick .	720.40155
also , it should be noted that the polytonal freedom of his melodies and harmonic modulations , the brilliant orchestrations , the adroitness for evading the heaviness of figured bass , the skill in florid counterpoint were not lost in his mature output , even in the spectacular historical dramas of the stage and cinema , where a large , dramatic canvas of sound was required .	1343.5826
that prokofieff ' s harmonies and forms sometimes seem professionally routine to our ears , may or may not indicate that he was less of an `` original ' ' than we prefer to believe .	383.83746
need for novelty may be a symptom of cultural fatigue and instability .	716.80774
prokofieff might well emerge as a cultural hero , who , by the force of his creative life , helped preserve the main stream of tradition , to which the surviving idioms of current experimentalism may be eventually added and integrated .	545.8735
at this date , it seems probable that the name of serge prokofieff will appear in the archives of history , as an effective traditionalist , who was fully aware of the lure and danger of experimentation , and used it as it served his purpose	417.40247
yet was never caught up in it -- never a slave to its academic dialectics .	699.7266
certainly , it is the traditional clarity of his music which has endeared him to the western world -- not his experimentations .	714.91187
so prokofieff was able to cultivate his musical talents and harvest a rich reward from them .	739.6942
nor can anyone be certain that prokofieff would have done better , or even as well , under different circumstances .	337.17578
his fellow-countryman , igor stravinsky , certainly did not .	953.45264
why did prokofieff expand in stature and fecundity , while stravinsky ( who leaped into fame like a young giant ) dwindled in stature and fruitfulness ? ?	2488.618
i think the answer is to be found in prokofieff ' s own words `` the clarity must be new , not old ' ' .	125.52144
when prokofieff forged his new clarity of `` lucid , straightforward music , so difficult to compose ' ' , he shaped his talents to his purpose .	526.26166
when stravinsky shaped his purpose to the shifting scenes of many cultures , many salons , many dialectics , many personalities , he tried to refashion himself into a stylist of many styles , determined by many disparate cultures .	841.1916
prokofieff was guided in a consistent direction by the life of his own people -- by the compass of their national ideas .	205.65903
but stravinsky was swayed by the attitudes of whatever culture he was reflecting .	233.43547
in all his miscalculations , stravinsky made the fatal historical blunder of presuming that he could transform other composers ' inspirations -- representing many peoples , time periods and styles -- into his own music by warping the harmony , melody , or form , to verify his own experiments .	1126.131
because of the authentic homogeneity of his early nationalistic materials , and his flair for orchestrations -- his brilliant petruchka , his savage sacre du printemps , his incisive les noces -- the world kept hoping that he could recapture the historical direction for which his native talents were predisposed .	1782.8774
but time is running out , and many of stravinsky ' s admirers begin to fear that he will never find terra firma .	1028.3706
his various aesthetic postulates remain as landmarks of a house divided against itself supra-expressionism , neo-paganism , neo-classicism , neo-romanticism , neo-jazz , neo-ecclesiasticism , neo-popularism , and most recently , post-serialism -- all competing with each other within one composer ! !	2163.2676
what a patchwork of proclamations and renunciations ! !	4047.1335
meager and shabby by-products linger to haunt our memories of a once mighty protagonist	4290.897
a maladroit reharmonization of our national anthem ( the star-spangled banner )	11870.777
a poor attempt to write an idiomatic jazz concerto	20425.97
his hopes that the tunes from his old music might be used for popular american commercial songs ! !	758.71893
stravinsky , nearing the age of eighty , is like a lost and frantic bird , flitting from one abandoned nest to another , searching for a home .	792.04205
prokofieff was able to adjust his creative personality to a swiftly changing world without losing his particular force and direction .	1115.0404
in the process , his native endowments were stretched , strengthened and disciplined to serve their human purpose .	1108.5123
with a large and circumspect 20th-century technique , he wove the materials of national heroes and events , national folklore and children ' s fairy tales -- slavic dances and love songs -- into a solid musical literature which served his people well , and is providing much enjoyment to the world at large .	876.28217
of course , it must not be forgotten that in achieving this historical feat , prokofieff had the vast resources of his people behind him	365.2646
symphony orchestras , opera and ballet companies	1509.67
it must be conceded that his native land provided prokofieff with many of the necessary conditions for great creative incentive economic security and cultural opportunities , incisive idioms , social fermentations for a new national ideology -- a sympathetic public and a large body of performers especially trained to fulfill his purpose .	1117.0249
thus in prokofieff the union of soviet socialist republics produced one of the great composers of the twentieth century .	307.59326
that his moods , even in his early years , are those of his people , does him honor , as his music honors those who inspired it .	318.3226
that he mastered every aspect of his medium according to his own great talents and contemporary judgments , is a good and solid symbol of his people under the tremendous pressures of proclaiming and practising the rigors of a new culture	622.01776
and perhaps of even greater significance -- his music is strong 20th-century evidence of the effectiveness of evolution , based on a broad traditionalism for the creative art of music .	590.0814
april 10 marked a memorable date in new york ' s musical history -- indeed in the musical history of the entire eastern united states .	243.71751
on that date the musicians emergency fund , organized to furnish employment for musicians unable to obtain engagements during the depression and to provide relief for older musicians who lost their fortunes in the stock market crash , observed its 30th anniversary .	1544.3533
roy mason is essentially a landscape painter whose style and direction has a kinship with the english watercolorists of the early nineteenth century , especially the beautifully patterned art of john sell cotman .	1551.1046
and like this english master , mason realizes his subjects in large , simplified masses which , though they seem effortless , are in reality the result of skilled design born of hard work and a thorough distillation of the natural form that inspired them .	935.69763
as a boy roy mason began the long process of extracting the goodness of the out-of-doors , its tang of weather , its change of seasons , its variable moods .	765.2945
his father , a professional engraver and an amateur landscape painter , took his sons on numerous hunting expeditions , and imparted to them his knowledge and love of nature .	1207.4003
out of this background of hunting and fishing , it was only natural that roy first painted subjects he knew best hunters in the field , fishermen in the stream , ducks and geese on the wing -- almost always against a vast backdrop of weather landscape .	909.45996
it is this subject matter that has brought mason a large and enthusiastic following among sportsmen , but it is his exceptional performance with this motif that commends him to artists and discerning collectors .	1935.4215
mason had to earn the privilege of devoting himself exclusively to painting .	968.59204
like many others , he had to work hard , long hours in a struggling family business which , though it was allied to art of a kind -- the design and production of engraved seals -- bore no relation to the painting of pictures .	483.62195
but it did teach roy the basic techniques of commercial art , and later , for twelve years , he and his sister nina conducted an advertising art studio in philadelphia .	715.55646
on the death of their father , they returned to their home in batavia , new york .	289.46545
after more years of concentrated effort , roy and his brother max finally established a thriving family business at the old stand .	1034.8116
during all this time roy continued to paint , first only on weekends , and then , as the family business permitted , for longer periods .	584.44696
gradually he withdrew from the shop altogether , and for the past thirty years , he has worked independently as a painter , except for his continued hunting and fishing expeditions .	386.395
but even on these , the palette often takes over while the shotgun cools off ! !	1402.8813
except for a rich friendship with the painter , chauncey ryder who gave him the only professional instruction he ever had -- and this was limited to a few lessons , though the two artists often went on painting trips together -- roy developed his art by himself .	884.181
in the best tradition , he first taught himself to see , then to draw with accuracy and assurance , and then to paint .	245.83595
he worked in oil for years before beginning his work in watercolor , and his first public recognition and early honors , including his election to the academy , were for his essays in the heavier medium .	489.80853
gradually watercolor claimed his greater affection until today it has become his major , if not exclusive , technique .	702.86
it has been my privilege to paint with roy mason on numerous occasions , mostly in the vicinity of batavia .	1095.0979
more often than not i have found easy excuse to leave my own work and stand at a respectable distance where i could watch this man transform raw nature into a composed , not imitative , painting .	939.4741
what i have observed time and time again is a process of integration , integration that begins as abstract design and gradually takes on recognizable form	905.5243
color patterns that are made to weave throughout the whole composition	1390.0233
and that over-all , amazing control of large washes which is the mason stylemark .	1673.0487
finally come those little flicks of a rigger brush and the job is done .	1415.7686
but for the technical fact , we have the artist ' s own testimony	166.8942
`` of late years , i find that i like best to work out-of-doors .	158.6714
first i make preliminary watercolor sketches in quarter scale ( approximately af inches ) in which i pay particular attention to the design principles of three simple values -- the lightest light , the middle tone , and the darkest dark -- by reducing the forms of my subject to these large patterns .	614.3356
if a human figure or wild life are to be part of the projected final picture , i try to place them in the initial sketch .	190.37689
for me , these will belong more completely to their surroundings if they are conceived in this early stage , though i freely admit that i do not hesitate to add or eliminate figures on the full sheet when it serves my final purpose .	492.35623
`` i am thoroughly convinced that most watercolors suffer because the artist expects nature will do his composing for him	2431.0005
as a result , such pictures are only a literal translation of what the artist finds in the scene before him .	414.39346
just because a tree or other object appears in a certain spot is absolutely no reason to place it in the same position in the painting , unless the position serves the design of the whole composition .	335.17282
if the artist would study his work more thoroughly and move certain units in his design , often only slightly , finer pictures would result .	1224.6825
out of long experience i have found that incidental figures and other objects like trees , logs , and bushes can be traced from the original sketch and moved about in the major areas on the final sheet until they occupy the right position , which i call clicking .	626.1769
`` speed in painting a picture is valid only when it imparts spontaneity and crispness , but unless the artist has lots of experience so that he can control rapid execution , he would do well to take these first sketches and soberly reorder their design to achieve a unified composition .	937.4729
`` if i have seemed to emphasize the structure of the composition , i mean to project equal concern for color .	226.75227
often , in working out-of-doors under all conditions of light and atmosphere , a particular passage that looked favorable in relation to the subject will be too bright , too dull , or too light , or too dark when viewed indoors in a mat .	519.2639
when this occurs , i make the change on the sketch or on the final watercolor -- if i have been working on a full sheet in the field .	163.74292
`` when working from one of my sketches i square it up and project its linear form freehand to the watercolor sheet with charcoal .	2892.716
when this linear draft is completed , i dust it down to a faint image .	495.3226
from this point , i paint in as direct a manner as possible , by flowing on the washes with as pure a color mixture as i can manage .	804.8744
however , first i thoughtfully study my sketch for improvement of color and design along the lines i have described .	846.04205
then i plan my attack the parts i will finish first , the range of values , the accenting of minor details -- all in all , mechanics of producing the finished job with a maximum of crispness .	494.2602
the longer i work , the more i am sure that for me , at least , a workmanlike method is important .	218.08446
trial and error are better placed in the preliminary sketch than in hoping for miracles in the final painting .	876.17773
`` as for materials , i use the best available .	106.6628
i work on a watercolor easel in the field , and frequently resort to a large garden umbrella to protect my eyes from undue strain .	1438.8463
in my studio i work at a tilt-top table , but leave the paper unfixed so that i can move it freely to control the washes .	762.15967
i have used a variety of heavy-weight hand-made papers , but prefer an english make , rough surface , in 400-pound weight .	3686.3103
after selecting a sheet and inspecting it for flaws ( even the best sometimes has foreign ' nubbins ' on its surface ) , i sponge it thoroughly on both sides with clean , cold water .	3447.0142
then i dry the sheet under mild pressure so that it will lie flat as a board .	730.1826
`` in addition to the usual tools , i make constant use of cleansing tissue , not only to wipe my brushes , but to mop up certain areas , to soften edges , and to open up lights in dark washes .	947.2638
the great absorbency of this tissue and the fact that it is easier to control than a sponge makes it an ideal tool for the watercolorist .	430.64362
i also use a small electric hand-blower to dry large washes in the studio .	1693.6171
`` my brushes are different from those used by most watercolorists , for i combine the sable and the bristle .	1214.271
the red sables are 8	7869.035
two riggers , 6 and 10	415.76608
and a very large , flat wash brush .	1803.422
the bristles are a fitch 2 and a one-half inch brush shaved to a sharp chisel edge .	4768.0933
`` my usual palette consists of top-quality colors alizarin crimson , orange , raw sienna , raw umber , burnt sienna , sepia , cerulean blue , cobalt blue , french ultramarine blue , winsor green , hooker ' s green 2 , cadmium yellow pale , yellow ochre , payne ' s gray , charcoal gray , davy ' s gray , and ivory black ' ' .	3598.1743
in analyzing the watercolors of roy mason , the first thing that comes to mind is their essential decorativeness , yet this word has such a varied connotation that it needs some elaboration here .	1135.7332
true , a mason watercolor is unmistakably a synthesis of nature rather than a detailed inventory .	908.42615
unlike many decorative patterns that present a static flat convention , this artist ' s pictures are full of atmosphere and climate .	464.6704
long observation has taught mason that most landscape can be reduced to three essential planes a foreground in sharp focus -- either a light area with dark accents or a dark one with lights	1376.8235
a middle distance often containing the major motif	3291.4043
and a background , usually a silhouetted form foiled against the sky .	4285.904
in following this general principle , mason provides the observer with a natural eye progression from foreground to background , and the illusion of depth is instantly created .	1138.2423
when painting , mason ' s physical eyes are half-closed , while his mind ' s eye is wide open , and this circumstance accounts in part for the impression he wishes to convey .	420.1019
he does not insist on telling all he knows about any given subject	923.0742
rather his pictures invite the observer to draw on his memory , his imagination , his nostalgia .	271.35474
it is for this reason that roy avoids selecting subjects that require specific recognition of place for their enjoyment .	1345.3668
his pictures generalize , though they are inspired by a particular locale	753.7768
they universalize in terms of weather , skies , earth , and people .	284.357
by dealing with common landscape in an uncommon way , roy mason has found a particular niche in american landscape art .	1249.7301
living with his watercolors is a vicarious experience of seeing nature distilled through the eyes of a sensitive interpretor , a breath and breadth of the outdoor world to help man honor the creator of it all .	864.2419
the artist was born in gilbert mills , new york , in 1886 , and until two years ago when he and his wife moved to california , he lived in western new york , in batavia .	406.55472
when i looked up the actual date of his birth and found it to be march 15th , i realized that roy was born under the right zodiacal sign for a watercolorist the water sign of pisces ( february 18 thru march 20 ) .	829.82416
and how very often a water plane is featured in his landscapes , and how appropriate that he should appear in american artist again , in his natal month of march ! !	357.63614
over the years , beginning in 1929 , mason has been awarded seventeen major prizes including two gold medals	2876.2578

the russian gymnasts beat the tar out of the american gymnasts in the 1960 olympics for one reason -- they were better .	390.8587
they were better trained , better looking , better built , better disciplined and something else -- they were better dancers .	593.7404
our athletes are only just beginning to learn that they must study dance .	318.0583
the russians are all trained as dancers before they start to study gymnastics .	1468.9878
but why gymnastics at all ? ?	58.48955
and is the sport really important ? ?	433.0843
after all , we did pretty well in some other areas of the olympics competition .	510.03333
but if it is important , what can we do to improve ourselves ? ?	148.9492
it is more than just lack of dance training that is our problem , for just as gymnastics can learn from dance , dance has some very important things to learn from gymnastics .	699.74866
taking first things first , let ' s understand the sport called gymnastics .	642.4409
it is made up of tumbling , which might be said to start with a somersault , run through such stunts as headstands , handstands , cartwheels , backbends , and culminate in nearly impossible combinations of aerial flips and twists and apparatus work .	1850.5403
the apparatus used by gymnasts was once a common sight in american gyms , but about 1930 it was dropped in favor of games .	667.69775
the parallel bars , horse , buck , springboard , horizontal bar , rings , and mats formerly in the school gyms were replaced by baseball , volleyball , basketball and football .	2631.7224
but the russians use gymnastics as the first step in training for all other sports because it provides training in every basic quality except one , endurance .	612.6158
the gymnast must develop strength , flexibility , coordination , timing , rhythm , courage , discipline , persistence and the desire for perfection .	564.2306
in short , gymnastics uses every part of the body and requires a great deal of character as well .	332.95352
the addition of endurance training later , when the body is mature enough to benefit from it without danger of injury , provides that final quality that makes the top athlete , soldier or citizen .	795.63245
another reason gymnastic study is valuable is that it can be started very early in life .	194.21368
( an enterprising teacher or parent could start training a healthy child at the age of seven days .	531.3648
most europeans have been exercising newborn infants for centuries .	6058.1274
) in most sports , as in most walks of life , the angels are on the side of those who begin young , and the russian competitor of 16 has at least thirteen years of training behind him .	378.91995
the american is very lucky if he has three .	388.7001
if a nation wished to get a head start in physical fitness over all other nations , it would start its kindergarten students on a program of gymnastics the day they entered and thus eliminate a large number of the problems that plague american schools .	451.73178
first of the problems attacked would be fatigue and emotional tension , since action relieves both .	1795.3284
oddly enough , it is proven that there would be less reading difficulty .	241.66861
certainly there would be less anxiety , fewer accidents ( it is the clumsy child who sustains the worst injuries ) , and higher scholastic averages , since alert children work better .	1339.0569
russia knows this , and that is why there were over 800 , 000 competing for places as candidates for the olympic gymnastic team .	560.33673
eighty thousand won top honors and a chance to try for the team itself .	239.17584
we could scarcely find eighty in our great land of over 180 million people .	1217.9417
and what has dancing to do with all this ? ?	114.44296
russia ' s young gymnasts have studied dance before having the rigorous training on apparatus .	2983.845

president kennedy has asked that we become a physically fit nation .	1809.2083
if we wait until children are in junior high or high school , we will never manage it .	547.52783

the only area in which american boys hold their own is the baseball throw .	798.0212
for arm and shoulder strength a chinning bar is recommended .	2197.552
it should be installed over a door that is in full view of everyone , and a chair should be placed under it , a little to one side .	226.66266
those children who can chin themselves should be told to do one chin-up each time they pass under it .	1046.824
those who are too weak , should climb on the chair and , starting at the top of the chin , let themselves slowly down .	312.18744
when they can take ten seconds to accomplish the descent , they will have the strength to chin-up .	561.8524
parents should be informed about this system and encouraged to do the same with the whole family at home .	170.59628
arm , shoulder , chest , upper and lower back strength will be aided with the horse kick .	704.9769
keeping the hands in the starting position , run in place to a quick rhythm .	353.8448
after this has become easy , use slower and slower rhythms , kicking higher and higher .	1706.3086
follow this by crossing from one corner of the room to the other on all fours , kicking as high as possible .	458.70114
push-ups are essential , but few have the strength for them at first .	349.90753
start on the knees in a large circle .	136.78923
fall slowly forward onto the hands and let the body down to rest on the floor .	160.56934
do this exercise six times each class period .	713.7255
as strength improves start in a standing position with legs wide apart and upper body bent forward .	1154.7698
start by falling forward to a point close to the feet , and , as strength improves , fall farther and farther out .	349.2461
try to push back to the stand position from the stretched position without any intermediate pushes from the hands .	616.825
the push-up itself can be taught by starting at the top of the push-up with legs spread wide .	551.65796
let the body down slowly , taking at least five seconds for the letting down .	619.7934
five of these done daily for about a week will develop the strength for one push-up .	463.16196
handstands come after arms , chest and shoulders have developed at least a minimum of strength .	374.60452
of course those who have developed more will find them easier .	494.13245
start with the class standing in a circle , with weight on the right foot and the left extended a little way into the circle .	319.22687
at first each child should do a kick-up by himself so that the teacher can determine those ready to work alone , and those who need help .	505.0546
drop both hands to the floor and at the same time kick the right foot up in back .	510.9778
the left will follow at once .	207.95262
the right will land first , followed by the left .	139.13164
care should be taken to see that the hands are placed on the floor before the kick starts and also that the landing foot is brought as close to the hands as possible .	288.9158
this will prevent flat falls and toe injuries .	1469.8876
bare feet are better for such work than any form of slipper .	846.39795
eventually the class will be able to kick up high enough so that the teacher can catch the leading leg .	552.30853
the child should then bring both legs together overhead , point the toes and tighten the seat muscles .	1759.1837
be sure that the landing foot is brought close to the hands and that only one foot lands at a time .	405.57733
the backbend is of extreme importance to any form of free gymnastics , and , as with all acrobatics , the sooner begun the better the results .	566.3803
have the class lie supine with knees apart and bent .	4913.2363
place flat palms on either side of the head a few inches away from the ears , fingers pointing toward the shoulders .	616.5054
arch the back upwards to make a bridge .	161.66725
be sure the head drops backward so that the child looks at the floor rather than toward the ceiling .	702.08014
as flexibility improves , the feet will move closer to the hands and the bridge rise higher .	512.70337
later this can be combined with the handstand to provide a walkover .	2421.202
to further increase back flexibility , work on the back circle .	1080.2108
place the hands in front of the chest .	79.808044
keep the legs straight and the toes pointed .	560.85504
straighten the arms slowly , this arches the back .	339.6027
at the peak of the arch , tip the head back and bend the knees in an effort to touch toes to head .	543.15247
improvement can be measured by the lessening distance between toes and head .	1042.3678
the last essential to the beginner ' s gymnastic program is the somersault , or forward roll .	798.7353
this used to be part of every child ' s bag of tricks , but few children can do it today	327.49896
some are actually incapable of rolling forward and are completely confused when not sitting or standing upright .	1322.1552
for most small children , learning a forward roll is simply a matter of copying another child who can .	1465.0851
after it has been seen , have the child start on a mat on hands and knees ( a thin , inexpensive mat is quite sufficient for anything that does not require falling ) .	634.626
he places the hands on either side of the head , keeping the chin down on the chest .	234.14738

one or two practice runs should be sufficient for solo .	796.9838
if , however , the child is weak , overweight , or afraid , more help will be needed .	383.66672
when the child raises his seat into the air , the teacher takes hold under both sides of the pelvis	793.4191
then no matter what happens , the child ' s performance will be controlled .	217.70595
by lifting the seat upwards a little , the weight is taken off the neck and the back is kept rounded .	420.36584
these are beginnings , but correctly learned they prepare for satisfying and exciting stunts that can be performed by a strong , flexible body ( we are not talking of eccentric extremes ) .	1638.9431
even if gymnastics are not the ultimate goal , the good tumbler will be a better dancer , a better athlete , and a human being with a greater margin of safety in any activity .	421.20615
it is very important for parents to understand that early training is imperative .	399.74338
and dancing school , so helpful in artistic and psychological development , also contributes to this essential early training -- and can contribute even more .	591.7069
every taxpayer is well aware of the vast size of our annual defense budget and most of our readers also realize that a large portion of these expenditures go for military electronics .	450.4543
we have noted how some electronic techniques , developed for the defense effort , have evenutally been used in commerce and industry .	656.79596
the host of novel applications of electronics to medical problems is far more thrilling because of their implication in matters concerning our health and vitality .	874.5523
when we consider the electronic industry potential for human betterment , the prospect is staggering .	1805.6678
the author has recently studied the field of medical electronics and has been convinced that , in this area alone , the application of electronic equipment has enormous possibilities .	816.07666
the benefits electronics can bring to bio-medicine may be greater by far than any previous medical discovery .	728.1475
we use the term `` bio-medicine ' ' because of the close interrelation between biology and medical research .	381.71982
electronics has been applied to medicine for many years in the form of such familiar equipment as the x-ray machine , the electrocardiograph , and the diathermy machine .	473.9554
recently many doctors have installed ultrasonic vibration machines for deep massage of bruises , contusions , and simple bursitis .	11956.569
commonly used electronic devices which are found in practically every hospital are closed-circuit tv and audio systems for internal paging and instruction , along with radiation counters , timers , and similar devices .	2682.55
in this article we will concentrate on the advances in the application of electronics in bio-medical research laboratories because this is where tomorrow ' s commonplace equipment originates .	1058.5864
from the wealth of material and the wide variety of different electronic techniques perfected in the past few years we have selected a few examples which appear to be headed for use in the immediate future and which offer completely new tools in medical research .	652.34973
many cells , bacteria , and other microorganisms are transparent to visible light and must be stained for microscopic investigation .	796.39874
this stain often disrupts the normal cell activity or else colors only the outside .	765.5963
a completely new insight into living cells and their structure will be possible by use of a new technique which replaces visible light with ultraviolet radiation and combines a microscope with a color-tv system to view the results .	795.68665
fig . 1 is a simplified block diagram of the ultraviolet microscopy system developed at the medical electronics center of rockefeller institute .	1308.8489
by combining the talents of a medical man , dr . aterman , a biophysicist , mr . berkely , and an electronics expert , dr . zworykin , this novel technique has been developed which promises to open broad avenues to understanding life processes .	557.62177
three different wavelengths of ultraviolet radiation are selected by the variable filters placed in front of the three mercury xenon lights which serve as the ultraviolet sources .	1128.4951
these wavelengths are reflected in sequence through the specimen by the rotating mirror	1021.2206
the specimen is magnified by the microscope .	104.9694
instead of the observer ' s eye the image orthicon in the tv camera does the `` looking ' ' .	637.5484
the microscope and orthicon are both selected to operate well into the ultraviolet spectrum , which means that all lenses must be quartz .	799.4585
the video signal is amplified and then switched , in synchronism with the three ultraviolet light sources which are sequenced by the rotating mirror so that during one-twentieth of a second only one wavelength , corresponding to red , green , or blue , is seen .	1574.2551
( note because of light leakage from one ultraviolet source to another , the lights are switched by a commutator-like assembly rotated by a synchronous motor .	3025.664
this assembly also supplies a 20-cps switching gate for the electronics circuitry .	5606.4116
) this is the same system as was used in the field-sequential color-tv system which preceded the present simultaneous system .	2105.0627
three separate amplifiers then drive a 21-inch tricolor tube .	12671.833
the result is a color picture of the specimen where the primary colors correspond to the three different ultraviolet wavelengths .	929.9321
many of the cells and microorganisms which are transparent to visible light , absorb or reflect the much shorter wavelengths of the ultraviolet spectrum .	1197.6569
different parts of these cells sometimes absorb or reflect different wavelengths so that it is often possible to see internal portions of cells in a different color .	1467.9193
where the microscope under visible light may show only vague shadows or nothing at all , ultraviolet illumination and subsequent translation into a color tv picture reveal a wealth of detail .	1503.9945
at the present time the research team which pioneered this new technique is primarily interested in advancing and perfecting it .	1606.2034
the medical title of `` lobar ventilation in man ' ' by drs . c . j . martin and a . c . young , covers a brief paper which is one part of a much larger effort to apply electronics to the study of the respiratory process .	307.8929
at the university of washington medical school , the electronics group has developed the `` respiratory gas analyzer ' ' shown in fig . 3 .	459.38803
this unit , affectionately dubbed `` the monster ' ' , can be wheeled to any convenient location and provides a wealth of information about the patient ' s breathing .	362.8374
in the lower center rack an 8-channel recorder indicates the percentage of carbon dioxide and nitrogen from the upper and lower lobes of one lung , the total volume of inhalation per breath , the flow of air from both lobes , and the pressure of the two lobes with respect to each other .	958.2136
usually the patient breathes into a mouthpiece while walking a treadmill , standing still , or in some other medically significant position .	1572.6307
from the resulting data the doctor can determine lung defects with hitherto unknown accuracy and detail .	2395.6897
the original electrocardiograph primarily indicates irregularities in the heartbeat , but today ' s techniques allow exact measurements of the flow of blood through the aorta , dimensioning of the heart and its chambers , and a much more detailed study of each heartbeat .	644.543
for many of these measurements the chest must be opened , but the blood vessels and the heart itself remain undisturbed .	546.3943
a group of researchers at the university of washington have given a paper which briefly outlines some of these techniques .	520.71545
one simple method of measuring the expansion of the heart is to tie a thin rubber tube , filled with mercury , around the heart and record the change in resistance as the tube is stretched .	511.83328
a balanced resistance bridge and a pen recorder are all the electronic instrumentation needed .	1103.7695
sonar can be used to measure the thickness of the heart by placing small crystal transducers at opposite sides of the heart or blood vessel and exciting one with some pulsed ultrasonic energy .	1152.3643
the travel time of sound in tissue is about 1500 meters per second	6711.193
thus it takes about 16 msec . to traverse 25 mm . of tissue .	1289.4021
a sonar or radar-type of pulse generator and time-delay measuring system is required for body-tissue evaluation .	5783.838
in addition to the heart and aorta , successful measurements of liver and spleen have also been made by this technique .	690.0086
the doppler effect , using ultrasonic signals , can be employed to measure the flow of blood without cutting into the blood vessel .	696.07825
a still more sophisticated system has been devised for determining the effective power of the heart itself .	260.36926
it uses both an ultrasonic dimensioning arrangement of the heart and a catheter carrying a thermistor inserted into the bloodstream .	2141.4697
the latter measures the heat carried away by the bloodstream as an indication of the velocity of the blood flow .	382.263
it is also possible to utilize a pressure transducer , mounted at the end of a catheter which is inserted into the heart ' s left ventricle , to indicate the blood pressure in the heart itself .	337.12094
this pressure measurement may be made at the same time that the ultrasonic dimensioning measurement is made .	322.61072
a simplified version of the instrumentation for this procedure is shown in fig . 2 .	189.70813
outputs of the two systems are measured by a pulse-timing circuit and a resistance bridge , followed by a simple analogue computer which feeds a multichannel recorder .	2208.9407
from this doctors can read heart rate , change in diameter , pressure , and effective heart power .	333.42398
several years ago headlines were made by a small radio transmitter capsule which could be swallowed by the patient and which would then radio internal pressure data to external receivers .	1269.6932
this original capsule contained a battery and a transistor oscillator and was about 1 cm . in diameter .	914.87164
battery life limited the use of this `` pill ' ' to about 8 to 30 hours maximum .	413.25488
a refinement of this technique has been described by drs . zworykin and farrar and mr . berkely of the medical electronics center of the rockefeller institute .	919.34534
in this novel arrangement the `` pill ' ' is much smaller and contains only a resonant circuit in which the capacitor is formed by a pressure-sensing transducer .	727.22906
as shown in fig . 4 , an external antenna is placed over or around the patient and excited 3000 times a second with short 400-kc . bursts .	1183.4272
the energy received by the `` pill ' ' causes the resonant circuit to `` ring ' ' on after the burst and this `` ringing ' ' takes place at the resonant frequency of the `` pill ' ' .	226.46646
these frequencies are amplified and detected by the fm receiver after each burst of transmitted energy and , after the `` pill ' ' has been calibrated , precise internal pressure indications can be obtained .	820.5805
one of the advantages of this method is that the `` pill ' ' can remain in the patient for several days , permitting observation under natural conditions .	239.35005
applications to organs other than the gastrointestinal tract are planned for future experiments .	1494.1494
one of the most gratifying applications of an important technique of submarine detection is in the exploration of the human body .	456.2956
our readers are familiar with the principles of sonar where sound waves are sent out in water and the echoes then indicate submerged objects .	882.6506
various methods of pulsing , scanning , and displaying these sound waves are used to detect submarines , map ocean floors , and even communicate under water .	1644.3169
in medicine the frequencies are much higher , transducers and the sonar beams themselves are much smaller , and different scanning techniques may be used , but the principles involved are the same as in sonar .	623.5233
because the body contains so much liquid , transmission of ultrasonic signals proceeds fairly well in muscles and blood vessels .	3040.97
bones and cartilage transmit poorly and tend to reflect the ultrasonic signals .	739.79724
based on this phenomenon , a number of investigators have used this method to `` look through ' ' human organs .	451.12
a good example of the results obtainable with ultrasonic radiation is contained in papers presented by dr . g . baum who has explored the human eye .	1009.8858
he can diagnose detachment of the retina where conventional methods indicate blindness due to glaucoma .	6635.201
the method used to scan the eye ultrasonically is illustrated in fig . 6 .	903.33685
the transducer is coupled to the body through a water bath , not shown .	353.92477
for display , dr . baum uses a portion of an af , an airborne radar indicator , and then photographs the screen to obtain a permanent record .	496.5658
a typical `` sonogram ' ' of a human eye , together with a description of the anatomical parts , is shown in fig . 5 .	91.78162
the frequency used for these experiments is 15 mc . and the transducer is a specially cut crystal with an epoxy lens capable of providing beam diameters smaller than one millimeter .	3456.221
the transducer itself moves the beam in a sector scan , just like a radar antenna , while the entire transducer structure is moved over a 90-degree arc in front of the eye to `` look into ' ' all corners .	616.0032
the total picture is only seen by the camera which integrates the many sector scans over the entire 90-degree rotation period .	3301.9902
drs . howry and holmes at the university of colorado medical school have applied the same sonar technique to other areas of soft tissue and have obtained extremely good results .	912.097
by submerging the patient in a tub and rotating the transducer while the scanning goes on , they have been able to get cross-section views of the neck , as shown in fig . 7 , as well as many other hitherto impossible insights .	373.36105
as mentioned before , bone reflects the sound energy and in fig . 7 the portion of the spine shows as the black area in the center .	344.69666
arteries and veins are apparent by their black , blood-filled centers and the surrounding white walls .	1166.7806

oersted ' s boyhood represented a minimal chance of either attaining greatness or serving his people so well and over so long a span of life .	838.61633
he was born in the small danish town of rudkoebing on the island of langeland in the south-central part of denmark on august 14 , 1777 .	1193.9437
his father soeren was the village apothecary whose slender income made it difficult to feed his family , let alone educate them in a town without even a school .	986.9063
the two older boys , hans and anders , his junior by a year , therefore went daily to the home of a warm and friendly wigmaker nearby for instruction in german	873.63617
his wife taught the two boys to read and write danish .	776.4341
other brothers later joined them for instruction with oldenburg , the wigmaker , and also arithmetic was added to bible reading , german , and danish in the informal curriculum .	825.2716
oldenburg ' s contributions were soon exhausted and the boys had to turn to a wider circle of the town ' s learned , such as the pastor , to supplement the simple teaching .	222.86351
from the town surveyor , hans learned drawing and mathematics and , from a university student , some academic subjects .	549.7602
the mayor of the town taught them english and french .	2475.0347
whatever hans or anders learned separately they passed on to each other	1511.8737
they read every book that they could borrow in the village .	115.89268
at 12 , hans was sufficiently mature to help his father in the apothecary shop , which helped stimulate his interest in medicine and science .	547.3299
his earlier love for literature and history remained with him for his entire life .	336.09018
in 1793 the brothers decided to enter the university of copenhagen ( founded in 1479 ) and the following spring found them at the university preparing to matriculate for the autumn session .	919.33563
while hans devoted himself to the sciences of medicine , physics , and astronomy , his brother studied law .	279.96472
the brothers continued to help each other during their studies , sharing a joint purse , lodging together in the dormitory and dining together at the home of their aunt .	910.3242
they supplemented their income by small government assistance , by tutoring and economizing wherever they could .	1156.4244
so impressive were those serious years of study at the university that hans later wrote , `` to be perfectly free , the young man must revel in the great kingdom of thought and imagination	440.77658
there is a struggle there , in which , if he falls , it is easy for him to rise again , there is freedom of utterance there , which draws after it no irreparable consequences on society .	318.78802
i lived in this onward-driving contest where each day overcame a new difficulty , gained a new truth , or banished a previous error ' ' .	1061.7313
he openly proclaimed his pleasure in lecturing and writing about science .	1044.897
in this third year at the university , hans , in 1797 , was awarded the first important token of recognition , a gold medal for his essay on `` limits of poetry and prose ' ' .	330.20862
he completed his training in pharmacy also , taking his degree with high honors in 1797 , and in 1799 was awarded the degree of doctor of philosophy along with a prize for an essay in medicine .	844.6868
he proposed a fresh theory of alkalis which later was accepted in chemical practices .	1251.9238
hans ' student days were at a time when europe was in a new intellectual ferment following the revolutions in america and in france , germany and italy were rising from divisive nationalisms and a strong wave of intellectual awareness was sweeping the continent .	780.55457
the new century opened with oersted beginning his professional career in charge of an apothecary shop in copenhagen and as lecturer at the university .	846.9612
he was stirred by the announcement of volta ' s discovery of chemical electricity and he immediately applied the voltaic pile to experiments with acids and alkalis .	2339.9783
the following year he devoted to the customary `` wanderjahr ' ' , traveling in germany , france , and the netherlands , meeting the philosophers schelling , fichte , and tieck .	828.24524
he also met count rumford ( born benjamin thompson in woburn , mass . ) who was then serving the elector of bavaria , and the physicist ritter	2097.1929
these were oersted ' s main contacts in science .	187.2585
from gottingen ( 1801 ) where he stayed for 10 days , he wrote , `` the first question asked everywhere is about galvanism .	358.34882
as everybody is curious to see the battery of glass tubes i have invented , i have had quite a small one made here of four glass tubes ( in copenhagen i used 30 ) and intend to carry it with me ' ' .	338.684
oersted joined ritter at jena and stayed with him for 3 weeks , continuing their correspondence after he left .	818.0918
with ritter he was exposed to the fantastic profusion of ideas that stormed through his host ' s fertile but disorganized mind .	1432.6252
oersted remodeled ritter ' s notes into an essay in french which was submitted to the institut de france for its annual prize of 3 , 000 francs .	580.1225
the sound discoveries of this quixotic genius were so diluted by those of fantasy that the prize was never awarded to him .	1080.8461
in may , 1803 , ritter , in another flight of fancy , wrote to oersted a letter that contained a remarkable prophecy .	717.1551
he related events on earth to periodic celestial phenomena and indicated that the years of maximum inclination of the ecliptic coincided with the years of important electrical discoveries .	1034.0914
thus , 1745 corresponded to the invention of the `` leiden ' ' jar by kleist , 1764 that of the electrophorus by wilcke , 1782 produced the condenser of volta , and 1801 the voltaic pile .	2505.6978
ritter proceeded , `` you now emerge into a new epoch in which late in the year 1819 or 1820 , you will have to reckon .	645.88324
this we might well witness ' ' .	40.04349
ritter died in 1810 and oersted not only lived to see the event occur but was the author of it .	453.3329
in 1803 oersted returned to copenhagen and applied for the university ' s chair in physics but was rejected because he was probably considered more a philosopher than a physicist .	439.95703
however , he continued experimenting and lecturing , publishing the results of his experiments in german and danish periodicals .	1217.4823
in 1806 his ambition was realized and he became professor of physics at the copenhagen university , though not realizing full professorship ( ordinarius ) until 1817 .	1364.8113
during oersted ' s attendance at the university , it was poorly equipped with physical apparatus for experimenting in the sciences .	336.49875
he was , however , fortunate in his contact with prof . j . g . l . manthey ( 1769-1842 ) , teacher of chemistry , who , in addition to his academic chair , was also proprietor of the `` lion pharmacy ' ' in copenhagen where oersted assisted him .	409.95212
manthey maintained a valuable collection of physical and chemical apparatus which was at oersted ' s disposal during and after his graduation .	437.20963
in 1800 , manthey went abroad and oersted was appointed manager of the lion pharmacy .	854.4852
in february 1801 , oersted did manage to experiment with physical apparatus and reported experiments made with a voltaic battery of 600 plates of zinc and silver and of later experiments with a battery of 60 plates of zinc and lead .	1141.3597
in the following year , 1803 , oersted , simultaneously with davy , discovered that acids increased the strength of a voltaic battery more than did salts .	1811.7732
eager as he was to pursue this promising line , he was so loaded down with the management of the pharmacy and lectures in the medical and pharmaceutical faculties at the university that he could devote only sunday afternoons to `` galvanizing ' ' .	370.5416
he assumed his academic career with the same intensity and thoroughness that had marked every step in his rise from boyhood .	1003.6837
the university was the only one in denmark and the status of professor represented the upper social level .	616.73553
his broad interest in literary , political , and philosophical movements opened many doors to him .	771.55975
his friends were numerous and their ties to him were strong .	453.30176
the years 1812 and 1813 saw him in germany and france again , but on this visit to berlin he did not seek out the philosophers as he had on his first journey .	399.73138
in berlin he published his views of the chemical laws of nature in german and this was issued in french translation ( paris , 1813 ) under the title recherches sur l ' identite des forces chimiques et electriques , a work held in very high esteem by the new generation of research chemists .	1039.2362
his interest in finding a relationship between voltaic electricity and magnetism is here first indicated .	1422.7826
chapter 8 , is entitled `` on magnetism ' ' and in it are included such remarks as , `` one has always been tempted to compare the magnetic forces with the electrical forces .	307.17407
the great resemblance between electrical and magnetic attractions and repulsions and the similarity of their laws necessarily would bring about this comparison .	976.0357
it is true , that nothing has been found comparable with electricity by communication	766.7764
but the phenomena observed had such a degree of analogy to those depending on electrical distribution that one could not find the slightest difference .	581.44324
the form of galvanic activity is halfway between the magnetic form and the electrical form .	630.2076
there , forces are more latent than in electricity , and less than in magnetism .	689.92737
but in such an important question , we would be satisfied if the judgment were that the principal objection to the identity of forces which produce electricity and magnetism were only a difficulty , and not a thing which is contrary to it .	292.02023
one could also add to these analogies that steel loses its magnetism by heat , which proves that steel becomes a better conductor through a rise in temperature , just as electrical bodies do .	1581.1884
it is also found that magnetism exists in all bodies of nature , as proven by bruckmann and coulomb .	1940.7787
by that , one feels that magnetic forces are as general as electrical forces .	1424.2507
an attempt should be made to see if electricity , in its most latent stage , has any action on the magnet as such ' ' .	289.85883
his plan and intent were clearly charted .	1271.7552
oersted returned in 1814 and resumed an active part in university and political discussions .	914.2166
in one debate he supported the freedom of judgment as opposed to dogma , in another he held that the practice of science was in fact an act of religious worship .	336.9808
he continued as a popular lecturer .	1603.534
he devised a detonating fuse in which a short wire was caused to glow by an electric current .	902.7724
in 1819 under royal command he undertook a very successful geological expedition to bornholm , one of the danish islands , being one of three scientists in the expedition .	864.98157
it was with the assistance of one of the members of this expedition , lauritz esmarch , that oersted succeeded in producing light by creating an electric discharge in mercury vapor through which an electric current was made to flow .	1005.58215
together they also developed a new form of voltaic cell in which the wooden trough was replaced by one of copper , thereby producing stronger currents .	965.25854
esmarch was among those who witnessed oersted ' s first demonstration of his discovery .	379.26416
the association between electric ( both electrostatic and voltaic ) forces and magnetic forces had been recognized by investigators for many decades .	1151.4327
electrical literature contained numerous references to lightning that had magnetized iron and had altered the polarity of compass needles .	3316.9915
in the late 1700 ' s beccaria and van marum , among others , had magnetized iron by sending an electrostatic charge through it .	976.6735
beccaria had almost stumbled on a lead to the relationship between electricity and magnetism when a discharge from a leyden jar was sent transversally through a piece of watch-spring steel making its ends magnetic .	2753.3792
the resulting magnetic effect proved stronger than when the discharge was made lengthwise .	3220.7966
the experiments of romagnosi and others have already been noted but no one had determined the cause-and-effect relationship between these two primary forces .	699.354
oersted ' s own earlier experiments were unimpressive , possibly because he had , like other experimenters , laid the conducting wire across the compass needle instead of parallel with it .	1233.9941
the sequence of events leading to his important discovery still remains ambiguous but it seems that one of the advanced students at the university related that the first direct event that led to the publication of oersted ' s discovery occurred during a private lecture made before a group of other advanced students in the spring of 1820 .	445.76123
at this lecture oersted happened to place the conducting wire over and parallel to a magnetic needle .	1167.7085
