we may then dismiss the time difference between these courses and the usual four year course of the interior design student as not having serious bearing on the subject .	542.4846
the real question that follows is -- how are those four years used and what is their value as training ? ?	500.75186
the american institute of interior designers has published a recommended course for designers and a percentage layout of such a course .	957.9263
an examination of some forty catalogs of schools offering courses in interior design , for the most part schools accredited by membership in the national association of schools of art , and a further `` on the spot ' ' inspection of a number of schools , show their courses adhere pretty closely to the recommendations .	562.38556
one or two of the schools have a five year curriculum , but the usual pattern of american education has limited most of them to the four-year plan which seems to be the minimum in acceptable institutions .	404.35785
the suggested course of the a . i . d . was based on the usual course offered and on the opinion of many educators as to curricular necessities .	328.40363
obviously , the four year provision limits this to fundamentals and much desirable material must be eliminated .	1040.6332
without comparing the relative merits of the two courses -- architecture versus interior design -- let us examine the educational needs of the interior designer .	887.85535
to begin with , what is an interior designer ? ?	486.0304
`` the dictionary of occupational titles ' ' published by the u . s . department of labor describes him as follows `` designs , plans and furnishes interiors of houses , commercial and institutional structures , hotels , clubs , ships , theaters , as well as set decorations for motion picture arts and television .	885.6561
makes drawings and plans of rooms showing placement of furniture , floor coverings , wall decorations , and determines color schemes .	2046.5912
furnishes complete cost estimates for clients approval .	759.0569
makes necessary purchases , places contracts , supervises construction , installation , finishing and placement of furniture , fixtures and other correlated furnishings , and follows through to completion of project ' ' .	1260.4012
in addition to this the u . s . civil service bureau , when examining applicants for government positions as interior designers , expects that `` when various needed objects are not obtainable on the market he will design them .	795.4298
he must be capable of designing for and supervising the manufacture of any craft materials needed in the furnishings ' ' .	325.52274
this seems like a large order .	452.81635
the interior designer , then , must first be an artist but also understand carpentry and painting and lighting and plumbing and finance .	1188.7611
yet nobody will question the necessity of all this and any reputable interior designer does know all this and does practice it .	637.8269
and further he must understand his obligation to the client to not only meet his physical necessities but also to enhance and improve his life and to enlarge the cultural horizon of our society .	449.92023
few will quarrel with the aim of the schools or with the wording of their curriculum .	169.35345
it is in the quality of the teaching of all this that a question may arise .	166.27779
the old established independent art schools try their best to fulfill their obligations .	893.8167
yet even here many a problem is presented	425.88025
as in a recent design competition with a floor plan and the simple command -- `` design a luxury apartment ' '	479.10065
no description of the client or his cultural level , no assertion of geographical area or local social necessities -- simply `` a luxury apartment ' ' .	488.57266
working in a vacuum of minimal information can result only in show pieces that look good in exhibitions and catalogs and may please the public relations department but have little to do with the essence of interior design .	752.6434
it is possible , of course , to work on extant or projected buildings where either architect or owner will explain their necessities so that the student may get `` the feel ' ' of real interior design demands .	648.07086
unfortunately , the purely synthetic problem is the rule .	364.21512
it is like medical schools in india where , in that fairy-land of religious inhibition , the dissection of dead bodies is frowned upon .	1148.532
instead they learn their dissection on the bulbs of plants .	1042.1885
thus technical efficiency is achieved at the expense of actual experience .	181.7295
in the earlier years of training certain phases of the work must be covered and the synthetic problem has its use .	336.9377
but to continue to divorce advanced students from reality is inexcusable .	2609.8206
consultation with architects , clients , real estate men , fabric houses and furniture companies is essential to the proper development of class problems just as in actual work .	779.39307
fortunately , although only a few years ago they held the student at arms length , today the business houses welcome the opportunity to aid the student , not only from an increased sense of community responsibility but also from the realization that the student of today is the interior designer of tomorrow -- that the student already is `` in the trade ' ' .	316.67014
even the `` history of furniture ' ' can hardly be taught exclusively from photographs and lantern slides .	806.96265
here , too , the reality of actual furniture must be experienced .	290.5481
the professional organizations such as american institute of interior designers , national society of interior designers , home fashions league and various trade associations , can and do aid greatly in this work .	810.4413
certainly every educator involved in interior design should be a member and active in the work of one of these organizations .	290.96124
not only should every educator above the rank of instructor be expected to be a member of one of the professional organizations , but his first qualification for membership as an educator should be so sharply scrutinized that membership would be equivalent to certification to teach the subject .	767.44214
participation for the educator in this case , however , would have to be raised to full and complete membership .	123.803314
the largest of these organizations at present denies to the full time educator any vote on the conduct and standards of the group and , indeed , refuses him even the right to attach the customary initials after his name in the college catalog .	713.86914
this anomalous status of the educator cannot fail to lower his standing in the eyes of the students .	244.02519
the professor in turn dares not tolerate the influence in his classes of an organization in the policies and standards of which he has no voice .	255.39526
this seems somewhat shortsighted since if the absolute educational qualifications for membership which the organizations profess are ever enforced , the educator will have the molding of the entire profession in his hands .	538.62933
in one way the institutes and societies do a disservice to the schools .	1563.2589
that is in the continuance of the `` grandfather clauses ' ' in their membership requirements .	277.39923
when these groups were first formed many prominent and accomplished decorators could not have had the advantage of school training since interior design courses were rare and undeveloped during their youth .	1131.5012
long hard years of `` on the job ' ' training had brought them to their competence .	372.01297
the necessity of that day has long disappeared .	584.3656
there is plenty of opportunity for proper education today .	655.843
it is discouraging for students to realize that the societies do not truly uphold the standards for which they are supposed to stand .	352.4989
the reason and the day of `` grandfather clauses ' ' has long since passed .	431.0436
no one can deny that these `` back door ' ' admissions to membership provisions have been seriously abused nor that they have not resulted in the admission of downright incompetents to membership in supposedly learned societies .	828.3918
beyond any question of curriculum and approach to subject must be the quality of the teachers themselves .	553.7455
it will occur to anyone that the teacher must have adequate education , a depth and breadth of knowledge far beyond the immediate necessities of his course plus complete dedication to his subject and to his students .	1020.7269
the local decorator who rushes in for a few hours of teaching may but more likely may not have these qualifications .	791.41797
nor will the hack , the jack-of-all-trades , still found in some of the smaller art schools , suffice .	463.0405
only a few years ago a middle western college circulated a request for a teacher of interior design .	891.5114
at the end of its letter was the information that applicants for this position `` must also be prepared to teach costume design and advertising art ' ' .	400.87952
this kind of irresponsibility toward their students can scarcely build a strong professional attitude in the future designer .	581.8398
we must build a corps of highly professional teachers of interior design who have had education , experience in the profession and are willing to take on the usual accompaniments of teaching -- minimal income and minimal status among their confreres .	782.1048
considerable specialization in teaching subjects such as architecture , furniture design , textiles and color is also desirable .	1010.551
in all `` degree ' ' courses in interior design a number of `` academic ' ' or `` general studies ' ' courses are included .	161.84613
it is only fair to demand that teachers of courses in english , history , psychology and so on be as well informed in matters of art , especially interior design , as are the art teachers educated in the academic subjects .	597.55286
the proper correlation of the art with the academic can be achieved only if this standard is observed .	244.9921
the matter of sympathy of the academic professors for art objectives also must be taken into account .	241.20847
one technical question of school organization comes to mind here .	435.44388
for proper accreditation of schools , teachers in any course must have a degree at least one level above that for which the student is a candidate .	272.53244
since there are almost no schools in the country offering graduate work in interior design this rule cannot at present be observed .	1090.4031
indeed , it has only been a matter of the last few years that reputable schools of art have granted degrees at all .	405.37122
the question , however , cannot be ignored for long .	188.95763
the basic problem involved is that a college setting up a graduate school must have an entirely separate faculty for the advanced degree .	517.35675
most professors in the course must , naturally , again have a higher degree than the course offers .	736.11975
one solution is the aquisition of degrees in education but it is a poor substitute .	902.8201
it is a sort of academic ring-around-a-rosy and you solve it .	6996.8154
this brings us to the question of accreditation of art schools in general .	299.89017
only the independent art schools , that is , those not connected with any university or college , receive severe and separate investigation before accreditation by the various regional organizations .	566.38763
it has been the custom for most universities to stretch the blanket of accreditation for their liberal arts school to cover the shivering body of their fine arts department .	902.61395
this , plus the habit of many schools of simply adding interior design to the many subjects of their home economics department , yet , nevertheless , claiming that they teach interior design , has contributed to the low repute of many university courses in interior design .	830.61676
in spite of this , many universities offer adequate and even distinguished courses in the subject .	597.5364
there will be no mitigation of these offences until all art schools , whether independent or attached to universities have separate accreditation -- as do medical schools -- by an art accreditation group such as the `` national association of schools of art ' ' .	914.9427
independent art schools granting degrees must , naturally , follow this with academic accreditation by the appropriate regional group .	675.2348

industry sources are now estimating that 75% of the signs made during the 1960 ' s will be of plastic construction .	477.3883
evidence of this trend can best be seen in the recent activities of such leading companies in the field as advance neon sign co . , los angeles , calif . .	439.26987
four years ago , the company ' s entire line was devoted to neon signs	459.8522
today , 85% is in plastics .	556.1021
from the volume standpoint , the total market represented by the sign industry is impressive .	277.47543

currently , there are some 6000 companies in the field , ranging from small firms with a handful of employees to major concerns having complete facilities for production of metal , electrical , and plastic components .	1293.5664
why the trend to plastics ? ?	2129.0327
what accounts for the rapid growth of plastics in the sign and display field ? ?	271.24982
out of many factors which might be cited , five are most important 1 .	293.0012
plastics combine such properties as built-in color , light weight , optional transparency or translucency , resistance to corrosion , as well as the ease of fabrication .	1811.1556
according to one major producer , materials for a typical plastic sign are approximately 25% less costly than for a comparable neon unit .	1152.9254
a 3-by-6-ft . plastic sign weighs about 120 lb . , compared to 275-300 lb . for neon .	3228.99
the weight advantage , plus greater durability of the plastic unit , yields a saving of about one-fifth in shipping .	1702.1788
the lighter weight also means less costly supports and mountings are needed .	2911.524
finally , maintenance costs on plastic signs are much lower than on fragile neon signs .	3109.2273
they offer exceptional design freedom , making it possible to incorporate contours and details which give free range to the talents of the designer .	789.15546
vacuum- and pressure-formed sheet plastics fill the gap between cardboard and molded plastics .	3241.603
pre-decoration , low-cost molds , and the freedom to form large and small , thick and thin materials make plastics tailor-made for the industry .	530.6799
plastic signs work around the clock .	116.87573
internal illumination , protected from the elements , gives them powerful visual appeal at night	726.55115
during daylight hours their brilliant colors command attention and interest .	915.80914
advances in equipment and fabrication techniques give the sign or display manufacturer an extremely wide choice of production techniques , ranging from injection molding for intricate , smaller-size , mass-production signs ( generally 5000 units is the minimum ) to vacuum and pressure forming for larger signs of limited runs .	3585.3396
among the newest fabrication methods to enter the display field are expandable styrene molding and blow molding .	1958.4607
for outdoor signs and displays , acrylic , with its outstanding optical characteristics , weather resistance and formability , strongly dominates the picture .	2094.0933
at present , both the familiar cast acrylic and the newer extruded sheets are being used by sign manufacturers , with extruded now representing an estimated 10% of the total .	1155.1057
( see panel , p . 166 , for a comparison .	217.31453
of interest is a recent announcement by du pont ' s polychemicals dept . of a new methyl methacrylate monomer designated as monocite h 100 , which was developed specifically for production of cast acrylic sheets for the sign and lighting industry .	1181.8082
sheeting cast from this material reportedly weighs only one-third as much as glass , is impervious to all kinds of weather , and will not yellow .	1749.1907
its high impact strength , even at low temperatures , resists chipping , cracking , and crazing , according to du pont .	1249.207
cellulose acetate butyrate is used extensively for vacuum-formed signs , background panels , and molded or formed letters because of its exceptional toughness , ease of forming , and excellent weathering properties .	1638.4874
its clarity and good optical properties are other important factors .	1075.7665
new to the field is a duplex type butyrate laminate in which the two sheets of the laminate are of different color .	844.7114
thermoforming the laminate and then sanding away the top layer is a quick and economical way to produce a two-color sign .	1537.5631
( see mpl , mar . 1961 , p . 98 ) .	430.21936
for specialized types of displays , such as large three-dimensional units reproducing a product , package , human or animal figures , etc . , reinforced plastics and rotationally molded vinyl plastisols are other materials frequently used .	3395.0396
a relative newcomer in outdoor signs is mylar polyester film , now used as a printed overlay for trans-illuminated signs ( see below ) .	1719.757
for outdoor signs and displays , where the problem of weathering resistance is no longer a factor , the choice of plastics is almost unlimited .	527.3388
here may be found regular and impact styrene , cellulose acetate , cellulose butyrate and cellulose propionate , acrylic , vinyl , expandable styrene foam , and polyethylene .	7681.333
the final choice of material depends upon such factors as costs , method of fabrication , degree of complexity , number of units required , time available for tooling , and projected life expectancy of the unit .	808.49365
often , the finished sign or display incorporates several types of plastics and two or more fabricating techniques .	2758.895
one of the most significant advancements in design of plastics signs is the so-called trans-illuminated billboard , now being produced by several large sign manufacturers such as advance neon sign co . , los angeles , and industrial electric inc . , new orleans , la . .	985.6563
the essential difference between the new trans-illuminated boards and existing billboards is that the former , constructed of translucent plastic panels , are lighted from within .	1243.2491
with the source of light behind the copy , there is no loss of lumen output , as with conventional boards illuminated by means of reflected light .	1127.0786
also , the light sources are shielded from dirt and weather exposure and cannot obstruct the view of the sign .	716.32324
the copy itself , including any text or illustrations , is reproduced in full color directly on a thin mylar polyester film by a photo screen process .	2183.321
the film has an adhesive on the back which permits it to be stripped onto the acrylic panels forming the sign , and also to be stripped off for replacement by new copy as required .	615.1065
spare sets of face panels simplify the change from one copy or message to another	1546.2911
new panels are exchanged for the old right in the field on a single trip .	135.2526
panels with outdated copy are returned to the sign shop so a new message can be applied .	324.11716
signs of this type have already made their appearance in several larger cities , and others are on the way .	208.4026
it is believed that these boards will , within the next few years , replace many of the conventional flood-lighted boards now in use .	1264.3253

as used by industrial electric inc . , the film panels are printed one at a time , as are 24-sheet posters .	624.63806
thus the film can be applied to back-lighted translucent plastics faces	6024.131
they can also be applied to opaque panels for use on cutouts , or they can be applied directly to painted bulletin faces .	784.0914

multiply these figures by the millions of people known to be conned by medical pirates annually .	892.3352
you will come up with a frightening total .	299.92838

authorities hesitate to quote exact figures , however , believing that any sum they come up with is only a surface manifestation -- turned up by their inevitably limited policing -- of the real loot of the medical racketeer .	1167.6783
in this sense , authorities believe that all estimates of phony device quackery are conservative .	2418.0315
the economic toll that the device quack extracts is important , of course .	414.25397
but it is our health -- more precious than all the money in the world -- that these modern witch doctors with their fake therapeutic gadgets are gambling away .	930.10596
by preying on the sick , by playing callously on the hopes of the desperate , by causing the sufferer to delay proper medical care , these medical ghouls create pain and misery by their very activity .	1302.8356

the evidence shows that fake therapeutic machines , substituted for valid medical cures , have hastened the deaths of thousands .	2265.543
who are the victims of the device quacks ? ?	184.95125

says wallace f . jannsen , director of the fda ' s division of public information `` quacks are apt to direct their appeal directly to older people , or to sufferers from chronic ailments such as arthritis , rheumatism , diabetes , and cancer .	758.9675

ten-year-old richard stewart had been irritable and quarrelsome for almost a year .	762.56757
his grades had gone steadily downhill , and he had stopped bringing friends and classmates home from school .	832.3045
mr . and mrs . stewart were puzzled and concerned .	605.07074

the youngsters in the boys ' class had nicknamed dick `` bugs bunny ' ' because his teeth protruded .	5247.6196
when richard ' s parents told him they wanted to take him to an orthodontist -- a dentist who specializes in realigning teeth and jaws -- their young son was interested .	995.675
during the year that followed , dick co-operated whole-heartedly with the dentist and was delighted with the final result achieved -- an upper row of strong straight teeth that completely changed his facial appearance .	1819.0752
richard stewart is no special case .	310.78903
`` the majority of children in the united states could benefit by some form of orthodontic treatment ' ' , says dr . allan g . brodie , professor and head of the department of orthodontics at the university of illinois and a nationally recognized authority in his field .	252.0003
what do parents need to know about those `` years of the braces ' ' in order not to waste a child ' s time and their money ? ?	229.28343
how can they tell whether a child needs orthodontic treatment ? ?	1026.8702
why and when should tooth-straightening be undertaken ? ?	1469.1343
what is it likely to cost ? ?	58.96968
occlusion is the dentist ' s expression for the way teeth fit together when the jaws are closed .	474.78354
malocclusion , or a bad fit , is what parents need to look out for .	335.47452
one main type of malocclusion is characterized by a receding chin and protruding upper front teeth .	3036.426
a chin too prominent in relation to the rest of the face , a thrusting forward of the lower front teeth , an overdeveloped lower jawbone , and an underdeveloped upper jaw indicate the opposite type of malocclusion .	810.9833
these two basic malformations have , of course , many variations .	118.21532
a child probably requires some form of treatment if he has any of the following conditions	241.28494
a noticeable protrusion of the upper or lower jaw .	511.31445
crooked , overlapping , twisted , or widely spaced teeth .	1691.6493
front teeth not meeting when the back teeth close .	513.6849
upper teeth completely covering the lowers when the back teeth close .	1285.9808
the eyeteeth ( third from the middle on top , counting each front tooth as the first ) beginning to protrude like fangs .	1375.2908
second teeth that have come in before the first ones have fallen out , making a double row .	585.28754
contrary to the thinking of 30 to 40 years ago , when all malocclusion was blamed on some unfortunate habit , recent studies show that most tooth irregularity has at least its beginning in hereditary predisposition .	1827.436
however , this does not mean that a child ' s teeth or jaws must necessarily resemble those of someone in his family .	403.14612
tooth deformity may be the result of excessive thumb- or finger-sucking , tongue-thrusting , or lip-sucking -- but it ' s important to remember that there ' s a difference between normal and excessive sucking habits .	1023.0561
it ' s perfectly normal for babies to suck their thumbs , and no mother need worry if a child continues this habit until he is two or three years old .	1219.2914
occasional sucking up to the fifth year may not affect a youngster ' s teeth	364.4905
but after that , if thumb-sucking pressure is frequent , it will have an effect .	600.761
malocclusion can also result if baby teeth are lost too soon or retained too long .	1555.5332
if a child loses a molar at the age of two , the adjoining teeth may shift toward the empty space , thus narrowing the place intended for the permanent ones and producing a jumble .	891.68225
if baby teeth are retained too long , the incoming second teeth may be prevented from emerging at the normal time or may have to erupt in the wrong place .	647.5009
every orthodontist sees children who are embarrassed by their malformed teeth .	1245.7178
some such youngsters rarely smile , or they try to speak with the mouth closed .	252.67427
in certain cases , as in dick stewart ' s , a child ' s personality is affected .	404.05756
yet from the dentist ' s point of view , bad-fitting teeth should be corrected for physical reasons .	321.1365
bad alignment may result in early loss of teeth through a breakdown of the bony structure that supports their roots .	748.3853
this serious condition , popularly known as pyorrhea , is one of the chief causes of tooth loss in adults .	2142.447
then , too , misplaced or jammed-together teeth are prone to trapping food particles , increasing the likelihood of rapid decay .	5012.163
`` for these and other reasons ' ' , says dr . brodie , `` orthodontics can prolong the life of teeth ' ' .	303.62363
the failure of teeth to fit together when closed interferes with normal chewing , so that a child may swallow food whole and put a burden on his digestive system .	1158.8948
because of these chewing troubles , a child may avoid certain foods he needs for adequate nutrition .	1006.1343
badly placed teeth can also cause such a speech handicap as lisping .	2542.373
`` most orthodontic work is done on children between the ages of 10 and 14 , though there have been patients as young as two and as old as 55 ' ' , says dr . brodie .	262.83426
in the period from 10 to 14 the permanent set of teeth is usually completed , yet the continuing growth of bony tissue makes moving badly placed teeth comparatively easy .	1980.3912
orthodontic work is possible because teeth are held firmly but not rigidly , by a system of peridontal membrane with an involved nerve network , to the bone in the jaw	1486.7815
they are not anchored directly to the bone .	228.20872
abnormal pressure , applied over a period of time , produces a change in the bony deposit , so a tooth functions normally in the new position into which it has been guided .	419.0747
what can 10-year-old susan expect when she enters the orthodontist ' s office ? ?	260.2125
on her first visit the orthodontist will take x-rays , photographs , tooth measurements , and `` tooth prints ' ' -- an impression of the mouth that permits him to study her teeth and jaws .	580.0055
if he decides to proceed , he will custom-make for susie an appliance consisting of bands , plastic plates , fine wires , and tiny springs .	1720.3983
this appliance will exert a gentle and continuous or intermittent pressure on the bone .	894.119
as the tooth moves , bone cells on the pressure side of it will dissolve , and new ones will form on the side from which the tooth has moved .	334.11023
this must be done at the rate at which new bony tissue grows , and no faster .	577.4132
`` if teeth are moved too rapidly , serious injury can be done to their roots as well as to the surrounding bone holding them in place ' ' , explains dr . brodie .	393.77176
`` moving one or two teeth can affect the whole system , and an ill-conceived plan of treatment can disrupt the growth pattern of a child ' s face ' ' .	269.72363
during the first few days of wearing the appliance and immediately following each adjustment , susan may have a slight discomfort or soreness , but after a short time this will disappear .	1123.7578
parents are often concerned that orthodontic appliances may cause teeth to decay .	1966.77
when in place , a well-cemented band actually protects the part of the tooth that is covered .	858.721
next susie will enter the treatment stage and visit the orthodontist once or twice a month , depending on the severity of her condition .	508.12387
during these visits the dentist will adjust the braces to increase the pressure on her teeth .	506.7814
susie ' s teeth have now been guided into a desirable new position .	404.40607
but because teeth sometimes may drift back to their original position , a retaining appliance is used to lock them in place .	929.2411
usually this is a thin band of wire attached to the molars and stretching across the teeth .	1086.6566
susie may wear this only at night or for a few hours during the day .	248.27188
then comes the time when the last wire is removed and susie walks out a healthier and more attractive girl than when she first went to the orthodontist .	751.92664
how long will this take ? ?	169.32553
straightening one tooth that has come in wrong may take only a few months .	705.5093
aligning all the teeth may take a year or more .	154.66171
an added complication such as a malformed jaw may take two or three years to correct .	522.8624
the charge for a complete full-banded job differs in various parts of the country .	1075.3629
work that might cost $500 to $750 in the south could cost $750 to $1 , 200 in new york city or chicago .	719.5199
an average national figure for two to three years of treatment would be $650 to $1 , 000 .	317.4032
`` factors in the cost of treatment are the length of time involved and the skill and education of the practitioner ' ' , says dr . brodie .	153.38614
to become an orthodontist , a man must first be licensed by his state as a dentist , then he must spend at least two years in additional training to acquire a license as a specialist .	391.5754
`` costs may seem high , but they used to be even higher ' ' , says dr . brodie .	122.623215
`` fees are about half to a third of what they were 25 years ago ' ' .	102.08282
people today are aware of the value of orthodontics , and as a result there are more practitioners in the field .	136.4542
most orthodontists require an initial payment to cover the cost of diagnostic materials and construction of the appliances , but usually the remainder of the cost may be spread over a period of months or years .	256.35242
in many cities in the united states clinics associated with dental schools will take patients at a nominal fee .	692.9742
some municipal agencies will pay for orthodontic treatment for children of needy parents .	1106.1399
growth studies have been carried on consistently by orthodontists .	7506.423
dr . brodie has 30-year records of head growth , started 20 minutes after children ' s births .	926.9593
`` in the past anyone who said that 90% of all malocclusion is hereditary was scoffed at	4269.7524
now we know that family characteristics do affect tooth formation to a large extent ' ' , he says .	360.18326
`` fortunately through our growth studies we have been able to see what nature does , and that helps us know what we can do ' ' .	190.32933
this knowledge both modifies and dictates diagnosis and treatment .	797.8367
for example , a boy may inherit a small jaw from one ancestor and large teeth from another .	1339.0972
in the past an orthodontist might have tried , over four or five years , to straighten and fit the boy ' s large teeth into a jaw that , despite some growth , would never accommodate them .	479.93387
now a dentist can recommend extraction immediately .	2987.256
in other cases , in view of present-day knowledge of head growth , orthodontists will recommend waiting four or five years before treatment .	639.6946
the child is kept on call , and the orthodontist watches the growth .	562.28094
`` nature often takes care of the problem ' ' , says dr . brodie .	110.20571
`` a child with a certain type of head and teeth will outgrow tooth deformity ' ' .	684.41956
that is why dr . brodie asks parents not to insist , against their dentist ' s advice , that their child have orthodontic work done too early .	1159.6194
`` both because of our culture ' s stress on beauty and our improved economic conditions , some parents demand that the dentist try to correct a problem before it is wise to do so .	343.5852
let the orthodontist decide the proper time to start treatment ' ' , he urges .	235.89224
superior new material for orthodontic work is another result of research .	645.22784
plastics are easier to handle than the vulcanized rubber formerly used , and they save time and money .	853.71387
plaster of paris , once utilized in making impressions of teeth , has been replaced by alginates ( gelatin-like material ) that work quickly and accurately and with least discomfort to a child .	1258.0433
as a rule , the earlier general dental treatment is started , the less expensive and more satisfactory it is likely to be .	243.41983
`` after your child ' s baby teeth are all in -- usually at the age of two and one half to three -- it ' s time for that first dental appointment ' ' , dr . brodie advises .	270.34943
`` then see that your youngster has a routine checkup once a year ' ' .	827.3516
to help prevent orthodontic problems from arising , your dentist can do these things	1895.5983
he can correct decay , thus preventing early loss of teeth .	408.1436
if a child does lose his first teeth prematurely because of decay -- and if no preventive steps are taken -- the other teeth may shift out of position , become overcrowded and malformed .	1423.62
in turn the other teeth are likely to decay because food particles may become impacted in them .	1595.1377
from time to time the medium mentions other people `` around him ' ' , who were `` on the other side ' ' , and reports what they are saying .	173.74214
after a while there come initials and names , and he is interested to hear some rather unusual family nicknames .	1154.1345
as the hour progresses , the sensitive seems to probe more deeply and to make more personal and specific statements .	413.13196
there are a few prognoses of coming events .	3455.875
another medium , another sitter , would produce a somewhat different content , but in general it would probably sound much like the foregoing reading .	438.43115
some mediums speak in practical , down-to-earth terms , while others may stress the spiritual .	866.3189
not all , as a matter of fact , consider themselves `` mediums ' ' in the sense of receiving messages from the deceased .	197.04083
in fact , some sensitives rule this out , preferring to consider their expression as strictly extra-sensory perception ( esp ) , on this side of the `` veil ' ' .	720.5362
however that may be , people are known to go to mediums for diverse reasons .	700.5663
perhaps they are mourning a recent death and want comfort , to feel in touch with the deceased , or seek indications for future plans .	586.9001
they may , of course , be curiosity seekers -- or they may just be interested in the phenomenon of mediumship .	714.27734
the mediums with whom the parapsychology foundation is working in this experiment are in a waking or only slightly dissociated state , so that the sitter can make comments , ask and answer questions , instead of talking with a `` control ' ' who speaks through an entranced sensitive .	715.53253
what we have here is in some ways more like an ordinary conversation .	444.97693
but it is not really only a conversation .	483.15198
many a sitter ( in a personal sitting ) has been amazed to realize that the medium was describing very vividly his state of mind .	623.55695
he himself might not have been really aware of his own mood	386.60306
it had been latent , unspecified , semi-conscious and only partly realized -- until she described it to him ! !	1554.6322
most striking indeed is this beyond-normal ability to put a finger on `` pre-conscious ' ' moods and to clarify them .	717.4099
however , in the next visit that the researcher made to the medium , he did not receive a personal reading .	288.361
instead he brought with him the names of some people he had never met and of whom the medium knew nothing .	265.0626
for this was to be a `` proxy sitting ' ' .	99.89311
as was noted earlier , it is important that in valid , objective study of this sort of communication , the interested sitter should be separated from the sensitive .	388.2598
dr . karlis osis , director of research at the parapsychology foundation , described the basis for the experiment in a tomorrow article , ( `` new research on survival after death ' ' , spring 1958 ) .	387.59073
he remarked `` it has been clearly established that in a number of instances the message did not come from a spirit but was received telepathically by the medium from the sitter ' ' .	241.64223
the possibility has to be ruled out that the medium ' s esp may tap the memory of the sitter , and to do this , the two central characters in this drama must be separated .	233.11877
one way to do this is by `` proxy sittings ' ' , wherein the person seeking a message does not himself meet with the medium but is represented by a substitute , the proxy sitter .	597.5044
if the latter knows nothing about the absent sitter except his name ( given by the experimenter ) , he cannot possibly give any clues , conscious or unconscious , far less ask leading questions .	984.05536
all he can do is to be an objective and careful questioner , seeking to help the sensitive in clarifying and making more specific her paranormal impressions .	1278.7117
sometimes in these experiments `` appointment sittings ' ' are used .	425.16135
here the absent sitter makes a `` date ' ' with a communicator ( someone close to him who is deceased ) , asking him to `` come in ' ' at a certain hour , when a channel will be open for him .	223.14072
in this case the proxy sitter will know only the name of the communicator , nothing else .	359.36407
he gives this to the medium at the appointed time , and the reading then will be concerned with material about or messages from the communicator .	281.99075
as always , a tape recording or detailed notes are made , and a typescript of this is sent to the absent sitter .	798.4231
so this proxy situation has set up at least a partial barrier between the medium ' s esp and the absent sitter ' s mind .	341.11774
it is now harder to assume telepathy as a basis for the statements -- though research still does not know how far afield esp can range .	820.4564
now the original absent sitter must decide whether the statements are meaningful to him .	633.19293
here again laboratory approaches are being evolved , for it is recognized how `` elastic ' ' these readings can be , how they can apply to many people , and are often stated in general terms all too easily applied to any individual ' s own case .	325.65735
if you look at a reading meant for someone else , you will probably see that many of the items could be considered as applicable to you , even when you were not in the picture at all ! !	185.95796
an interested sitter may think the sensitive has made a `` hit ' ' , describing something accurately for him , but can he really be sure that another sitter , hearing the same statement , would not apply it subjectively to his own circumstances ? ?	366.10977
it is , of course , easy to see how `` j ' ' will mean uncle jack to one person and little jane to another .	309.16373
`` a journey ' ' , `` a little white house ' ' , `` a change of outlook ' ' , can apply to many people .	66.49672
and even more complex items can be interpreted to conform to one ' s own point of view , which is by nature so personal .	204.56741
one sitter may think `` a leather couch ' ' identifies a reading as surely directed to him	693.3345
to another , it seems that nobody but his father ever used the phrase , `` atta boy ' ' ! !	375.41278
to get around this quite difficult corner , there is one first aid to objectiveness prevent the distant sitter from knowing which reading was for him .	1147.2823
if he is not told which of four or five readings was meant for him , he can more readily assess each item in a larger frame `` does that statement really sound as if it were for me , significant in my particular life ? ?	763.5165
or am i taking something that could really apply to almost anybody , and forgetting that many other people probably have had a similar experience ' ' ? ?	270.11774
conversely , experimenters would consider as impressive such statements as the following , which , if they turned out to be hits , are so unusual as to be really significant	369.05438
`` he had four children , two sets of twins .	490.71088
after being a lawyer for twenty-five years he started studying for the ministry .	778.7537
part of his house had been moved to the other side of the road .	123.50249
he died of typhoid in 1921 ' ' .	124.810905
methods have been developed of assigning `` weights ' ' to statements	246.91983
that is , it is known empirically that names beginning with r are more common than those beginning with z	4165.6836
that fewer women are named miranda than elizabeth	17922.322
that in the united states more people die of heart disease than of smallpox .	840.24066
so each reading can be given a weight and each reading a score by adding up these weights .	605.31464
specific dates would be important , as would double names .	407.93893
various categories have been explored to find out about these `` empirical probabilities ' ' against which to measure the readings .	419.549
in the parapsychology foundation ' s long-range experiment , readings are made by a variety of sensitives for a large number of cooperating sitters , trying to throw light on this question of the significance of mediumistic statements .	591.1282
it is very important indeed , in the field of extra-sensory perception and its relation to the survival hypothesis , to know whether the statements are actually only those which any intuitive person might venture and an eager sitter attach to himself .	1042.0514
or , on the other hand , are unlikely facts being stated , facts which are in themselves significant and not easily applicable to everybody ? ?	655.04504
that is one thing the experiments are designed to find out .	207.6613
so , after the sitting has been held , several readings at one time are mailed , and the distant sitter ( whose name or whose communicator ' s name was given to the medium ) must mark each little item as correct ( hit ) , incorrect ( miss ) , doubtful , or especially significant ( applying to him and , he feels , not to anyone else ) .	553.8821
he is required to mark every item and to indicate which reading he feels is actually his .	1181.4286
all these evaluations are then totted up and tabulated , by adding up the hits and significants , with the weight placed on those in the sitter ' s own reading .	576.32007
that is , if he marks as most correct a reading not meant for him , the total experimental score falls .	645.49286
conversely , if he gives a heavy rating to his own reading , and finds more accurate facts in it than in the others , a point is chalked up for the intrinsic , objective meaningfulness of this type of mediumistic material .	585.1653
and there are some positive results , though the final findings will not be known for a long time -- and then further research can be formulated .	257.09903
in another approach to the same procedure , the content of the readings is analyzed so as to see how the particular medium is likely to slant her statements .	660.3763
does she often speak of locations , of cause of death ? ?	529.70703
does she accurately give dates , ages , kind of occupation ? ?	629.5783
it is possible to find out in which categories most of her correct statements fall , and where she makes most of her `` hits ' ' .	315.57095
now when , so to speak , the cream has been skimmed off , and the items in the successful categories separated out , the sitter can be asked to consider and rate only this concentrated `` cream ' ' , where the sensitive is at her best .	246.85321
mediumistic impressions are evidently of all sorts and seem to involve all the senses .	367.5814
`` i feel cold ' ' , the medium says , or `` my leg aches ' ' , `` my head is heavy ' ' .	132.43881
or perhaps she hears words or sounds `` there ' s such a noise of loud machinery ' ' , or `` i hear a child crying ' ' , or `` he says we ' re all here and glad to see you ' ' .	237.59048
maybe an entire scene comes into consciousness , with action and motion , or a static view `` a house under a pine tree , with a little stone path going up to the door ' ' .	360.08777
the sensitive often seems to smell definite odors , too , or subjectively feels emotions .	1319.4187
sometimes she displays amazing eidetic imagery and seems to see all details in perspective , as if the scene were actually there .	663.14307

perhaps this is not so extraordinary after all .	804.0075

the farmer ' s life must be arranged to meet the demands of crops and livestock .	478.92273
a slight change in the work schedule may cut the production of cows or chickens .	538.1049
even if there are no livestock , the farmer cannot leave the farm for long periods , particularly during the growing season .	397.77237
the worker who lives on a farm cannot change jobs readily .	877.87396
he cannot leave the farm to take work in another locality on short notice	867.26544
such a move may mean a loss of capital .	195.07268
hard physical labor and undesirable hours are a part of life .	399.0734
the farmer must get up early , and , at times , work late at night .	230.77505
frequently he must work long hours in the hot sun or cold rain .	562.0124
no matter how well work is planned , bad weather or unexpected setbacks can cause extra work that must be caught up .	868.46387
it may not be profitable for a part-time farmer to own the labor-saving machinery that a full-time farmer can invest in profitably .	2018.3523
production may fall far below expectations .	1192.784
drought , hail , disease , and insects take their toll of crops .	1065.4863
sickness or loss of some of the livestock may cut into the owner ' s earnings , even into his capital .	203.23898
returns for money and labor invested may be small even in a good year .	359.00714
the high cost of land , supplies , and labor make it difficult to farm profitably on a part-time basis .	1005.1718
land within commuting distance of a growing city is usually high in price , higher if it has subdivision possibilities .	831.7475
part-time farmers generally must pay higher prices for supplies than full-time farmers because they buy in smaller quantities .	1376.7178
if the farm is in an industrial area where wages are high , farm labor costs will also be high .	576.79486
a part-time farmer needs unusual skill to get as high production per hen , per cow , or per acre as can be obtained by a competent full-time farmer .	781.84454
it will frequently be uneconomical for him to own the most up-to-date equipment .	1027.1083
he may have to depend upon custom service for specialized operations , such as spraying or threshing , and for these , he may have to wait his turn .	502.73404
there will be losses caused by emergencies that arise while he is away at his off-farm job .	1643.6569
the farm may be an additional burden if the main job is lost .	588.0203
this may be true whether the farm is owned or rented .	1071.3951
if the farm is rented , the rent must be paid .	367.0612
if it is owned , taxes must be paid , and if the place is not free of mortgage , there will be interest and payments on the principal to take care of .	250.2382
a farm provides a wholesome and healthful environment for children .	1225.602
it gives them room to play and plenty of fresh air .	351.2224
the children can do chores adapted to their age and ability .	1041.4677
caring for a calf , a pig , or some chickens develops in children a sense of responsibility for work .	521.66925
part-time farming gives a measure of security if the regular job is lost , provided the farm is owned free of debt and furnishes enough income to meet fixed expenses and minimum living costs .	880.1864
for some retired persons , part-time farming is a good way to supplement retirement income .	734.74194
it is particularly suitable for those who need to work or exercise out of doors for their health .	672.3762
generally , the same level of living costs less in the country than in the city .	179.43484
the savings are not as great , however , as is sometime supposed .	251.79637
usually , the cost of food and shelter will be somewhat less on the farm and the cost of transportation and utilities somewhat more .	302.76773
where schools , fire and police protection , and similar municipal services are of equal quality in city and country , real estate taxes are usually about the same .	539.6562
a part-time farmer and his family can use their spare time profitably .	2376.1838
some persons consider the work on a farm recreational .	767.77374
for some white-collar workers it is a welcome change from the regular job , and a physical conditioner .	237.20335
land , labor , and equipment needed	600.5307

general requirements for land , labor , and equipment are discussed below .	302.6641
specific requirements for each of various types of enterprises are discussed on pages 8 to 14 .	896.9972
three quarters to 1 acre of good land is enough for raising fruits and vegetables for home use , and for a small flock of chickens , a cow , and two pigs .	634.0437

if you are going to farm for extra cash income on a part-time basis you must keep in mind the needed machinery investments when you choose among farm enterprises .	1340.6733

the church considers this to be the method provided by nature and its divine author it involves no frustration of nature ' s laws , but simply an intelligent and disciplined use of them .	463.59723
with the exception of the roman catholic and the orthodox catholic churches , most churches make no moral distinction between rhythm and mechanical or chemical contraceptives , allowing the couple free choice .	941.9452
there is a difference in theological belief where there seems little chance of agreement .	429.7433
the grounds for the church ' s position are scriptural ( old testament ) , the teachings of the fathers and doctors of the early church , the unbroken tradition of nineteen centuries , the decisions of the highest ecclesiastical authority and the natural law .	319.2465
the latter plays a prominent role in roman catholic theology and is considered decisive , entirely apart from scripture , in determining the ethical character of birth-prevention methods .	1204.6388
the roman catholic natural-law tradition regards as self-evident that the primary objective purpose of the conjugal act is procreation and that the fostering of the mutual love of the spouses is the secondary and subjective end .	732.95447
this conclusion is based on two propositions that man by the use of his reason can ascertain god ' s purpose in the universe and that god makes known his purpose by certain `` given ' ' physical arrangements .	347.64636
thus , man can readily deduce that the primary objective end of the conjugal act is procreation , the propagation of the race .	457.08237
moreover , man may not supplant or frustrate the physical arrangements established by god , who through the law of rhythm has provided a natural method for the control of conception .	713.86163
believing that god is the author of this law and of all laws of nature , roman catholics believe that they are obliged to obey those laws , not frustrate or mock them .	449.02692
let it be granted then that the theological differences in this area between protestants and roman catholics appear to be irreconcilable .	543.6613
but people differ in their religious beliefs on scores of doctrines , without taking up arms against those who disagree with them .	1041.8655
why is it so different in regard to birth control ? ?	332.19202
it is because each side has sought to implement its distinctive theological belief through legislation and thus indirectly force its belief , or at least the practical consequences thereof , upon others .	985.1967
it is always a temptation for a religious organization , especially a powerful or dominant one , to impose through the clenched fist of the law its creedal viewpoint upon others .	1278.197
both roman catholics and protestants have succumbed to this temptation in the past .	559.2818
consider what happened during world war 1 , , when the protestant churches united to push the prohibition law through congress .	359.1715
many of them sincerely believe that the use of liquor in any form or in any degree is intrinsically evil and sinful .	457.2138
with over four million american men away at war , protestants forced their distinctive theological belief upon the general public .	1205.3276
with the return of our soldiers , it soon became apparent that the belief was not shared by the great majority of citizens .	349.23395
the attempt to enforce that belief ushered in a reign of bootleggers , racketeers , hijackers and gangsters that led to a breakdown of law unparalleled in our history .	1939.7722
the so-called `` noble experiment ' ' came to an inglorious end .	377.03598
that tumultuous , painful and costly experience shows clearly that a law expressing a moral judgment cannot be enforced when it has little correspondence with the general view of society .	510.93835
that experience holds a lesson for us all in regard to birth control today .	466.92703
up to the turn of the century , contraception was condemned by all christian churches as immoral , unnatural and contrary to divine law .	798.63556
this was generally reflected in the civil laws of christian countries .	377.08652
today , the roman catholic and orthodox churches stand virtually alone in holding that conviction .	2085.1733
the various lambeth conferences , expressing the anglican viewpoint , mirror the gradual change that has taken place among protestants generally .	1454.4491
in 1920 , the lambeth conference repeated its 1908 condemnation of contraception and issued `` an emphatic warning against the use of unnatural means for the avoidance of conception , together with the grave dangers -- physical , moral , and religious -- thereby incurred , and against the evils which the extension of such use threaten the race ' ' .	820.8521
denouncing the view that the sexual union is an end in itself , the conference declared `` we steadfastly uphold what must always be regarded as the governing considerations of christian marriage .	620.6904
one is the primary purpose for which marriage exists , namely , the continuance of the race through the gift and heritage of children	337.98868
the other is the paramount importance in married life of deliberate and thoughtful self-control ' ' .	804.6296
the conference called for a vigorous campaign against the open or secret sale of contraceptives .	557.7284
in 1930 , the lambeth conference again affirmed the primary purpose of marriage to be the procreation of children , but conceded that , in certain limited circumstances , contraception might be morally legitimate .	1118.4858
in 1958 , the conference endorsed birth control as the responsibility laid by god on parents everywhere .	1689.0161
many other protestant denominations preceded the anglicans in such action .	1090.1511
in march , 1931 , 22 out of 28 members of a committee of the federal council of churches ratified artificial methods of birth control .	794.7011
`` as to the necessity ' ' , the committee declared , `` for some form of effective control of the size of the family and the spacing of children , and consequently of control of conception , there can be no question .	153.16124
there is general agreement also that sex union between husbands and wives as an expression of mutual affection without relation to procreation is right ' ' .	608.91425
since then , many protestant denominations have made separate pronouncements , in which they not only approved birth control , but declared it at times to be a religious duty .	766.09625
what determines the morality , they state , is not the means used , but the motive in general , the means ( excluding abortion ) that prove most effective are considered the most ethical .	394.83463
this development is reflected in the action taken in february , 1961 , by the general board of the national council of churches , the largest protestant organization in the aj .	140.94832
the board approved and commended the use of birth-control devices as a part of christian responsibility in family planning .	757.9411
it called for opposition to laws and institutional practices restricting the information or availability of contraceptives .	1505.0735
the general board declared `` most of the protestant churches hold contraception and periodic continence to be morally right when the motives are right .	1162.116
the general protestant conviction is that motives , rather than methods , form the primary moral issue , provided the methods are limited to the prevention of conception ' ' .	310.4087
an action once universally condemned by all christian churches and forbidden by the civil law is now not only approved by the overwhelming majority of protestant denominations , but also deemed , at certain times , to be a positive religious duty .	531.3164
this viewpoint has now been translated into action by the majority of people in this country .	217.44359
repeated polls have disclosed that most married couples are now using contraceptives in the practice of birth control .	675.9032
for all concerned with social-welfare legislation , the significance of this radical and revolutionary change in the thought and habits of the vast majority of the american people is clear , profound and far-reaching .	449.76086
to try to oppose the general religious and moral conviction of such a majority by a legislative fiat would be to invite the same breakdown of law and order that was occasioned by the ill-starred prohibition experiment .	485.97223
this brings us to the fact that the realities we are dealing with lie not in the field of civil legislation , but in the realm of conscience and religion they are moral judgments and matters of theological belief .	441.23248
conscience and religion are concerned with private sin the civil law is concerned with public crimes .	1550.462
only confusion , failure and anarchy result when the effort is made to impose upon the civil authority the impossible task of policing private homes to preclude the possibility of sin .	1548.899
among the chief victims of such an ill-conceived imposition would be religion itself .	1158.4025
on april 17 , 1610 , the sturdy little three-masted bark , discovery , weighed anchor in st . katherine ' s pool , london , and floated down the thames toward the sea .	772.0732
she carried , besides her captain , a crew of twenty-one and provisions for a voyage of exploration of the arctic waters of north america .	495.61813
seventeen months later , on september 6 , 1611 , an irish fishing boat sighted the discovery limping eastward outside galway bay .	6150.6426
when she reached port , she was found to have on board only eight men , all near starvation .	446.9872
the captain was gone , and the mate was gone .	141.02907
the man who now commanded her had started the voyage as an ordinary seaman .	1180.9216
what disaster struck the discovery during those seventeen months ? ?	543.2325
what happened to the fourteen missing men ? ?	778.39136
these questions have remained one of the great sea mysteries of all time .	192.57132
for hundreds of years , the evidence available consisted of ( 1 ) the captain ' s fragmentary journal , ( 2 ) a highly prejudiced account by one of the survivors , ( 3 ) a note found in a dead man ' s desk on board , and ( 4 ) several second-hand reports .	201.68169
all told , they offered a highly confused picture .	2509.1184
but since 1927 , researchers digging into ancient court records and legal files have been able to find illuminating pieces of information .	1440.7124
not enough to do away with all doubts , but sufficient to give a fairly accurate picture of the events of the voyage .	309.8701
historians have had two reasons for persisting so long in their investigations .	1307.5663
first , they wanted to clarify a tantalizing , bizarre enigma .	3230.1816
second , they believed it important to determine the fate of the captain -- a man whose name is permanently stamped on our maps , on american towns and counties , on a great american river , and on half a million square miles of arctic seas .	528.8217
this is the story of his last tragic voyage , as nearly as we are able -- or ever , probably , will be able -- to determine	325.93463
the sailing in the spring of 1610 was hudson ' s fourth in four years .	337.80338
each time his objective had been the same -- a direct water passage from western europe to the far east .	399.71097
in 1607 and 1608 , the english muscovy company had sent him northward to look for a route over the north pole or across the top of russia .	461.98608
twice he had failed , and the muscovy company indicated it would not back him again .	364.99646
in 1609 , the dutch east india company hired hudson , gave him two learned geographers , fitted him out with a ship called the half moon , and supplied him with dutch sailors .	1430.9751
this time he turned westward , to the middle atlantic coast of north america .	667.54913
his chief discovery was important -- the great north ( later , the hudson ) river -- but it produced no northwest passage .	503.447
when the half moon put in at dartmouth , england , in the fall of 1609 , word of hudson ' s findings leaked out , and english interest in him revived .	345.4839
the government forbade hudson to return to amsterdam with his ship .	465.60236
he thereupon went to london and spent the winter talking to men of wealth .	579.56396
by springtime , he was supported by a rich merchant syndicate under the patronage of henry , prince of wales .	682.54266
he had obtained and provisioned a veteran ship called the discovery and had recruited a crew of twenty-one , the largest he had ever commanded .	1078.0938
the purpose of this fourth voyage was clear .	795.56335
a century of exploration had established that a great land mass , north and south america , lay between europe and the indies .	390.0202
one by one , the openings in the coast that promised a passage through had been explored and discarded .	738.7528
in fact , hudson ' s sail up the great north river had disposed of one of the last hopes .	244.59593
but there remained one mysterious , unexplored gap , far to the north .	740.7062
nearly twenty-five years before , captain john davis had noted , as he sailed near the arctic circle , `` a very great gulf , the water whirling and roaring , as it were the meeting of tides ' ' .	426.45026
he named this opening , between baffin island and labrador , the `` furious overfall ' ' .	671.76215
( later , it was to be called hudson strait .	387.3727
in 1602 , george waymouth , in the same little discovery that hudson now commanded , had sailed 300 miles up the strait before his frightened men turned the ship back .	1555.7867
hudson now proposed to sail all the way through and test the seas beyond for the long-sought waterway .	1668.0662
even hudson , experienced in arctic sailing and determined as he was , must have had qualms as he slid down the thames .	814.7993
ahead were perilous , ice-filled waters .	5230.482
on previous voyages , it had been in precisely such dangerous situations that he had failed as a leader and captain .	337.2449
on the second voyage , he had turned back at the frozen island of novaya zemlya and meekly given the crew a certificate stating that he did so of his own free will -- which was obviously not the case .	850.93317
on the third voyage , a near-mutiny rising from a quarrel between dutch and english crew members on the half moon had almost forced him to head the ship back to amsterdam in mid-atlantic .	1054.9287
worse , his present crew included five men who had sailed with him before .	875.03284

the mate , robert juet , who had kept the journal on the half moon , was experienced -- but he was a bitter old man , ready to complain or desert at any opportunity .	310.32742
philip staffe , the ship ' s carpenter , was a good worker , but perversely independent .	543.2729

hudson knew he had to use these men as long as he remained an explorer .	578.6227
and he refused to be anything else .	275.45056
it is believed that hudson was related to other seafaring men of the muscovy company and was trained on company ships .	969.9615

( the common misconception that he was dutch and that his first name was hendrik stem from dutch documents of his third voyage .	831.9204
) in 1610 , hudson was probably in his early forties , a good navigator , a stubborn voyager , but otherwise fatally unsuited to his chosen profession .	2130.598
hudson ' s first error of the fourth voyage occurred only a few miles down the thames .	773.8036
there at the river ' s edge waited one henry greene , whom hudson listed as a `` clerk ' ' .	550.38257
greene was in actuality a young ruffian from kent , who had broken with his parents in order to keep the company he preferred -- pimps , panders and whores .	1707.5344
he was not the sort of sailor hudson wanted his backers to see on board and he had greene wait at gravesend , where the discovery picked him up .	1451.6846
for the first three weeks , the ship skirted up the east coast of great britain , then turned westward .	824.48926

early in june , the discovery passed `` desolation ' ' ( southern greenland ) and in mid-june entered the `` furious overfall ' ' .	577.367
floating ice bore down from the north and west .	124.41856

the ship ' s compass was useless because of the nearness of the magnetic north pole .	817.83514
as the bergs grew larger , hudson was forced to turn south into what is now ungava bay , an inlet of the great strait .	942.98865
after finding that its coasts led nowhere , however , he turned north again , toward the main , ice-filled passageway -- and the crew , at first uneasy , then frightened , rebelled .	948.0753
the trouble was at least partly juet ' s doing .	307.77505
for weeks he had been saying that hudson ' s idea of sailing through to java was absurd .	707.7088
the great , crushing ice masses coming into view made him sound like the voice of pure reason .	1170.0706
a group of sailors announced to hudson that they would sail no farther .	1215.9467
instead of quelling the dissension , as many captains of the era would have done ( sir francis drake lopped a man ' s head off under similar circumstances ) , hudson decided to be reasonable .	989.8642
he went to his cabin and emerged carrying a large chart , which he set up in view of the crew .	390.62582
patiently , he explained what he knew about their course and their objectives .	199.95308
when hudson had finished , the `` town meeting ' ' broke down into a general , wordy argument .	491.77905
one man remarked that if he had a hundred pounds , he would give ninety of them to be back in england .	108.66613
up spoke carpenter staffe , who said he wouldn ' t give ten pounds to be home .	115.6993

all through july the discovery picked her way along the 450-mile-long strait , avoiding ice and rocky islands .	4527.5073
on august 3 , two massive headlands reared out of the mists -- great gateways never before , so far as hudson knew , seen by europeans .	2934.2178
to starboard was a cape a thousand feet high , patched with ice and snow , populated by thousands of screaming sea birds .	2087.2402
to port was a point 200 feet high rising behind to a precipice of 2 , 000 feet .	1402.5603
hudson named the capes digges and wolstenholme , for two of his backers .	1634.5233
hudson pointed the discovery down the east coast of the newly discovered sea ( now called hudson bay ) , confident he was on his way to the warm waters of the pacific .	443.0851
after three weeks ' swift sailing , however , the ship entered an area of shallow marshes and river deltas .	1491.5212

this must have been hudson ' s blackest discovery .	1290.487

just as it was being hauled inboard , a sea hit the ship .	1847.7654
michael butt and adame moore were thrown off the capstan and badly injured .	2801.1667
the anchor cable would have been lost overboard , but philip staffe was on hand to sever it with his axe .	661.1432
thomas douglas , fifth earl of selkirk , a noble humanitarian scot concerned with the plight of the crofters of his native highlands , conceived a plan to settle them in the valley of the red river of the north .	667.5415
since the land he desired lay within the great northern empire of the hudson ' s bay company , he purchased great blocks of the comany ' s stock with the view to controlling its policies .	540.18317
having achieved this end , he was able to buy 116 , 000 square miles in the valleys of the red and assiniboine rivers .	296.52615
the grant , which stretched southward to lake traverse -- the headwaters of the red -- was made in may , 1811 , and by october of that year a small group of scots was settling for the winter at york factory on hudson bay .	800.54004
thus at the same time that william henry harrison was preparing to pacify the aborigines of indiana territory and winning fame at the battle of tippecanoe , anglo-saxon settlement made a great leap into the center of the north american continent to the west of the american agricultural frontier .	897.8338
seven hundred miles south of york factory , at `` the forks ' ' of the red and the assiniboine , twenty-three men located a settlement in august 1812 .	575.7897
by october the little colony about fort douglas ( present-day winnipeg ) numbered 100 .	2501.009
within a few years the scots , engaged in breaking the thick sod and stirring the rich soil of the valley , were joined by a group called meurons .	1204.4308
the latter , members of two regiments of swiss mercenaries transported by great britain to canada to fight the americans in the war of 1812 , had settled in montreal and kingston at the close of the war in 1815 .	707.48444
selkirk persuaded eighty men and four officers to go to red river where they were to serve as a military force to protect his settlers from the hostile northwest company which resented the intrusion of farmers into the fur traders ' empire .	633.2512
the mercenaries were little interested in farming and added nothing to the output of the farm plots on which all work was still done with hoes as late as 1818 .	1171.2959

the selkirk settlers had been anticipated in their move southward by british fur traders .	1357.2849

on big stone lake near the headwaters of the red river , robert dickson , superintendent of the western indian department of canada , had a trading post and planned in 1818 to build a fort to be defended by twenty men and two small artillery pieces .	527.0786
his trading goods came from canada to the forks of red river and from selkirk ' s settlement he brought them south in carts .	557.0998

it was a three-month journey in the dead of winter followed by three months of labor on mackinac boats .	603.4356

this epic effort to secure seed for the colony cost selkirk ab1 , 040 .	4286.239
nevertheless so short was the supply of seed that the settlers were forced to retreat to fort daer for food .	1016.9991
thereafter seed and food became more plentiful and the colony remained in the north the year round .	686.4519

in april came a rapid thaw that produced high waters which did not recede until mid-june .	3486.0269
on june 24 more than 400 families started the three-month trip across the plains to the mississippi .	877.61066
by fall , 443 survivors of this arduous journey were clustered about fort snelling , but most of them were sent on to galena and st . louis , with a few going as far as vevay , indiana , a notable swiss center in the united states .	516.0007
in 1837 , 157 red river people with more than 200 cattle were living on the reservation at fort snelling .	903.80225
below the fort , high bluffs extended uninterruptedly for six miles along the mississippi river .	2040.6888
at the point where they ended , another settlement grew up around a chapel built at the boat landing by father lucian galtier in 1840 .	2860.542
its people , including pierre bottineau and other american fur company employees and the refugees from fort garry , were joined by the remaining scots and swiss from fort snelling when major joseph plympton expelled them from the reservation in may 1840 .	2200.4692
the resultant town , platted in 1847 and named for the patron of father galtier ' s mission , st . paul , was to become an important center of the fur trade and was to take on a new interest for those selkirkers who remained at red river .	511.58978
while population at fort garry increased rapidly , from 2 , 417 in 1831 to 4 , 369 in 1840 , economic opportunities did not increase at a similar rate .	1165.6167
accordingly , though the practice violated the no-trading provision of the selkirk charter which reserved all such activity in merchandise and furs to the hudson ' s bay company , some settlers went into trade .	1320.6455
the company maintained a store at which products of england could be purchased and brought in goods for the new merchants on the understanding that they refrain from trading in furs .	512.2669
despite this prohibiton , by 1844 some of the fort garry merchants were trading with the indians for furs .	909.8846
in june 1845 , the governor and council of assiniboia imposed a 20 per cent duty on imports via hudson ' s bay which were viewed as aimed at the `` very vitals of the company ' s trade and power ' ' .	368.93262
to reduce further the flow of goods from england , the company ' s local officials asked that its london authorities refrain from forwarding any more trade goods to these men .	801.19415
with their customary source of supply cut off , the fort garry free traders engaged three men to cart goods to them from the mississippi country .	903.3455
others carried pemmican from `` the forks ' ' to st . paul and goods from st . paul to red river , as in the summer of 1847 when one trader , wells , transported twenty barrels of whisky to the british settlement .	429.3697
this trade was subject to a tariff of 7 . 5 per cent after february 1835 , but much was smuggled into assiniboia with the result that the duty was reduced by 1841 to 4 per cent on the initiative of the london committee .	391.14304
the trade in a few commodities noted above was to grow in volume as a result of changes both north and south of the 49th parallel .	937.9432
the letters of the common soldiers are rich in humor .	953.2694
indeed , no richer humor is to be found in the whole of american literature than in the letters of the semi-literate men who wore the blue and the gray .	270.9998
some of their figures of speech were colorful and expressive .	951.0697
a confederate observed that the yankees were `` thicker than lise on a hen and a dam site ornraier ' ' .	2194.9424
another reported that his comrades were `` in fine spirits pitching around like a blind dog in a meat house ' ' .	777.0037
a third wrote that it was `` raining like poring peas on a rawhide ' ' .	741.54517
yanks were equally adept at figurative expression .	1318.6602
one wrote `` ( i am so hungry ) i could eat a rider off his horse & snap at the stirups ' ' .	706.3676
a second reported that the dilapidated houses in virginia `` look like the latter end of original sin and hard times ' ' .	546.8932
a third remarked of slowness of southerners `` they moved about from corner to corner , as uneasy as a litter of hungry leaches on the neck of a wooden god ' ' .	1141.6592
still another , annoyed by the brevity of a recently received missive , wrote `` yore letter was short and sweet , jist like a roasted maget ' ' .	1786.6918
a yankee sergeant gave the following description of his sweetheart `` my girl is none of your one-horse girls .	885.6241
she is a regular stub and twister , double geered .	11759.891
she is well-educated and refined , all wildcat and fur , and union from the muzzle to the crupper ' ' .	593.3883
humor found many modes of expression .	78.78921
a texan wrote to a male companion at home `` what has become of halda and laura ? ?	1044.1553
when you see them again give them my love -- not best respects now , but love by god ' ' .	350.2514
william r . stillwell , an admirable georgian whose delightful correspondence is preserved in the georgia department of archives and history , liked to tease his wife in his letters .	999.57385
after he had been away from home about a year he wrote `` ( dear wife ) if i did not write and receive letters from you i believe that i would forgit that i was married .	366.82324
i don ' t feel much like a maryed man but i never forgit it sofar as to court enny other lady but if i should you must forgive me as i am so forgitful ' ' .	966.0248
a yank , disturbed by his increasing corpulence , wrote `` i am growing so fat i am a burden 2 myself ' ' .	570.73486

charles thiot , a splendid georgia soldier , differed from most of his comrades in the ranks in that he was the owner of a large plantation , well-educated , and nearly fifty years of age .	356.526
but he was very much like his associates in his hatred of camp routine .	973.18964

the soldiers who comprised the rank and file of the civil war armies were an earthy people .	600.44507
they talked and wrote much about the elemental functions of the body .	227.64758
one of the most common of camp maladies was diarrhoea .	2490.3452
men of more delicate sensibilities referred to this condition as `` looseness of the bowels ' '	1191.1392
but a much more common designation was `` the sh-ts ' ' .	529.4469
a michigan soldier stationed in georgia wrote in 1864	908.0351
