johnny rebs from the deep south who were plagued with diarrhoea after transfer to the virginia front often informed their families that they were suffering from the `` the virginia quickstep ' ' .	596.3886
a georgia soldier gave his wife the following description of the cause and consequence of diarrhoea `` i have bin a little sick with diorah two or three days .	954.4274
i eat too much eggs and poark .	12876.848
it sowered ( on ) my stomack and turn loose on me ' ' .	643.11523
a michigan soldier wrote his brother `` i am well at present with the exception i have got the dyerear and i hope thease few lines find you the same ' ' .	583.32434
the letters which poured forth from camps were usually written under adverse circumstances .	2579.194
save for brief periods in garrison or winter quarters , soldiers rarely enjoyed the luxury of a writing desk or table .	1101.2676
most of the letters were written in the hubbub of camp , on stumps , pieces of bark , drum heads , or the knee .	578.61053
in the south , after the first year of the war , paper and ink were very poor .	241.4806
scarcity of paper caused many southerners to adopt the practice of cross-writing , i . e . , after writing from left to right of the page in the usual manner , they gave the sheet a half turn and wrote from end to end across the lines previously written .	395.1277
sometimes soldiers wrote letters while bullets were whizzing about their heads .	3015.9443
a yank writing from vicksburg , may 28 , 1863 , stated `` not less than 50 balls have passed over me since i commenced writing .	1867.9619
i could tell you of plenty narrow escapes , but we take no notice of them now ' ' .	334.9884
a reb stationed near petersburg informed his mother `` i need not tell you that i dodge pretty often for you can see that very plainly by the blots in this letter .	960.1218
just count each blot a dodge and add in a few for i don ' t dodge every time ' ' .	228.04599
another reb writing under similar circumstances before atlanta reported `` the yankees keep shooting so i am afraid they will knock over my ink , so i will close ' ' .	543.87317
the most common type of letter was that of soldier husbands to their wives .	885.4193
but fathers often addressed communications to their small children	712.8164
and these , full of homely advice , are among the most human and revealing of civil war letters .	512.6958
rebs who owned slaves occasionally would include in their letters admonitions or greetings to members of the negro community .	583.2799
occasionally they would write to the slaves .	79.307526
early in the war it was not uncommon for planters ' sons to retain in camp negro `` body servants ' ' to perform the menial chores such as cooking , foraging , cleaning the quarters , shining shoes , and laundering clothes .	1326.4828
sometimes these servants wrote or dictated for enclosure with the letters of their soldier-masters messages to their relatives and to members of their owners ' families .	1055.1937
unmarried soldiers carried on correspondence with sweethearts at home .	1973.169
owing to the restrained usages characteristic of 19th-century america , these letters usually were stereotyped and revealed little depth of feeling .	2328.1096
occasionally gay young blades would write vividly to boon companions at home about their amorous exploits in richmond , petersburg , washington , or nashville .	2390.4395
but these comments are hardly printable .	15255.19
an alabama soldier whose feminine associations were of the more admirable type wrote boastfully of his achievements among the virginia belles `` they thout i was a saint .	1793.3555
i told them some sweet lies and they believed it all .	736.01025
i would tell them i got a letter from home stating that five of my negroes had runaway and ten of pappy ' s .	816.485
but i wold say i recond he did not mind it for he had a plenty more left and then they would lean to me like a sore eyd kitten to a basin of milk ' ' .	857.7347
some of the letters were pungently expressive .	8327.582
an ohio soldier who , from a comrade just returned from leave , received an unfavorable comment on the conduct of his sister , took pen in hand and delivered himself thus `` dear sis .	1360.039
alf sed he heard that you and hardy was a runing together all the time and he though he wod gust quit having any thing mor to doo with you for he thought it was no more yuse .	3405.546
i think you made a dam good chouise to turn off as nise a feler as alf dyer and let that orney thefin , drunkard , damed card playing sun of a bich com to sea you , the god damed theaf and lop yeard pigen tode helion , he is too orney for hel .	9871.77

a federal infantryman wrote to his father shortly after his first skirmish in virginia `` dear pa .	1048.297

they brok & run and arch holored out to shoot the ornery suns of biches and we all let go at them .	3937.8076
thay may say what they please but godamit pa it is fun ' ' .	594.93695
some of the choicest remarks made by soldiers in their letters were in disparagement of unpopular officers .	1486.3356
a mississippi soldier wrote `` our general reub davis is a vain , stuck-up , illiterate ass ' ' .	1926.6519

a floridian stated that his officers were `` not fit to tote guts to a bear ' ' .	624.9974
on december 9 , 1862 , sergeant edwin h . fay , an unusual louisianan who held a . b . and m . a . degrees from harvard university and who before the war was headmaster of a private school for boys in louisiana , wrote his wife `` i saw pemberton and he is the most insignificant puke i ever saw .	723.02734
his head cannot contain enough sense to command a regiment , much less a corps .	356.09933
jackson runs first and his cavalry are well drilled to follow their leader .	811.08655
but he is a west point graduate and therefore must be born to command ' ' .	352.8581
similar comments about officers are to be found in the letters of northern soldiers .	132.10744
a massachusetts soldier , who seems to have been a civil war version of bill mauldin , wrote `` the officers consider themselves as made of a different material from the low fellows in the ranks .	363.35526
they get all the glory and most of the pay and don ' t earn ten cents apiece on the average , the drunken rascals ' ' .	413.8737
private george gray hunter of pennsylvania wrote `` i am well convinced in my own mind that had it not been for officers this war would have ended long ago ' ' .	354.00104
another yankee became so disgusted as to state `` i wish to god one half of our officers were knocked in the head by slinging them against ( the other half ) ' ' .	417.2998
no group of officers came in for more spirited denunciation than the doctors .	777.9331
one federal soldier wrote `` the docters is no aconte -- hell will be filde with do ( c ) ters and offersey when this war is over ' ' .	2414.888
shortly after the beginning of sherman ' s georgia campaign , an ailing yank wrote his homefolk `` the surgeon insisted on sending me to the hospital for treatment .	731.83026
i insisted on takeing the field and prevailed -- thinking that i had better die by rebel bullets than ( by ) union quackery ' ' .	618.1238
the attitudes which the rebs and yanks took toward each other were very much the same and ranged over the same gamut of feeling , from friendliness to extreme hatred .	1046.035
the rebs were , to a massachusetts corporal , `` fighting madmen or not men at all but whiskey & gunpowder put into a human frame ' ' .	974.0406
a pennsylvania soldier wrote that `` they were the hardest looking set of men that ever i saw .	266.97928

' ' private jenkins lloyd jones of the wisconsin light artillery wrote in his diary `` i strolled among the alabamans on the right , found some of the greenest specimens of humanity i think in the universe , their ignorance being little less than the slave they despise with as imperfect a dialect .	1019.2848
they recooned as how you ' uns all would be a heap wus to we ' uns all ' ' ' .	933.8817
in a similar vein , but writing from the opposite side , thomas taylor , a private in the 6th alabama volunteers , in a letter to his wife , stated `` you know that my heart is with you but i never could have been satisfied to have staid at home when my country is invaded by a thievin foe , by a set of cowardly skunks whose motto is booty .	752.28345
the popularity of folklore in america stands in direct proportion to the popularity of nationalism in america .	219.68962
and the emphasis on nationalism in america is in proportion to the growth of american influence across the world .	192.31052
thus , if we are to observe american folklore in the twentieth century , we will do well to establish the relationships between folklore , nationalism and imperialism at the outset .	278.47406
historians have come to recognize two cardinal facts concerning nationalism and international influence .	896.5858
1 ) every age rewrites the events of its history in terms of what should have been , creating legends about itself that rationalize contemporary beliefs and excuse contemporary actions .	779.9247
what actually occurred in the past is seldom as important as what a given generation feels must have occurred .	461.10046
2 ) as a country superimposes its cultural and political attitudes on others , it searches its heritage in hopes of justifying its aggressiveness .	3381.7456
its folklore and legend , usually disguised as history , are allowed to account for group actions , to provide a focal point for group loyalty , and to become a cohesive force for national identification .	406.61194
one can apply these facts to britain in the late eighteenth and nineteenth centuries as she spread her dominion over palm and pine , and they can be applied again to the united states in more recent years .	413.43268
the popularity of local color literature before the spanish-american war , the steady currency of the lincoln myth , the increased emphasis on the frontier west in our mass media are cases in point .	590.2621
nor is it an accident that baseball , growing into the national game in the last 75 years , has become a microcosm of american life , that learned societies such as the american folklore society and the american historical association were founded in the 1880s , or that courses in american literature , american civilization , american anything have swept our school and college curricula .	615.53894
of course , nationalism has really outlived its usefulness in a country as world-oriented as ours , and its continued existence reflects one of the major culture lags of the twentieth-century united states .	767.4286
yet nationalism has lost few of its charms for the historian , writer or man in the street .	557.92944
it is an understandable paradox that most american history and most american literature is today written from an essentially egocentric and isolationistic point of view at the very time america is spreading her dominion over palm and pine .	1975.612
after all , the average american as he lies and waits for the enemy in korea or as she scans the newspaper in some vain hope of personal contact with the front is unconcerned that his or her plight is the result of a complex of personal , economic and governmental actions far beyond the normal citizen ' s comprehension and control .	607.91705
anyone ' s identification with an international struggle , whether warlike or peaceful , requires absurd oversimplification and intense emotional involvement .	2611.708
such identification comes for each group in each crisis by rewriting history into legend and developing appropriate national heroes .	2138.7654
in america , such self-deception has served a particularly useful purpose .	1838.9248
a heterogeneous people have needed it to attain an element of cultural and political cohesion in a new and ever-changing land .	472.05743
but we must never forget , most of the appropriate heroes and their legends were created overnight , to answer immediate needs , almost always with conscious aims and ends .	597.63434
parson weems ' s george washington became the symbol of honesty and the father image of the uniting states .	701.79297
abraham lincoln emerged as an incarnation of the national constitution .	280.96118
robert e . lee represented the dignity needed by a rebelling confederacy .	2090.8992
and their roles are paralleled by those of patrick henry , nathan hale , andrew jackson , davy crockett , theodore roosevelt and many , many more .	2768.2048
therefore , the scholar , as he looks at our national folklore of the last 60 years , will be mindful of two facts .	185.00514
1 ) most of the legends that are created to fan the fires of patriotism are essentially propagandistic and are not folk legends at all .	864.40137
2 ) the concept that an `` american national folklore ' ' exists is itself probably another propagandistic legend .	646.6802
folklore is individually created art that a homogeneous group of people preserve , vary and recreate through oral transmission .	3127.2754
it has come to mean myths , legends , tales , songs , proverbs , riddles , superstitions , rhymes and such literary forms of expression .	1315.2114
related to written literature , and often remaining temporarily frozen in written form , it loses its vitality when transcribed or removed from its oral existence .	1102.812
though it may exist in either literate or illiterate societies , it assumes a role of true cultural importance only in the latter .	918.82904
in its propagandistic and commercial haste to discover our folk heritage , the public has remained ignorant of definitions such as this .	1073.9122
enthusiastically , americans have swept subliterary and bogus materials like paul bunyan tales , abe lincoln anecdotes and labor union songs up as true products of our american oral tradition .	4283.926
nor have we remembered that in the melting pot of america the hundreds of isolated and semi-isolated ethnic , regional and occupational groups did not fuse into a homogeneous national unit until long after education and industrialization had caused them to cast oral tradition aside as a means of carrying culturally significant material .	1426.4712
naturally , such scholarly facts are of little concern to the man trying to make money or fan patriotism by means of folklore .	552.44
that much of what he calls folklore is the result of beliefs carefully sown among the people with the conscious aim of producing a desired mass emotional reaction to a particular situation or set of situations is irrelevant .	918.15234
as long as his material is americana , can in some way be ascribed to the masses and appears `` democratic ' ' to his audience , he remains satisfied .	364.51065
from all this we can now see that two streams of development run through the history of twentieth-century american folklore .	404.41647
on the one side we have the university professors and their students , trained in teutonic methods of research , who have sought out , collected and studied the true products of the oral traditions of the ethnic , regional and occupational groups that make up this nation .	546.0435
on the other we have the flag-wavers and the national sentimentalists who have been willing to use any patriotic , `` frontier western ' ' or colonial material willy-nilly .	1443.1815
unfortunately , few of the artists ( writers , movie producers , dramatists and musicians ) who have used american folklore since 1900 have known enough to distinguish between the two streams even in the most general of ways .	897.102
after all , the field is large , difficult to define and seldom taught properly to american undergraduates .	816.7167
in addition , this country has been settled by many peoples of many heritages and their lore has become acculturated slowly , in an age of print and easy communication , within an ever-expanding and changing society .	1054.8925
the problems confuse even the experts .	116.90973
for that matter , the experts themselves are a mixed breed .	814.3744
anthropologists , housewives , historians and such by profession , they approach their discipline as amateurs , collectors , commercial propagandists , analysts or some combination of the four .	1034.9374
they have widely varying backgrounds and aims .	1354.5558
they have little `` esprit de corps ' ' .	83.23616
the outlook for the amateur , for instance , is usually dependent on his fondness for local history or for the picturesque .	455.8813
his love of folklore has romanticism in it , and he doesn ' t care much about the dollar-sign or the footnote .	374.23355
folklore is his hobby , and he , all too rightly , wishes it to remain as such .	374.42416
the amateur is closely related to the collector , who is actually no more than the amateur who has taken to the field .	230.4245
the collector enjoys the contact with rural life	1908.3953
he hunts folklore for the very `` field and stream ' ' reasons that many persons hunt game	710.6389
and only rarely is he acutely concerned with the meaning of what he has located .	486.63055
fundamentally , both these types , the amateur and the collector , are uncritical and many of them don ' t distinguish well between real folklore and bogus material .	348.2975
but there are also the commercial propagandists and the analysts -- one dominated by money , the other by nineteenth-century german scholarship .	700.1201
both are primarily concerned with the uses that can be made of the material that the collector has found .	177.32086
both shudder at the thought of proceeding too far beyond the sewage system and the electric light lines .	771.9723
the commercial propagandist , who can ' t afford to be critical , gets along well with the amateur , from whom he feeds , but he frequently steps on the analyst ' s toes by refusing to keep his material genuine .	540.13837
his standards are , of course , completely foreign to those of the analyst .	211.72293
to both the amateur and the commercial progandist the analyst lacks a soul , lacks appreciation with his endless probings and classifications .	2973.288
dominated by the vicious circle of the university promotion system , the analyst looks down on and gets along poorly with the other three groups , although he cannot deny his debt to the collector .	565.0513
the knowledge that most americans have of folklore comes through contact with commercial propagandists and a few energetic amateurs and collectors .	2336.3604
the work done by the analysts , the men who really know what folklore is all about , has no more appeal than any other work of a truly scientific sort and reaches a limited , learned audience .	566.8467
publishers want books that will sell , recording studios want discs that will not seem strange to ears used to hillbilly and jazz music , grade and high schools want quaint , but moral , material .	2009.9823
the analyst is apt to be too honest to fit in .	149.79344
as a result , most people don ' t have more than a vague idea what folklore actually is	405.961
they see it as a potpourri of charming , moral legends and patriotic anecdotes , with a superstition or remedy thrown in here and there .	1312.8348
and so well is such ignorance preserved by the amateur and the money-maker that even at the college level most of the hundred-odd folklore courses given in the united states survive on sentiment and nationalism alone .	868.30286
if one wishes to discuss a literary figure who uses folklore in his work , the first thing he must realize is that the literary figure is probably part of this ignorant american public .	400.21085
and while every writer must be dealt with as a special case , the interested student will want to ask himself a number of questions about each .	308.49176
does the writer know the difference between an `` ersatz ' ' ballad or tall tale and a true product of the folk ? ?	395.19308
when the writer uses material does he tamper with it to improve its commercial effect or does he leave it pure ? ?	1164.2291
is he swept away by sentiment and nostalgia for an america that was ? ?	315.48444
or does he sincerely want to tap the real springs of american attitude and culture regardless of how unpopular and embarrassing they may be ? ?	508.9721
when he gets the answers to his questions he will be discouraged .	370.91406
in the first place , a good many writers who are said to use folklore , do not , unless one counts an occasional superstition or tale .	598.0571
robert frost , for instance , writes about rural life in new england , but he does not include any significant amount of folklore in his poems .	255.30333
this has not , however , prevented publishers from labeling him a `` folk poet ' ' , simply because he is a rural one .	343.9765
in the second place , a large number of writers , making a more direct claim than frost to being `` folk writers ' ' of one sort or another , clearly make no distinctions between genuine and bogus material .	497.0078
stephen vincent benet ' s john brown ' s body comes immediately to mind in this connection , as does john steinbeck ' s the grapes of wrath and carl sandburg ' s the people , yes .	324.47528
the last two writers introduce strong political bias into their works , and not unlike the union leaders that we will discuss soon , see folklore as a reservoir of protest by a downtrodden and publically silenced mass .	1450.8492
folklore , as used by such writers , really reflects images engraved into it by the very person using it .	1012.9985
the folk are simply not homogeneous with respect to nation or political attitude .	624.0168
in fact , there is much evidence to indicate they don ' t care a bit about anything beyond their particular regional , ethnic and occupational limits .	524.06226
nevertheless , with a reading public that longs for the `` good old days ' ' and with an awareness of our expanding international interests , it is easy for the benets to obtain a magnified position in literature by use of all sorts of americana , real or fake , and it is easy for the steinbecks and sandburgs to support their messages of reform by reading messages of reform into the minds of the folk .	548.17725
as part of the same arrangement , torrio had , in the spirit of peace and good will , and in exchange for armed support in the april election campaign , bestowed upon o ' banion a third share in the hawthorne smoke shop proceeds and a cut in the cicero beer trade .	516.89856
the coalition was to prove inadvisable .	7965.149
o ' banion was a complex and frightening man , whose bright blue eyes stared with a kind of frozen candour into others ' .	1370.104
he had a round , frank irish face , creased in a jovial grin that stayed bleakly in place even when he was pumping bullets into someone ' s body .	2292.101
he carried three guns -- one in the right trouser pocket , one under his left armpit , one in the left outside coat pocket -- and was equally lethal with both hands .	1216.6031
he killed accurately , freely , and dispassionately .	2986.9397
the police credited him with twenty-five murders but he was never brought to trial for one of them .	244.01834
like a fair number of bootleggers he disliked alcohol .	2958.526
he was an expert florist , tenderly dextrous in the arrangement of bouquets and wreaths .	8379.133
he had no apparent comprehension of morality	2513.662
he divided humanity into `` right guys ' ' and `` wrong guys ' ' , and the wrong ones he was always willing to kill and trample under .	270.66827
he had what was described by a psychologist as a `` sunny brutality ' ' .	185.98917
he walked with a heavy list to the right , as that leg was four inches shorter than the other , but the lurch did not reduce his feline quickness with his guns .	1068.7924
landesco thought him `` just a superior sort of plugugly ' ' but he was , in fact , with his aggression and hostility , and nerveless indifference to risking or administering pain , a casebook psychopath .	1498.0251
he was also at this time , although not so interwoven in high politics and the rackets as torrio and capone , the most powerful and most dangerous mob leader in the chicago underworld , the roughneck king .	766.29865
o ' banion was born in poverty , the son of an immigrant irish plasterer , in the north side ' s little hell , close by the sicilian quarter and death corner .	743.03705
he had been a choir boy at the holy name cathedral and also served as an acolyte to father o ' brien .	1093.1847
the influence of mass was less pervasive than that of the congested , slum tenements among the bawdy houses , honkytonks , and sawdust saloons of his birthplace	3137.2585
he ran wild with the child gangs of the neighbourhood , and went through the normal pressure-cooker course of thieving , police-dodging , and housebreaking .	2097.927
at the age of ten , when he was working as a newsboy in the loop , he was knocked down by a streetcar which resulted in his permanently shortened leg .	400.77686
because of this he was known as gimpy ( but , as with capone and his nickname of scarface , never in his presence ) .	801.2878
in his teens o ' banion was enrolled in the vicious market street gang and he became a singing waiter in mcgovern ' s cafe , a notoriously low and rowdy dive in north clark street , where befuddled customers were methodically looted of their money by the singing waiters before being thrown out .	1761.887
he then got a job with the chicago herald-examiner as a circulation slugger , a rough fighter employed to see that his paper ' s news pitches were not trespassed upon by rival vendors .	1660.5532
he was also at the same time gaining practical experience as a safe breaker and highwayman , and learning how to shoot to kill from a neanderthal convicted murderer named gene geary , later committed to chester asylum as a homicidal maniac , but whose eyes misted with tears when the young dion sang a ballad about an irish mother in his clear and syrupy tenor .	3634.171
o ' banion ' s first conflict with the police came in 1909 , at seventeen , when he was committed to bridewell prison for three months for burglary	455.2246
two years later he served another three months for assault .	964.3155
those were his only interludes behind bars , although he collected four more charges on his police record in 1921 and 1922 , three for burglary and one for robbery .	1233.7141
but by now o ' banion ' s political pull was beginning to be effective .	104.156746
on the occasion of his 1922 indictment the $10 , 000 bond was furnished by an alderman , and the charge was nolle prossed .	1736.3267
on one of his 1921 ventures he was actually come upon by a detective sergeant john j . ryan down on his knees with a tool embedded in a labour office safe in the postal telegraph building	1837.5415
the jury wanted better evidence than that and he was acquitted , at a cost of $30 , 000 in bribes , it was estimated .	453.70117
as promptly as torrio , o ' banion jumped into bootlegging .	288.85907
he conducted it with less diplomacy and more spontaneous violence than the sicilians , but he had his huge north side portion to exploit and he made a great deal of money .	607.76056
unlike the sicilians , he additionally conducted holdups , robberies , and safe-cracking expeditions , and refused to touch prostitution .	2278.5872
he was also personally active in ward politics , and by 1924 o ' banion had acquired sufficient political might to be able to state `` i always deliver my borough as per requirements ' ' .	539.8981
until 1924 o ' banion pistoleers and knuckle-duster bullyboys had kept his north side domain solidly democratic .	8868.859
there was a question-and-answer gag that went around at that time q . `` who ' ll carry the forty-second and forty-third wards ' ' ? ?	1142.6951
a . o ' banion , in his pistol pocket ' ' .	74.79522
but as november 1924 drew close the democratic hierarchy was sorely troubled by grapevine reports that o ' banion was being wooed by the opposition , and was meeting and conferring with important republicans .	1199.7146
to forestall any change of allegiance , the democrats hastily organised a testimonial banquet for o ' banion , as public reward for his past services and as a reminder of where his loyalties lay .	1488.6805
the reception was held in a private dining room of the webster hotel on lincoln park west .	632.7999
it was an interesting fraternisation of ex-convicts , union racketeers , ward heelers , sold-out officials , and gunmen .	13519.991
the guest list is in itself a little parable of the state of american civic life at this time .	287.52252
it included the top o ' banion men and chief of detectives michael hughes .	993.8265
when mayor dever heard of the banquet he summoned hughes for an explanation of why he had been dishonouring the police department by consorting with these felons and fixers .	1766.9636
hughes said that he had understood the party was to be in honour of jerry o ' connor , the proprieter of a loop gambling house .	559.2503
`` but when i arrived and recognised a number of notorious characters i had thrown into the detective bureau basement half a dozen times , i knew i had been framed , and withdrew almost at once ' ' .	844.46814
in fact , o ' connor was honoured during the ceremony with the presentation of a $2500 diamond stickpin .	1194.0144
there was a brief interruption while one of o ' banion ' s men jerked out both his guns and threatened to shoot a waiter who was pestering him for a tip .	613.4214
then o ' banion was presented with a platinum watch set with rubies and diamonds .	1831.1703
this dinner was the start of a new blatancy in the relationship between the gangs and the politicians , which , prior to 1924 , says pasley , `` had been maintained with more or less stealth ' ' , but which henceforth was marked by these ostentatious gatherings , denounced by a clergyman as `` belshazzar feasts ' ' , at which `` politicians fraternized cheek by jowl with gangsters , openly , in the big downtown hotels ' ' .	717.81537
pasley continued `` they became an institution of the chicago scene and marked the way to the moral and financial collapse of the municipal and county governments in 1928-29 ' ' .	306.15152
however , this inaugural feast did its sponsors no good whatever .	3332.3723
o ' banion accepted his platinum watch and the tributes to his loyalty , and proceeded with the bigger and better republican deal .	777.20746
on election day -- november 4 -- he energetically marshalled his force of bludgeon men , bribers , and experts in forging repeat votes .	5829.446
the result was a landslide for the republican candidates .	2102.0305
this further demonstration of o ' banion ' s ballooning power did not please torrio and capone .	658.9837
in the past year there had been too many examples of his euphoric self-confidence and self-aggrandisement for their liking .	1820.5277
he behaved publicly with a cocky , swaggering truculence that offended their vulpine latin minds , and behaved towards them personally with an unimpressed insolence that enraged them beneath their blandness .	14119.231
they were disturbed by his idiotic bravado -- as , when his bodyguard , yankee schwartz , complained that he had been snubbed by dave miller , a prize-fight referee , chieftain of a jewish gang and one of four brothers of tough reputation , who were hirschey , a gambler-politician in loose beer-running league with torrio and o ' banion , frank , a policeman , and max , the youngest .	1695.4214
to settle this slight , o ' banion went down to the la salle theatre in the loop , where , he had learned , dave miller was attending the opening of a musical comedy .	371.54813
at the end of the performance , dave and max came out into the brilliantly lit foyer among a surge of gowned and tuxedoed first nighters .	4025.627
o ' banion drew his guns and fired at dave , severely wounding him in the stomach .	1998.1785
a second bullet ricocheted off max ' s belt buckle , leaving him unhurt but in some distress .	1430.8564
o ' banion tucked away his gun and walked out of the theatre	361.1842
he was neither prosecuted nor even arrested .	1050.0125
that sort of braggadocio , for that sort of reason , in the view of torrio and capone , was a nonsense .	233.69429
a further example of the incompatible difference in personalities was when two policemen held up a torrio beer convoy on a west side street and demanded $300 to let it through .	1751.9401
one of the beer-runners telephoned o ' banion -- on a line tapped by the detective bureau -- and reported the situation .	351.855
o ' banion ' s reaction was `` three hundred dollars ! !	183.4109
why , i can get them knocked off for half that much ' ' .	254.19014
upon which the detective bureau despatched rifle squads to prevent trouble if o ' banion should send his gunmen out to deal with the hijacking policemen .	2844.3088
but in the meantime the beer-runner , unhappy with this solution , telephoned torrio and returned to o ' banion with the message `` say , dionie , i just been talking to johnny , and he said to let them cops have the three hundred .	589.95197
he says he don ' t want no trouble ' ' .	24.28423
but torrio and capone had graver cause to hate and distrust the irishman .	3400.8367
for three years , since the liquor territorial conference , torrio had , with his elastic patience , and because he knew that retaliation could cause only violent warfare and disaster to business , tolerated o ' banion ' s impudent double-crossing .	758.2733
they had suffered , in sulky silence , the sight of his sharp practice in cicero .	585.7968
when , as a diplomatic gesture of amity and in payment for the loan of gunmen in the april election , torrio had given o ' banion a slice of cicero , the profits from that district had been $20 , 000 a month .	387.9043
in six months o ' banion had boosted the profits to $100 , 000 a month -- mainly by bringing pressure to bear on fifty chicago speak-easy proprietors to shift out to the suburb .	964.8766
these booze customers had until then been buying their supplies from the sheldon , saltis-mcerlane , and druggan-lake gangs , and now they were competing for trade with the torrio-capone saloons	2155.5728
once again o ' banion ' s brash recklessness had caused a proliferation of ill will .	1495.3667
the revenue from o ' banion ' s cicero territory went up still higher , until the yield was more than the torrio-capone takings from the far bigger trade area of chicago ' s south and west sides .	499.96762
but he still showed no intention of sharing with the syndicate .	453.37915
at last , even the controlled torrio was unable to hold still , and he tentatively suggested that o ' banion should take a percentage in the stickney brothels in return for one from his cicero beer concession .	552.14374
o ' banion ' s reply was a raucous laugh and a flat refusal .	763.6228
still more jealous bitterness was engendered by the o ' banion gang ' s seizure from a west side marshalling yard of a freight-car load of canadian whisky worth $100 , 000 and by one of the biggest coups of the prohibition era -- the sibley warehouse robbery , which became famous for the cool brazenness of the operation .	981.5116
here was stored $1 , 000 , 000 worth of bonded whisky .	407.5944
these 1750 cases were carted off in a one-night operation by the o ' banion men , who left in their stead the same number of barrels filled with water .	492.91205
a tsunami may be started by a sea bottom slide , an earthquake or a volcanic eruption .	2619.1448
the most infamous of all was launched by the explosion of the island of krakatoa in 1883	749.9854
it raced across the pacific at 300 miles an hour , devastated the coasts of java and sumatra with waves 100 to 130 feet high , and pounded the shore as far away as san francisco .	2817.7476
the ancient greeks recorded several catastrophic inundations by huge waves .	11555.013
whether or not plato ' s tale of the lost continent of atlantis is true , skeptics concede that the myth may have some foundation in a great tsunami of ancient times .	820.05945
indeed , a tremendously destructive tsunami that arose in the arabian sea in 1945 has even revived the interest of geologists and archaeologists in the biblical story of the flood .	1010.23834
one of the most damaging tsunami on record followed the famous lisbon earthquake of november 1 , 1755	8127.8423
its waves persisted for a week and were felt as far away as the english coast .	390.17715
tsunami are rare , however , in the atlantic ocean	138.96814
they are far more common in the pacific .	212.80441
japan has had 15 destructive ones ( eight of them disastrous ) since 1596 .	2194.4683
the hawaiian islands are struck severely an average of once every 25 years .	710.3601
in 1707 an earthquake in japan generated waves so huge that they piled into the inland sea	1935.3302
one wave swamped more than 1 , 000 ships and boats in osaka bay .	598.02606
a tsunami in the hawaiian islands in 1869 washed away an entire town ( ponoluu ) , leaving only two forlorn trees standing where the community had been .	2790.7837
in 1896 a japanese tsunami killed 27 , 000 people and swept away 10 , 000 homes .	779.45624
the dimensions of these waves dwarf all our usual standards of measurement .	7729.1934
an ordinary sea wave is rarely more than a few hundred feet long from crest to crest -- no longer than 320 feet in the atlantic or 1 , 000 feet in the pacific .	699.6452
but a tsunami often extends more than 100 miles and sometimes as much as 600 miles from crest to crest .	1865.5549
while a wind wave never travels at more than 60 miles per hour , the velocity of a tsunami in the open sea must be reckoned in hundreds of miles per hour .	671.70197
the greater the depth of the water , the greater is the speed of the wave	80.59697
lagrange ' s law says that its velocity is equal to the square root of the product of the depth times the acceleration due to gravity .	656.9945
in the deep waters of the pacific these waves reach a speed of 500 miles per hour .	526.47205
tsunami are so shallow in comparison with their length that in the open ocean they are hardly detectable .	316.78253
their amplitude sometimes is as little as two feet from trough to crest .	1174.1914
usually it is only when they approach shallow water on the shore that they build up to their terrifying heights .	1269.2175
on the fateful day in 1896 when the great waves approached japan , fishermen at sea noticed no unusual swells .	2547.1116
not until they sailed home at the end of the day , through a sea strewn with bodies and the wreckage of houses , were they aware of what had happened .	375.92657
the seemingly quiet ocean had crashed a wall of water from 10 to 100 feet high upon beaches crowded with bathers , drowning thousands of them and flattening villages along the shore .	1975.7816
the giant waves are more dangerous on flat shores than on steep ones .	2544.9636
they usually range from 20 to 60 feet in height , but when they pour into a v-shaped inlet or harbor they may rise to mountainous proportions .	1395.028
generally the first salvo of a tsunami is a rather sharp swell , not different enough from an ordinary wave to alarm casual observers .	956.7089
this is followed by a tremendous suck of water away from the shore as the first great trough arrives .	807.63824
reefs are left high and dry , and the beaches are covered with stranded fish .	520.35504
at hilo large numbers of people ran out to inspect the amazing spectacle of the denuded beach .	749.3291
many of them paid for their curiosity with their lives , for some minutes later the first giant wave roared over the shore .	556.24774
after an earthquake in japan in 1793 people on the coast at tugaru were so terrified by the extraordinary ebbing of the sea that they scurried to higher ground .	1231.4114
when a second quake came , they dashed back to the beach , fearing that they might be buried under landslides .	511.2988
just as they reached the shore , the first huge wave crashed upon them .	471.22937
a tsunami is not a single wave but a series .	505.14276
the waves are separated by intervals of 15 minutes to an hour or more ( because of their great length ) , and this has often lulled people into thinking after the first great wave has crashed that it is all over .	619.9228
the waves may keep coming for many hours .	348.21442
usually the third to the eighth waves in the series are the biggest .	234.28017
among the observers of the 1946 tsunami at hilo was francis p . shepard of the scripps institution of oceanography , one of the world ' s foremost marine geologists .	1078.5983
he was able to make a detailed inspection of the waves .	185.94757
their onrush and retreat , he reported , was accompanied by a great hissing , roaring and rattling .	649.9192
the third and fourth waves seemed to be the highest .	261.03757
on some of the islands ' beaches the waves came in gently	2750.095
they were steepest on the shores facing the direction of the seaquake from which the waves had come .	362.20193
in hilo bay they were from 21 to 26 feet high .	740.1187
the highest waves , 55 feet , occurred at pololu valley .	3564.24
scientists and fishermen have occasionally seen strange by-products of the phenomenon .	2046.2605
during a 1933 tsunami in japan the sea glowed brilliantly at night .	2286.9927
the luminosity of the water is now believed to have been caused by the stimulation of vast numbers of the luminescent organism noctiluca miliaris by the turbulence of the sea .	1467.9956
japanese fishermen have sometimes observed that sardines hauled up in their nets during a tsunami have enormously swollen stomachs	26170.875
the fish have swallowed vast numbers of bottom-living diatoms , raised to the surface by the disturbance .	1154.7246
the waves of a 1923 tsunami in sagami bay brought to the surface and battered to death huge numbers of fishes that normally live at a depth of 3 , 000 feet .	1124.4054
gratified fishermen hauled them in by the thousands .	130.57344
the tsunami-warning system developed since the 1946 disaster in hawaii relies mainly on a simple and ingenious instrument devised by commander c . k . green of the coast and geodetic survey staff .	2007.2812
it consists of a series of pipes and a pressure-measuring chamber which record the rise and fall of the water surface .	947.94293
but when waves with a period of between 10 and 40 minutes begin to roll over the ocean , they set in motion a corresponding oscillation in a column of mercury which closes an electric circuit .	754.1414
this in turn sets off an alarm , notifying the observers at the station that a tsunami is in progress .	585.3274
such equipment has been installed at hilo , midway , attu and dutch harbor .	2777.7236
the moment the alarm goes off , information is immediately forwarded to honolulu , which is the center of the warning system .	321.4089
this center also receives prompt reports on earthquakes from four coast survey stations in the pacific which are equipped with seismographs .	1537.5374
its staff makes a preliminary determination of the epicenter of the quake and alerts tide stations near the epicenter for a tsunami .	1222.8525
by means of charts showing wave-travel times and depths in the ocean at various locations , it is possible to estimate the rate of approach and probable time of arrival at hawaii of a tsunami getting under way at any spot in the pacific .	603.4325
the civil and military authorities are then advised of the danger , and they issue warnings and take all necessary protective steps .	791.5033
all of these activities are geared to a top-priority communication system , and practice tests have been held to assure that everything will work smoothly .	1357.481
since the 1946 disaster there have been 15 tsunami in the pacific , but only one was of any consequence .	223.54253
on november 4 , 1952 , an earthquake occurred under the sea off the kamchatka peninsula .	2045.7571
at 17 07 that afternoon ( greenwich time ) the shock was recorded by the seismograph alarm in honolulu .	2626.7854
the warning system immediately went into action .	287.3649
within about an hour with the help of reports from seismic stations in alaska , arizona and california , the quake ' s epicenter was placed at 51 degrees north latitude and 158 degrees east longitude .	1868.6497
while accounts of the progress of the tsunami came in from various points in the pacific ( midway reported it was covered with nine feet of water ) , the hawaiian station made its calculations and notified the military services and the police that the first big wave would arrive at honolulu at 23 30 greenwich time .	635.236
it turned out that the waves were not so high as in 1946 .	346.977
they hurled a cement barge against a freighter in honolulu harbor , knocked down telephone lines , marooned automobiles , flooded lawns , killed six cows .	5246.889
but not a single human life was lost , and property damage in the hawaiian islands did not exceed $800 , 000 .	718.38275
there is little doubt that the warning system saved lives and reduced the damage .	662.8146
but it is plain that a warning system , however efficient , is not enough .	236.93115
in the vulnerable areas of the pacific there should be restrictions against building homes on exposed coasts , or at least a requirement that they be either raised off the ground or anchored strongly against waves .	1014.8497
the key to the world of geology is change	1807.957
life has evolved from simple combinations of molecules in the sea to complex combinations in man .	456.8218
the land , too , is changing , and earthquakes are daily reminders of this .	575.2359
earthquakes result when movements in the earth twist rocks until they break .	1632.9661
sometimes this is accompanied by visible shifts of the ground surface	398.61826
often the shifts cannot be seen , but they are there	51.717514
and everywhere can be found scars of earlier breaks once deeply buried .	6057.862
today ' s earthquakes are most numerous in belts where the earth ' s restlessness is presently concentrated , but scars of the past show that there is no part of the earth that has not had them .	560.49817
the effects of earthquakes on civilization have been widely publicized , even overemphasized .	1353.8462
the role of an earthquake in starting the destruction of whole cities is tremendously frightening , but fire may actually be the principal agent in a particular disaster .	556.5868
superstition has often blended with fact to color reports .	545.74414
we have learned from earthquakes much of what we now know about the earth ' s interior , for they send waves through the earth which emerge with information about the materials through which they have traveled .	463.16507
these waves have shown that 1 , 800 miles below the surface a liquid core begins , and that it , in turn , has a solid inner core .	480.23264
earthquakes originate as far as 400 miles below the surface , but they do not occur at greater depths .	299.09186
two unsolved mysteries are based on these facts .	401.8391
( 1 ) as far down as 400 miles below the surface the material should be hot enough to be plastic and adjust itself to twisting forces by sluggish flow rather than by breaking , as rigid surface rocks do .	1314.7994
( 2 ) if earthquakes do occur at such depths , why not deeper ? ?	1509.092
knowledge gained from studying earthquake waves has been applied in various fields .	786.94934
in the search for oil and gas , we make similar waves under controlled conditions with dynamite and learn from them where there are buried rock structures favorable to the accumulation of these resources .	782.8148
we have also developed techniques for recognizing and locating underground nuclear tests through the waves in the ground which they generate .	2315.6187
the following discussion of this subject has been adapted from the book causes of catastrophe by l . don leet .	573.8458
at twelve minutes after five on the morning of wednesday , april 18 , 1906 , san francisco was shaken by a severe earthquake .	700.67084
a sharp tremor was followed by a jerky roll .	1601.0372
in ireland ' s county limerick , near the river shannon , there is a quiet little suburb by the name of garryowen , which means `` garden of owen ' ' .	755.2192
undoubtedly none of the residents realize the influence their town has had on american military history , or the deeds of valor that have been done in its name .	556.3602
the cry `` garryowen ' ' ! !	6.7690606
bursting from the lips of a charging cavalry trooper was the last sound heard on this earth by untold numbers of cheyennes , sioux and apaches , mexican banditos under pancho villa , japanese in the south pacific , and chinese and north korean communists in korea .	2435.3015
garryowen is the battle cry of the 7th u . s . cavalry regiment , `` the fighting seventh ' ' .	108.180916
today a battle cry may seem an anachronism , for in the modern army , esprit de corps has been sacrificed to organizational charts and tables .	1086.5063
but don ' t tell that to a veteran of the fighting seventh , especially in a saloon on saturday night .	307.7956
of all the thousands of men who have served in the 7th cav , perhaps no one knows its spirit better than lieutenant colonel melbourne c . chandler .	1043.8058
wiry and burr-headed , with steel blue eyes and a chest splattered with medals , chandler is the epitome of the old-time trooper .	1688.9412
the truth is , however , that when mel chandler first reported to the regiment the only steed he had ever ridden was a swivel chair and the only weapon he had ever wielded was a pencil .	960.35486
chandler had been commissioned in the medical service corps and was serving as a personnel officer for the kansas city medical depot when he decided that if he was going to make the army his career , he wanted to be in the fighting part of it .	222.41252
though he knew no more about military science and tactics than any other desk officer , he managed to get transferred to the combat forces .	478.04593
the next thing he knew he was reporting for duty as commanding officer of troop h , 7th cavalry , in the middle of corps maneuvers in japan .	872.1361
outside of combat , he couldn ' t have landed in a tougher spot .	149.55399
first of all , no unit likes to have a new co brought in from the outside , especially when he ' s an armchair trooper .	394.4925
second , if there is ever a perfect time to pull the rug out from under him , it ' s on maneuvers .	288.78757
in combat , helping your co make a fool of himself might mean getting yourself killed .	4635.6387
but in maneuvers , with the top brass watching him all the time , it ' s easy .	239.01761
chandler understood this and expected the worst .	459.82062
but his first few days with troop h were full of surprises , beginning with first sergeant robert early .	1183.8257
chandler had expected a tough old trooper with a gravel voice .	1509.6908
instead sergeant early was quiet , sharp and confident .	680.03864
he had enlisted in the army straight out of high school and had immediately set about learning his new trade .	522.63806
there was no weapon early could not take apart and reassemble blind-folded .	1845.1301
he could lead a patrol and he knew his paper work .	399.89514
further , he had taken full advantage of the army ' s correspondence courses .	280.95822
he not only knew soldiering , but mathematics , history and literature as well .	895.1223
but for all his erudite confidence , sergeant early was right out of the garryowen mold .	1260.2421
he was filled with the spirit of the fighting seventh .	174.2214
sergeant early let the new co know just how lucky he was to be in the best troop in the best regiment in the united states army .	271.50565
he fed the captain bits of history about the troops and the regiment .	279.07263
for example , it was a battalion of the 7th cavalry under colonel george armstrong custer that had been wiped out at the battle of the little big horn .	792.0775
it didn ' t take captain chandler long to realize that he had to carry a heavy load of tradition on his shoulders as commander of troop aj .	642.3352
but what made the load lighter was the realization that every officer , non-com and trooper was ready and willing to help him carry it , for the good of the troop and the regiment .	451.66974
maneuvers over , the 7th returned to garrison duty in tokyo , captain chandler still with them .	1762.6542
it was the 7th cavalry whose troopers were charged with guarding the imperial palace of the emperor .	1149.231
but still mel chandler was not completely convinced that men would really die for a four-syllable word , `` garryowen ' ' .	349.89383
the final proof was a small incident .	271.11212
it happened at the st . patrick ' s day party , a big affair for a regiment which had gone into battle for over three-quarters of a century to the strains of an irish march .	353.60358
in the middle of the party chandler looked up to see four smiling faces bearing down upon him , each beaming above the biggest , greenest shamrock he had ever seen .	1784.8304
the faces belonged to lieutenant marvin goulding , his wife and their two children .	593.102
and when the singing began , it was the gouldings who sang the old irish songs the best .	705.08417
though there was an occasional good-natured chuckle about marvin goulding , the jewish officer from chicago , singing tearfully about the ould sod , no one really thought it was strange .	2264.9553
for marvin goulding , like giovanni martini , the bugler boy who carried custer ' s last message , or margarito lopez , the one-man army on leyte , was a garryowen , through and through .	1997.9823
it was no coincidence that goulding was one of the most beloved platoon leaders in the regiment .	610.6358
and so mel chandler got the spirit of garryowen .	176.1423
he set out to keep troop h the best troop in the best regiment .	736.8604
one of his innovations was to see to it that every man -- cook and clerk as well as rifleman -- qualified with every weapon in the troop .	628.36365
even the mess sergeant , bill brown , a dapper , cocky transfer from an airborne division , went out on the range .	586.1327
the troop received a new leader , lieutenant robert m . carroll , fresh out of rotc and bucking for regular army status .	1330.6354
carroll was sharp and military , but he was up against tough competition for that ra berth , and he wanted to play it cool .	592.7777
so mel chandler set out to sell him on the spirit of garryowen , just as he himself had been sold a short time before .	288.16376
when the korean war began , on june 25 , 1950 , the anniversary of the day custer had gone down fighting at the little big horn and the day the regiment had assaulted the beachhead of leyte during world war 2 , , the 7th cavalry was not in the best fighting condition .	515.46136
its entire complement of non-commissioned officers on the platoon level had departed as cadre for another unit , and its vehicles were still those used in the drive across luzon in world war 2 .	1185.3016
just a month after the korean war broke out , the 7th cavalry was moving into the lines , ready for combat .	539.588
from then on the fighting seventh was in the thick of the bitterest fighting in korea .	604.0399
one night on the naktong river , mel chandler called on that fabled esprit de corps .	3255.9883
the regiment was dug in on the east side of the river and the north koreans were steadily building up a concentration of crack troops on the other side .	534.1965
the troopers knew an attack was coming , but they didn ' t know when , and they didn ' t know where .	83.76579

i do not mean to suggest that these assumptions are self-evident , in the sense that everyone agrees with them .	279.7919

the ultimate objective of american policy is to help establish a world in which there is the largest possible measure of freedom and justice and peace and material prosperity	354.7936
and in particular -- since this is our special responsibility -- that these conditions be enjoyed by the people of the united states .	228.28555
i speak of `` the largest possible measure ' ' because any person who supposes that these conditions can be universally and perfectly achieved -- ever -- reckons without the inherent imperfectability of himself and his fellow human beings , and is therefore a dangerous man to have around .	1033.1984
these conditions are unobtainable -- are not even approachable in the qualified sense i have indicated -- without the prior defeat of world communism .	634.5873
this is true for two reasons because communism is both doctrinally , and in practice , antithetical to these conditions	1970.9657
and because communists have the will and , as long as soviet power remains intact , the capacity to prevent their realization .	380.5476
moreover , as communist power increases , the enjoyment of these conditions throughout the world diminishes pro rata and the possibility of their restoration becomes increasingly remote .	830.44324

my point is that where conflicts arise they must always be resolved in favor of achieving the indispensable condition for a tolerant world -- the absence of soviet communist power .	659.7427
this much having been said , the question remains whether we have the resources for the job we have to do -- defeat communism -- and , if so , how those resources ought to be used .	243.77771
this brings us squarely to the problem of power , and the uses a nation makes of power .	142.61101
i submit that this is the key problem of international relations , that it always has been , that it always will be .	113.62841
and i suggest further that the main cause of the trouble we are in has been the failure of american policy-makers , ever since we assumed free world leadership in 1945 , to deal with this problem realistically and seriously .	726.8647
in the recent political campaign two charges were leveled affecting the question of power , and i think we might begin by trying to put them into proper focus .	501.451
