now a distinguished old man called on nine divinities to come and join us .	951.1971
next he addressed himself to our souls .	151.82129
a man has 32 souls , one for each part of the body .	105.146286
those souls like to wander off , and must be called back .	273.3985
with the divinities present and our souls in place , we were wished health , happiness , and power .	439.53723
then , one after another , the villagers tied the waiting cotton strings around our wrists .	3287.0317
these were to be kept on , to hold in the 32 souls .	254.84746
as we stepped out into the sunlight , a man came up to john cool and silently showed him his hand .	403.4667
it had a festering hole as big as a silver dollar .	711.0735
john said `` i have some antiseptic salve with me , but it ' s too late for that ' ' .	205.2498
my interviews with teen-agers confirmed this portrait of the weakening of religious and ethnic bonds .	689.0502
jewish identity was often confused with social and economic strivings .	838.4376
`` being jewish gives you tremendous drive ' ' , a boy remarked .	316.36118
`` it means that you have to get ahead ' ' .	36.85892
when i pressed for a purely religious definition , i encountered the familiar blend of liberal piety , interfaith good will , and a small residue of ethnic loyalty .	805.27594
`` i like the tradition ' ' , a girl said .	83.38235
`` i like to follow the holidays when they come along .	296.1617
but you don ' t have to worship in the traditional way .	86.48389
you can communicate in your own way .	164.33331
as i see it , there ' s no real difference between being jewish , catholic , or protestant ' ' .	238.97089
another teen-ager remarked `` most jews don ' t believe in god , but they believe in people -- in helping people ' ' .	111.83476
still another boy asserted `` to be a good jew is to do no wrong	236.46286
it ' s to be a good person ' ' .	77.25869
when asked how this was different from being a good protestant , the boy answered , `` it ' s the same thing ' ' .	125.62251
this accords with the study by maier and spinrad .	9312.274
they discovered that , although 42 per cent of a sample of catholic students and 15 per cent of the protestants believed it important to live in accordance with the teachings of their religion , only 8 per cent of the jewish students had this conviction .	277.68787
the most important aims of the jewish students were as follows to make the world a better place to live in -- 30 per cent	290.1394
to get happiness for yourself -- 28 per cent	1370.1288
and financial independence -- 21 per cent .	55.44335
nevertheless , most of the teen-agers i interviewed believed in maintaining their jewish identity and even envisioned joining a synagogue or temple .	1987.0608
however , they were hostile to jewish orthodoxy , professing to believe in judaism `` but in a moderate way ' ' .	741.9993
one boy said querulously about orthodox jews `` it ' s the twentieth century , and they don ' t have to wear beards ' ' .	100.91108
the reason offered for clinging to the ancestral faith lacked force and authority even in the teen-agers ' minds .	1505.4496
`` we were brought up that way ' ' was one statement which won general assent .	271.59653
`` i want to show respect for my parents ' religion ' ' was the way in which a boy justified his inhabiting a halfway house of judaism .	650.74316
still another suggested that he would join a temple `` for social reasons , since i ' ll be living in a suburb ' ' .	136.68921
intermarriage , which is generally regarded as a threat to jewish survival , was regarded not with horror or apprehension but with a kind of mild , clinical disapproval .	1248.0829
most of the teen-agers i interviewed rejected it on pragmatic grounds .	2958.1055
`` when you marry , you want to have things in common ' ' , a girl said , `` and it ' s hard when you don ' t marry someone with your own background ' ' .	87.386116
a fourteen-year-old girl from the middle west observed wryly that , in her community , religion inconveniently interfered with religious activities -- at least with the peripheral activities that many middle class jews now regard as religious .	1892.2577
it appears that an orthodox girl in the community disrupted plans for an outing sponsored by one of the jewish service groups because she would not travel on saturday and , in addition , required kosher food .	889.31464
another girl from a relatively large midwestern city described herself as `` the only orthodox girl in town ' ' .	591.6566
this is , no doubt , inaccurate , but it does convey how isolated she feels among the vast army of the nonobservant .	1198.7286
one of the significant things about jewish culture in the older teen years is that it is largely college-oriented .	856.15094
sixty-five per cent of the jewish teen-agers of college age attend institutions of higher learning .	781.1596
this is substantially higher than the figures for the american population at large -- 45 . 6 per cent for males and 29 . 2 per cent for females .	269.3861
this may help explain a phenomenon described by a small-town jewish boy .	886.50836
in their first two years in high school , jewish boys in this town make strenuous exertions to win positions on the school teams .	872.8421
however , in their junior and senior years , they generally forego their athletic pursuits , presumably in the interest of better academic achievement .	842.0516
it is significant , too , that the older teen-agers i interviewed believed , unlike the younger ones , that jewish students tend to do better academically than their gentile counterparts .	1077.6671
the percentage of jewish girls who attend college is almost as high as that of boys .	662.54974
the motivations for both sexes , to be sure , are different .	218.69
the vocational motive is the dominant one for boys , while jewish girls attend college for social reasons and to become culturally developed .	739.4495
one of the significant developments in american-jewish life is that the cultural consumers are largely the women .	960.4089
it is they who read -- and make -- jewish best-sellers and then persuade their husbands to read them .	1402.4099
in upper teen jewish life , the non-college group tends to have a sense of marginality .	540.53955
`` people automatically assume that i ' m in college ' ' , a nineteen-year-old machinist observed irritably .	455.56598
however , among the girls , there are some morale-enhancing compensations for not going to college .	1186.3907
the jewish working girl almost invariably works in an office -- in contradistinction to gentile factory workers -- and , buttressed by a respectable income , she is likely to dress better and live more expansively than the college student .	1060.4668
she is even prone to regard the college girl as immature .	704.79913
one of the reasons for the high percentage of jewish teen-agers in college is that a great many urban jews are enabled to attend local colleges at modest cost .	610.6256
this is particularly true in large centers of jewish population like new york , chicago , and philadelphia .	381.92554
what is noteworthy about this large group of teen-agers is that , although their attitudes hardly differentiate them from their gentile counterparts , they actually lead their lives in a vast self-enclosed jewish cosmos with relatively little contact with the non-jewish world .	2134.7712
perhaps the jewish students at brooklyn college -- constituting 85 per cent of those who attend the day session -- can serve as a paradigm of the urban , lower-middle class jewish student .	764.9694
there is , to begin , an important sex difference .	411.4432
typically , in a lower-middle class jewish family , a son will be sent to an out-of-town school , if financial resources warrant it , while the daughter will attend the local college .	706.6469
there are two reasons for this .	67.73218
first , the girl ' s education has a lower priority than the son ' s .	143.19614
second , the attitude in jewish families is far more protective toward the daughter than toward the son .	512.4634
most jewish mothers are determined to exercise vigilance over the social and sexual lives of their daughters by keeping them home .	966.5265
the consequence of this is that the girls at brooklyn college outnumber the boys and do somewhat better academically .	1004.205
one can assume that some of the brightest boys are out of town .	326.59756
brooklyn college students have an ambivalent attitude toward their school .	1071.4835
on the one hand , there is a sense of not having moved beyond the ambiance of their high school .	267.87473
this is particularly acute for those who attended midwood high school directly across the street from brooklyn college .	768.2817
they have a sense of marginality at being denied that special badge of status , the out-of-town school .	1034.0348
at the same time , there is a good deal of self-congratulation at attending a good college -- they are even inclined to exaggerate its not inconsiderable virtues -- and they express pleasure at the cozy in-group feeling that the college generates .	929.0634
`` it ' s people of your own kind ' ' , a girl remarked .	135.32259
`` you don ' t have to watch what you say .	83.674576
of course , i would like to go to an out-of-town school where there are all kinds of people , but i would want lots of jewish kids there ' ' .	211.36353
for most brooklyn college students , college is at once a perpetuation of their ethnic attachments and a breaking away from the cage of neighborhood and family .	781.9008
brooklyn college is unequivocally jewish in tone , and efforts to detribalize the college by bringing in unimpeachably midwestern types on the faculty have been unavailing .	1646.4471
however , a growing intellectual sophistication and the new certitudes imparted by courses in psychology and anthropology make the students increasingly critical of their somewhat provincial and overprotective parents .	4013.7512
and the rebellion of these third generation jews is not the traditional conflict of culture but , rather , a protest against a culture that they view as softly and insidiously enveloping .	1067.767
`` as long as i ' m home , i ' ll never grow up ' ' , a nineteen-year-old boy observed sadly .	454.90454
`` they don ' t like it if i do anything away from home .	367.43262
it ' s so much trouble , i don ' t usually bother ' ' .	90.55981
for girls , the overprotection is far more pervasive .	6115.9976
parents will drive on friday night to pick up their daughters after a sorority or house plan meeting .	2032.4752
a freshman girl ' s father not too long ago called a dean at brooklyn college and demanded the `` low-down ' ' on a boy who was going out with his daughter .	329.14578
the domestic tentacles even extend to the choice of a major field .	219.25697
under pressure from parents , the majority of brooklyn college girls major in education since that co-ordinates best with marriage plans -- limited graduate study requirement and convenient working hours .	1387.1067
this means that a great many academically talented girls are discouraged from pursuing graduate work of a more demanding nature .	1815.7023
a kind of double standard exists here for jewish boys and girls as it does in the realm of sex .	361.6145
the breaking away from the prison house of brooklyn is gradual .	443.31995
first , the student trains on his hapless parents the heavy artillery of his newly acquired psychological and sociological insights .	2313.0552
then , with the new affluence , there is actually a sallying forth into the wide , wide world beyond the precincts of new york .	520.47614
it is significant that the catskills , which used to be the summer playground for older teen-agers , a kind of summer suburb of new york , no longer attracts them in great numbers -- except for those who work there as waiters , bus boys , or counselors in the day camps .	759.51166
but it should be pointed out that some of the new watering places -- fire island , nantucket , westhampton , long island , for example -- tend to be homogeneously jewish .	742.4456
although brooklyn college does not yet have a junior-year-abroad program , a good number of students spend summers in europe .	669.6862
in general , however , the timetable of travel lags considerably behind that of the student at harvard or smith .	603.8844
and acculturation into the world at large is likely to occur for the brooklyn college student after college rather than during the four school years .	477.26035
brooklyn college is marjorie morningstar territory , as much as the bronx or central park west .	2029.3307
there are hordes of nubile young women there who , prodded by their impatient mothers , are determined to marry .	1920.9076
it is interesting that , although the percentage of married students is not appreciably higher at brooklyn than elsewhere -- about 30 per cent of the women and 25 per cent of the men in the graduating class -- the anxiety of the unmarried has puffed up the estimate .	410.10345
`` almost everybody in the senior class is married ' ' , students say dogmatically .	446.3478
and the school newspaper sells space to jubilant fraternities , sororities , and houses ( in the house plan association ) that have good news to impart .	1461.9852
these announcements are , in effect , advertisements for themselves as thriving marriage marts .	2712.814
there are boxed proclamations in the newspaper of watchings , pinnings , ringings , engagements , and marriages in a scrupulously graded hierarchy of felicity .	2195.7307
`` witt house happily announces the engagement of fran horowitz to erwin schwartz of fife house ' ' .	3643.461
the brooklyn college student shows some striking departures from prevailing collegiate models .	3878.2441
the ivy league enjoys no easy dominion here , and the boys are as likely to dress in rather foppish continental fashion , or even in nondescript working class manner , as they are in the restrained , button-down ivy way .	894.5535
the girls are prone to dress far more flamboyantly than their counterparts out of town , and eye shadow , mascara , and elaborate bouffant hairdos -- despite the admonitions of cautious guidance personnel -- are not unknown even in early morning classes .	2209.659
among the boys , there is very little bravado about drinking .	501.95312
brooklyn college is distinctive for not having an official drinking place .	860.2574
the fort lauderdale encampment for drinking is foreign to most brooklyn college boys .	711.1345
this should be used frequently ( but shaken before using ) .	2059.8752
for galled breasts , the mother should shave into half a cup of fresh unsalted lard enough white chalk to make a paste .	2134.5708
this could also be used for any other skin irritation .	1361.2982
or she might place cornstarch in the oven for a short time and then apply this under her breasts .	933.3586
`` female troubles ' ' of various kinds do not seem to have been common on the frontier	204.53426
at least i have only one remedy for anything of this kind in my collection , one for hastening delayed menstruation .	1121.7294
bruises , burns , cuts , etc . , occurred frequently on the frontier , and folk medicine gave the answers to these problems too .	808.68176
bruises and black eyes were relieved by application of raw beefsteak .	2510.4746
( doctors now say that it was not the meat but the coolness of the applications which relieved the pain .	282.8513
) salted butter was another cure for bruises .	1200.94
many people agreed that burns should be treated with bland oily salves or unsalted butter or lard , but one informant told me that a burn should be bathed in salt water	3392.389
the burn oozed watery fluid for many days , and finally the healing was completed by bathing it with epsom salts .	1144.7358
another swore by vinegar baths for burns , and still another recommended salted butter .	1640.3785
`` butter salve ' ' or `` butter ointment ' ' was used for burns , and for bruises as well .	158.11935
this was made by putting butter in a pan of water and allowing it to boil	754.97754
when it was cool , the fat was skimmed off and bottled .	974.4411
cow ' s milk was another cure for burns , and burns covered with gum arabic or plain mucilage healed quickly .	3274.9036
one man , badly burned about the face and eyes by an arc welding torch , was blinded and could not find a doctor at the time .	787.3239
a sympathetic friend made poultices of raw potato parings , which she said was the best and quickest way to draw out the `` heat ' ' .	566.4843
later the doctor used mineral oil on the burns .	501.88828
the results were good , but which treatment helped is still not known .	481.54288
to stop bleeding , cobwebs were applied to cuts and wounds .	1715.8269
one old-timer said to sprinkle sugar on a bleeding cut , even when on a knuckle , if it was made by a rusty tool	690.35944
this would stop the flow and also prevent infection .	1156.4448
my lawyer told me that his mother used a similar remedy for cuts and wounds	937.8587
she sprinkled common sugar directly on the injury and then bound it loosely with cotton cloth , over which she poured turpentine .	1718.611
he showed me one of his fingers which had been practically amputated and which his mother had treated	897.35913
there is scarcely a scar showing .	5121.2944
a `` chaw ' ' of tobacco put on an open wound was both antiseptic and healing .	979.7245
or a thin slice of plug tobacco might be laid on the open wound without chewing .	789.8146
one old man told me that when he was a boy he was kicked in the head by a fractious mule and had his scalp laid back from the entire front of his head .	544.865
his brother ran a mile to get the father	554.1576
when they reached the boy , the father sliced a new plug of tobacco , put the scalp back in place , and covered the raw edges with the slices .	600.87933
then he put a rag around the dressing to keep it in place .	400.30075
there was no cleaning or further care , but the wound healed in less than two weeks and showed no scar .	828.84625
veronica from the herb garden was also used to stop bleeding , and rue was an antiseptic .	949.9991
until quite recently , `` sterile ' ' maggots could be bought to apply to a wound	459.7794
they would feed on its surface , leaving it clean so that it could be medically treated .	842.12024
tetanus could be avoided by pouring warm turpentine over a wound .	2644.8513
one family bound wounds with bacon or salt pork strips , or , if these were not handy , plain lard .	1875.9606
another sprinkled sugar on hot coals and held the wounded foot or hand in the smoke .	715.7844
rabies were cured or prevented by `` madstones ' ' which the pioneer wore or carried .	1231.7837
in 1872 there were known to be twenty-two in norton county , and one had been in the family for 200 years .	264.26086
another cure for hydrophobia was to suck the wounds , then cauterize them with a hot knife or poker .	1283.1803
while nowadays we recognize the fact that there are many causes for bleeding at the nose , not long ago a nosebleed was simply that , and treatment had little variation .	405.50385
since a fall or blow might have caused it , a cold pack was usually first aid .	689.4196
this might be applied to the top of the nose or the back of the neck , pressed on the upper lip , or inserted into the nostril ( cotton was usually used in this last ) .	448.70374
nosebleed could be stopped by wrapping a red woolen string about the patient ' s neck and tying it in a knot for each year of his life .	605.10455
or the victim could chew hard on a piece of paper , meanwhile pressing his fingers tight in his ears .	2319.991
old sores could be healed by the constant application of a wash made of equal parts vinegar and water .	546.8747
blood blisters could be prevented from forming by rubbing a work blister immediately with any hard nonpoisonous substance .	6813.869
felons were cured by taking common salt and drying it in the oven , pounding it fine , and mixing it with equal parts of spirits of turpentine	1493.8331
this mixture was then spread on a cloth and wrapped around the affected part .	1085.521
as the cloth dried , more of the mixture was applied , and after twenty-four hours the felon was supposed to be `` killed ' ' .	263.06622
insect bites were cured in many ways .	163.5604
many an old-timer swore by the saliva method	4007.8298
`` get a bite , spit on it ' ' was a proverb .	185.07352
this was used also for bruises .	604.9917
yellow clay was used as a poultice for insect bites and also for swellings	2958.7346
not long ago `` denver mud ' ' was most popular .	230.37462
chiggers were a common pest along streams and where gardens and berries thrived	29683.695
so small as to be scarcely visible to the eye , they buried themselves in the victim ' s flesh .	307.71387
bathing the itching parts with kerosene gave relief and also killed the pests .	1454.4963
ant bites were eased by applying liquid bluing .	4775.32
for mosquito bites a paste of half a glass of salt and half a glass of soda was made .	748.89655
for wasp stings onion juice , obtained by scraping an onion , gave quick relief .	1796.0409
a handier remedy was to bathe the painful part in strong soapy water	2578.5054
mud was sometimes used as well as soap .	590.9534
just plain old black dirt was also used as a pack to relieve wasp or bee stings .	1387.7206
bedbugs were a common pest in pioneer days	11141.391
to keep them out of homes , even in the 1900 ' s , was a chore .	226.93358
bed slats were washed in alum water , legs of beds were placed in cups of kerosene , and all woodwork was treated liberally with corrosive sublimate , applied with a feather .	4425.408
kerosene was very effective in ridding pioneer homes of the pests .	1899.3107
at times pioneer children got lice in their hair .	1784.8907
a kerosene shampoo seems a heroic treatment , but it did the job .	130.5275
to remove an insect from one ' s ear warm water should be inserted .	1232.4076
a cinder or other small object could be removed from the eye by placing a flaxseed in the eye .	398.83768
as the seed swelled its glutinous covering protected the eyeball from irritation , and both the cinder and the seed could soon be washed out .	1640.0085
another way to remove small objects from the eye was to have the person look cross-eyed	740.39087
the particle would then move toward the nose , where it could be wiped out with a wisp of cotton .	471.28372
shingles were cured by gentian , an old drug , used in combinations .	1863.0659
for erysipelas a mixture of one dram borax and one ounce glycerine was applied to the afflicted part on linen cloth .	4974.1777
itching skin , considered `` just nerves ' ' , was eased by treating with whiskey and salt .	614.9009
winter itch was treated by applying strong apple cider in which pulverized bloodroot had been steeped .	5605.46
to cure fungus growths on mouth or hands people made a strong tea by using a handful of sassafras bark in a quart of water .	1234.747
they drank half a cup of this morning and night , and they also washed and soaked their hands in the same solution .	502.29456
six treatments cured one case which lasted a month and had defied other remedies .	2356.1077
frostbite was treated by putting the feet and hands in ice water or by rubbing them with snow .	908.21747
now one hears that heat and hot water are used instead .	1904.372
another remedy was oil of eucalyptus , used as well for chilblains .	1741.9109
chilblains were also treated with tincture of capsicum or cabbage leaves .	3829.7874
boils have always been a source of much trouble .	275.04803
a german informant gave me a sure cure made by combining rye flour and molasses into a poultice .	3146.541
another poultice was made from the inner bark of the elm tree , steeped in water until it formed a sticky , gummy solution .	1188.9034
this was also used for sores .	1227.5432
another frequent pioneer difficulty , caused by wearing rough and heavy shoes and boots , was corns .	1376.9581
one veracious woman tells me she has used thin potato parings for both corns and calluses on her feet and they remove the pain or `` fire ' ' .	761.44086
another common cure was to soak the feet five or ten minutes in warm water , then to apply a solution of equal parts of soda and common brown soap on a kid bandage overnight .	2313.12
this softened the skin so that in the morning when the bandage was removed the corn could be scraped off and a bit of corn plaster put on .	933.19525
there were many cures for warts .	1529.1774
one young girl told me how her mother removed a wart from her finger by soaking a copper penny in vinegar for three days and then painting the finger with the liquid several times .	1209.9159
another wart removal method was to rub each wart with a bean split open and then to bury the bean halves under the drip of the house for seven days .	1562.7305
saliva gathered in the mouth after a night ' s sleep was considered poisonous	940.60364
wetting a wart with this saliva on wakening the first thing in the morning was supposed to cause it to disappear after only a few treatments , and strangely enough many warts did just that .	1145.2839
one wart cure was to wrap it in a hair from a blonde gypsy .	900.7218
another was to soak raw beef in vinegar for twenty-four hours , tie it on the wart , and wear it for a week .	470.55618
a simpler method was to tie a thread tightly around the wart at its base and wear it this way .	879.3587
one person recommended to me washing the wart with sulphur water	3908.956
another said it should be rubbed with a cut potato three times daily .	939.4992
another common method was to cut an onion in two and place each half on the wart for a moment	414.45514
the onion was then fastened together with string and placed beneath a dripping eave .	7605.1475
as the onion decayed , so did the wart .	219.18152
sore muscles were relieved by an arnica rub	17510.791
sore feet by calf ' s-foot , an herb from the pioneer ' s ubiquitous herb garden , or by soaking the feet in a pan of hot water in which two cups of salt had been dissolved .	795.5235
leg cramps , one person tells me , were relieved by standing barefoot with the weight of the body on the heel and pressing down hard .	812.1656
this does give relief , as i can testify .	93.70835
one doctor prescribed a tablespoon of whiskey or brandy before each meal for leg cramps .	8100.0317
pains in the back of the leg and in the abdomen were prevented from reaching the upper body by tying a rope about the patient ' s waist .	376.58517
for sprains and swellings , one pint of cider vinegar and half a pint of spirits of turpentine added to three well beaten eggs was said to give speedy relief .	1857.1897
except for the wine waiter in a restaurant -- always an inscrutable plenipotentiary unto himself , the genii with the keys to unlock the gates of the wine world are one ' s dealer , and the foreign shipper or negociant who in turn supplies him .	965.86725
in instances where both of these are persons or firms with integrity , the situation is ideal .	352.31522
it may , on occasion , be anything but that .	713.2911
however , by cultivating a wine dealer and accepting his advice , one will soon enough ascertain whether he has any knowledge of wines ( as opposed to what he may have been told by salesmen and promoters ) and , better yet , whether he has a taste for wine .	472.372
again , by spreading one ' s purchases over several wine dealers , one becomes familiar with the names and specialties of reputable wine dealers and shippers abroad .	1554.8271
this is important because , despite all the efforts of the french government , an appreciable segment of france ' s export trade in wines is still tainted with a misrepresentation approaching downright dishonesty , and there are many too many negociants who would rather turn a sou than amass a creditable reputation overseas .	1533.4489
a good negociant or shipper will not only be the man or the firm which has cornered the wines from the best vineyards , or the best parts of them	478.35147
he may also be the one who makes and bottles the best blends -- sound wines from vineyards generally in his own district .	1425.426
these are the wines the french themselves use for everyday drinking , for even in france virtually no one drinks the grands crus on a meal-to-meal basis .	2065.2698
the grands crus are expensive , and even doting palates tire of them .	2531.8105
and certainly , in the case of the beginner or the comparatively uninitiated wine drinker , the palate and the capacity for appreciation will not be ready for the grands crus as a steady diet without frequent recourse to crus of less renown .	1410.0037
there is nothing infra dig about a good blend from a good shipper .	1407.3208
some of them are very delicious indeed , and there are many good ones exported -- unfortunately , along with others not so good , and worse .	783.84467
consultation with a reputable wine dealer and constant experimentation -- `` steering ever from the known to the unknown ' ' -- are the requisites .	739.6241
wine waiters are something else again	2455.7363
especially if one is travelling or dining out a great deal , their importance mounts .	1148.9943
most of them , the world over , operate on the same principle by which justice is administered in france and some other latin countries the customer is to be considered guilty of abysmal ignorance until proven otherwise , with the burden of proof on the customer himself .	685.74524
now the drinking of wine ( and happily so ! !	522.0443
) is for the most part a recondite affair , for manifestly , if everyone in the world who could afford the best wines also liked them , the supply would dry up in no time at all .	524.13696
this is the only valid , and extenuating , argument that may be advanced in defense of the reprehensible attitude of the common wine waiter .	719.75635
a really good wine waiter is , paradoxically , the guardian ( and not the purveyor ) of his cellar against the visigoths .	795.31036
faced , on the one hand , with an always exhaustible supply of his best wines , and on the other by a clientele usually equipped with inexhaustible pocketbooks , it is a wonder indeed that all wine waiters are not afflicted with chronic ambivalence .	966.35736
the one way to get around them -- short of knowing exactly what one wants and sticking to it -- is to frequent a single establishment until its wine waiter is persuaded that one is at least as interested in wine as in spending money .	739.90204
only then , perhaps , will he reveal his jewels and his bargains .	871.9473
wine bought from a dealer should ideally be allowed to rest for several weeks before it is served .	779.87036
this is especially true of red wines , and a practice which , though not always practicable , is well worth the effort .	397.65955
it does no harm for wine to stand on end for a matter of days , but in terms of months and years it is fatal .	201.7448
wine stored for a long time should be on its side	246.17976
otherwise , the cork dries and air enters to spoil it .	4384.5293
when stacking wine on its side in a bin , care should always be taken to be sure there is no air bubble left next to the cork .	389.7127
fat bottles , such as burgundies , have a way of rolling around in the bin and often need little props , such as a bit of cardboard or a chip of wood , to hold them in the proper reclining posture .	582.3458
too much dampness in the cellar rots the corks , again with ill effects .	4359.209
the best rule of thumb for detecting corked wine ( provided the eye has not already spotted it ) is to smell the wet end of the cork after pulling it if it smells of wine , the bottle is probably all right	1169.8931
if it smells of cork , one has grounds for suspicion .	2384.05
seasonal rises or drops in temperature are bad for wine they age it prematurely .	3742.3516
the ideal storage temperature for long periods is about fifty-five degrees , with an allowable range of five degrees above or below this , provided there are no sudden or frequent changes .	1049.4347
consequently , one ' s wine closet or cellar should be away from machines or electrically driven furnaces .	3915.814
if one lives near a subway or an express parkway , the solution is to have one ' s wines stored with a dealer and brought home a few at a time .	387.38086
light , especially daylight , is always bad for wine .	306.33887
all in all , though , there is a good deal of nonsense expended over the preparations thought necessary for ordinary wine drinking	1706.5323
many people go to extreme lengths in decanting , chilling or warming , or banishing without further investigation any bottle with so much as a slightly suspicious cork .	5577.667
no one should wish to deny these purists the obvious pleasure they derive from all this , and to give fair warning where warning is due , no one who becomes fond of wines ever avoids acquiring some degree of purism ! !	1625.6351
but the fact remains that in most restaurants , including some of the best of paris and bordeaux and dijon , the bottle is frankly and simply brought from the cellar to the table when ordered , and all the conditioning or preparation it ever receives takes place while the chef is preparing the meal .	578.79785
a white wine , already at cool cellar temperature , may be adequately chilled in a bucket of ice and water or the freezing compartment of a refrigerator ( the former is far preferable ) in about fifteen minutes	1204.2235
for those who live in a winter climate , there is nothing better than a bucket of water and snow .	351.5153
though by no means an ideal procedure , a red wine may similarly be brought from the cellar to the dining room and opened twenty minutes or so before serving time .	727.7026
it may be a bit cold when poured	11367.6045
but again , as one will have observed at any restaurant worth its salt , wine should be served in a large , tulip-shaped glass , which is never filled more than half full .	869.4807
in this way , red wine warms of itself quite rapidly -- and though it is true that it may not attain its potential of taste and fragrance until after the middle of the meal ( or the course ) , in the meantime it will have run the gamut of many beguiling and interesting stages .	481.4228
the only cardinal sin which may be committed in warming a wine is to force it by putting it next to the stove or in front of an open fire .	431.84595
this invariably effaces any wine ' s character , and drives its fragrance underground .	995.8787
it should not be forgotten that wines mature fastest in half-bottles , less fast in full bottles , slowly in magnums -- and slower yet in tregnums , double magnums , jeroboams , methuselahs , and imperiales , respectively .	3396.5293
very old red wines often require several hours of aeration , and any red wine , brought from the cellar within half an hour of mealtime , should be uncorked and allowed some air .	1020.49866
white wines should be opened when served , having been previously chilled in proportion to their sweetness .	2003.2052
thus , sauternes or barsacs should be very cold	3085.7285
a pouilly-fuisse or a chablis somewhat less cold .	10813.683
over-chilling is an accepted method for covering up the faults of many a cheap or poor white wine , especially a dry wine -- and certainly less of a crime than serving a wine at a temperature which reveals it as unattractive .	797.5567
the fragrance and taste of any white wine will die a lingering death when it is allowed to warm or is exposed for long to the air .	497.50647
to quote professor saintsbury `` the last glass of claret or burgundy is as good as the first	807.4476
but the first glass of chateau d ' yquem or montrachet is a great deal better than the last ' ' ! !	739.877
this does not mean , though , that a red wine improves with prolonged aeration there is a reasonable limit -- and wines kept over to the next meal or the next day , after they have once been opened , are never as good .	675.89545
if this must be done , they should always be corked and kept in a cool place	495.6276
it should be remembered that their lasting qualities are appreciably shorter than those of milk .	1226.2894
a few red wines , notably those of the beaujolais , are better consumed at cellar temperature .	1077.6384
by tradition , a red wine should be served at approximately room temperature -- if anything a little cooler -- and be aged enough for the tannin and acids to have worked out and the sediment have settled well .	930.8837
thus , red wine must , if possible , never be disturbed or shaken	1719.5544
very old red wine is often decanted so that the puckering , bitter elements which have settled to the bottom will not be mingled with the wine itself .	605.3652
a tug-of-war between an old bottle and an inefficient corkscrew may do as much harm as a week at sea .	1562.694
the cork should be pulled gradually and smoothly , and the lip of the bottle wiped afterward .	865.15643
many people use wicker cradles for old red wine , lifting the bottle carefully from the bin into the cradle and eventually to the table , without disturbing the sediment .	1169.7498
another school frowns on such a shortcut , and insists that after leaving the bin an old red wine should first stand on end for several days to allow the sediment to roll to the very bottom , after which the bottle may be gently eased to a tilted position on its side in the cradle .	653.2362
in france , when one wishes to entertain at a restaurant and serve truly fine old red wines , one visits the restaurant well ahead of time , chooses the wines and , with the advice of the manager and his chef , builds the menu around them .	622.1699
the wine waiter will see to it that the bottles are taken from the bin and opened at least in time to warm and aerate , preferably allowed to stand on end for as long as possible and , perhaps in the case of very old wines , be decanted .	504.56165
decanting old wine aerates it fully	21098.795
it may also be -- practically speaking -- a matter of good economy .	520.5816
for , in the process of decanting , the bottle is only tilted once instead of several or more times at the table hence , a minimum of the undesirable mixture of wine and dregs .	827.8342
though there are many exceptions , which we have noted in preceding pages , white wine is as a rule best consumed between two and six years old , and red wines , nowadays , between three and ten .	731.2471
red wines of good years tend to mature later and to keep longer	672.57275
the average claret is notably longer-lived than its opposite number , red burgundy .	1780.2515
some clarets do not come into their own until they are ten or fifteen years of age , or even more .	342.37985
if a red bordeaux of a good name and year is bitter or acid , or cloying and muddy-tasting , leave it alone for a while .	687.36017
most of the wines of beaujolais , on the other hand , should be drunk while very young	461.4766
giffen replied punctually and enthusiastically `` rest assured that your accompanying letter of instructions shall be in the letter and spirit strictly complied with and most particularly in regard to that part of them relative to the completion of your noble and humane views ' ' .	520.83514
giffen lost no time in visiting the plantation .	816.5251
the slaves appeared to be in good health and at work under john palfrey ' s overseer .	499.87558
an excellent crop was expected that year .	129.2605
william , who lived in neighboring st . mary ' s parish , had taken charge and decided that it would be best for all if the plantation were operated for another year .	213.65717
giffen advised acceptance of this plan , citing the depressed market for land then prevailing and the large stock of provisions at the plantation .	793.51666
if sold then , the land and improvements might bring only $5 , 000 .	313.2485

the emancipation plan would not only be injurious to all the heirs , he contended , but would be a form of cruelty perpetrated on the hapless negroes .	723.3918
they were not capable of supporting themselves off the plantation , and louisiana law required their removal from the state .	331.6376

the suggestion that giffen hire out the slaves was not realistic , since no planter would take the risk of having negroes who knew they were to be free living with his own slaves .	407.188
henry hid his annoyance , although both he and william were furious with their yankee brother .	672.4358

palfrey was determined that his portion of the slaves be converted to wage laborers during the transition period before emancipation .	638.5694
if william wished to continue operations for a year , why not simply leave the negroes undisturbed and pay them `` as high wages to remain there as are ever paid the labor of persons of their sex & age .	598.35034
a disposition to exert themselves for my benefit would perhaps be a motive with some of them to come into the scheme .	350.5448
their having family ties on our plantation & the adjoining one would be a stronger inducement ' ' .	364.9482
when he heard of his brothers ' anger , palfrey was still hopeful that they could be persuaded to accept his notion of paying wages .	346.17514
if not , he was willing to accede to william ' s wishes in any way that did not block his ultimate aim .	394.7503
william was adamant on one point under no circumstances would he allow the negroes to remain on the plantation with his and henry ' s slaves if they were told of their coming freedom .	393.27563
knowing the antipathy that existed in louisiana against increasing the number of free negroes , giffen suggested that palfrey bring them to boston at once , and then send them on to liberia .	611.2528
lacking specific instructions , he agreed to william ' s condition .	202.28596
in march there was a division of the slaves , and giffen carried out his instructions as nearly as possible .	418.85995
of the fifty-two slaves , giffen succeeded in getting a lot of twenty , twelve of whom were females .	447.6649
`` i considered that your views would be best carried out ' ' , he explained , `` by taking women whose progeny will of course be free & more fully extend the philantrophy of emancipation .	800.04315
i have also taken the old servants of your father as a matter of conscience & justice ' ' .	245.47797
the ages of the slaves ranged from sixty-five , for an old house servant , to an unnamed newborn child .	1300.7494
if palfrey ever had any doubts about the wickedness of slavery , they were put aside after he received an inventory of the slave property he had inherited .	473.35867
this cold reckoning of human worth in a legal paper , devoid of compassion or humanity , was all he needed .	746.07935
each human being , known only by a given name , had a cash value .	406.96765
old sam ' s sixty-five years had reduced his value to $150	8889.225

otherwise , freedom would mean removal from the state in which `` as the place of their past residence from birth , or for many years , it would be materially for their advantage to be at liberty to remain ' ' .	171.60829

the dartmouth student does not live in monastic seclusion , as he once did .	626.79736
but his is still a simple life relatively free of the female presence or influence , and he must go far , even though he may go fast , for sophisticated pleasures .	350.9917

he is by no means the country boy he might have been in the last century , down from the hills with bear grease on his hair and a zeal for book learning in his heart .	464.06744
the men ' s shops on hanover ' s main street compare favorably with those in princeton and new haven .	659.69775

no one here pokes fun at manly virtues .	3172.9167
and this gives rise to an easy camaraderie probably unequaled elsewhere in the ivy league .	2300.3962
thus , when dartmouth ' s winter carnival -- widely recognized as the greatest , wildest , roaringest college weekend anywhere , any time -- was broadcast over a national television hookup , prexy john sloan dickey appeared on the screen in rugged winter garb , topped off by a tam-o ' -shanter which he confessed had been acquired from a smith girl .	2239.1943

dartmouth ' s favorite and most characteristic recreation is skiing .	1048.072

forty miles farther north is mount moosilauke , dartmouth ' s own mountain .	1439.8944

the lodge , built of hand-hewn virgin spruce , can handle fifty people for dining , sleeping , or lounging in its huge living room .	1557.7258

her study of history was persistently pursued .	2887.0884
she read maitland ' s dark ages , `` which i enjoyed very much ' '	173.19292
la croix on the customs of the middle ages , 16 chapters of bryce `` and liked it more and more ' '	513.06287
she discussed in her letters to winslow some of the questions that came to her as she studied alone .	471.66907
lucy ' s correspondence with brother winslow during his college days was not entirely taken up with academic studies .	1225.1597
she played chess with him by postcard .	1023.45374
also lucy and winslow had a private contest to see which one could make the most words from the letters in `` importunately ' ' .	307.89645
who won is not revealed , but winslow ' s daughter eleanor says they got up to 1 , 212 words .	527.5523
there was another family interest also .	521.70135
winslow had musical talents , as had his father before him .	224.35187
at different times he served as glee-club and choir leader and as organist .	4450.684
and it was lucy upton who first started the idea of a regular course in music at spelman college .	624.65
winslow upton after graduation from brown university and two years of graduate study , accepted a position at the harvard observatory .	552.15796
for three years he was connected with the u . s . naval observatory and with the u . s . signal corps	103.98321
and after 1883 , was professor of astronomy at brown university .	1200.5741
the six expeditions to study eclipses of the sun , of which he was a member , took him to colorado , virginia , and california as well as to the south pacific and to russia .	348.6203
after her father ' s death , lucy and her youngest sister lived for a few years with winslow in washington , d . c . .	204.53922
`` their house ' ' , writes albert s . flint , `` was always a haven of hospitality and good cheer , especially grateful to one like myself far from home ' ' .	387.9034
lucy was a lively part of the household .	114.514366
moreover , she had physical as well as mental vigor .	13483.281
winslow , as his daughters eleanor and margaret recall , used to characterize her as `` our iron sister ' ' .	934.8324
there is reason to suppose that lucy would have made a record as publicly distinguished as her brother had it not been that her mother ' s death occurred just as she was about to enter college .	507.6727
as a matter of fact , albert s . flint expressed his conviction that `` her physical strength , her mental power , her lively interest in all objects about her and her readiness to serve her fellow beings ' ' would have led her `` to a distinguished career amongst the noted women of this country ' ' .	482.02832
while in washington , d . c . , lucy upton held positions in the u . s . census office , and in the pension bureau .	108.92328
they were not sufficiently challenging however , and she resigned in 1887 , to go to germany with her brother winslow and his family while he was there on study .	481.75464
after the months in europe , she returned to boston and became active in church and community life .	298.1113
what was called an `` accidental meeting ' ' with miss packard in washington turned her attention to spelman .	653.3254
here was a cause she believed in .	539.4403
after correspondence with miss packard and to the joy of miss packard and miss giles , she came to atlanta , in the fall of 1888 , to help wherever needed , although there was then no money available to pay her a salary .	357.1506
she served for a number of years without pay beyond her travel and maintenance .	557.2643
her students have spoken of the exacting standards of scholarship and of manners and conduct she expected and achieved from the students	599.98114
of her `` great power of discernment ' '	825.2901
of `` her exquisiteness of dress ' ' , `` her well-modulated voice that went straight to the hearts of the hearers ' '	480.64246
her great love of flowers and plants and birds	789.59924
and her close knowledge of individual students .	112.91377
she drew on all her resources of mind and heart to help them -- to make them at home in the world	274.06537
and as graduates gratefully recall , she drew on her purse as well .	556.8809
many a student was able to remain at spelman , only because of her unobtrusive help .	456.24817
under miss upton , the work of the year 1909-10 went forward without interruption .	667.0037
after all , she had come to spelman seminary in 1888 , and had been since 1891 except for one year , associate principal or dean .	868.1409
she had taught classes in botany , astronomy ( with the aid of a telescope ) , geometry , and psychology .	481.4469
miss upton and miss packard , as a matter of fact , had many tastes in common .	270.8525
and both believed that intellectual growth must go hand in hand with the development of sturdy character and christian zeal .	1113.8829
both loved the out-of-doors , including mountain climbing and horseback riding .	3970.0627
in 1890 when the trip to europe and the holy land was arranged for miss packard , it was miss upton who planned the trip , and `` with rare executive ability ' ' bore the brunt of `` the entire pilgrimage from beginning to end ' ' .	457.50473
so strenuous it was physically , with its days of horseback riding over rough roads that it seems an amazing feat of endurance for both miss packard and miss upton .	1493.489
at the fifteenth anniversary ( 1896 ) as already quoted , miss upton projected with force and eloquence the spelman of the future as a college of first rank , with expanding and unlimited horizons .	748.26184
when dr . wallace buttrick , wise in his judgment of people , declined to have the science building named for him , he wrote miss tapley ( april 7 , 1923 ) `` if you had asked me , i think i would have suggested that you name the building for miss upton .	690.4701
her services to the school for many years were of a very high character , and i have often thought that one of the buildings should be named for her ' ' .	122.5498
such were the qualities of the acting-president of the seminary after the death of miss giles .	406.20343
at the meeting of the board of trustees , on march 3 , 1910 , miss upton presented the annual report of the president .	237.11107
she noted that no student had been withdrawn through loss of confidence	2292.5195
that the enrollment showed an increase of boarding students as was desired	2179.668
and that the year ' s work had gone forward smoothly .	349.77957
she urged the importance of more thorough preparation for admission .	502.67148
the raising of the $25 , 000 improvement fund two days before the time limit expired , and the spontaneous `` praise demonstration ' ' held afterward on the campus , were reported as events which had brought happiness to miss giles .	689.80304
with the fund in hand , the debt on the boilers had been paid	544.15155
rockefeller and packard halls had been renovated	2233.924
and ground had been broken for the superintendent ' s home .	153.45563
miss upton spoke gratefully of the response of spelman graduates and negro friends in helping to raise the fund , and their continuing efforts to raise money for greatly needed current expenses .	892.742
she spoke also with deep thankfulness of the many individuals and agencies whose interest and efforts through the years had made the work so fruitful in results .	716.38605
two bequests were recorded one of $200 under the will of mrs . harriet a . copp of los angeles	418.51138
and one of $2 , 000 under the will of miss celia l . brett of hamilton , new york , a friend from the early days .	458.02164
miss upton told the trustees that the death of miss giles was `` the sorest grief ' ' the seminary had ever been called upon to bear .	770.3863
the daughters of spelman , she said , had never known or thought of spelman without her .	582.4133
the removal of miss packard 18 years earlier had caused them great sorrow , but they still had miss giles .	2673.8596
now the school was indeed bereft .	12863.519
`` yet spelman has strong , deep roots , and will live for the blessing of generations to come ' ' .	373.57922
miss mary jane packard , sophia ' s half-sister , became ill in march , 1910	736.3301
and when school closed , she was unable to travel to massachusetts .	112.872696
she remained in atlanta through june and july	1034.7583
before coming on a visit to spelman in 1885 , miss mary had been a successful teacher in worcester , and her position there was held open for her for a considerable period .	486.41922
but she decided to stay at spelman .	342.83942
she helped with teaching as well as office work for a few years -- the catalogues show that she had classes in geography , rhetoric and bookkeeping .	932.4293
soon the office work claimed all her time .	767.47876
she was closely associated with the founders in all their trials and hardships .	302.60867
quiet and energetic , cheerful and calm , she too was a power in the development of the seminary .	328.6096
miss giles always used to refer to her as `` sister ' ' .	162.47717
she served as secretary in the seminary office for 25 years , and was in charge of correspondence , records , and bookkeeping .	218.52094
the books of the school hold a memorial to her	1017.50793
and so do the hearts of students and of teachers .	278.9368
mary j . packard , states a messenger editorial , was `` efficient , pains-taking , self-effacing , loving , radiating the spirit of her master .	1235.5278
with infinite patience she responded to every call , no matter at what cost to herself , and to her all went , for she was sure to have the needed information or word of cheer .	420.05624
in a few school districts one finds a link between school and job .	898.3661
in those vocational programs organized with smith-hughes money , there may be a close tie between the labor union and a local employer on the one hand and the vocational teacher on the other .	353.0385
in these cases a graduate may enter directly into an apprentice program , saving a year because of his vocational courses in grades 11 and 12 .	872.15027
the apprentice program will involve further education on a part-time basis , usually at night , perhaps using some of the same equipment of the high school .	340.46268
these opportunities are to be found in certain cities in such crafts as auto mechanics , carpentry , drafting , electrical work , tool-and-die work , and sheet-metal work .	1132.2537
formally organized vocational programs supported by federal funds allow high school students to gain experience in a field of work which is likely to lead to a full-time job on graduation .	550.18005
the `` diversified occupations ' ' program is a part-time trade-preparatory program conducted over two school years on a cooperative basis between the school and local industrial and business employers .	638.59717
the `` distributive education ' ' program operates in a similar way , with arrangements between the school and employers in merchandising fields .	393.4861
in both cases the student attends school half-time and works in a regular job the other half .	1296.2035
he receives remuneration for his work .	136.68582
in a few places cooperative programs between schools and employers in clerical work have shown the same possibilities for allowing the student , while still in school , to develop skills which are immediately marketable upon graduation .	1098.0978
adult education courses , work-study programs of various sorts -- these are all evidence of a continuing interest of the schools in furthering educational opportunities for out-of-school youth .	1270.0863
in general , however , it may be said that when a boy or a girl leaves the high school , the school authorities play little or no part in the decision of what happens next .	263.9644
if the student drops out of high school , the break with the school is even more complete .	237.75778
when there is employment opportunity for youth , this arrangement -- or lack of arrangement -- works out quite well .	835.9335
indeed , in some periods of our history and in some neighborhoods the job opportunities have been so good that undoubtedly a great many boys who were potential members of the professions quit school at an early age and went to work .	534.68243
statistically this has represented a loss to the nation , although one must admit that in an individual case the decision in retrospect may have been a wise one .	254.81514
i make no attempt to measure the enduring satisfaction and material well-being of a man who went to work on graduation from high school and was highly successful in the business which he entered .	379.8547
he may or may not be `` better off ' ' than his classmate who went on to a college and professional school .	239.67122
but in the next decades the nation needs to educate for the professions all the potential professional talent .	1209.2838
in a later chapter dealing with the suburban school , i shall discuss the importance of arranging a program for the academically talented and highly gifted youth in any high school where he is found .	502.01227
in the negro neighborhoods and also to some extent in the mixed neighborhoods the problem may be one of identification and motivation .	336.55222
high motivation towards higher education must start early enough so that by the time the boy or girl reaches grade 9 he or she has at least developed those basic skills which are essential for academic work .	810.0762
undoubtedly far more can be done in the lower grades in this regard in the negro schools .	158.38393
however , the teacher can only go so far if the attitude of the community and the family is anti-intellectual .	284.99158
and the fact remains that there are today few shining examples of negroes in positions of intellectual leadership .	568.0269
this is not due to any policy of discrimination on the part of the northern universities .	162.93866
quite the contrary , as i can testify from personal experience as a former university president .	346.92206
rather we see here another vicious circle .	1452.627
the absence of successful negroes in the world of scholarship and science has tended to tamp down enthusiasm among negro youth for academic careers .	906.95636
i believe the situation is improving , but the success stories need to be heavily publicized .	481.6662
here again we run into the roadblock that negroes do not like to be designated as negroes in the press .	279.42938
how can the vicious circle be broken ? ?	526.2318
this is a problem to which leaders of opinion , both negro and white , should devote far more attention .	460.62643
it is at least as important as the more dramatic attempts to break down barriers of inequality in the south .	571.0844
i should like to underline four points i made in my first report with respect to vocational education .	694.24585
first and foremost , vocational courses should not replace courses which are essential parts of the required academic program for graduation .	635.7455
second , vocational courses should be provided in grades 11 and 12 and not require more than half the student ' s time in those years	340.4434
however , for slow learners and prospective dropouts these courses ought to begin earlier .	4961.145
third , the significance of the vocational courses is that those enrolled are keenly interested in the work	431.28787
they realize the relevance of what they are learning to their future careers , and this sense of purpose is carried over to the academic courses which they are studying at the same time .	253.75392
fourth , the type of vocational training programs should be related to the employment opportunities in the general locality .	382.12302
this last point is important because if high school pupils are aware that few , if any , graduates who have chosen a certain vocational program have obtained a job as a consequence of the training , the whole idea of relevance disappears .	601.4704
vocational training which holds no hope that the skill developed will be in fact a marketable skill becomes just another school `` chore ' ' for those whose interest in their studies has begun to falter .	539.75085
those who , because of population mobility and the reputed desire of employers to train their own employees , would limit vocational education to general rather than specific skills ought to bear in mind the importance of motivation in any kind of school experience .	975.7983
i have been using the word `` vocational ' ' as a layman would at first sight think it should be used .	330.34216
i intend to include under the term all the practical courses open to boys and girls .	503.97925
these courses develop skills other than those we think of when we use the adjective `` academic ' ' .	392.82358
practically all of these practical skills are of such a nature that a degree of mastery can be obtained in high school sufficient to enable the youth to get a job at once on the basis of the skill .	277.1426
they are in this sense skills marketable immediately on graduation from high school .	2453.5544
to be sure , in tool-and-die work and in the building trades , the first job must be often on an apprentice basis , but two years of half-time vocational training enables the young man thus to anticipate one year of apprentice status .	944.22784
similarly , a girl who graduates with a good working knowledge of stenography and the use of clerical machines and who is able to get a job at once may wish to improve her skill and knowledge by a year or two of further study in a community college or secretarial school .	556.2976
of course , it can be argued that an ability to write english correctly and with some degree of elegance is a marketable skill .	545.90186
so , too , is the mathematical competence of a college graduate who has majored in mathematics .	666.8435
in a sense almost all high school and college courses could be considered as vocational to the extent that later in life the student in his vocation ( which may be a profession ) will be called upon to use some of the skills developed and the competence obtained .	418.3723
in spite of the shading of one type of course into another , i believe it is useful to talk about vocational courses as apart from academic courses .	441.70297
perhaps a course in typewriting might be regarded as the exception which proves the rule .	1089.088
today many college bound students try to take a course in personal typing , as they feel a certain degree of mastery of this skill is almost essential for one who proposes to do academic work in college and a professional school .	577.4259
most of our largest cities have one or more separate vocational or technical high schools .	797.88654
in this respect , public education in the large cities differs from education in the smaller cities and consolidated school districts .	538.82587
the neighborhood high schools are not , strictly speaking , comprehensive schools , because some of the boys and girls may be attending a vocational or technical high school instead of the local school .	423.7256
indeed , one school superintendent in a large city objects to the use of the term comprehensive high school for the senior high schools in his city , because these schools do not offer strictly vocational programs .	394.0569
he prefers to designate such schools as `` general ' ' high schools .	245.15137
the suburban high school , it is worth noting , also is not a widely comprehensive high school because of the absence of vocational programs .	399.59436
the reason is that there is a lack of interest on the part of the community .	62.868908
therefore employment and education in all the schools in a metropolitan area are related in different ways from those which are characteristic of the comprehensive high school described in my first report .	344.231
the separate vocational or technical high schools in the large cities must be reckoned as permanent institutions .	575.1163
by and large their programs are satisfactorily connected both to the employment situation and to the realities of the apprentice system .	384.67224
it is not often realized to what degree certain trades are in many communities closed areas of employment , except for a lucky few .	975.5834
one has to talk confidentially with some of the directors of vocational high schools to realize that a boy cannot just say , `` i want to be a plumber ' ' , and then , by doing good work , find a job .	252.07687
it is far more difficult in many communities to obtain admission to an apprentice program which involves union approval than to get into the most selective medical school in the nation .	514.8438
two stories will illustrate what i have in mind .	89.47872
one vocational instructor in a city vocational school , speaking of his course in a certain field , said he had no difficulty placing all students in jobs outside of the city .	306.38998
in the city , he said , the waiting list for those who want to join the union is so long that unless a boy has an inside track he can ' t get in .	297.69733
in a far distant part of the united states , i was talking to an instructor about a boy who in the twelfth grade was doing special work .	260.2006
`` what does he have in mind to do when he graduates ' ' ? ?	69.37584
`` oh , he ' ll be a plumber ' ' , came the answer .	144.13982
`` but isn ' t it almost impossible to get into the union ' ' ? ?	51.46368
`` he ' ll have no difficulty ' ' , i was told .	62.99218
`` he has very good connections ' ' .	83.29298
in my view , there should be a school which offers significant vocational programs for boys within easy reach of every family in a city .	419.14526
ideally these schools should be so located that one or more should be in the area where demand for practical courses is at the highest .	260.62427
an excellent example of a successful location of a new vocational high school is the dunbar vocational high school in chicago .	388.19446
located in a bad slum area now undergoing redevelopment , this school and its program are especially tailored to the vocational aims of its students .	687.6027
hardly a window has been broken since dunbar first was opened ( and vandalism in schools is a major problem in many slum areas ) .	1045.1984
i discovered in the course of a visit there that almost all the pupils were negroes .	330.3039
they were learning trades as diverse as shoe repairing , bricklaying , carpentry , cabinet making , auto mechanics , and airplane mechanics .	2354.0605
the physical facilities at dunbar are impressive , but more impressive is the attitude of the pupils .	331.33743
the soybean seed is the most important leguminous food in the world .	517.1202
in the united states , where half of the world crop is grown , soybeans are processed for their edible oil .	784.6666
the residue from soybean processing goes mainly into animal feeds .	3497.402
soybeans are extensively processed into a remarkable number of food products in the orient .	354.79413
american chemists , seeking to increase exports of soybeans , have adapted modern techniques and fermentation methods to improve their use in such traditional japanese foods as tofu and miso and in tempeh of indonesia .	1937.0363
soybean flour , grits , flakes , `` milk ' ' , and curd can be bought in the united states .	83.02242
peanuts are the world ' s second most important legume .	563.93634
they are used mainly for their oil .	255.21252
we produce peanut oil , but to a much greater extent we eat the entire seed .	425.4984
blanched peanuts , as prepared for making peanut butter or for eating as nuts , are roasted seeds whose seedcoats have been rubbed off .	2284.816
cereal grains , supplemented with soybeans or dry edible peas or beans , comprise about two-thirds or three-fourths of the diet in parts of asia and africa .	1024.8075
in western europe and north america , where the level of economic development is higher , grains and other seed products furnish less than one-third of the food consumed .	638.7936
rather , meat and potatoes , sugar , and dairy products are the main sources of carbohydrate , protein , oils , and fats .	476.7777
people depend less on seeds for foods in australia , new zealand , and argentina , where extensive grazing lands support sheep or cattle , and the consumption of meat is high .	2674.3008
feeds for livestock took about one-sixth of the world ' s cereal crop in 1957-1958 .	682.51404
most of the grain is fed to swine and dairy cows and lesser amounts to beef cattle and poultry .	1366.1428
about 90 percent of the corn used in the united states is fed to animals .	219.1932
the rest is used for human food and industrial products .	384.99008
more than half of the sorghum and barley seeds we produce and most of the byproducts of the milling of cereals and the crushing of oilseeds are fed to livestock .	1125.7782
more than 200 million tons of seeds and seed products are fed to livestock annually in the united states .	476.33777
the efficiency with which animals convert grains and forages to meat has risen steadily in the united states since the 1930 ' s and has paralleled the increased feeding of the cake and meal that are a byproduct when seeds are processed for oil .	899.7182
the demand for food is so great in the world that little arable land can be given over to growing the nonfood crops .	755.2728
seeds grown for industrial uses hold a relatively minor position .	1103.3916
chief among the seed crops grown primarily for industrial uses are the oil-bearing seeds -- flax , castor , tung ( nuts from the china wood-oil tree ) , perilla ( from an oriental mint ) , and oiticica ( from a brazilian tree ) .	2578.4192
oils , or liquid fats , from the seeds of flax and tung have long been the principal constituents of paints and varnishes for protecting and beautifying the surfaces of wood and metal .	1900.4413
these oils develop hard , smooth films when they dry and form resinlike substances .	2542.5962
the artist who paints in oil uses drying oils to carry the pigments and to protect his finished work for the ages .	662.74286
one of the finest of artists ' oils comes from poppy seeds .	2160.5193
seeds of soybean , cotton , corn , sesame , and rape yield semidrying oils .	1499.278
some are used in paints along with drying oils .	4004.105
palm oil protects the surfaces of steel sheets before they are plated with tin .	3179.0413
castor oil , made from castorbeans , has gone out of style as a medicine .	512.9298
this nondrying oil , however , is now more in demand than ever before as a fine lubricant , as a constituent of fluids for hydraulically operated equipment , and as a source of chemicals to make plastics .	783.51953
almond oil , another nondrying oil , was once used extensively in perfumery to extract flower fragrances .	9289.045
it is still used in drugs and cosmetics , but it is rather scarce and sometimes is adulterated with oils from peach and plum seeds .	1716.5618
liquid fats from all these oilseeds enter into the manufacture of soaps for industry and the household and of glycerin for such industrial uses as making explosives .	1911.7461
sizable amounts of soybean , coconut , and palm kernel oil -- seed oils that are produced primarily for food purposes -- also are used to make soaps , detergents , and paint resins .	1040.3186
solid fats from the seeds of the mahua tree , the shea tree , and the coconut palm are used to make candles in tropical countries .	848.16797
seeds are a main source of starch for industrial and food use in many parts of the world .	446.7215
corn and wheat supply most of the starch in the united states , canada , and australia .	145.97052
in other countries where cereal grains are not among the principal crops of a region , starchy tubers or roots are processed for starch .	1941.3962
starch is used in the paper , textile , and food-processing industries and in a multitude of other manufacturing operations .	774.4603
gums were extracted from quince , psyllium ( fleawort ) , flax , and locust ( carob ) seeds in ancient times .	996.0668
today the yearly import into the united states of locust bean gum is more than 15 million pounds	1418.8618
of psyllium seed , more than 2 . 6 million .	274.79004
the discovery during the second world war that guar gum was similar to imported locust gum increased its cultivation in western asia and initiated it in the united states .	1082.3097
water-soluble gums are used in foods and drugs and in the manufacture of pulp and paper as thickeners , stabilizers , or dispersing agents .	2538.4702
guar gum thickens salad dressings and stabilizes ice cream .	1286.8033
quince seed gum is the main ingredient in wave-setting lotions .	8030.86
once regarded as an agricultural nuisance , psyllium was sold in the 1930 ' s as a mechanical laxative under 117 different brands .	2444.0007
locust gum is added to pulp slurries to break up the lumps of fibers in making paper .	2113.206
the seeds of hard , fibrous , stony fruits , called nuts , provide highly concentrated foods , oils , and other materials of value .	1053.0922
most nuts consist of the richly packaged storage kernel and its thick , adherent , brown covering -- the seedcoat .	3272.8743
the kernels of brazil nuts , cashews , coconuts , filberts , hazelnuts , hickory nuts , pecans , walnuts , and pine nuts are predominantly oily .	1525.5563
almonds and pistachio nuts are not so high in oil but are rich in protein .	557.4816
all nut kernels are rich in protein .	809.2542
the world production of familiar seed nuts -- almonds , brazil nuts , filberts , and the english walnuts -- totals about 300 thousand tons annually .	3139.8652
coconuts , the fruit of the coconut palm , have the largest of all known seeds and are grown in south pacific islands as a crop for domestic and export markets .	727.50653
the oil palm of west africa yields edible oil from both the flesh and the seed or kernel of its fruit .	1739.3728
world production of copra , the oil-bearing flesh of the coconut , was a little more than 3 million tons in 1959 .	306.27722
exports from producing countries in terms of equivalent oil were a little more than 1 million tons , about half of which was palm kernels or oil from them and about half was palm oil .	666.1834
other nuts consumed in lesser quantity include the spicy nutmeg	42915.87
the soap nut , which owes its sudsing power to natural saponins	40669.227
the marking nut , used for ink and varnish	16141.653
the aromatic sassafras nut of south america	374.15253
and the sweet-smelling cumara nut , which is suited for perfumes .	1130.525
a forest crop that has not been extensively cultivated is ivory nuts from the tagua palm .	2358.016
the so-called vegetable ivory is the hard endosperm of the egg-sized seed .	1721.1049
it is used for making buttons and other small , hard objects of turnery .	1340.1263
seeds of the sago palm are used in bermuda to make heads and faces of dolls sold to tourists .	3288.9666
the color and shape of seeds have long made them attractive for ornaments and decorations .	1035.514
since biblical times , rosaries have been made from jobs-tears -- the seeds of an asiatic grass .	2897.1084
bead tree seeds are the necklaces of south pacific islanders and the eyes of buddha dolls in cuba .	2329.2224
victorian ladies had a fad of stringing unusual seeds to wear as jewelry .	6224.5747
handmade christmas wreaths and trees often contain a variety of seeds collected during the year .	642.27795
tradition has assigned medicinal values to seeds because of their alkaloids , aromatic oils , and highly flavored components .	2190.882
although science has given us more effective materials , preparations from anise , castorbean , colchicum , nux vomica , mustard , fennel , and stramonium are familiar to many for the relief of human ailments .	1073.1412
flaxseed poultices and mustard plasters still are used by some persons .	660.57184
peanut and sesame oils often are used as carriers or diluents for medicines administered by injection .	3090.868
still another group of seeds ( sometimes tiny , dry , seed-bearing fruits ) provide distinctive flavors and odors to foods , although the nutrients they supply are quite negligible .	11648.317
the common spices , flavorings , and condiments make up this group .	1810.4476
