you will come to alemagna , a delightful , though moderately expensive restaurant , which is particularly noted for its exceptional selection of ice creams and patisseries .	2632.635
either here , or in one of the modest restaurants nearby , is just the place to end this first walk through the heart of rome .	265.5184
the second walk through the heart of rome should be taken after lunch , so that you will reach the pincian hill when the soft light of the late afternoon is at its best .	317.84592
rare , indeed , is the harlem citizen , from the most circumspect church member to the most shiftless adolescent , who does not have a long tale to tell of police incompetence , injustice , or brutality .	677.2934
i myself have witnessed and endured it more than once .	493.63812
the businessmen and racketeers also have a story .	306.0279
( and this is not , perhaps , the place to discuss harlem ' s very complex attitude toward black policemen , nor the reasons , according to harlem , that they are nearly all downtown .	346.62308
it is hard , on the other hand , to blame the policeman , blank , good-natured , thoughtless , and insuperably innocent , for being such a perfect representative of the people he serves .	613.3737
he , too , believes in good intentions and is astounded and offended when they are not taken for the deed .	692.78784
he has never , himself , done anything for which to be hated -- which of us has ? ?	274.19827
-- and yet he is facing , daily and nightly , people who would gladly see him dead , and he knows it .	531.2062
there is no way for him not to know it there are few things under heaven more unnerving than the silent , accumulating contempt and hatred of a people .	661.1183
he moves through harlem , therefore , like an occupying soldier in a bitterly hostile country	685.5108
which is precisely what , and where , he is , and is the reason he walks in twos and threes .	472.8644
and he is not the only one who knows why he is always in company the people who are watching him know why , too .	378.7751
any street meeting , sacred or secular , which he and his colleagues uneasily cover has as its explicit or implicit burden the cruelty and injustice of the white domination .	1255.0051
and these days , of course , in terms increasingly vivid and jubilant , it speaks of the end of that domination .	344.13895
the white policeman standing on a harlem street corner finds himself at the very center of the revolution now occurring in the world .	302.17004
he is not prepared for it -- naturally , nobody is -- and , what is possibly much more to the point , he is exposed , as few white people are , to the anguish of the black people around him .	220.19722
even if he is gifted with the merest mustard grain of imagination , something must seep in .	2113.219
he cannot avoid observing that some of the children , in spite of their color , remind him of children he has known and loved , perhaps even of his own children .	186.41348
he knows that he certainly does not want his children living this way .	419.56317
he can retreat from his uneasiness in only one direction into a callousness which very shortly becomes second nature .	1435.2181
he becomes more callous , the population becomes more hostile , the situation grows more tense , and the police force is increased .	414.50275
one day , to everyone ' s astonishment , someone drops a match in the powder keg and everything blows up .	1308.4457
before the dust has settled or the blood congealed , editorials , speeches , and civil-rights commissions are loud in the land , demanding to know what happened .	1384.976
what happened is that negroes want to be treated like men .	331.95877
negroes want to be treated like men a perfectly straightforward statement , containing only seven words .	1263.0587
people who have mastered kant , hegel , shakespeare , marx , freud , and the bible find this statement utterly impenetrable .	2587.1968
the idea seems to threaten profound , barely conscious assumptions .	2956.7378
a kind of panic paralyzes their features , as though they found themselves trapped on the edge of a steep place .	1051.1581
i once tried to describe to a very well-known american intellectual the conditions among negroes in the south .	408.39203
my recital disturbed him and made him indignant	1456.8438
and he asked me in perfect innocence , `` why don ' t all the negroes in the south move north ' ' ? ?	137.30307
i tried to explain what has happened , unfailingly , whenever a significant body of negroes move north .	840.6487
they do not escape jim crow they merely encounter another , not-less-deadly variety .	16478.664
they do not move to chicago , they move to the south side	282.46017
they do not move to new york , they move to harlem .	417.38855
the pressure within the ghetto causes the ghetto walls to expand , and this expansion is always violent .	1294.2407
white people hold the line as long as they can , and in as many ways as they can , from verbal intimidation to physical violence .	511.13382
but inevitably the border which has divided the ghetto from the rest of the world falls into the hands of the ghetto .	308.76743
the white people fall back bitterly before the black horde	5438.613
the landlords make a tidy profit by raising the rent , chopping up the rooms , and all but dispensing with the upkeep	2060.23
and what has once been a neighborhood turns into a `` turf ' ' .	222.33511
this is precisely what happened when the puerto ricans arrived in their thousands -- and the bitterness thus caused is , as i write , being fought out all up and down those streets .	735.2655
northerners indulge in an extremely dangerous luxury .	2006.1991
they seem to feel that because they fought on the right side during the civil war , and won , they have earned the right merely to deplore what is going on in the south , without taking any responsibility for it	335.1426
and that they can ignore what is happening in northern cities because what is happening in little rock or birmingham is worse .	991.2793
well , in the first place , it is not possible for anyone who has not endured both to know which is `` worse ' ' .	155.17392
i know negroes who prefer the south and white southerners , because `` at least there , you haven ' t got to play any guessing games ' ' ! !	201.86229
the guessing games referred to have driven more than one negro into the narcotics ward , the madhouse , or the river .	970.83
i know another negro , a man very dear to me , who says , with conviction and with truth , `` the spirit of the south is the spirit of america ' ' .	131.12775
he was born in the north and did his military training in the south .	177.62152
he did not , as far as i can gather , find the south `` worse ' '	159.25908
he found it , if anything , all too familiar .	455.20312
in the second place , though , even if birmingham is worse , no doubt johannesburg , south africa , beats it by several miles , and buchenwald was one of the worst things that ever happened in the entire history of the world .	522.3152
the world has never lacked for horrifying examples	15989.179
but i do not believe that these examples are meant to be used as justification for our own crimes .	468.7496
this perpetual justification empties the heart of all human feeling .	155.85437
the emptier our hearts become , the greater will be our crimes .	297.9277
thirdly , the south is not merely an embarrassingly backward region , but a part of this country , and what happens there concerns every one of us .	576.08514
as far as the color problem is concerned , there is but one great difference between the southern white and the northerner the southerner remembers , historically and in his own psyche , a kind of eden in which he loved black people and they loved him .	548.9924
historically , the flaming sword laid across this eden is the civil war .	422.3414
personally , it is the southerner ' s sexual coming of age , when , without any warning , unbreakable taboos are set up between himself and his past .	698.6084
everything , thereafter , is permitted him except the love he remembers and has never ceased to need .	754.4795
the resulting , indescribable torment affects every southern mind and is the basis of the southern hysteria .	1203.6575
none of this is true for the northerner .	401.48343
negroes represent nothing to him personally , except , perhaps , the dangers of carnality .	491.80106
southerners see them all the time .	43.675354
northerners never think about them whereas southerners are never really thinking of anything else .	4461.3975
negroes are , therefore , ignored in the north and are under surveillance in the south , and suffer hideously in both places .	660.70917
neither the southerner nor the northerner is able to look on the negro simply as a man .	228.16434
it seems to be indispensable to the national self-esteem that the negro be considered either as a kind of ward ( in which case we are told how many negroes , comparatively , bought cadillacs last year and how few , comparatively , were lynched ) , or as a victim ( in which case we are promised that he will never vote in our assemblies or go to school with our kids ) .	581.4737
they are two sides of the same coin and the south will not change -- cannot change -- until the north changes .	288.0349
the country will not change until it re-examines itself and discovers what it really means by freedom .	882.9065
in the meantime , generations keep being born , bitterness is increased by incompetence , pride , and folly , and the world shrinks around us .	1966.802
it is a terrible , an inexorable , law that one cannot deny the humanity of another without diminishing one ' s own in the face of one ' s victim , one sees oneself .	325.4852
walk through the streets of harlem and see what we , this nation , have become .	359.02222
east river , downtown postscript to a letter from harlem	3687.3406
the fact that american negroes rioted in the u . n . while adlai stevenson was addressing the assembly shocked and baffled most white americans .	1412.4578
stevenson ' s speech , and the spectacular disturbance in the gallery , were both touched off by the death , in katanga , the day before , of patrice lumumba .	328.66397
stevenson stated , in the course of his address , that the united states was `` against ' ' colonialism .	109.53287
god knows what the african nations , who hold 25 per cent of the voting stock in the u . n . were thinking -- they may , for example , have been thinking of the u . s . abstention when the vote on algerian freedom was before the assembly -- but i think i have a fairly accurate notion of what the negroes in the gallery were thinking .	181.04657
i had intended to be there myself .	231.12248
it was my first reaction upon hearing of lumumba ' s death .	325.55084
i was curious about the impact of this political assassination on negroes in harlem , for lumumba had -- has -- captured the popular imagination there .	787.1238
i was curious to know if lumumba ' s death , which is surely among the most sinister of recent events , would elicit from `` our ' ' side anything more than the usual , well-meaning rhetoric .	577.3199
and i was curious about the african reaction .	276.34796
however , the chaos on my desk prevented my being in the u . n . gallery .	202.64104
had i been there , i , too , in the eyes of most americans , would have been merely a pawn in the hands of the communists .	135.93536
the climate and the events of the last decade , and the steady pressure of the `` cold ' ' war , have given americans yet another means of avoiding self-examination , and so it has been decided that the riots were `` communist ' ' inspired .	350.27045
nor was it long , naturally , before prominent negroes rushed forward to assure the republic that the u . n . rioters do not represent the real feeling of the negro community .	273.25632
according , then , to what i take to be the prevailing view , these rioters were merely a handful of irresponsible , stalinist-corrupted provocateurs .	1622.8972
it is a view which even a minimal effort at observation would immediately contradict .	1212.937
one has only , for example , to walk through harlem and ask oneself two questions .	562.055
the first question is would i like to live here ? ?	203.75015
and the second question is why don ' t those who now live here move out ? ?	211.35565
the answer to both questions is immediately obvious .	722.7026
unless one takes refuge in the theory -- however disguised -- that negroes are , somehow , different from white people , i do not see how one can escape the conclusion that the negro ' s status in this country is not only a cruel injustice but a grave national liability .	326.26694
now , i do not doubt that , among the people at the u . n . that day , there were stalinist and professional revolutionists acting out of the most cynical motives .	329.83173
wherever there is great social discontent , these people are , sooner or later , to be found .	357.95996
their presence is not as frightening as the discontent which creates their opportunity .	882.9638
what i find appalling -- and really dangerous -- is the american assumption that the negro is so contented with his lot here that only the cynical agents of a foreign power can rouse him to protest .	697.014
it is a notion which contains a gratuitous insult , implying , as it does , that negroes can make no move unless they are manipulated .	733.7385
color was delayed until 1935 , the wide screen until the early fifties .	576.6305
movement itself was the chief and often the only attraction of the primitive movies of the nineties .	459.50674
each film consisted of fifty feet , which gives a running time of about one minute on the screen .	386.87173
as long as audiences came to see the movement , there seemed little reason to adventure further .	467.40106
motion-picture exhibitions took place in stores in a general atmosphere like that of the penny arcade which can still be found in such urban areas as times square .	513.1027
brief snips of actual events were shown parades , dances , street scenes .	1649.7571
the sensational and frightening enjoyed popularity a train rushes straight at the audience , or a great wave threatens to break over the seats .	992.90094
an early edison production was the execution of mary , queen of scots .	605.1874
the unfortunate queen mounted the scaffold	1172.7808
an early film by a competitor of the wizard of menlo park simply showed a long kiss performed by two actors of the contemporary stage .	1623.8085
in the field of entertainment there is no spur to financial daring so effective as audience boredom , and the first decade of the new device was not over before audiences began staying away in large numbers from the simple-minded , one-minute shows .	1501.0176
in response , the industry allowed the discovery of the motion picture as a form of fiction and thus gave the movies the essential form they have had to this day .	309.3134
despite the sheer beauty and spectacle of numerous documentaries , art films , and travelogues , despite the impressive financial success of such a recent development as cinerama , the movies are at heart a form of fiction , like the play , the novel , or the short story .	508.4891
moreover , the most artistically successful of the nonfiction films have invariably borrowed the narrative form from the fiction feature .	1440.3187
thus such great american documentaries as the river and the plow that broke the plains were composed as visual stories rather than as illustrated lectures .	1342.0632
the discovery that movies are a form of fiction was made in the early years of this century and it was made chiefly by two men , a french magician , georges melies , and an american employee of edison , edwin s . porter .	430.25632
of the two , porter is justly the better known , for he went far beyond the vital finding of fiction for films to take the first step toward fashioning a language of film , toward making the motion picture the intricate , efficient time machine that it has remained since , even in the most inept hands .	730.32294
melies , however , out of his professional instincts as a magician , discovered and made use of a number of illusionary techniques that remain part of the vocabulary of film .	775.10016
one of these is the `` dissolve ' ' , which makes possible a visually smooth transition from scene to scene .	648.92706
as the first scene begins to fade , the succeeding scene begins to appear .	980.2596
for a moment or two , both scenes are present simultaneously , one growing weaker , one growing stronger .	852.8293
in a series of fairy tales and fantasies , melies demonstrated that the film is superbly equipped to tell a straightforward story , with beginning , middle and end , complications , resolutions , climaxes , and conclusions .	1168.4916
immediately , the film improved and it improved because in narrative it found a content based on time to complement its own unbreakable connection with time .	1135.3792
physically , a movie is possible because a series of images is projected one at a time at such a speed that the eye `` remembers ' ' the one that has gone before even as it registers the one now appearing .	396.2883
linking the smoothly changing images together , the eye itself endows them with the illusion of movement .	1041.339
the `` projection ' ' time of painting and sculpture is highly subjective , varying from person to person and even varying for a given person on different occasions .	796.35547
so is the time of the novel .	43.210964
the drama in the theater and the concert in the hall both have a fixed time , but the time is fixed by the director and the players , the conductor and the instrumentalists , subject , therefore , to much variation , as record collectors well know .	280.85416
the time of the motion picture is fixed absolutely .	2028.9581
the film consists of a series of still , transparent photographs , or `` frames ' ' , 35-mm . -wide .	536.35986
each frame comes between the light and the lens and is individually projected on the screen , at the rate , for silent movies , of 16 frames per second , and , for sound films , 24 frames per second .	455.1107
this is the rate of projection	1159.9651
it is also the rate of photographing .	703.1613
time is built into the motion picture , which cannot exist without time .	255.95166
now time is also the concern of the fictional narrative , which is , at its simplest , the story of an action with , usually , a beginning , a middle , and an end -- elements which demand time as the first condition for their existence .	189.97745
the `` moving ' ' picture of the train or the wave coming at the audience is , to be sure , more intense than a still picture of the same subject , but the difference is really one of degree	284.59232
the cinematic element of time is merely used to increase the realism of an object which would still be reasonably realistic in a still photo .	364.13507
in narrative , time is essential , as it is in film .	102.46159
almost everything about the movies that is peculiarly of the movies derives from a tension created and maintained between narrative time and film time .	2120.4685
this discovery of melies was vastly more important than his sometimes dazzling , magician ' s tricks produced on film .	1470.5913
it was porter , however , who produced the very first movie whose name has lived on through the half century of film history that has since ensued .	509.93628
the movie was the great train robbery and its effects on the young industry and art were all but incalculable .	1053.1438
overnight , for one thing , porter ' s film multiplied the standard running time of movies by ten .	675.0609
the great train robbery is a one-reel film .	1410.7568
one reel -- from eight to twelve minutes -- became the standard length from the year of robbery , 1903 , until griffith shattered that limit forever with birth of a nation in 1915 .	950.5052
the reel itself became and still is the standard of measure for the movies .	469.4202
the material of the porter film is simplicity itself	2846.7104
much of it has continued to be used over the years and the heart of it -- good guys and bad guys in the old west -- pretty well dominated television toward the end of the 1950 ' s .	302.2447
a band of robbers enters a railroad station , overpowers and ties up the telegraph operator , holds up the train and escapes .	1472.4277
a posse is formed and pursues the robbers , who , having made their escape , are whooping it up with some wild , wild women in a honky-tonk hide-out .	1716.6101
the robbers run from the hide-out , take cover in a wooded declivity , and are shot dead by the posse .	767.4564
as a finale is appended a close-up of one of the band taking aim and firing his revolver straight at the audience .	878.4845
all this is simple enough , but in telling the story porter did two important things that had not been done before .	1301.7173
each scene is shot straight through , as had been the universal custom , from a camera fixed in a single position , but in the outdoor scenes , especially in the capture and destruction of the outlaws , porter ' s camera position breaks , necessarily , with the camera position standard until then , which had been , roughly , that of a spectator in a center orchestra seat at a play .	447.0241
the plane of the action in the scene is not parallel with the plane of the film in the camera or on the screen .	153.12532
if the change , at first sight , seems minor , we may recall that it took the italian painters about two hundred years to make an analogous change , and the italian painters , by universal consent , were the most brilliant group of geniuses any art has seen .	593.9687
in that apparently simple shift porter opened the way to the sensitive use of the camera as an instrument of art as well as a mechanical recording device .	451.07568
he revealed the potential value of the `` cut ' ' as the basic technique in the art of the film .	101.699326
cutting , of course , takes place automatically in the creation of a film .	259.0977
the meaning of the word is quite physical , to begin with .	345.33316
the physical film is cut with a knife at the end of one complete sequence , and the cut edge is joined physically , by cement , to the cut edge of the beginning of the next sequence .	275.23645
if , as a home movie maker , you shoot the inevitable footage of your child taking its first steps , you have merely recorded an historical event .	1082.8848
if , in preparing that shot for the inevitable showing to your friends , you interrupt the sequence to paste in a few frames of the child ' s grandmother watching this event , you have begun to be an artist in film	373.12738
you are employing the basic technique of film	1065.9478
as the robbers leave the looted train , the film suddenly cuts back to the station , where the telegrapher ' s little daughter arrives with her father ' s dinner pail only to find him bound on the floor .	648.4894
the two events are taking place at the same time .	201.66862
time and space have both become cinematic .	7816.015
we leap from event to event -- including the formation of the posse -- even though the events , in `` reality ' ' are taking place not in sequence but simultaneously , and not near each other but at a considerable distance .	395.5686
the `` chase ' ' as a standard film device probably dates from the great train robbery , and there is a reason for the continued popularity of the device .	292.7631
the chase in itself is a narrative	483.94098
it presumes both speed and urgency and it demands cutting -- both from pursued to pursuer and from stage to stage of the journey of both .	1138.4882
the simple , naked idea of one man chasing another is of its nature better fitted for the film than it is for any other form of fiction .	506.33746
the cowboy films , the cops and robbers films , and the slapstick comedy films culminating in an insane chase are not only catering to what critics may assume to be a vulgar taste for violence	1627.9747
these films and these sequences are also seeking out -- instinctively or by design -- the peculiarly cinematic elements of narrative .	1742.8373
the creator of the art of the film d . w . griffith	227.35999
there still remained the need for one great film artist to explore the full potential of the new form and to make it an art .	340.43884
when he came to the movies -- more or less by accident -- they were still cheap entertainment capable of enthralling the unthinking for an idle few minutes .	1044.3689
in about seven years griffith either invented or first realized the possibilities of virtually every resource at the disposal of the film maker .	1436.01
before he was forty griffith had created the art of the film .	348.4922
not that there had not been attempts , mostly european , to do exactly that .	427.3991
but in general the european efforts to make an art of the entertainment had ignored the slowly emerging language of the film itself .	605.1005
staggeringly condensed versions of famous novels and famous plays were presented .	1026.16
great actors and actresses -- the most notable being sarah bernhardt -- were hired to repeat their stage performances before the camera .	1459.2014
in all of this extensive and expensive effort , the camera was downgraded to the status of recording instrument for art work produced elsewhere by the actor or by the author .	692.19806
the phonograph today , for all its high fidelity and stereophonic sound , is precisely what the early art purveyors in the movies wished to make of the camera .	852.5329
not surprisingly , this approach did not work .	237.27136
the effort produced a valuable record of stage techniques in the early years of the century and some interesting records of great theater figures who would otherwise be only names .	416.9531
but no art at all was born of the art effort in the early movies .	206.28445
in general , religious interest seems to exist in all parts of the metropolis	290.11893
congregational membership , however , is another thing .	75.69135
a congregation survives only if it can sustain a socially homogeneous membership	1366.5155
that is , when it can preserve economic integration .	290.96887
religious faith can be considered a necessary condition of membership in a congregation , since the decision to join a worshiping group requires some motive force , but faith is not a sufficient condition for joining	633.7487
the presence of other members of similar social and economic level is the sufficient condition .	387.0769
the breakdown of social homogeneity in inner city areas and the spread of inner city blight account for the decline of central city churches .	1055.901
central cities reveal two adverse features for the major denominations ( 1 ) central cities tend to be areas of residence for lower social classes	403.05325
( 2 ) central cities tend to be more heterogeneous in social composition .	403.07767
the central city areas , in other words , exhibit the two characteristics which violate the life principle of congregations of the major denominations they have too few middle-class people	770.7093
they mix middle-class people with lower-class residents .	922.6359
central city areas have become progressively poorer locales for the major denominations since the exodus of middle-class people from most central cities .	1360.6072
with few exceptions , the major denominations are rapidly losing their hold on the central city .	619.60547
the key to protestant development , therefore , is economic integration of the nucleus of the congregation .	118.704765
members of higher and lower social status often cluster around this nucleus , so that protestant figures on social class give the impression of spread over all social classes	1346.1754
but this is deceptive , for the core of membership is concentrated in a single social and economic stratum .	291.64508
the congregation perishes when it is no longer possible to replenish that core from the neighborhood	520.68665
moreover , residential mobility is so high in metropolitan areas that churches have to recruit constantly in their core stratum in order to survive	637.0758
they can lose higher- and lower-status members from the church without collapsing , but they need adequate recruits for the core stratum in order to preserve economic integration .	729.361
the congregation is first and foremost an economic peer group	2663.2385
it is secondarily a believing and worshiping fellowship .	3485.5913
if it were primarily a believing fellowship , it would recruit believers from all social and economic ranks , something which most congregations of the new protestantism ( with a few notable exceptions ) have not been able to do .	408.49585
they survive only when they can recruit social and economic peers .	458.82407
the vulnerability of protestant congregations to social differences has often been attributed to the `` folksy spirit ' ' of protestant religious life	660.8633
in fact , a contrast is often drawn in this regard with the `` impersonal ' ' roman catholic parish .	635.837
we have seen that the folksy spirit is confined to economic peers	2095.955
consequently , the vulnerability to social difference should not be attributed to the stress on personal community in protestant congregations	373.24713
actually , there is little evidence of such personal community in protestant congregations , as we shall see in another connection .	285.69855
the vulnerability of protestantism to social differences stems from the peculiar role of the new religious style in middle-class life , where the congregation is a vehicle of social and economic group identity and must conform , therefore , to the principle of economic integration .	288.24567
this fact is evident in the recruitment of new members .	90.86069
the rule of economic integration in congregational life can be seen in the missionary outreach of the major denominations .	428.8463
there is much talk in theological circles about the `` church as mission ' ' and the `` church ' s mission ' '	220.6154
theologians have been stressing the fact that the church does not exist for its own sake but as a testimony in the world for the healing of the world .	128.82646
a crucial question , therefore , is what evangelism and mission actually mean in metropolitan protestantism .	485.08853
if economic integration really shapes congregational life , then evangelism should be a process of extending economic integration .	812.70984
the task of a congregation would be defined , according to economic integration , as the work of co-opting individuals and families of similar social and economic position to replenish the nuclear core of the congregation .	391.36896
( co-optation means to choose by joint action in order to fill a vacancy	582.2728
it can also mean the assimilation of centers of power from an environment in order to strengthen an organization .	254.9791
) in a mobile society , congregational health depends on a constant process of recruitment	2676.4187
this recruitment , however , must follow the pattern of economic integration or it will disrupt the congregation	332.42288
therefore , the recruitment or missionary outreach of the congregation will be co-optation rather than proclamation -- like elements will have to be assimilated .	586.4497
evangelism and congregational outreach have not been carefully studied in the churches	416.5662
one study in pittsburgh , however , has illuminated the situation .	132.35442
in a sample of new members of pittsburgh churches , almost 60 per cent were recruited by initial `` contacts with friendly members ' ' .	566.3725
if we add to these contacts with friendly members the `` contacts with an organization of the church ' ' ( 11 . 2 per cent of the cases ) , then a substantial two thirds of all recruitment is through friendly contact .	279.39114
on the surface , this seems a sound approach to christian mission members of the congregation show by their friendly attitudes that they care for new people	610.3546
the new people respond in kind by joining the church .	415.77994
missionary outreach by friendly contact looks somewhat different when one reflects on what is known about friendly contact in metropolitan neighborhoods	1642.4778
the majority of such contacts are with people of similar social and economic position	670.15326
association by level of achievement is the dominant principle of informal relations .	516.63074
this means that the antennae of the congregation are extended into the community , picking up the wave lengths of those who will fit into the social and economic level of the congregation	510.93472
the mission of the church is actually a process of informal co-optation	1142.268
the lay ministry is a means to recruit like-minded people who will strengthen the social class nucleus of the congregation .	551.0115
churches can be strengthened through this process of co-optation so long as the environs of the church provide a sufficient pool of people who can fit the pattern of economic integration	556.3798
once the pool of recruits diminishes , the congregation is helpless -- friendly contacts no longer keep it going .	1872.1584
the transmutation of mission to co-optation is further indicated by the insignificance of educational activities , worship , preaching , and publicity in reaching new members .	585.2197
the proclamation of the churches is almost totally confined to pastoral contacts by the clergy ( 17 . 3 per cent of new members ) and friendly contacts by members ( over two thirds if organizational activities are included ) .	1013.55945
publicity accounted for 1 . 1 per cent of the initial contacts with new members .	119.813774
in general , friendly contact with a member followed by contact with a clergyman will account for a major share of recruitment by the churches , making it quite evident that the extension of economic integration through co-optation is the principal form of mission in the contemporary church	583.49634
economic integration and co-optation are the two methods by which protestants associate with and recruit from the neighborhood .	879.217
the inner life of congregations will prosper so long as like-minded people of similar social and economic level can fraternize together	3419.9543
the outer life of congregations -- the suitability of the environment to their survival -- will be propitious so long as the people in the area are of the same social and economic level as the membership .	378.21198
economic integration ceases when the social and economic statuses in an area become too mixed or conflict with the status of the congregation .	395.74652
in a rapidly changing society congregations will run into difficulties repeatedly , since such nice balances of economic integration are hard to sustain in the metropolis for more than a single generation .	1088.2787
the fact that metropolitan churches of the major denominations have moved approximately every generation for the last hundred years becomes somewhat more intelligible in the light of this struggle to maintain economic balance .	402.90012
the expense of this type of organization in religious life , when one recalls the number of city churches which deteriorated beyond repair before being abandoned , raises fundamental questions about the principle of protestant survival in a mobile society	797.8838
nonetheless , the prevalence of economic integration in congregations illumines the nature of the protestant development .	569.86035
it was observed in the introductory chapter that metropolitan life had split into two trends -- expanding interdependence on an impersonal basis and growing exclusiveness in local communal groupings .	1945.893
these trends seem to be working at cross-purposes in the metropolis .	493.43762
residential associations struggle to insulate themselves against intrusions .	29443.314
the motifs of impersonal interdependence and insulation of residential communities have polarized	4212.895
the schism between central city and suburb , negro and white , blue collar and white collar can be viewed as symptomatic of this deeper polarization of trends in the metropolis .	773.12683
it now becomes evident that the denominational church is intimately involved with the economy of middle-class culture , for it serves to crystallize the social class identity of middle-class residential groupings .	804.32733
the accelerated pace of metropolitan changes has accentuated the drive to conformity in congregations of the major denominations .	1234.5962
this conformity represents a desperate attempt to stabilize a hopelessly unstable environment .	2121.472
more than creatures of metropolitan forces , the churches have taken the lead in counteracting the interdependence of metropolitan life , crystallizing and perpetuating the stratification of peoples , giving form to the struggle for social homogeneity in a world of heterogeneous peoples .	799.7922
since american life is committed above all to productivity and a higher standard of economic life , the countervailing forces of residential and religious exclusiveness have fought a desperate , rearguard action against the expanding interdependence of the metropolis .	1048.0581
consumer communities have suffered at the hands of the productive interests .	102.743004
negroes , puerto ricans , and rural newcomers are slowly making their way into the cities .	499.9445
soon they will fight their way into the lower middle-class suburbs , and the churches will experience the same decay and rebuilding cycle which has characterized their history for a century .	456.63382
the identification of the basic unit of religious organization -- the parish or congregation -- with a residential area is self-defeating in a modern metropolis , for it simply means the closing of an iron trap on the outreach of the christian fellowship and the transmutation of mission to co-optation .	555.6208
mission to the metropolis contradicts survival of the congregation in the residential community , because the middle classes are fighting metropolitan interdependence with residential exclusion .	1178.7062
this interpretation of the role of residence in the economy of middle-class culture could lead to various projections for the churches .	407.356
it could be argued that any fellowship which centers in residential neighborhoods is doomed to become an expression of the panic for stable identity among the middle classes .	756.4221
it could be argued that only such neighborhoods can sustain religious activity , since worship presupposes some local stabilities .	4016.121
whatever projection one makes , the striking fact about congregational and parochial life is the extent to which it is a vehicle of the social identity of middle-class people .	323.9687
attention will be given in the next chapter to the style of association in the denominational churches	355.88327
this style is characteristically an expression of the communal style of the middle classes .	364.57602
the keynotes of this style are activism and emphasis on achievements in gaining self-esteem .	5677.072
these values give direction to the life of the middle-class man or woman , dictating the methods of child rearing , determining the pattern of community participation , setting the style for the psychiatric treatment of middle-class illness , and informing the congregational life of the major denominations .	624.4603
`` fellowship by likeness ' ' and `` mission by friendly contact ' ' form the iron cage of denominational religion .	399.72125
its contents are another matter , for they reveal the kinds of interests pursued by the congregation .	863.2127
what goes on in the cage will occupy our attention under the rubric of the organization church .	741.4691
an understanding of the new role of residential association in an industrial society serves to illuminate the forces which have fashioned the iron cage of conformity which imprisons the churches in their suburban captivity .	1260.3141
the perplexing question still remains as to why the middle classes turn to the churches as a vehicle of social identity when their clubs and charities should fill the same need .	479.6234
with capital largely squandered , there seemed to them no other course to pursue .	318.09894
the directors sold directly to concessionaires , who had to make their profits above the high prices asked by the company .	353.09442
these concessionaires traded where they wished and generally dealt with the indians through engages , who might be habitants , voyageurs , or even soldiers .	734.03033
the concessionaires also had to pay a tax of one-tenth on the goods they traded , and all pelts were to be taken to company stores and shipped to france in company ships .	569.7353
the company disposed of the pelts , but with what profit , the records do not show .	233.98431
in accord with its penurious policy , the company failed to furnish presents to hold the loyalty of the principal indians .	585.8244
the lavish use of presents had been effective in expanding the indian trade of new france and louisiana in the previous century , and the change in liberality aroused resentment in the minds of the red men .	370.91528
traders from the english colonies were far more generous , and indian loyalty turned to them .	1008.0744
protests from governors and intendants passed unheeded , and the parsimonious policy of the company probably let loose indian insurrections that brought ruin to the company .	2400.4062
in 1721 the king sent three commissioners to louisiana with full powers to do all that was necessary to protect the colony .	360.81876
they ordered the raising of troops and obtained 75 , 000 livres with which to build forts .	680.7634
they adopted a program by which louisiana was divided into five districts .	803.15643
in each of these there was to be a strong military post , and a trading depot to supply the smaller trading houses .	364.91638
for southeastern louisiana , mobile was the principal post , and it was to furnish supplies for trade to the north and east , in the region threatened by british traders .	303.05255
mobile was to be the anchor of a chain of posts extending northward to the sources of the tennessee river .	418.5962
fort toulouse , on the alabama river , had been erected in 1714 for trade with the alabamas and choctaws , but money was available for only one other new post , near the present nashville , tennessee , and this was soon abandoned .	789.3714
west of the mobile district was the lower mississippi district , of which new orleans was headquarters .	398.19843
dependent upon it were posts on the lower mississippi and the region westward to the frontiers of new spain .	705.865
on the middle mississippi a principal post was to be located near the mouth of the arkansas .	231.92986
it was hoped that to this post would flow a large quantity of furs from the west , principally down the arkansas river .	662.965
on the ohio or wabash was to be built another post `` at the fork of two great rivers ' ' .	357.17532
other posts would be established up the ohio and wabash to protect communication with canada .	948.95056
on the upper mississippi the illinois post was to be established near kaskaskia , and dependent posts were to be built on the missouri , `` where there are mines in abundance ' ' .	287.87302
each of the five principal posts was to have a director , responsible to a director-general at new orleans .	717.2105
an elaborate system of accounting and reports was worked out , and the trade was to be managed in the most scientific way .	204.64117
concessionaires were to be under the supervision of the directors .	181.5072
engages must be loyal to the concessionaires , and must serve until the term provided in the engagement was ended .	245.267
the habitants were to be encouraged to trade and were to dispose of their pelts to the concessionaires .	288.53305
only two principal storehouses were actually established -- one at mobile , the other at new orleans .	490.84314
new orleans supplied the goods for the trade on the mississippi , and west of that river , and on the ohio and wabash .	197.50563
mobile was also supplied by new orleans with goods for the mobile district .	368.5662
the power that bienville exercised during his first administration cannot be determined .	448.37073
regulations for the indian trade were made by the conseil superieure de la louisiane , and bienville apparently did not have control of that body .	589.6806
the conseil even treated the serious matter of british aggression as its business and , on its own authority , sent to disaffected savages merchandise `` suitable for the peltry trade ' ' .	811.1531
it decided , also , that the purely secular efforts of bienville were insufficient , and sent missionaries to win the savages from the heathen carolinians .	1012.45856
during the first administration of bienville , the peltry trade of the mobile district was a lucrative source of revenue .	610.41595
the alabamas brought in annually 15 , 000 to 20 , 000 deerskins , and the choctaws and chickasaws brought the total up to 50 , 000 pelts .	589.4346
these deerskins were the raw material for the manufacture of leather , and were the only articles which the tribes of this district had to exchange for european goods .	753.461
during his first administration , bienville succeeded in keeping carolina traders out of the alabama country and the choctaw country .	915.60657
the director of the post at mobile kept an adequate amount of french goods , of a kind to which they were accustomed , to supply the indian needs .	440.80478
the alabama and tombigbee rivers furnished a highway by which goods could be moved quickly and cheaply .	1698.0768
de la laude , commander of the alabama post , had the friendship of the natives , and was able to make them look upon the british as poor competitors .	264.91678

he became , after a time , commander of a post on the alabama river , but his operations extended from mobile throughout the district , and he finally obtained a monopoly of the indian trade .	297.0465
the chickasaws were the principal source of trouble in the mobile district .	281.33963
their territory lay to the north , near the sources of the alabama , the tombigbee , the tennessee , and cumberland rivers , and was easily accessible to traders among the near-by cherokees .	713.7105
in 1720 some chickasaws massacred the french traders among them , and did not make peace for four years .	388.08414

there is much more freedom in the schools here than i expected -- some think too much .	471.25702

there seems to be no purpose in life that is sure -- no certain guiding principles to give stability .	656.5448
as a result , money is spent quickly and freely , with no thought of its value .	634.656
gambling is everywhere , especially among students .	684.8364

i was told that it is quite likely that japanese soldiers would not fight again -- for why should they ? ?	686.36615

the achievement of the desegregation of certain lunch counters not only by wise action by local community leaders but by voluntary action following consultation between attorney general rogers and the heads of certain national chain stores should , of course , be applauded .	1218.0276
but for it to be just to attain this same result by means of the force of a boycott throughout the nation would require the verification of facts contrary to those assumed in the foregoing case .	458.98666
the suppositions in the previous illustration might be sufficiently altered by establishing a connection between general company practice and local practice in the south , and by establishing such direct connection between the practice and the economic well-being of stores located in new york and general company policy .	624.03107
then the boycott would not be secondary , but a primary one .	99.29597
it would be directed against the actual location of the unjust policy which , for love ' s sake and for the sake of justice , must be removed , and , indivisible from this , to the economic injury of the people directly and objectively a part of this policy .	242.25034
perhaps this would be sufficient to justify an economic boycott of an entire national chain in order , by threatening potential injury to its entire economy , to effect an alteration of the policy of its local stores in the matter of segregation .	417.04517
such a general boycott might still be a blunt or indiscriminating instrument , and therefore of questionable justification .	1553.4784
action located where the evil is concentrated will prove most decisive and is most clearly legitimate .	989.45886
moreover , prudence alone would indicate that , unless the local customs are already ready to fall when pushed , the results of direct economic action everywhere upon national chain stores will likely be simply to give undue advantage to local and state stores which conform to these customs , leading to greater decentralization and local autonomy within the company , or even ( as the final self-defeat of an unjust application of economic pressure to correct injustice ) to its going out of business in certain sections of the country ( as , for that matter , the quakers , who once had many meetings in the pre-civil war south , largely went out of business in that part of the country over the slavery issue , never to recover a large number of southern adherents ) .	545.65906
in any case , anyone who fails to make significant distinction between primary and secondary applications of economic pressure would in principle already have justified that use of economic boycott as a means which broke out a few years ago or was skillfully organized by white citizens ' councils in the entire state of mississippi against every local philco dealer in that state , in protest against a philco-sponsored program over a national tv network on which was presented a drama showing , it seemed , a `` high yellow gal ' ' smooching with a white man .	1061.098
it is true , of course , that the end or objective of this action was different .	144.61229
but since this is a world in which people disagree about ends and goals and concerning justice and injustice , and since , in a situation where direct action and economic pressure are called for , the justice of the matter has either not been clearly defined by law or the law is not effectively present , there has to be a morality of means applied in every case in which people take it upon themselves to use economic pressures or other forms of force .	402.5274
the need that we not give unqualified approval to any but a limited use of economic pressure directed against the actual doers of injustice is clear also in light of the fact that white citizens ' councils seem resolved to maintain segregation mainly by the use of these same means and not ordinarily by physical violence .	942.05743
an unlimited use of economic pressures for diametrically opposite causes could devastate the pre-conditions of any fellow humanity as surely as this would be destroyed by the use of more obviously brutal means .	1411.0873
the end or aim of the action , of course , is also important , especially where it is not alone a matter of changing community customs but of the use of deadly economic power to intimidate a person from stepping forward to claim his legal rights , e . g . , against negroes who register to vote in fayette county , tennessee , at the present moment .	385.55646
here the recourse is in steps to give economic sustenance to those being despoiled , and to legal remedies .	3862.2625
this , however , is sufficient to show that more or less non-violent resistance and economic conflict ( if both sides are strong enough ) can be war of all against all no less than if other means are used .	446.9908
it is also sufficient to show the christian and any other champion of justice that he needs to make sure not only that his cause is just but also that his conduct is just , i . e . , that , if economic pressure has to be resorted to , this be applied directly against those persons directly in the way of some salutary change in business or institutional practices , while , if injury fall upon others , it fall upon them indirectly and secondarily ( however inevitably ) and not by deliberate intent and direct action against them .	510.1934
it is clear that non-violent resistance is a mode of action in need of justification and limitation in christian morality , like any other form of resistance .	711.62604
the language used itself often makes very clear that this is only another form of struggle for victory ( perhaps to be chosen above all others ) .	579.4714
one of the sit-in leaders has said `` nobody from the top of heaven to the bottom of hell can stop the march to freedom .	325.806

the present writer certainly agrees with that statement , and would also affirm this -- in the order of justice .	220.8836
however , it is also a christian insight to know that unless charity interpenetrates justice it is not likely to be freedom that marches forward .	1077.4956
and when charity interpenetrates man ' s struggle for justice and freedom it does not simply surround this with a sentimental good will .	504.32135
it also definitely fashions conduct in the way explained above , and this means far more than in the choice of non-violent means .	535.6174
r . b . gregg has written that `` non-violence and good will of the victim act like the lack of physical opposition by the user of physical jiu-jitsu , to cause the attacker to lose his moral balance .	1255.1481
he suddenly and unexpectedly loses the moral support which the usual violent resistance of most victims would render him ' '	628.7497
and again , that `` the object of non-violent resistance is partly analogous to this object of war -- namely , to demoralize the opponent , to break his will , to destroy his confidence , enthusiasm , and hope .	391.6124
in another respect it is dissimilar , for non-violent resistance demoralizes the opponent only to re-establish in him a new morale that is firmer because it is based on sounder values ' ' .	800.26746
a trial of strength , however , is made quite inevitable by virtue of the fact that anyone engaging in non-violent resistance will be convinced that his action is based on sounder values than those of his opponent	391.7958
and in warfare with any means , men commonly disagree over the justice of the cause .	417.65173
this makes necessary a morality of means , and principles governing the conduct of resistance whenever this is thought to be justified .	585.4737
the question , then , is whether sufficient discrimination in the use of even non-violent means of coercion is to be found in the fact that such conduct demoralizes and overcomes the opponent while re-moralizing and re-establishing him .	814.2176
here it is relevant to remember that men commonly regard some causes as more important than their lives	1041.8933

since the will and word of god are for them concentrated in christ-like love , it seems clear to them that non-violent resistance is quite another thing .	603.82104
