and therein , i feel , many northerners delude themselves about the south .	824.4563
for one thing , this is not a subject often discussed or analyzed .	617.25543
there seems to be almost a conspiracy of silence veiling it .	6212.708
i suppose the reason is a kind of wishful thinking don ' t talk about the final stages of reconstruction and they will take care of themselves .	278.37357
or else the north really believes that all southerners except a few quaint old characters have come around to realizing the errors of their past , and are now at heart sharers of the american dream , like everybody else .	841.7296
if the circumstances are faced frankly it is not reasonable to expect this to be true .	287.5809
the situation of the south since 1865 has been unique in the western world .	529.6843
regardless of rights and wrongs , a population and an area appropriate to a pre-world-war- 1 great power have been , following conquest , ruled against their will by a neighboring people , and have had imposed upon them social and economic controls they dislike .	1138.916
and the great majority of these people are of anglo-saxon or celtic descent .	671.8442
this is the only case in modern history of a people of britannic origin submitting without continued struggle to what they view as foreign domination .	1715.7876
the fact is due mainly to international wars , both hot and cold .	669.82
in every war of the united states since the civil war the south was more belligerent than the rest of the country .	101.61862
so instead of being tests of the south ' s loyalty , the spanish war , the two world wars , and the korean war all served to overcome old grievances and cement reunion .	423.2107
and there is no section of the nation more ardent than the south in the cold war against communism .	329.05222
had the situation been reversed , had , for instance , england been the enemy in 1898 because of issues of concern chiefly to new england , there is little doubt that large numbers of southerners would have happily put on their old confederate uniforms to fight as allies of britain .	973.1001
it is extraordinary that a people as proud and warlike as southerners should have been as docile as they have .	539.5465
the north should thank its stars that such has been the case	357.84033
but at the same time it should not draw false inferences therefrom .	1449.4559
the two main charges levelled against the bourbons by liberals is that they are racists and social reactionaries .	2097.0579
there is much truth in both these charges , and not many bourbons deny them .	485.19492
whatever their faults , they are not hypocrites .	328.9832
most of them sincerely believe that the anglo-saxon is the best race in the world and that it should remain pure .	185.9123
many northeners believe this , too , but few of them will say so publicly .	227.54968
the bourbon economic philosophy , moreover , is not very different from that of northern conservatives .	311.5096
but those among the bourbons who remain unreconstructed go much further than this .	2467.4705
they believe that if the south had been let alone it would have produced a civilization superior to that of modern america .	490.45404
as it is , they consider that the north is now reaping the fruits of excess egalitarianism , that in spite of its high standard of living the `` american way ' ' has been proved inferior to the english and scandinavian ways , although they disapprove of the socialistic features of the latter .	429.08725
the south ' s antipathy to northern civilization includes such charges as poor manners , harsh accents , lack of appreciation of the arts of living like gastronomy and the use of leisure .	1583.1853
their own easier , slower tempo is especially dear to southerners	5399.357
and i have heard many say that they are content to earn a half or a third as much as they could up north because they so much prefer the quieter habits of their home town .	947.52216
in the past , the duties of the state , as sir henry maine noted long ago , were only two in number internal order and external security .	449.1918
by prevailing over other claimants for the loyalties of men , the nation-state maintained an adequate measure of certainty and order within its territorial borders .	780.94653
outside those limits it asserted , as against other states , a position of sovereign equality , and , as against the `` inferior ' ' peoples of the non-western world , a position of dominance .	246.84485
it became the sole `` subject ' ' of `` international law ' ' ( a term which , it is pertinent to remember , was coined by bentham ) , a body of legal principle which by and large was made up of what western nations could do in the world arena .	280.65695
( that corpus of law was a reflection of the power system in existence during the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries .	304.17688
speaking generally , it furthered -- and still tends to further -- the interests of the western powers .	569.369
the enormous changes in world politics have , however , thrown it into confusion , so much so that it is safe to say that all international law is now in need of reexamination and clarification in light of the social conditions of the present era .	391.5909
beyond the two basic tasks mentioned above , no attention was paid by statesman or scholar to an idea of state responsibility , either internally or externally .	1022.6986
this was particularly true in the world arena , which was an anarchical battleground characterized by strife and avaricious competition for colonial empires .	2329.8674
that any sort of duty was owed by his nation to other nations would have astonished a nineteenth-century statesman .	1736.2844
his duty was to his sovereign and to his nation , and an extension to peoples beyond the territorial boundaries was not to be contemplated .	409.97382
thus , to cite but one example , the pax britannica of the nineteenth century , whether with the british navy ruling the seas or with the city of london ruling world finance , was strictly national in motivation , however much other nations ( e . g . , the united states ) may have incidentally benefited .	483.2013
at the same time , all suggestions that some sort of societal responsibility existed for the welfare of the people within the territorial state was strongly resisted .	543.6406
social darwinism was able to stave off the incipient socialist movement until well into the present century .	851.71375
however , in recent decades , for what doubtless are multiple reasons , an unannounced but nonetheless readily observable shift has occurred in both facets of national activity .	1465.0271
a concept of responsibility is in process of articulation and establishment .	2331.528
already firmly implanted internally , it is a growing factor in external matters .	162.78993
a little more than twenty years ago the american people turned an important corner .	372.37802
in what has aptly been called a `` constitutional revolution ' ' , the basic nature of government was transformed from one essentially negative in nature ( the `` night-watchman state ' ' ) to one with affirmative duties to perform .	438.07968
the `` positive state ' ' came into existence .	71.4073
for lawyers , reflecting perhaps their parochial preferences , there has been a special fascination since then in the role played by the supreme court in that transformation -- the manner in which its decisions altered in `` the switch in time that saved nine ' ' , president roosevelt ' s ill-starred but in effect victorious `` court-packing plan ' ' , the imprimatur of judicial approval that was finally placed upon social legislation .	632.47174
of greater importance , however , is the content of those programs , which have had and are having enormous consequences for the american people .	201.21983
labor relations have been transformed , income security has become a standardized feature of political platforms , and all the many facets of the american version of the welfare state have become part of the conventional wisdom .	470.53442
a national consensus of near unanimity exists that these governmental efforts are desirable as well as necessary .	2414.4575
ratified in the republican party victory in 1952 , the positive state is now evidenced by political campaigns being waged not on whether but on how much social legislation there should be .	657.1838
the general acceptance of the idea of governmental ( i . e . , societal ) responsibility for the economic well-being of the american people is surely one of the two most significant watersheds in american constitutional history .	317.3469
the other , of course , was the civil war , the conflict which a century ago insured national unity over fragmentation .	410.14468
a third , one of at least equal and perhaps even greater importance , is now being traversed american immersion and involvement in world affairs .	1297.7378
internal national responsibility , now a truism , need not be documented .	529.28156
nevertheless , it may be helpful to cite one example -- that of employment -- for , as will be shown below , it cuts across both facets of the new concept .	306.41132
thirty years ago , while the nation was wallowing in economic depression , the prevailing philosophy of government was to stand aside and allow `` natural forces ' ' to operate and cure the distress .	464.4141
that guiding principle of the hoover administration fell to the siege guns of the new deal	779.8231
less than a score of years later congress enacted the employment act of 1946 , by which the national government assumed the responsibility of taking action to insure conditions of maximum employment .	434.68524
hands-off the economy was replaced by conscious guidance through planning -- the economic side of the constitutional revolution .	590.8368
in 1961 the first important legislative victory of the kennedy administration came when the principle of national responsibility for local economic distress won out over a `` state ' s-responsibility ' ' proposal -- provision was made for payment for unemployment relief by nation-wide taxation rather than by a levy only on those states afflicted with manpower surplus .	1144.1688
the american people have indeed come a long way in the brief interval between 1930 and 1961 .	656.04816
internal national responsibility is a societal response to the impact of the industrial revolution .	293.48474
reduced to its simplest terms , it is an assumption of a collective duty to compensate for the inability of individuals to cope with the rigors of the era .	267.50266
national responsibility for individual welfare is a concept not limited to the united states or even to the western nations .	221.70172
a measure of its widespread acceptance may be derived from a statement of the international congress of jurists in 1959 .	241.06749
meeting in new delhi under the auspices of the international commission of jurists , a body of lawyers from the free world , the congress redefined and expanded the traditional rule of law to include affirmative governmental duties .	690.8086
it is noteworthy that the majority of the delegates to the congress were from the less developed , former colonial nations .	293.01462
the rule of law , historically a principle according everyone his `` day in court ' ' before an impartial tribunal , was broadened substantively by making it a responsibility of government to promote individual welfare .	930.0887
recognizing that the rule of law is `` a dynamic concept which should be employed not only to safeguard the civil and political rights of the individual in a free society ' ' , the congress asserted that it also included the responsibility `` to establish social , economic , educational and cultural conditions under which his legitimate aspirations and dignity may be realized ' ' .	338.43814
the idea of national responsibility thus has become a common feature of the nations of the non-soviet world .	605.5866
for better or for worse , we all now live in welfare states , the organizing principle of which is collective responsibility for individual well-being .	630.8834
whether a concept analogous to the principle of internal responsibility operates in a nation ' s external relations is less obvious and more difficult to establish .	365.30585
the hypothesis ventured here is that it does , and that evidence is accumulating validating that proposition .	1286.6241
the content is not the same , however rather than individual security , it is the security and continuing existence of an `` ideological group ' ' -- those in the `` free world ' ' -- that is basic .	170.80458
external national responsibility involves a burgeoning requirement that the leaders of the western nations so guide their decisions as to further the viability of other friendly nations .	596.91156
if internal responsibility suggests acceptance of the socialist ideal of equality , then external responsibility implies adherence to principles of ideological supranationalism .	2015.3683
reference to two other concepts -- nationalism and sovereignty -- may help to reveal the contours of the new principle .	317.01523
in its beginnings the nation-state had to struggle to assert itself -- internally , against feudal groups , and externally , against the power and influence of such other claimants for loyalty as the church .	948.756
the breakup of the holy roman empire and the downfall of feudalism led , not more than two centuries ago , to the surge of nationalism .	744.06525
( since the time-span of the nation-state coincides roughly with the separate existence of the united states as an independent entity , it is perhaps natural for americans to think of the nation as representative of the highest form of order , something permanent and unchanging .	291.6782
) the concept of nationalism is the political principle that epitomizes and glorifies the territorial state as the characteristic type of socal structure .	2050.1252
but it is more than that .	298.07687
for it includes the emotional ties that bind men to their homeland and the complex motivations that hold a large group of people together as a unit .	852.5415
today , as new nations rise from the former colonial empires , nationalism is one of the hurricane forces loose in the world .	483.24756
almost febrile in intensity , the principle has become worldwide in application -- unfortunately at the very time that nationalist fervors can wreak greatest harm .	1839.8606
historically , however , the concept is one that has been of marked benefit to the people of the western civilizational group .	241.92307
by subduing disparate lesser groups the nation has , to some degree at least , broadened the capacity for individual liberty .	440.1125
within their confines , moreover , technological and industrial growth has proceeded at an accelerated pace , thus increasing the cornucopia from which material wants can be satisfied .	1054.8088
while the pattern is uneven , some having gained more than others , nationalism has in fact served the western peoples well .	740.74506
( whether historical nationalism helped the peoples of the remainder of the world , and whether today ' s nationalism in the former colonial areas has equally beneficial aspects , are other questions .	467.6657
it is one of the ironic quirks of history that the viability and usefulness of nationalism and the territorial state are rapidly dissipating at precisely the time that the nation-state attained its highest number ( approximately 100 ) .	1135.2064
but it is more than irony one of the main reasons why nationalism is no longer a tenable concept is because it has spread throughout the planet .	741.9314
in other words , nationalism worked well enough when it had limited application , both as to geography and as to population	955.79425
it becomes a perilous anachronism when adopted on a world-wide basis .	1495.7847
complementing the political principle of nationalism is the legal principle of sovereignty .	214.71495
the former receives its legitimacy from the latter .	816.31445
operating side by side , together they helped shore up the nation-state .	988.34216
while sovereignty has roots in antiquity , in its present usage it is essentially modern .	480.7777
jean bodin , writing in the sixteenth century , may have been the seminal thinker , but it was the vastly influential john austin who set out the main lines of the concept as now understood .	326.16165
austin ' s nineteenth-century view of law and sovereignty still dominates much of today ' s legal and political thinking .	476.94415
to him , law is the command of the sovereign ( the english monarch ) who personifies the power of the nation , while sovereignty is the power to make law -- i . e . , to prevail over internal groups and to be free from the commands of other sovereigns in other nations .	259.40005
these fundamental ideas -- the indivisibility of sovereignty and its dual ( internal-external ) aspects -- still remain the core of that concept of ultimate political power .	1047.145
the nation-state , then , exemplifies the principle of nationalism and exercises sovereignty supreme power over domestic affairs and independence from outside control .	1414.0852
in fact , however , both principles have always been nebulous and loosely defined .	794.8907
high-level abstractions are always difficult to pin down with precision .	2211.3762
that is particularly true of sovereignty when it is applied to democratic societies , in which `` popular ' ' sovereignty is said to exist , and in federal nations , in which the jobs of government are split .	178.86923
nevertheless , nationalism and sovereignty are reputed , in the accepted wisdom , to describe the modern world .	358.24905
is there a different reality behind the facade ? ?	524.32324
does the surface hide a quite different picture ? ?	288.29886
the short answer to those questions is `` yes ' ' .	103.573616
to some degree they are being supplanted by a concept of national responsibility .	409.45743
as evidence to support that view , consider the following illustrative instances .	910.6155
can thermonuclear war be set off by accident ? ?	311.2216
what steps have been taken to guard against the one sort of mishap that could trigger the destruction of continents ? ?	2567.4536
are we as safe as we should be from such a disaster ? ?	128.334
is anything being done to increase our margin of safety ? ?	328.32468
will the danger increase or decrease ? ?	240.09743
i have just asked these questions in the pentagon , in the white house , in offices of key scientists across the country and aboard the submarines that prowl for months underwater , with neat rows of green launch tubes which contain polaris missiles and which are affectionately known as `` sherwood forest ' ' .	964.5463
i asked the same questions inside the launch-control rooms of an atlas missile base in wyoming , where officers who wear sidearms are manning the `` commit buttons ' ' that could start a war -- accidentally or by design -- and in the command centers where other pistol-packing men could give orders to push such buttons .	1866.7856
to the men in the instrument-jammed bomber cockpits , submarine compartments and the antiseptic , windowless rooms that would be the foxholes of tomorrow ' s impersonal intercontinental wars , the questions seem farfetched .	2979.2754
there is unceasing pressure , but its sources are immediate .	194.72539
`` readiness exercises ' ' are almost continuous .	227.22624
each could be the real thing .	342.30185
in the command centers there are special clocks ready to tick off the minutes elapsed since `` e hour ' ' .	1193.774
`` e ' ' stands for `` execution ' ' -- the moment a `` go order ' ' would unleash an american nuclear strike .	343.96582
there is little time for the men in the command centers to reflect about the implications of these clocks .	172.1883
they are preoccupied riding herd on control panels , switches , flashing colored lights on pale green or gray consoles that look like business machines .	2687.9895
they know little about their machinery beyond mechanical details .	1632.7347
accidental war is so sensitive a subject that most of the people who could become directly involved in one are told just enough so they can perform their portions of incredibly complex tasks .	556.1973
among the policy makers , generals , physicists , psychologists and others charged with controlling the actions of the button pushers and their `` hardware ' ' , the answers to my questions varied partly according to a man ' s flair for what the professionals in this field call `` scenarios ' ' .	706.406
as an air force psychiatrist put it `` you can ' t have dry runs on this one ' ' .	829.2886
the experts are thus forced to hypothesize sequences of events that have never occurred , probably never will -- but possibly might .	1513.9404
only one rule prevailed in my conversations with these men the more highly placed they are -- that is , the more they know -- the more concerned they have become .	237.15608
already accidental war is a silent guest at the discussions within the kennedy administration about the urgency of disarmament and nearly all other questions of national security .	480.49008
only recently new `` holes ' ' were discovered in our safety measures , and a search is now on for more .	294.84534
work is under way to see whether new restraining devices should be installed on all nuclear weapons .	578.09503
meanwhile , the experts speak of wars triggered by `` false pre-emption ' ' , `` escalation ' ' , `` unauthorized behavior ' ' and other terms that will be discussed in this report .	504.38458
they inhabit a secret world centered on `` go codes ' ' and `` gold phones ' ' .	172.0213
their conversations were , almost invariably , accompanied by the same gestures -- arms and pointed forefingers darting toward each other in arclike semicircular motions .	5244.3926
one arm represented our bombers and missiles , the other arm `` theirs ' ' .	214.99146
yet implicit in each movement was the death of millions , perhaps hundreds of millions , perhaps you and me -- and the experts .	323.8723
it is their job to think about the unthinkable .	400.38245
unanimously they believe that the world would become a safer place if more of us -- and more russians and communist chinese , too -- thought about accidental war .	755.24725
the first systematic thinking about this pandora ' s box within pandora ' s boxes was done four years ago by fred ikle , a frail , meek-mannered swiss-born sociologist .	1397.8265
he was , and is , with the rand corporation , a nonprofit pool of thinkers financed by the u . s . air force .	385.29456
his investigations made him the paul revere of accidental war , and safety procedures were enormously increased .	1776.8228
in recent weeks , as a result of a sweeping defense policy reappraisal by the kennedy administration , basic united states strategy has been modified -- and large new sums allocated -- to meet the accidental-war danger and to reduce it as quickly as possible .	773.83826
the chain starts at bmews ( ballistic missile early warning system ) in thule , greenland .	4469.5913
its radar screens would register soviet missiles shortly after they are launched against the united states .	639.60156
bmews intelligence is simultaneously flashed to norad ( north american air defense command ) in colorado springs , colorado , for interpretation	2187.7483
to the sac command and control post , forty-five feet below the ground at offutt air force base , near omaha , nebraska	2744.3442
to the joint war room of the joint chiefs of staff in the pentagon and to the president .	244.79475
telephones , teletypes , several kinds of radio systems and , in some cases , television , link all vital points .	711.7292
alternate locations exist for all key command centers .	919.63556
for last-ditch emergencies sac has alternate command posts on kc-135 jet tankers .	11826.968
multiple circuits , routings and frequencies make the chain as unbreakable as possible .	701.4056
the same principle of `` redundancy ' ' applies to all communications on these special networks .	494.5688
and no messages can be transmitted on these circuits until senders and receivers authenticate in advance , by special codes , that the messages actually come from their purported sources .	1458.4745
additional codes can be used to challenge and counterchallenge the authentications .	4144.7725
only the president is permitted to authorize the use of nuclear weapons .	312.39737
but what if somebody decides to break it ? ?	184.64407
the president cannot personally remove the safety devices from every nuclear trigger .	1592.0048
hundreds of men are required to pass the word to the button pushers and to push the buttons .	559.64276
what if one or more of them turn irrational or suddenly , coolly , decide to clobber the russians ? ?	1376.9358
what if the president himself , in the language of the military , `` goes ape ' ' ? ?	129.00749
or singlehandedly decided to reverse national policy and hit the soviets without provocation ? ?	855.28424
nobody can be absolutely certain of the answers .	134.05263
however , the system is designed , ingeniously and hopefully , so that no one man could initiate a thermonuclear war .	1530.3357
even the president cannot pick up his telephone and give a `` go ' ' order .	317.12497
even he does not know the one signal for a nuclear strike -- the `` go code ' ' .	194.3457
in an emergency he would receive available intelligence on the `` gold-phone circuit ' ' .	299.9119
a system of `` gold ' ' -- actually yellow -- phones connects him with the offices and action stations of the secretary of defense , the joint chiefs of staff , the sac commander and other key men .	597.05304
all can be connected with the gold circuit from their homes .	273.615
all could help the president make his decision .	1029.5326
the talk would not be in code , but neither would it ramble .	1998.027
vital questions would be quickly answered according to a preprepared agenda .	1565.6251
officers who participate in the continual practice drills assured me that the president ' s decision could be made and announced on the gold circuit within minutes after the first flash from aj .	722.16113
if communications work , his decision would be instantly known in all command posts that would originate the actual go order .	706.54315
for these centers , too , are on the gold circuit .	239.07631
they include the navy ' s atlantic command at norfolk , virginia , which is in contact with the polaris subs	611.9548
air force forward headquarters in europe and in the pacific , which control tactical fighters on ships and land bases	1046.0186
and sac , which controls long-range bombers and atlas missiles .	2808.6086
let us look in on one of these nerve centers -- sac at omaha -- and see what must still happen before a wing of b-52 bombers could drop their aj .	1368.9749
the key man almost certainly would be col . william w . wisman , sac ' s senior controller .	371.76785
he or his deputy or one of their seven assistants , all full colonels , mans the heart of the command post twenty-four hours a day .	1091.3707
it is a quiet but impressive room -- 140 feet long , thirty-nine feet wide , twenty-one feet high .	3680.0825
movable panels of floor-to-ceiling maps and charts are crammed with intelligence information .	2448.718
and bill wisman , forty-three , a farmer ' s son from beallsville , ohio , is a quiet but impressive man .	846.1361
his eyes are steady anchors of the deepest brown .	705.3421
his movements and speech are precise , clear and quick .	571.8419
no question ruffles him or causes him to hesitate .	512.94574
wisman , who has had the chief controller ' s job for four years , calls the signals for a team operating three rows of dull-gray consoles studded with lights , switches and buttons .	880.9645
at least a dozen men , some armed , are never far away from him .	518.5874
in front of him is a gold phone .	485.1121
in emergencies the sac commander , gen . thomas power , or his deputies and their staff would occupy a balcony that stretches across the length of the room above wisman and his staff .	610.5336
at general power ' s seat in the balcony there is also a gold phone .	294.60883
general power would participate in the decision making .	175.86343
wisman , below , would listen in and act .	383.86105
his consoles can give him instant contact with more than seventy bases around the world and with every sac aircraft .	1162.1476
he need only pick up one of the two red telephone receivers at his extreme left , right next to the big red button marked alert .	733.417
( there are two receivers in case one should be dropped and damaged .	849.3574
but wisman , too , does not know the go code .	263.33755
he must take it from `` the red box ' ' .	114.43565
in point of fact , this is a beige box with a bright red door , about one and a half feet square and hung from the wall about six feet from the door to wisman ' s right .	366.5501
the box is internally wired so the door can never be opened without setting off a screeching klaxon ( `` it ' s real obnoxious ' ' ) .	1301.3368
now we must become vague , for we are approaching one of the nation ' s most guarded secrets .	307.87457
the codes in the red box -- there are several of them covering various contingencies -- are contained in a sealed x-ray-proof `` unique device ' ' .	708.1223
they are supplied , a batch at a time , by a secret source and are continually changed by wisman or his staff , at random intervals .	525.99194
but even the contents of wisman ' s box cannot start a war .	336.00638
they are mere fragments , just one portion of preprepared messages .	671.3632
what these fragments are and how they activate the go order may not be revealed .	723.15625
the pieces must be placed in the context of the prepared messages by wisman ' s staff .	217.1283
in addition to the authentication and acknowledgment procedures which precede and follow the sending of the go messages , again in special codes , each message also contains an `` internal authenticator ' ' , another specific signal to convince the recipient that he is getting the real thing .	1150.666
i asked wisman what would happen if he broke out the go codes and tried to start transmitting one .	847.55994
`` i ' d wind up full of bullet holes ' ' , he said , and there was no question that he was talking about bullets fired by his coworkers .	361.56366
now let us imagine a wing of b-52 ' s , on alert near their `` positive control ( or fail-safe ) points ' ' , the spots on the map , many miles from soviet territory , beyond which they are forbidden to fly without specific orders to proceed to their targets .	452.73795
they , too , have fragments of the go code with them .	817.5501
as wisman put it , `` they have separate pieces of the pie , and we have the whole pie .	1049.8182
once we send out the whole pie , they can put their pieces into it .	219.00943
unless we send out the whole pie , their pieces mean nothing ' ' .	229.09425
why does wisman ' s ever-changing code always mesh with the fragments in possession of the button pushers ? ?	2057.273
the answer is a cryptographic secret .	44262.207
at any rate , three men out of a six-man b-52 crew are required to copy down wisman ' s go-to-war message .	4116.555
each must match wisman ' s `` pie ' ' with the fragment that he carries with him .	162.30186
all three must compare notes and agree to `` go ' ' .	153.31763
after that , it requires several minutes of concentrated work , including six separate and deliberate actions by a minimum of three men sitting at three separate stations in a bomber , each with another man beside him to help , for an armed bomb to be released .	690.2051
unless all gadgets are properly operated -- and the wires and seals from the handles removed first -- no damage can be done .	659.16095
suddenly , however , their posture changed and the game ended .	732.9073
they went as rigid as black statuary six figures , lean and tall and angular , went still .	2662.8562
their heads were in the air sniffing .	1597.2765
they all swung at the same instant in the same direction .	181.82469
they saw it before i did , even with my binoculars .	436.60593
it was nothing more than a tiny distant rain squall , a dull gray sheet which reached from a layer of clouds to the earth .	650.6532
in the 360 degrees of horizon it obscured only a degree , no more .	1839.3922
a white man would not have seen it .	113.75966
the aborigines fastened upon it with a concentration beyond pathos .	1446.0457
watching , they waited until the squall thickened and began to move in a long drifting slant across the dry burning land .	986.86914
at once the whole band set off at a lope .	1471.1671
they were chasing a rain cloud .	1448.3906
they went after the squall as mercilessly as a wolf pack after an abandoned cow .	4704.295
i followed them in the jeep and now they did not care .	170.16171
the games were over , this was life .	190.94273
occasionally , for no reason that i could see , they would suddenly alter the angle of their trot .	253.96443
sometimes i guessed it was because the rain squall had changed direction .	612.80396
sometimes it was to skirt a gulley .	12459.395
their gait is impossible to convey in words .	131.71832
it has nothing of the proud stride of the trained runner about it , it is not a lope , it is not done with style or verve .	663.4074
it is the gait of the human who must run to live arms dangling , legs barely swinging over the ground , head hung down and only occasionally swinging up to see the target , a loose motion that is just short of stumbling and yet is wonderfully graceful .	1085.9207
it is a barely controlled skimming of the ground .	465.20203

seven founders -- george washington , benjamin franklin , john adams , thomas jefferson , alexander hamilton , james madison and john jay -- determined the destinies of the new nation .	644.3845
in certain respects , their task was incomparably greater than ours today , for there was nobody before them to show them the way .	413.86542

their writings assume more than dramatic or patriotic interest because of their conviction that the struggle in which they were involved was neither selfish nor parochial but , rather , as washington in his last wartime circular reminded his fellow countrymen , that `` with our fate will the destiny of unborn millions be involved ' ' .	956.6518
strong men with strong opinions , frank to the point of being refreshingly indiscreet , the founding seven were essentially congenial minds , and their agreements with each other were more consequential than their differences .	1115.7355
even though in most cases the completion of the definitive editions of their writings is still years off , enough documentation has already been assembled to warrant drawing a new composite profile of the leadership which performed the heroic dual feats of winning american independence and founding a new nation .	830.4908
before merging them into a common profile it is well to remember that their separate careers were extraordinary .	518.87335

eldest of the seven , benjamin franklin , a new englander transplanted to philadelphia , wrote the most dazzling success story in our history .	1035.8744
the young printer ' s apprentice achieved greatness in a half-dozen different fields , as editor and publisher , scientist , inventor , philanthropist and statesman .	1044.0084
author of the albany plan of union , which , had it been adopted , might have avoided the revolution , he fought the colonists ' front-line battles in london , negotiated the treaty of alliance with france and the peace that ended the war , headed the state government of pennsylvania , and exercised an important moderating influence at the federal convention .	723.0525
on a military mission for his native virginia the youthful george washington touched off the french and indian war , then guarded his colony ' s frontier as head of its militia .	825.4338
commanding the continental army for six long years of the revolution , he was the indispensable factor in the ultimate victory .	170.41742

during his two terms the constitution was tested and found workable , strong national policies were inaugurated , and the traditions and powers of the presidential office firmly fixed .	656.14105
john adams fashioned much of pre-revolutionary radical ideology , wrote the constitution of his home state of massachusetts , negotiated , with franklin and jay , the peace with britain and served as our first vice president and our second president .	547.80383
his political opponent and lifetime friend , thomas jefferson , achieved immortality through his authorship of the declaration of independence , but equally notable were the legal and constitutional reforms he instituted in his native virginia , his role as father of our territorial system , and his acquisition of the louisiana territory during his first term as president .	599.0495

if franklin was an authentic genius , then alexander hamilton , with his exceptional precocity , consuming energy , and high ambition , was a political prodigy .	1256.7465

even two decades ago in go down , moses faulkner was looking to the more urban future with a glimmer of hope that through its youth and its new way of life the south might be reborn and the curse of slavery erased from its soil .	841.7044
yet his concern even here is with a slowly changing socio-economic order in general , and he never deals with such specific aspects of this change as the urban and industrial impact .	491.11563
faulkner traces , in his vast and overpowering saga of yoknapatawpha county , the gradual changes which seep into the south , building layer upon layer of minute , subtle innovation which eventually tend largely to hide the old way .	1668.9055
thus faulkner reminds us , and wisely , that the `` new ' ' south has gradually evolved out of the old south , and consequently its agrarian roots persist .	487.6489
yet he presents a realm of source material which may well serve other writers if not himself the problems with which a new south must grapple in groping through a blind adolescence into the maturity of urbanization .	1747.4766
with new mechanization the modern farmer must perform the work of six men a machine stands between the agrarian and his soil .	553.1997
the thousands of city migrants who desert the farms yearly must readjust with even greater stress and tension the sacred wilderness is gradually surrendering to suburbs and research parks and industrial areas .	2480.8845
another element to concern the choreographer is that of the visual devices of the theatre .	183.44818
most avant-garde creators , true to their interest in the self-sufficiency of pure movement , have tended to dress their dancers in simple lines and solid colors ( often black ) and to give them a bare cyclorama for a setting .	709.8471
but robert rauschenberg , the neo-dadaist artist , has collaborated with several of them .	776.9178
he has designed a matching backdrop and costumes of points of color on white for mr . cunningham ' s summerspace , so that dancers and background merge into a shimmering unity .	937.74603
for mr . taylor ' s images and reflections she made some diaphanous tents that alternately hide and reveal the performer , and a girl ' s cape lined with grass .	1011.07446
mr . nikolais has made a distinctive contribution to the arts of costume and decor .	528.28485
in fact , he calls his productions dance-theatre works of motion , shape , light , and sound .	996.0558
to raise the dancer out of his personal , pedestrian self , mr . nikolais has experimented with relating him to a larger , environmental orbit .	589.7407
he began with masks to make the dancer identify himself with the creature he appeared to be .	327.44415
he went on to use objects -- hoops , poles , capes -- which he employed as extensions of the body of the dancer , who moved with them .	465.96884
the depersonalization continued as the dancer was further metamorphosed by the play of lights upon his figure .	881.5826
in each case , the object , the color , even the percussive sounds of the electronic score were designed to become part of the theatrical being of the performer .	238.72556
the dancer who never loosens her hold on a parasol , begins to feel that it is part of herself .	844.5938
or , clad from head to toe in fabric stretched over a series of hoops , the performer may well lose his sense of self in being a `` finial ' ' .	861.2047
as the dancer is depersonalized , his accouterments are animized , and the combined elements give birth to a new being .	2038.8699
from this being come new movement ideas that utilize dancer and property as a single unit .	1567.9778
thus , the avant-garde choreographers have extended the scope of materials available for dance composition .	1187.289
but , since they have rejected both narrative and emotional continuity , how are they to unify the impressive array of materials at their disposal ? ?	693.1995
some look deliberately to devices used by creators in the other arts and apply corresponding methods to their own work .	963.8254
others , less consciously but quite probably influenced by the trends of the times , experiment with approaches that parallel those of the contemporary poet , painter , and musician .	523.5293
an approach that has appealed to some choreographers is reminiscent of charles olson ' s statement of the process of projective verse `` one perception must immediately and directly lead to a further perception ' ' .	691.8157
the creator trusts his intuition to lead him along a path that has internal validity because it mirrors the reality of his experience .	500.8438
he disdains external restrictions -- conventional syntax , traditional metre .	5804.676
the unit of form is determined subjectively `` the heart , by the way of the breath , to the line ' ' .	101.228096
the test of form is fidelity to the experience , a gauge also accepted by the abstract expressionist painters .	986.59625
an earlier but still influential school of painting , surrealism , had suggested the way of dealing with the dream experience , that event in which seemingly incongruous objects are linked together through the curious associations of the subconscious .	988.1957
the resulting picture might appear a maze of restless confusions and contradictions , but it is more true to life than a portrait of an artificially contrived order .	727.5669
the contemporary painter tends to depict not the concrete objects of his experience but their essences as revealed in abstractions of their lines , colors , masses , and energies .	841.8637
he is still concerned , however , with a personal event .	70.6406
he accepts the accidents of his brushwork because they provide evidence of the vitality of the experience of creation .	249.14449
the work must be true to both the physical and the spiritual character of the experience .	184.7428
some painters have less interest in the experience of the moment , with its attendant urgencies and ambiguities , than in looking beyond the flux of particular impressions to a higher , more serene level of truth .	431.7741
rather than putting their trust in ephemeral sensations they seek form in the stable relationships of pure design , which symbolize an order more real than the disorder of the perceptual world .	1150.129
but in this approach it is the artist ' s ultimate insight , rather than his immediate impressions , that gives form to the work .	214.65106
others look to more objective devices of order .	258.4223
the musician employing the serial technique of composition establishes a mathematical system of rotations that , once set in motion , determines the sequence of pitches and even of rhythms and intensities .	2574.9275
the composer may reverse or invert the order of his original set of intervals ( or rhythms or dynamic changes ) .	844.7968
he may even alter the pattern by applying a scheme of random numbers .	388.5037
but he cannot order his elements by will , either rational or inspired .	655.93396
the system works as an impersonal mechanism .	914.0562
musicians who use the chance method also exclude subjective control of formal development .	3849.5793
again , the composer must select his own materials .	746.7471
but a tossing of coins , with perhaps the added safeguard of reference to the oracles of the i ching , the chinese book of changes , dictates the handling of the chosen materials .	913.9202
avant-garde choreographers , seeking new forms of continuity for their new vocabulary of movements , have turned to similar approaches .	474.4936
some let dances take their form from the experience of creation .	209.33322
according to katherine litz , `` the becoming , the process of realization , is the dance ' ' .	89.20135
the process stipulates that the choreographer sense the quality of the initial movement he has discovered and that he feel the rightness of the quality that is to follow it .	380.5126
the sequence may involve a sharp contrast for example , a quiet meditative sway of the body succeeded by a violent leap	1717.7786
or it may involve more subtle distinctions the sway may be gradually minimized or enlarged , its rhythmic emphasis may be slightly modified , or it may be transferred to become a movement of only the arms or the head .	566.97235
even the least alteration will change the quality .	173.21117
an exploration of these possible relationships constitutes the process of creation and thereby gives form to the dance .	821.86646
the approach to the depiction of the experience of creation may be analytic , as it is for miss litz , or spontaneous , as it is for merle marsicano .	655.60345
she , too , is concerned with `` the becoming , the process of realization ' ' , but she does not think in terms of subtle variations of spatial or temporal patterns .	341.76492
the design is determined emotionally `` i must reach into myself for the spring that will send me catapulting recklessly into the chaos of event with which the dance confronts me ' ' .	964.0047
looking back , miss marsicano feels that her ideas may have been influenced by those of jackson pollock .	1339.7716
at one time she felt impelled to make dances that `` moved all over the stage ' ' , much as pollock ' s paintings move violently over the full extent of the canvas .	497.73093
but her conscious need was to break away from constricting patterns of form , a need to let the experience shape itself .	693.64197
midi garth also believes in subjective continuity that begins with the feeling engendered by an initial movement .	917.688
it may be a free front-back swing of the leg , leading to a sideways swing of the arm that develops into a turn and the sensation of taking off from the ground .	909.5892
this became a dance called prelude to flight .	1962.4169
a pervading quality of free lyricism and a building from turns close to the ground towards jumps into the air gives the work its central focus .	1548.5344
alwin nikolais objects to art as an outpouring of personal emotion .	1943.6488
he seeks to make his dancers more `` godlike ' ' by relating them to the impersonal elements of shape , light , color , and sound .	524.376
if his dancers are sometimes made to look as if they might be creatures from mars , this is consistent with his intention of placing them in the orbit of another world , a world in which they are freed of their pedestrian identities .	238.08112
it is through the metamorphosed dancer that the germ of form is discovered .	1568.6255
in his recognition of his impersonal self the dancer moves , and this self , in the `` first revealed stroke of its existence ' ' , states the theme from which all else must follow .	361.6385
the theme may be the formation of a shape from which other shapes evolve .	440.0762
it may be a reaction to a percussive sound , the following movements constituting further reactions .	1219.1798
it may establish the relation of the figure of the dancer to light and color , in which case changes in the light or color will set off a kaleidescope of visual designs .	405.9014
unconcerned with the practical function of his actions , the dancer is engrossed exclusively in their `` motional content ' ' .	350.9959
movements unfold freely because they are uninhibited by emotional bias or purposive drive .	1932.725
but the metamorphosis must come first .	198.66345
though he is also concerned with freeing dance from pedestrian modes of activity , merce cunningham has selected a very different method for achieving his aim .	2771.4314
he rejects all subjectively motivated continuity , any line of action related to the concept of cause and effect .	424.7474
he bases his approach on the belief that anything can follow anything .	294.28772
an order can be chanced rather than chosen , and this approach produces an experience that is `` free and discovered rather than bound and remembered ' ' .	613.9528
thus , there is freshness not only in the individual movements of the dance but in the shape of their continuity as well .	338.29535
chance , he finds , enables him to create `` a world beyond imagination ' ' .	319.02023
he cites with pleasure the comment of a lady , who exclaimed after a concert `` why , it ' s extremely interesting .	327.93024
but i would never have thought of it myself ' ' .	224.39316
the sequence of movements in a cunningham dance is unlike any sequence to be seen in life .	558.60596
at one side of the stage a dancer jumps excitedly	18329.953
nearby , another sits motionless , while still another is twirling an umbrella .	2646.9268
a man and a girl happen to meet	896.0584
they look straight at the audience , not at each other .	101.507286
he lifts her , puts her down , and walks off , neither pleased nor disturbed , as if nothing had happened .	1072.6097
if one dancer slaps another , the victim may do a pirouette , sit down , or offer his assailant a fork and spoon .	1369.0807
their consequences are irrelevant -- or there are no consequences at all .	131.7503
the sequence is determined by chance , and mr . cunningham makes use of any one of several chance devices .	350.07874
he may take slips of paper from a grab bag .	443.58762
the answers derived by these means may determine not only the temporal organization of the dance but also its spatial design , special slips designating the location on the stage where the movement is to be performed .	467.68307
the other variables include the dancer who is to perform the movement and the length of time he is to take in its performance .	118.55531
the only factors that are personally set by the choreographer are the movements themselves , the number of the dancers , and the approximate total duration of the dance .	300.9663
the `` approximate ' ' is important , because even after the order of the work has been established by the chance method , the result is not inviolable .	197.28622
if a work is divided into several large segments , a last-minute drawing of random numbers may determine the order of the segments for any particular performance .	773.5948
and any sequence can not only change its positions in the work but can even be eliminated from it altogether .	492.81357
mr . cunningham tries not to cheat the chance method	1395.9355
he adheres to its dictates as faithfully as he can .	1160.6577
however , there is always the possibility that chance will make demands the dancers find impossible to execute .	899.25494
he must rearrange matters so that two performers do not bump into each other .	982.9078
he must construct transitions so that a dancer who is told to lie prone one second and to leap wildly the next will have some physical preparation for the leap .	796.98724
the north and the south were in greater agreement on sovereignty , through all their dispute about it , than were the founding fathers .	509.94214
the truth in their conflicting concepts was expounded by statesmen of the calibre of webster and calhoun , and defended in the end by leaders of the nobility of lincoln and lee .	686.3439
the people everywhere had grown meanwhile in devotion to basic democratic principles , in understanding of and belief in the federal balance , and in love of their union .	304.35666
repeated efforts -- beginning with the missouri compromise of 1821 -- were made by such master moderates as clay and douglas to resolve the difference peacefully by compromise , rather than clear thought and timely action .	952.9804
even so , confusion in this period gained such strength ( from compromise and other factors ) that it led to the bloodiest war of the nineteenth century .	379.37466
nothing can show more than this the immensity of the danger to democratic peoples that lies in even relatively slight deviation from their true concept of sovereignty .	858.7173
the present issue in atlantica -- whether to transform an alliance of sovereign nations into a federal union of sovereign citizens -- resembles the american one of 1787-89 rather than the one that was resolved by civil war .	845.0954
and so i would only touch upon it now ( much as i have long wanted to write a book about it ) .	571.0082
i think it is essential , however , to pinpoint here the difference between the two concepts of sovereignty that went to war in 1861 -- if only to see better how imperative is our need today to clarify completely our far worse confusion on this subject .	717.1472
the difference came down to this the southern states insisted that the united states was , in last analysis , what its name implied -- a union of states .	399.26773
to their leaders the constitution was a compact made by the people of sovereign states , who therefore retained the right to secede from it .	390.81378
this right of the state , its upholders contended , was essential to maintain the federal balance and protect the liberty of the people from the danger of centralizing power in the union government .	367.50903
the champions of the union maintained that the constitution had formed , fundamentally , the united people of america , that it was a compact among sovereign citizens rather than states , and that therefore the states had no right to secede , though the citizens could .	377.7495
writing to speed on august 24 , 1855 , lincoln made the latter point clear .	936.93115
in homely terms whose timeliness is startling today , he thus declared his own right to secede .	882.2012
we began by declaring that all men are created equal .	466.68976
we now practically read it , all men are created equal except negroes .	628.8543
when the know-nothings get control , it will read , all men are created equal except negroes and foreigners and catholics .	403.39764
when it comes to this , i shall prefer emigrating to some country where they make no pretence of loving liberty -- to russia , for instance , where despotism can be taken pure , without the base alloy of hypocrisy ' ' ( his emphasis )	829.1193
when the southern states exercised their `` right to secede ' ' , they formed what they officially styled `` the confederate states of america ' ' .	528.21686
dictionaries , as we have seen , still cite this government , along with the articles of confederation of 1781 , as an example of a confederacy .	403.7344
the fact is that the southern confederacy differed from the earlier one almost as much as the federal constitution did .	756.2256
the confederate constitution copied much of the federal constitution verbatim , and most of the rest in substance .	361.38422
it operated on , by and for the people individually just as did the federal constitution .	387.7495
it made substantially the same division of power between the central and state governments , and among the executive , legislative and judicial branches .	459.2071
the difference between confederacy and federal union in 1861	409.36884
many believe -- and understandably -- that the great difference between the constitution of the southern confederacy and the federal constitution was that the former recognized the right of each state to secede .	319.13904
but though each of its members had asserted this right against the union , the final constitution which the confederacy signed on march 11 -- nearly a month before hostilities began -- included no explicit provision authorizing a state to secede .	860.81384
its drafters discussed this vital point but left it out of their constitution .	483.63232
their president , jefferson davis , interpreted their constitution to mean that it `` admits of no coerced association ' ' , but this remained so doubtful that `` there were frequent demands that the right to secede be put into the constitution ' ' .	390.79758
the constitution of the southern `` confederation ' ' differed from that of the federal union only in two important respects it openly , defiantly , recognized slavery -- an institution which the southerners of 1787 , even though they continued it , found so impossible to reconcile with freedom that they carefully avoided mentioning the word in the federal constitution .	725.53845
they recognized that slavery was a moral issue and not merely an economic interest , and that to recognize it explicitly in their constitution would be in explosive contradiction to the concept of sovereignty they had set forth in the declaration of 1776 that `` all men are created equal , that they are endowed by their creator with certain unalienable rights , that among them are life , liberty and the pursuit of happiness .	591.5997
' ' the other important difference between the two constitutions was that the president of the confederacy held office for six ( instead of four ) years , and was limited to one term .	394.0691
these are not , however , differences in federal structure .	205.11107
the only important differences from that standpoint , between the two constitutions , lies in their preambles .	479.6408
the one of 1861 made clear that in making their government the people were acting through their states , whereas the preamble of 1787-89 expressed , as clearly as language can , the opposite concept , that they were acting directly as citizens .	570.1919
here are the two preambles federal constitution , 1789	7652.8613
`` we the people of the united states , in order to form a more perfect union , establish justice , insure domestic tranquility , provide for the common defence , promote the general welfare , and secure the blessings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity , do ordain and establish this constitution for the united states of america ' ' .	427.93973
`` we the people of the confederate states , each state acting in its sovereign and independent character , in order to form a permanent federal government , establish justice , insure domestic tranquility , and secure the blessings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity -- invoking the favor and the guidance of almighty god -- do ordain and establish this constitution for the confederate states of america ' ' .	657.7669
one is tempted to say that , on the difference between the concepts of sovereignty in these two preambles , the worst war of the nineteenth century was fought .	193.54066
but though the southern states , when drafting a constitution to unite themselves , narrowed the difference to this fine point by omitting to assert the right to secede , the fact remained that by seceding from the union they had already acted on the concept that it was composed primarily of sovereign states .	643.26825
if the union conceded this to them , the same right must be conceded to each remaining state whenever it saw fit to secede this would destroy the federal balance between it and the states , and in the end sacrifice to the sovereignty of the states all the liberty the citizens had gained by their union .	309.9945
lincoln saw that the act of secession made the issue for the union a vital one whether it was a union of sovereign citizens that should continue to live , or an association of sovereign states that must fall prey either to `` anarchy or despotism ' ' .	427.91687
much as he abhorred slavery , lincoln was always willing to concede to each `` slave state ' ' the right to decide independently whether to continue or end it .	478.62457
though his election was interpreted by many southerners as the forerunner of a dangerous shift in the federal balance in favor of the union , lincoln himself proposed no such change in the rights the constitution gave the states .	438.49472
after the war began , he long refused to permit emancipation of the slaves by union action even in the border states that stayed with the union .	301.30478
he issued his emancipation proclamation only when he felt that necessity left him no other way to save the union .	605.9141
in his message of december 2 , 1862 , he put his purpose and his policy in these words -- which i would call the lincoln law of liberty-and-union `` in giving freedom to the slave , we assure freedom to the free ' ' .	294.08194
what lincoln could not concede was that the states rather than the people were sovereign in the union .	313.6808
he fought to the end to preserve it as a `` government of the people , by the people , for the people ' ' .	68.87801
the truth on each side won in the civil war	228.72327
the fact that the americans who upheld the sovereignty of their states did this in order to keep many of their people more securely in slavery -- the antithesis of individual liberty -- made the conflict grimmer , and the greater .	470.40387
out of this ordeal the citizen emerged , in the south as in the north , as america ' s true sovereign , in `` a new birth of freedom ' ' , as lincoln promised .	178.18666
but before this came about , 214 , 938 americans had given their lives in battle for the two concepts of the sovereign rights of men and of states .	598.80963
on their decisive battlefield lincoln did not distinguish between them when he paid tribute to the `` brave men , living and dead , who fought here ' ' .	518.7608
he understood that both sides were at fault , and he reached the height of saying so explicitly in his second inaugural .	489.078
to my knowledge , lincoln remains the only head of state and commander-in-chief who , while fighting a fearful war whose issue was in doubt , proved man enough to say this publicly -- to give his foe the benefit of the fact that in all human truth there is some error , and in all our error , some truth .	455.41046
so great a man could not but understand , too , that the thing that moves men to sacrifice their lives is not the error of their thought , which their opponents see and attack , but the truth which the latter do not see -- any more than they see the error which mars the truth they themselves defend .	554.43115
it is much less difficult now than in lincoln ' s day to see that on both sides sovereign americans had given their lives in the civil war to maintain the balance between the powers they had delegated to the states and to their union .	469.69672
they differed in the balance they believed essential to the sovereignty of the citizen -- but the supreme sacrifice each made served to maintain a still more fundamental truth that individual life , liberty and happiness depend on a right balance between the two -- and on the limitation of sovereignty , in all its aspects , which this involves .	502.9721
the 140 , 414 americans who gave `` the last full measure of devotion ' ' to prevent disunion , preserved individual freedom in the united states from the dangers of anarchy , inherent in confederations , which throughout history have proved fatal in the end to all associations composed primarily of sovereign states , and to the liberties of their people .	653.26306
but the fact that 70 , 524 other americans gave the same measure of devotion to an opposing concept served liberty-and-union in other essential ways .	2005.41
its appeal from ballots to bullets at fort sumter ended by costing the southerners their right to have slaves -- a right that was even less compatible with the sovereignty of man .	837.1557
the very fact that they came so near to winning by the wrong method , war , led directly to their losing both the war and the wrong thing they fought for , since it forced lincoln to free their slaves as a military measure .	699.5018
there was a divine justice in one wrong thus undoing another .	2710.564
there was also a lesson , one that has served ever since to keep americans , in their conflicts with one another , from turning from the ballot to the bullet .	373.726
yet though the southern states lost the worst errors in their case , they did not lose the truth they fought for .	299.6659
the lives so many of them gave , to forestall what they believed would be a fatal encroachment by the union on the powers reserved to their states have continued ever since to safeguard all americans against freedom ' s other foe .	624.8824
as cells coalesced into organisms , they built new `` unnatural ' ' and internally controlled environments to cope even more successfully with the entropy-increasing properties of the external world .	1063.1178
the useful suggestion of professor david hawkins which considers culture as a third stage in biological evolution fits quite beautifully then with our suggestion that science has provided us with a rather successful technique for building protective artificial environments .	2332.2007
one wonders about its applicability to people .	1255.2019
will advances in human sciences help us build social structures and governments which will enable us to cope with people as effectively as the primitive combination of protein and nucleic acid built a structure of molecules which enabled it to adapt to a sea of molecular interaction ? ?	1485.088
the answer is , of course , yes .	117.21221
for the family is the simplest example of just such a unit , composed of people , which gives us both some immunity from , and a way of dealing with , other people .	343.35593
social invention did not have to await social theory any more than use of the warmth of a fire had to await lavoisier or the buoyant protection of a boat the formulations of archimedes .	922.5488
but it has been during the last two centuries , during the scientific revolution , that our independence from the physical environment has made the most rapid strides .	345.14944
we have ample light when the sun sets	602.03595
the temperature of our homes is independent of the seasons	412.1265
we fly through the air , although gravity pulls us down	9109.49
the range of our voice ignores distance .	5442.063
at what stage are social sciences then ? ?	617.18805
is the future of psychology akin to the rich future of physics at the time of newton ? ?	913.4454
there is a haunting resemblance between the notion of cause in copernicus and in freud .	983.03436
and it is certainly no slight to either of them to compare both their achievements and their impact .	530.5124
political theoretical understanding , although almost at a standstill during this century , did develop during the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries , and resulted in a flood of inventions which increased the possibility for man to coexist with man .	783.9238
consitutional government , popular vote , trial by jury , public education , labor unions , cooperatives , communes , socialized ownership , world courts , and the veto power in world councils are but a few examples .	1236.9722
most of these , with horrible exceptions , were conceived as is a ship , not as an attempt to quell the ocean of mankind , nor to deny its force , but as a means to survive and enjoy it .	404.862
the most effective political inventions seem to make maximum use of natural harbors and are aware that restraining breakwaters can play only a minor part in the whole scheme .	1392.4725
just as present technology had to await the explanations of physics , so one might expect that social invention will follow growing sociological understanding .	616.40924
we are desperately in the need of such invention , for man is still very much at the mercy of man .	186.59438
in fact the accumulation of the hardware of destruction is day by day increasing our fear of each other .	412.02
i want , therefore , to discuss a second and quite different fruit of science , the connection between scientific understanding and fear .	335.35266
there are certainly large areas of understanding in the human sciences which in themselves and even without political invention can help to dispel our present fears .	620.6436
lucretius has remarked `` the reason why all mortals are so gripped by fear is that they see all sorts of things happening in the earth and sky with no discernable cause , and these they attribute to the will of god ' ' .	433.92227
perhaps things were even worse then .	745.2313
it is difficult to reconstruct the primeval fears of man .	1072.2487
we get some clue from a few remembrances of childhood and from the circumstance that we are probably not much more afraid of people now than man ever was .	524.0573
we are not now afraid of atomic bombs in the same way that people once feared comets .	1091.3223
the bombs are as harmless as an automobile in a garage .	1084.8208
we are worried about what people may do with them -- that some crazy fool may `` push the button ' ' .	358.41345
i am certainly not adequately trained to describe or enlarge on human fears , but there are certain features of the fears dispelled by scientific explanations that stand out quite clearly .	833.22736
they are in general those fears that once seemed to have been amenable to prayer or ritual .	832.95844
they include both individual fears and collective ones .	646.3697
they arise in situations in which one believes that what happens depends not only on the external world , but also on the precise pattern of behavior of the individual or group .	259.1466
often it is recognized that all the details of the pattern may not be essential to the outcome but , because the pattern was empirically determined and not developed through theoretical understanding , one is never quite certain which behavior elements are effective , and the whole pattern becomes ritualized .	874.6516
yet often fear persists because , even with the most rigid ritual , one is never quite free from the uneasy feeling that one might make some mistake or that in every previous execution one had been unaware of the really decisive act .	608.6811
to say that science had reduced many such fears merely reiterates the obvious and frequent statement that science eliminated much of magic and superstition .	3893.338
but a somewhat more detailed analysis of this process may be illuminating .	334.41437
the frequently postulated antique worry that the daylight hours might dwindle to complete darkness apparently gave rise to a ritual and celebration which we still recognize .	1265.8274
it is curious that even centuries of repetition of the yearly cycle did not induce a sufficient degree of confidence to allow people to abandon the ceremonies of the winter solstice .	948.7682
this and other fears of the solar system have disappeared gradually , first , with the ptolemaic system and its built-in concept of periodicity and then , more firmly , with the newtonian innovation of an universal force that could account quantitatively for both terrestial and celestial motions .	1170.4377
this understanding provides a very simple example of the fact that one can eliminate fear without instituting any controls .	871.03723
in fact , although we have dispelled the fear , we have not necessarily assured ourselves that there are no dangers .	314.6493
there is still the remote possibility of planetoid collision .	7485.8057

across the front of a yard and down the side , they were iron , either spiked along the top or arched in half circles .	652.4288
alley fences were made of solid boards higher than one ' s head , but not so high as the golden glow in a corner or the hollyhocks that grew in a line against them .	647.49414
front fences were covered with virginia creeper or trumpet vines or honeysuckle .	10259.526

on these posts the gates swung open with a squeak and shut with a metallic clang .	9635.791
the only extended view possible to anyone less tall than the fences was that obtained from an upper bough of the apple tree .	862.3327
the primary quality of that view seems , now , to have been its quietness , but that cannot at the time have impressed us .	349.04047

every path from back door to barn was covered by a grape-arbor , and every yard had its fruit trees .	782.041

another had ended before it began .	171.86298

it is worth dwelling in some detail on the crisis of this story , because it brings together a number of characteristic elements and makes of them a curious , riddling compound obscurely but centrally significant for mann ' s work .	570.35345
the wife , amra , and her lover are both savagely portrayed , she as incarnate sensuality , `` voluptuous ' ' and `` indolent ' ' , possibly `` a mischief maker ' ' , with `` a kind of luxurious cunning ' ' to set against her apparent simplicity , her `` birdlike brain ' ' .	517.32806

when i try to work out my reasons for feeling that this passage is of critical significance , i come up with the following ideas , which i shall express very briefly here and revert to in a later essay .	374.04407
love is the crucial dilemma of experience for mann ' s heroes .	211.60948
the dramatic construction of his stories characteristically turns on a situation in which someone is simultaneously compelled and forbidden to love .	1169.0199
the release , the freedom , involved in loving another is either terribly difficult or else absolutely impossible	2309.927
and the motion toward it brings disaster .	1086.1138
this prohibition on love has an especially poignant relation to art	2439.0144
it is particularly the artist ( tonio kroger , aschenbach , leverkuhn ) who suffers from it .	2215.014
the specific analogy to the dilemma of love is the problem of the `` breakthrough ' ' in the realm of art .	87.233284
again , the sufferings and disasters produced by any transgression against the commandment not to love are almost invariably associated in one way or another with childhood , with the figure of a child .	836.9745
finally , the theatrical ( and perversely erotic ) notions of dressing up , cosmetics , disguise , and especially change of costume ( or singularity of costume , as with cipolla ) , are characteristically associated with the catastrophes of mann ' s stories .	1729.982
we shall return to these statements and deal with them more fully as the evidence for them accumulates .	812.23645
for the present it is enough to note that in the grotesque figure of jacoby , at the moment of his collapse , all these elements come together in prophetic parody .	464.8592
professionally a lawyer , that is to say associated with dignity , reserve , discipline , with much that is essentially middle-class , he is compelled by an impossible love to exhibit himself dressed up , disguised -- that is , paradoxically , revealed -- as a child , and , worse , as a whore masquerading as a child .	640.40295
that this abandonment takes place on a stage , during an ' artistic ' performance , is enough to associate jacoby with art , and to bring down upon him the punishment for art	374.28546
that is , he is suspect , guilty , punishable , as is anyone in mann ' s stories who produces illusion , and this is true even though the constant elements of the artist-nature , technique , magic , guilt and suffering , are divided in this story between jacoby and lautner .	640.7396
it appears that the dominant tendency of mann ' s early tales , however pictorial or even picturesque the surface , is already toward the symbolic , the emblematic , the expressionistic .	663.06525
in a certain perfectly definite way , the method and the theme of his stories are one and the same .	169.60188
something of this can be learned from `` the way to the churchyard ' ' ( 1901 ) , an anecdote about an old failure whose fit of anger at a passing cyclist causes him to die of a stroke or seizure .	443.69043
there is no more `` plot ' ' than that	74.608536
only slightly more , perhaps , than a newspaper account of such an incident would give .	461.61084
the artistic interest , then , lies in what the encounter may be made to represent , in the power of some central significance to draw the details into relevance and meaningfulness .	285.56207
the first sentence , with its platitudinous irony , announces an emblematic intent `` the way to the churchyard ran along beside the highroad , ran beside it all the way to the end	1474.1993
that is to say , to the churchyard ' ' .	60.605595
and the action is consistently presented with regard for this distinction .	551.14417
the highroad , one might say at first , belongs to life , while the way to the churchyard belongs to death .	321.38608
but that is too simple , and won ' t hold up .	114.24581
as the first sentence suggests , both roads belong to death in the end .	530.74133
but the highroad , according to the description of its traffic , belongs to life as it is lived in unawareness of death , while the way to the churchyard belongs to some other sort of life a suffering form , an existence wholly comprised in the awareness of death .	360.48514
thus , on the highroad , a troop of soldiers `` marched in their own dust and sang ' ' , while on the footpath one man walks alone .	984.6017
this man ' s isolation is not merely momentary , it is permanent .	665.96423
he is a widower , his three children are dead , he has no one left on earth	279.91226
